webTitle: Never mind Tyson, we is the tops at melting the plastic

fields.headline: Never mind Tyson, we is the tops at melting the plastic
fields.trailText: Darren bangs out on about privacy for the rich and famous before being done up like a kipper while going 12 rounds at the checkout in emulation of Iron Mike.
fields.body:
Monday

People often ask me: as a superstar, how do you cope with all the mither? What do you do about the fact there's always some inadequate who, to prove to his mates he's the hard man, has a go at Darren Tackle whenever he fetches up in a bar? And I say, let's leave Wattsy out of it, shall we?

At the end of the day we footballers is only human. Strip away the obvious God-given qualities that come with being a Premiership superstar and we is just like your next-door neighbour - though maybe not just like mine, who is a right stuck-up bint what complained about the team meeting we had at my place before Christmas. All right, so Vic and Bob formed a human pyramid in her pool at 3am, puked on her patio, then ran over her cat as they gunned off in Bob's new McLaren, but was that any cause to get Dibble involved?

Basically what I'm trying to tell you is: no comment. Like me old mate Becksy, my position as a leading role model does not give anyone the right to invade me privacy. Even to ask me how I cope with all the pressure of people trying to invade me privacy: that is a private matter. As I told the photographer from OK magazine when he come round to do the exclusive shots of me newly decorated snooker room, what goes on within the four walls of Tackle Towers is nobody's business but yours truly's.

Tuesday

Rodney bells at his usual unearthly.

"Listen up, boy," he says. "You seen in the newspaper about some plan to copyright goals? The idea is, the player will own the rights to his actual strike and can exploit it thereafter on a multi-media basis. There's money in it. So go out there and score, boy."

"Score what? Birds? Charlie? What?"

"Give me strength."

Wednesday

Training's buzzing with Mike Tyson and his little trip. Personally I don't think it should have been allowed but Wattsy is full of how it would have disappointed hundreds of his fans if he'd been stopped.

"Maximum 110% bona fide respect to the man," says Wattsy. "That's some trip, spending a million quid in one afternoon."

"It shouldn't have been allowed, Wattsy," I says. "I mean how is we footballers going to keep up our rep as the biggest of spenders if he can swan around unhindered melting the plastic?"

Thursday

The gauntlet has been thrown, the challenge laid down. Iron Mike's shopping has given Wattsy an idea and a book has been opened to predict who can spend the most in three hours. As an incentive, the Star has been invited to witness the cream of Britain regaining the title what matters: top shoppers.

Things is going rather well at the start for Darren Tackle. Three new suits and 13 diver's watches gives yours truly an early lead over Vic and Bob, who has shown a massive lack of experience by investing in shoes: never, frankly, a big enough spend.

Wattsy is bogged down with colour-coordination problems at Get Shirty and Hermann is declared an early faller when he fails to overcome his natural footballer's instincts and demands a freebie out of Suits Yoo. Oh yes, it's looking good for Tackle. No wonder the photographer from the Star is on his tail. Or he should be after I slipped him a score to stick with me.

Sadly it all goes the shape of a pear the minute we enters the Aston Martin showroom and the sales geezer refuses to let me drive away the first engine I sees.

"May I advise sir to weigh up the implications of the purchase for a moment."

"Bollocks to that," I says. "Giss the keys."

Then the geezer starts prattling on about how he has the reputation of the marque to consider and how he can't just allow cars like this to be bought on a whim. By then, with the clock against me, he's asked for it. I am obliged to use the ultimate weapon in the celebrity armoury.

"Do you know who I am?" I says.

"I'm afraid not, sir."

Friday

In the end, after the club's lawyers agreed a compensation deal for the damaged aerial, the geezer didn't press charges, even though it took a six-hour operation to remove it. But by then the damage was done: the Star had its picture, a footballer's private life had once more been dragged through the mire and, worse, Wattsy had creamed up in the book by buying the show home in that new golf-course development. Still, at least you know now what we mean by provocation.

fields.headline: Keegan faces German test first
fields.standfirst: Wembley may yet host England's opening game against their familiar nemesis
fields.trailText: England will begin the task of qualifying for the 2002 World Cup by trying to get part of the worst over first. In their opening match they will meet Germany at home, although just where "home" is has yet to be ascertained.
fields.body:
England will begin the task of qualifying for the 2002 World Cup by trying to get part of the worst over first. In their opening match they will meet Germany at home, although just where "home" is has yet to be ascertained.

It may be Old Trafford or St James' Park, Newcastle, or it may yet be Wembley, which is where they were planning to sign off with a friendly against the Germans in September before the stadium is demolished and rebuilt.

A final fixture at Wembley in September is still the plan, but having fixed the date of the World Cup qualifier against Germany for October 7 the FA may feel it even more fitting that the old place should stage one last meaningful encounter between England and the team who have the habit of frustrating them at every turn.

By then the urgency with which Wembley needs to be knocked down will be clearer. England will know if they have been awarded the 2006 World Cup, the decision having been taken by Fifa in Zurich in July 6. If the vote goes against South Africa, the favourites, the prize will rest between England and Germany.

More relevant to the outcome of the 2002 World Cup qualifier will be the result of the meeting between England and Germany in Charleroi on June 17 halfway through the first round of the European championship. Even more now is going to depend on Kevin Keegan's team performing sufficiently well in this game to gain the confidence they will need when hostilities are renewed in the autumn.

Since defeating West Germany in the 1966 World Cup final England have won only twice in 14 meetings, although they did come within a post's width of beating them in the Euro 96 semi-finals. The Germans won that tie on penalties, just as they had overcome England in the 1990 World Cup semi-finals.

A victory over Germany in October would send England to Finland four days later in a state of high optimism. Either way the course of their effort to reach the tournament proper in Japan and South Korea will be determined by the results of these two matches.

Glenn Hoddle's team reached the last World Cup largely on the back of impressive away performances, notably in Georgia, Poland and Italy. But on the way to Euro 2000 an early defeat in Sweden and points dropped at home to Bulgaria under Hoddle and Sweden under his successor, followed by tepid draws in Bulgaria and Poland, left Keegan sweating on the Swedes beating the Poles to send his team through to the play-offs.

Even there the euphoria of a 2-0 win against Scotland at Hampden soon gave way to public vilification after the Scots beat a feeble England side 1-0 at Wembley. The only way England can fully restore people's faith in their World Cup prospects will be by beating Germany in October and that is only likely to happen if Keegan has managed to produce a team of substance from Euro 2000.

After the October qualifiers England will not play another World Cup match until March next year, when they will be at home to Finland with a game in Albania four days later. They go to Greece on June 6 2001 and then comes the return visit to Germany on September 1, which already has an apocalyptic look about it.

England do have the advantage of playing their last two qualifiers, against Albania and Greece, at home but if they are to qualify automatically by winning Group Nine, avoiding another play-off, they will probably need to have taken at least four points off the Germans by then while avoiding slip-ups elsewhere.

"I'm delighted with the way the fixtures have worked out," said Keegan when he emerged from the seven-hour meeting with England's rivals in Frankfurt yesterday, "but obviously only the results will justify whether it's good or not."

 Brazil's bid to host the 2006 finals was dealt a body blow yesterday when Alan Rothenburg, head of Fifa's inspection team, said in Rio de Janeiro that the country's infrastructure needed improving.

fields.headline: Magpies swoop on Sparrowhawk
fields.trailText: Newcastle United were yesterday on the verge of signing the 19-year-old South American prodigy Diego Gavilan from the Paraguayan club Cerro Porteno for £1m.
fields.body:
Newcastle United were yesterday on the verge of signing the 19-year-old South American prodigy Diego Gavilan from the Paraguayan club Cerro Porteno for £1m.

Gavilan - the name means Sparrowhawk - was flying in to complete his move to England after impressing the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson during a spell on Tyneside last week. He has been capped eight times by Paraguay.

Newcastle have denied reports that they have offered £4m to the Buenos Aires club Velez Sarsfield for the midfield player Christian Bassedas.

Kevin Phillips has opened negotiations with Sunderland for a new five-year contract that would make him the highest-paid player in the club's history. The Premiership's leading scorer, who signed a three-year deal last season, has been linked with several other clubs but has indicated that he would like to stay at the Stadium of Light after being offered an estimated £20,000 a week.

The First Division leaders Charlton have signed the 20-year-old striker Ricardo Fuller, according to the Jamaican champions Tivoli Gardens, for a fee rising to £1m depending on appearances. The Jamaican is currently serving a two-month ban for violent conduct having kicked an opponent in the head as he left the field after being sent off for elbowing the same player.

Coventry have beaten off interest from Leeds and Spurs to complete the permanent signing of the Belgian under-21 striker Cédric Roussel for £1.2m. Roussel initially joined Coventry on loan from Ghent until the end of the season.

A record Premiership crowd of over 58,000 will watch Manchester United's game against Arsenal at Old Trafford on Monday. United are redeveloping Old Trafford and have been granted permission by Trafford Council to use 3,000 seats in the second tier of the East Stand ahead of schedule.

United's Norwegian international utility player Ronny Johnsen, who has not played since the European Cup final, is hoping to be fit by the time the club resume their Champions League campaign against Bordeaux on March 1. He has made slow progress after an operation to cure a condition known as "jumper's knee".

Jimmy Glass, the goalkeeper whose last-minute goal when on loan to Carlisle United saved the Brunton Park club from relegation from the Football League on the last day of last season, has left Swindon after failing to reach agreement over his future at the County Ground.

Tranmere have signed the Liverpool defender Phil Babb on a month's loan. He will be eligible to play in the Worthington Cup semi-final second leg at Bolton next Wednesday and in the FA Cup fifth round at Fulham three days later.

webTitle: Investors call on Ashton to end campaign

fields.headline: Investors call on Ashton to end campaign
fields.standfirst: Charterhouse fears for effect on Wednesday's share price
fields.trailText: A director of Sheffield Wednesday's biggest shareholder Charterhouse last night urged the MP Joe Ashton to abandon his campaign to have the club's manager and chairman removed from office.
fields.body:
A director of Sheffield Wednesday's biggest shareholder Charterhouse last night urged the MP Joe Ashton to abandon his campaign to have the club's manager and chairman removed from office.

Acting as a spokesman for the leading venture capitalists, Geoff Arbuthnott - also a member of Wednesday's plc board - said that Ashton's increasingly acrimonious dispute with the Yorkshire club was not only damaging morale inside Hillsborough but might well have a negative effect on the club's share value.

"In my opinion Joe Ashton is damaging the club and damaging the share value of the club," said Arbuthnott. "He is doing Sheffield Wednesday absolutely no favours at all."

Arbuthnott spoke out a few hours after Ashton had escalated his war of words with the Premiership's bottom club by insisting that Charterhouse was actively seeking a way in which to end its association with Wednesday.

Ashton claimed Charterhouse "wanted out" three years after purchasing a 36% shareholding in Wednesday and ploughing more than £15m into the club.

"There's no question Charterhouse want out," he said. "The problem is they can't see any buyer coming forward with the club in debt and at the bottom of the league. If Wednesday had the same debt and were at the top of the table, the club would still be a viable proposition; somebody might be prepared to come in."

Arbuthnott appealed for Ashton to abandon his attempts to have the manager Danny Wilson sacked and the chairman Dave Richards replaced. "I do not know what he hopes to achieve by all this," he said. "It is time to call a halt to this campaign of his."

Arbuthnott also criticised Ashton for failing to keep his word in the aftermath of a meeting last week between representatives of Charterhouse and the so-called "gang of four" MPs: Ashton, the education and employment secretary David Blunkett, Bill Michie and Clive Betts.

"He said he would say nothing after that meeting and I wish he had stuck to his word," said Arbuthnott. "Joe Ashton should let those inside the football club get on with their jobs."

In response to Ashton's claim that Charterhouse was anxious to cut ties with Wednesday, Arbuthnott said now was not the time to seek to put the club on the open market.

£#149; The proposed takeover of Cardiff City by the brother of the Sunday Sport publisher David Sullivan, part-owner of Birmingham City, has been temporarily blocked by the Football League.

Clive Sullivan, an Essex property developer and management consultant, is heading a consortium of Welsh exiles in the Channel Islands which wants to buy a 55% stake in the club. The £2.5m deal is due to be completed next Tuesday but the Football league has refused to sanction the takeover.

"Some information has been supplied," said John Nagle, the League's media relations executive. "But there are still several pieces of significant information which are missing, including the names of the people behind the bid."

Sullivan has consistently claimed that revealing the identities of the businessmen might jeopardise the deal. Speculation has revolved around Stan Thomas, the brother of Peter Thomas who financially supports Cardiff Rugby Club; Steve Morgan, chairman of the north Wales-based Redrow Homes Construction Group; the banker Sir Julian Hodge; and the golfer Ian Woosnam.

Sullivan denied that any of his brother's money was part of the takeover. There are clear Football League rules covering the multi-ownership of clubs.

Cardiff City's chairman Steve Borley was unavailable for comment yesterday.

webTitle: All Wright  Celtic striker is not a secret agent

fields.headline: All Wright  Celtic striker is not a secret agent
fields.trailText: Ian Wright is a professional footballer and a TV chat show host who also sells chickens. Yesterday, however, he had to prove what he did not do for a living.
fields.body:
Ian Wright is a professional footballer and a TV chat show host who also sells chickens. Yesterday, however, he had to prove what he did not do for a living.

The Celtic striker had to persuade the Football Association and the SFA that he was not in the business of buying and selling footballers. In the end he convinced both, so avoiding potentially ruinous consequences.

Although the "Wright Wright Wright" agency has an estimated 20 players in its stable, the man himself stated that he has no direct involvement. Under Fifa rules, no player is allowed to be an agent as well.

Suspicions arose when Wright boasted that he was trying to bring the Venezuelan striker Fernando de Ornelas to Celtic, adding that the coach John Barnes was giving him a trial.

But an SFA spokesman said last night: "We have been assured that the company operates through two of his friends and not through Wright himself. They are just using his name for marketing reasons.

"The consequences would have been very serious. But we have looked into it and are convinced that he was committing no breach."

The agency is run by his former Crystal Palace team-mates Andy Gray and Tony Finnigan and its latest recruit is Aston Villa's Stan Collymore.

Celtic will be without their Brazilian signing Rafael Scheidt for six weeks. The centre-half, who joined the club 11 days ago, is recovering in hospital after an appendix operation.

Meanwhile, the next Old Firm game will go ahead on March 8 at Celtic Park instead of February 23 because of a clash with international fixtures.

The Bulgarian FA has given Stilian Petrov permission to play for Celtic against Hearts on February 5. But the 20-year-old will miss the CIS Cup semi-final and a league game at Dundee on February 12 because of a tournament in Chile.

Photograph: Graham Whitby

Under Fifa rules, no player is allowed to be an agent as well. Suspicions arose when Wright boasted that he was trying to bring the Venezuelan striker Fernando de Ornelas to Celtic, adding that the coach John Barnes was giving him a trial. But an SFA spokesman said last night: "We have been assured that the company operates through two of his friends and not through Wright himself. They are just using his name for marketing reasons. "The consequences would have been very serious. But we have looked into it and are convinced that he was committing no breach." The agency is run by his former Crystal Palace team-mates Andy Gray and Tony Finnigan and its latest recruit is Aston Villa's Stan Collymore. Celtic will be without their Brazilian signing Rafael Scheidt for six weeks. The centre-half, who joined the club 11 days ago, is recovering in hospital after an appendix operation. Meanwhile, the next Old Firm game will go ahead on March 8 at Celtic Park instead of February 23 because of a clash with international fixtures. The Bulgarian FA has given Stilian Petrov permission to play for Celtic against Hearts on February 5. But the 20-year-old will miss the CIS Cup semi-final and a league game at Dundee on February 12 because of a tournament in Chile. Photograph: Graham Whitby

webTitle: Under-19s make sad exit from World Cup

fields.headline: Under-19s make sad exit from World Cup
fields.trailText: England's Under-19 team relinquished the Youth World Cup they won in South Africa two years ago when they suffered an emphatic nine-wicket defeat by India yesterday.
fields.body:
England's Under-19 team relinquished the Youth World Cup they won in South Africa two years ago when they suffered an emphatic nine-wicket defeat by India yesterday.

The defeat marks the end of a very disappointing tour for this young side. They arrived in Sri Lanka confident that they could win the tournament but have only won two matches. The large margin of defeat in all the games they have lost lengthens the shadow over English cricket.

The biggest disappointment has been the batting, which has consistently failed to post competitive scores. England's highest score was only 187 and only two 50s have been scored in their five matches.

The scorer of these 50s, the Durham left-hander Gary Pratt, provided the backbone of England's modest total of 182, top scoring with a fine 58 off 74 deliveries. After Mark Wallace had been run out by a direct hit in the fourth over, Ian Bell and John Maunders, who was playing his first game of the tour, battled hard to survive. Regularly playing and missing, the pair were only parted in the 15th over when Bell was caught behind off the medium pace of Ritender Sodhi.

Michael Carberry and Maunders then put on 38 for the third wicket before Maunders was stumped for 32. With England precariously placed on 74 for three off 25 overs the arrival of Pratt changed the tempo of the innings. Willing to use feet, but also quick to cut, he was the only player to look comfortable against the spinners.

However the 53-run partnership was ended when Carberry was caught behind for 36 and the dismissal marked the beginning of the end for England as wickets were then lost at regular intervals. When it came to England's turn to bowl they wasted the new ball by pitching far too short on a flat wicket. Manish Sharma and Raneet Ricky played themselves in cautiously before taking the attack to the English bowlers.

England soon became resigned to their inevitable defeat and an ignominious exit from the competition.

 Warwickshire have been given clearance to sign the promising South African-born 20-year-old all-rounder Ryan Sierra, who has an English mother and will not be classed as an overseas player.

fields.headline: England lines up all-Asian finale
fields.trailText: English cricket is in danger of gaining a worldwide reputation for imaginative radicalism. The EWCB is set to announce that India and Pakistan are to play three one-day internationals against each other in England at the end of the summer.
fields.body:
English cricket is in danger of gaining a worldwide reputation for imaginative radicalism. The EWCB is set to announce that India and Pakistan are to play three one-day internationals against each other in England at the end of the summer.

After more than a century of stonewall intransigence, suddenly English cricket is in danger of gaining a worldwide reputation for imaginative radicalism.

Three days ago in Pretoria, the England captain Nasser Hussain agreed to a contrived finish unprecedented in Test history. Now the England and Wales Cricket Board is set to announce that India and Pakistan are to play three one-day internationals against each other in England at the end of the summer.

The ECB, which two months ago published a series of recommendations on how to make the game in England more inclusive of ethnic minorities, said yesterday that Pakistan had agreed in principle to the three-match series, while India had still to make a decision.

The Pakistan Cricket Board's director of operations, Yawar Saeed, confirmed: "On our way back from Toronto [for the Sahara Cup] we have agreed to a stopover in England for a week to play three one-day internationals."

Following on from the commercial success of matches involving the two countries during last year's World Cup, particularly their Super Six game at Old Trafford, the ECB is hoping the new initiative will generate similar interest among Asian supporters.

"We had a great World Cup with a lot of excellent support from Asian communities, and this would be an ideal vehicle for us to continue our promotion of cricket to Asian and ethnic minorities around England," said Mark Hodgson, the ECB's media relations officer. The games will probably be played in September at three of England's bigger venues.

England visit Pakistan next winter for the first time since the infamous tour of 13 years ago when Mike Gatting became embroiled in an unseemly row with the Pakistani umpire Shakoor Rana in Faisalabad. Three Tests and three one-day internationals are scheduled.

fields.headline: England fumble for safe keeping
fields.trailText: Stewart has been left out of England's one-day squad for the triangular one-day tournament, which gets under way today in Johannesburg, and has returned home. Paul Weaver reads the runes after England defeated North West in their final warm-up game with a third-choice wicketkeeper.
fields.body:
Alec Stewart's Surrey home is surrounded by a leafy tranquility that today may well not reflect the mood of the man within. Stewart could be forgiven for meeting the cricket world with a charred smile and - for this is a man with a swift and biting wit - a sharply jocular remark or two.

To his undisguised chagrin Stewart was left out of England's one-day squad for the triangular one-day tournament, which gets under way today in Johannesburg with South Africa playing Zimbabwe, and returned home yesterday with the rest of the redundant Test players.

Instead, with an eye on the next World Cup in South Africa in 2003, England opted for Chris Read, Stewart's understudy in the recently completed series.

And who kept wicket here last night under lights against North West in the final one-day warm-up game? Mark Alleyne, that's who, only a very occasional gloveman for Gloucestershire when they are really up a gum tree. But Read's poor form is a worry. So is that of Darren Gough, who was also left out yesterday.

In the event England won easily by 41 runs. Graeme Hick, who made 77 from 81 deliveries, was the mainstay with Craig White (50), Chris Adams (47) and Vikram Solanki (38) contributing in a total of 264 for nine. The local bowler David Pryke, despite an eccentric run-up and action that suggested a traffic cop in rush hour, took five for 32.

North West were never capable of making a match of it and ended 223 for eight. Not even an 11-ball over from Alan Mullally, who bowled five wides, could drag them back into the contest.

A useful acclimatiser for day-night cricket, perhaps, but ideally Nasser Hussain wanted to play his international line-up. Read could still play on Sunday but because of his indifferent form the management has clearly decided to take out some insurance.

Wicketkeeping farces are among cricket's finest. Once, against New Zealand at Lord's in 1986, England had four stumpers in a single innings: Bruce French, Bill Athey, Bob Taylor, who was hauled away from a Cornhill sponsors' lunch, and Bobby Parks.

Farce may be too strong a word for this situation but there has certainly been a lack of coherent planning over England's one-day wicketkeeping.

The argument against Stewart is that he will be 40 in 2003, an age when he may prefer to keep the garden tidy rather than England's stumps. But this is a little too early to be preparing for the next World Cup. England have underplayed the importance of one-day cricket in the past and there are a number of meaningful internationals to be won in the next year or two.

Whether Stewart should keep wicket in Test matches has been one of modern English cricket's running sores but no one has seriously questioned the place of the team's outstanding all-rounder in one-day cricket. Stewart, after all, is the world's leading wicketkeeper-batsman, although Australia's Adam Gilchrist will soon be challenging for that crown.

He has played 125 one-day internationals and is England's most experienced man in the limited-overs game after Graham Gooch. In 11 years as an England player, this is the first time Stewart has been overlooked. Form can hardly be the reason, as he scored runs in Johannesburg, Durban and Centurion.

Yesterday a newspaper in Johannesburg reported a row between Stewart and the England captain Hussain after the concluding Centurion Test over his omission from the one-day tournament.

This was firmly denied by an ECB spokesman yesterday and certainly the rift story makes little sense when it is remembered that the two players enjoyed a successful rapport during the recent Test series.

Stewart, who now faces a non-urgent operation on his right ring finger, sounded miffed when he admitted he started the tour feeling he had something to prove. This week he said: "There was a lot of talk about me not playing and that annoyed me. I always knew I could play at this level."

Stewart was doubly disappointed not to be drafted in following the withdrawal of the injured Andy Flintoff.

 Jonty Rhodes's hamstring injury, which kept him out of the final Test, has also ruled him out of today's opening match against Zimbabwe and could see him miss the England game on Sunday.

webTitle: South Africa try to oust president

fields.headline: South Africa try to oust president
fields.trailText: The South African board president Raymond White is facing a motion to oust him, as a campaign to appoint a non-white chief executive gathers momentum.
fields.body:
The South African board president Raymond White is facing a motion to oust him, as a campaign to appoint a non-white chief executive gathers momentum.

The United Cricket Board of South Africa will meet tomorrow to discuss White's future and the appointment of a replacement for Dr Ali Bacher as the board's administrative head. Bacher had been due to step down as board managing director to take over the running of the 2003 World Cup in South Africa but White persuaded him to stay and do both jobs.

It has now emerged that White has been requested to resign by his fellow executive board member Gerald Majola in a letter circulated to all board members.

"I cannot allow you to retard the progress of the transformation of this game in defiance of the efforts of many," Majola says in what is effectively an open letter - and an open challenge.

"It is vitally important during the [cricket] World Cup and the period leading to it that blacks start playing a vital role in the running of the game," the letter goes on.

White was at the centre of a political storm in recent months after he admitted to questioning the selection of certain black players in a combined provincial team that played England in December.

Meanwhile, the West Indies players and management who lost every big match on their recent tour of New Zealand were this week summoned to an unprecedented "debriefing session" with the Caribbean board's executive committee.

"The meeting has been called [to hear] just what went wrong in New Zealand," the board's chief executive Steve Camacho said. "It is of understandable concern to everyone involved in West Indies cricket."

fields.headline: The empty chamber
fields.standfirst: The Wakeham proposals for reform are absurd and have lost the plot
fields.trailText: The Wakeham report goes straight to the heart of the big question - do we want any constitutional             reform or are we happy as we are? If there are problems with how we are governed, are the alternatives             worse? All the great issues of the day - Europe and the euro, proportional representation and now the             role of the second chamber - depend on the single question: is one-party dictatorship in an all-powerful             Commons the best of all possible governments? If you ask the people in that crude way the answer is             mainly yes. They like `strong' government. But then if you ask about a fairer voting system they also say             yes - indignant that parties elected on around 40% of the vote rule with absolute authority. If you             suggest checks and balances or fundamental rights beyond the reach of politicians, they say yes again.
fields.body:
The Wakeham report goes straight to the heart of the big question - do we want any constitutional reform or are we happy as we are? If there are problems with how we are governed, are the alternatives worse? All the great issues of the day - Europe and the euro, proportional representation and now the role of the second chamber - depend on the single question: is one-party dictatorship in an all-powerful Commons the best of all possible governments? If you ask the people in that crude way the answer is mainly yes. They like `strong' government. But then if you ask about a fairer voting system they also say yes - indignant that parties elected on around 40% of the vote rule with absolute authority. If you suggest checks and balances or fundamental rights beyond the reach of politicians, they say yes again.

This serious intellectual dilemma lies at the heart of all three constitutional issues. Many on the centre left have been wobbling since 1997. It looked so obvious in the days of the Thatcher dictatorship. Of course she should have been forced by PR into consensual politics by having to work with other parties in a rainbow-hued Commons of many parties and opinions. Of course a stronger second chamber should have saved us from the madness of the poll tax or the knee-jerk hysteria of Section 28 and dangerous dogs laws. Of course Europe offered the best protection against the worst outrages of Michael Howard. But now it's no longer quite so clear. Why share power when you can have it all?

Why let go when we have one of the best governments in modern times? Listen to the Tories unseductive offer of cross-party agreement on the future funding of the NHS (letting the private sector take over by degrees) and wonder why any government should voluntarily share with the enemy. The enemy might be Schr1/3oder and Jospin demanding we impose unfavourable new taxes on the City. The enemy might be Lib Dems demanding tax rises for the ideological sake of it. Or the enemy might be a powerful House of Lords insisting that the ancient right to trial by jury is not diluted. Who needs all that aggravation? Why share more power with Europe, with other British parties or with a second chamber when you can keep it all yourself?

In that recess of Tony Blair's brain where he keeps his `project', where he thinks about history and the new century, where he plans armageddon for the forces of conservatism, he believes that power should be better spread. But between the thought and the action falls the shadow. That shadow is the fierce opposition of many in his own party and his own cabinet. There is the even longer shadow of public opinion profoundly uninterested in constitutional reform - and when bounced, instinctively against change.

Unlike France, Germany or Italy, in Britain there is scant tradition of intellectual debate in politics. The public is never invited to engage in serious thought about the nature of power, who holds it or where it should reside. No amount of David Blunkett's citizenship studies in schools will compensate for the dearth of deep discussion by our politicians. Lack of any debate about where power is best exercised for which function has let the Eurosceptics run away with public opinion. It's easy to frighten people about losing sovereignty when they have never had any discussion about who has it anyway. In living memory the rest of Europe has drawn up constitutions and amended them. We have just bumbled along hanging on to Black Rod and mumbling about tradition.

And so Wakeham's report lands in a political wasteland. Who cares? A few anoraks and the Lib Dems. There was no great outcry when Labour caved in on its manifesto pledge: `The right of hereditary peers to sit and vote in the House of Lords will be ended by statute'. Nothing there about the 92 remaining - or about the right of any old hereditary to come and go as they please in the place and even to sit at the foot of the woolsack whenever they want to make trouble. These concessions were forced from the government under threat of losing two years' legislation. Presumably it didn't cross Labour 's mind that if they'd faced the old buffers down bravely the people would have risen up to support their government and chase the ermines away. No, the government has no great faith in the people. And that is why we shall not get a mainly elected second chamber.

Yesterday's report on the Lords is full of good Wakehamisms - I particularly liked `radical evolutionary change' - and it does make an elegant case for doing as little as possible. It lays out the awkward problem of creating a carbon copy Commons, replicating the same old party-political debates with a tired second team. Wakeham says the public voiced their distaste for yet another group of politicians `banging on at each other' - they have a point. Consider what damage `checks and balances' have done to the US presidency: Clinton's health policy and all his best endeavours were wrecked by a hostile congress. There is a lot to be said for strong one-party government with one party to blame if they get it wrong. The report found that in most democracies the second chamber is a constant subject of complaint and criticism. So the question looks finely balanced.

Oddly enough, it is not in the big idea but in the small print that Wakeham loses the argument. He takes his readers almost all the way on the undesirability of a wholly elected second chamber until we hit the old Churchill problem: `Democracy is the worst form of government except all those other forms that have been tried from time to time'. Once it is revealed how the 500 great and good are to be selected, the game is up. The more elaborately explained, the more absurd it becomes. Eight Commissioners (three from the political parties) with the judgment of Solomon will miraculously conjure up a chamber of equal gender, representing every walk of life, reflecting exact regional and ethnic balance, plus all professions and occupations, plus a religious, moral and philosophical balance, not forgetting the lords of appeal in ordinary and all the bishops. All these must add up to an exact party political balance. (Get me a Lib Dem Catholic woman chartered accountant with one leg from Cardiff! Never mind what she's like!)

It's impossible. Step by sensible step, somewhere along the way the commission lost the plot. I refer anyone who doubts it to chapter 15 - the Representation of Religious Faiths - because it is extremely funny. (The Rosicrucians have a pillar in the Dome's faith zone, do they get in here too?) Democracy has a lot going for it but if Labour doesn't think so they'd do better abolishing a second chamber altogether than creating this brand new anachronism.
fields.bodyText: The Wakeham report goes straight to the heart of the big question - do we want any constitutional reform or are we happy as we are? If there are problems with how we are governed, are the alternatives worse? All the great issues of the day - Europe and the euro, proportional representation and now the role of the second chamber - depend on the single question: is one-party dictatorship in an all-powerful Commons the best of all possible governments? If you ask the people in that crude way the answer is mainly yes. They like `strong' government. But then if you ask about a fairer voting system they also say yes - indignant that parties elected on around 40% of the vote rule with absolute authority. If you suggest checks and balances or fundamental rights beyond the reach of politicians, they say yes again. This serious intellectual dilemma lies at the heart of all three constitutional issues. Many on the centre left have been wobbling since 1997. It looked so obvious in the days of the Thatcher dictatorship. Of course she should have been forced by PR into consensual politics by having to work with other parties in a rainbow-hued Commons of many parties and opinions. Of course a stronger second chamber should have saved us from the madness of the poll tax or the knee-jerk hysteria of Section 28 and dangerous dogs laws. Of course Europe offered the best protection against the worst outrages of Michael Howard. But now it's no longer quite so clear. Why share power when you can have it all? Why let go when we have one of the best governments in modern times? Listen to the Tories unseductive offer of cross-party agreement on the future funding of the NHS (letting the private sector take over by degrees) and wonder why any government should voluntarily share with the enemy. The enemy might be Schr1/3oder and Jospin demanding we impose unfavourable new taxes on the City. The enemy might be Lib Dems demanding tax rises for the ideological sake of it. Or the enemy might be a powerful House of Lords insisting that the ancient right to trial by jury is not diluted. Who needs all that aggravation? Why share more power with Europe, with other British parties or with a second chamber when you can keep it all yourself? In that recess of Tony Blair's brain where he keeps his `project', where he thinks about history and the new century, where he plans armageddon for the forces of conservatism, he believes that power should be better spread. But between the thought and the action falls the shadow. That shadow is the fierce opposition of many in his own party and his own cabinet. There is the even longer shadow of public opinion profoundly uninterested in constitutional reform - and when bounced, instinctively against change. Unlike France, Germany or Italy, in Britain there is scant tradition of intellectual debate in politics. The public is never invited to engage in serious thought about the nature of power, who holds it or where it should reside. No amount of David Blunkett's citizenship studies in schools will compensate for the dearth of deep discussion by our politicians. Lack of any debate about where power is best exercised for which function has let the Eurosceptics run away with public opinion. It's easy to frighten people about losing sovereignty when they have never had any discussion about who has it anyway. In living memory the rest of Europe has drawn up constitutions and amended them. We have just bumbled along hanging on to Black Rod and mumbling about tradition. And so Wakeham's report lands in a political wasteland. Who cares? A few anoraks and the Lib Dems. There was no great outcry when Labour caved in on its manifesto pledge: `The right of hereditary peers to sit and vote in the House of Lords will be ended by statute'. Nothing there about the 92 remaining - or about the right of any old hereditary to come and go as they please in the place and even to sit at the foot of the woolsack whenever they want to make trouble. These concessions were forced from the government under threat of losing two years' legislation. Presumably it didn't cross Labour 's mind that if they'd faced the old buffers down bravely the people would have risen up to support their government and chase the ermines away. No, the government has no great faith in the people. And that is why we shall not get a mainly elected second chamber. Yesterday's report on the Lords is full of good Wakehamisms - I particularly liked `radical evolutionary change' - and it does make an elegant case for doing as little as possible. It lays out the awkward problem of creating a carbon copy Commons, replicating the same old party-political debates with a tired second team. Wakeham says the public voiced their distaste for yet another group of politicians `banging on at each other' - they have a point. Consider what damage `checks and balances' have done to the US presidency: Clinton's health policy and all his best endeavours were wrecked by a hostile congress. There is a lot to be said for strong one-party government with one party to blame if they get it wrong. The report found that in most democracies the second chamber is a constant subject of complaint and criticism. So the question looks finely balanced. Oddly enough, it is not in the big idea but in the small print that Wakeham loses the argument. He takes his readers almost all the way on the undesirability of a wholly elected second chamber until we hit the old Churchill problem: `Democracy is the worst form of government except all those other forms that have been tried from time to time'. Once it is revealed how the 500 great and good are to be selected, the game is up. The more elaborately explained, the more absurd it becomes. Eight Commissioners (three from the political parties) with the judgment of Solomon will miraculously conjure up a chamber of equal gender, representing every walk of life, reflecting exact regional and ethnic balance, plus all professions and occupations, plus a religious, moral and philosophical balance, not forgetting the lords of appeal in ordinary and all the bishops. All these must add up to an exact party political balance. (Get me a Lib Dem Catholic woman chartered accountant with one leg from Cardiff! Never mind what she's like!) It's impossible. Step by sensible step, somewhere along the way the commission lost the plot. I refer anyone who doubts it to chapter 15 - the Representation of Religious Faiths - because it is extremely funny. (The Rosicrucians have a pillar in the Dome's faith zone, do they get in here too?) Democracy has a lot going for it but if Labour doesn't think so they'd do better abolishing a second chamber altogether than creating this brand new anachronism.

fields.headline: Who doesn't dare, loses
fields.standfirst: The Wakeham report oozes complacency
fields.trailText: John Wakeham gets at least one thing right. He states in the                                                    opening section of his report on reform of the House of Lords,                                                    published yesterday, that the task of any royal commission is to                                                    produce recommendations which are "not only persuasive and                                                    intellectually coherent but also workable, durable and politically                                                    realistic". He is right. But those words also stand as an indictment of his report.
fields.body:
John Wakeham gets at least one thing right. He states in the opening section of his report on reform of the House of Lords, published yesterday, that the task of any royal commission is to produce recommendations which are "not only persuasive and intellectually coherent but also workable, durable and politically realistic". He is right.

But those words also stand as an indictment of his report. For in its determination to find a proposal that is "politically realistic" - that is, acceptable to the prime minister - the Wakeham commission has produced a dog's dinner of a report, which ducks the issues or fudges them and leaves a contradiction on every page. It claims to be radical when in fact it is cowardly, preferring preservation of the status quo to imaginative reform, and constantly endorsing the clubby ways of the past as best left alone. Above all, it keeps power out of the hands of the men and women of Britain, recommending an elaborate rabbit warren of systems and mechanisms over the clear, democratic solution that was staring it in the face. The sheer lack of coherence of the Wakeham report means it can have little chance of implementation. By failing the chairman's first standard, it will fail his second, too. "We did not wish to spend months compiling a report that would gather dust in a pigeonhole," he writes in his introduction. Yet that is the fate his report invites.

Our own preference for the second phase of House of Lords reform - the first being last year's removal of all but 92 of the hereditary peers - was no secret. Along with hundreds of others we submitted our proposal to the 12 commissioners, advocating a directly elected second chamber. When Lord Wakeham states that his goal is a house that reflects the political balance of the country, we believe that there is a very simple way to achieve that: it is called an election. Indeed, in a democracy it is surely the only legitimate way.

The Wakeham 12 have decided otherwise, for reasons they state but chiefly for one they do not: political realism. It was perfectly clear to the commission chairman that the man who had appointed him, Tony Blair, was no enthusiast for a wholly or even largely elected house. So, keen to avoid the pigeonhole, the former Tory minister did what all those years in the whips' office had trained him to do: delivered the fix. He doomed direct election from the outset. The result is a series of tortured mechanisms designed to produce a legitimate, representative chamber without the sine qua non of legitimate representation, namely democracy.

To take one example from many, the report promises a new appointments commission, dispatching people to the chamber in order to reflect the regional, gender and ethnic make-up of the country and in accordance with the political complexion of the electorate expressed at the last general election - all the while keeping the total membership at the 550 mark. How does that add up? At present there are roughly that number of life peers around, and Wakeham elsewhere suggests these unelected folk should retain their seats in a reformed chamber until the day they die. In other words, there will be no vacancies for the appointers to fill until the grim reaper has created them. It could take decades for the selection methods outlined yesterday to kick in. Or, to name another flaw, the three selection models set out in the report (proof that the commissioners could not agree among themselves) have elected members chosen not all at once, but in thirds. That would mean, for instance, Tyneside electing people today, then waiting 15 years to have another go. The Scottish Highlands would be represented today by people chosen in 1985. It makes no sense.

Elsewhere decisions are funked: the name of the reformed body and of its members are "left to evolve". Opportunities are missed: Wakeham is quite happy for the second chamber to retain its judicial function, even though it is part of the legislature - a clear violation of the doctrine of the separation of powers which is honoured all over the world but ignored in this country. He is somehow able to contemplate the present role of the lord chancellor without recognising any case for reform. Nor is there any sympathy for the idea, proved effective overseas, that a second chamber should review the appointments of key people to the executive.

Instead, the report repeatedly seeks to maintain the Lords in its cosy old ways, albeit by a system superficially more modern. It still wants the grandeur, the chumminess and the ultimate weakness of a second chamber ensuring that it presents no real challenge to our over-centralised executive. The creation of a genuine check and balance was the prize within the grasp of the Wakeham 12. They have fumbled that chance. By presenting such a muddled report they have made it easy for Mr Blair to ignore their deliberations. Theirs is not a clarion call for change, but a mumbled agreement among the Westminster club to keep things as they are. If this is the best idea for a replacement, the "interim" house created last year may turn out to be as permanent as the last one. And that, remember, survived for nearly a century.

fields.headline: Reformed chamber presented as 'radical evolution'
fields.standfirst: Wakeham report bans use of 'peer' but cannot decide                                                    on what to call members or the place where they sit
fields.trailText: The Wakeham commission's blueprint for the reformed House of Lords sets out the case for what it argues is "radical evolutionary change which will contribute to better government for all".
fields.body:
The Wakeham commission's blueprint for the reformed House of Lords sets out the case for what it argues is "radical evolutionary change which will contribute to better government for all".

Its 216-page report, A House for the Future, contains 132 recommendations that the commission claimed to be "persuasive and intellectually coherent but also workable, durable and politically realistic".

If implemented, the document says, no new member of the second chamber would arrive there on the same basis as any existing member of the upper house.

The royal commission proposes a second chamber of around 550 members - the majority of whom would be chosen by an independent appointments commission, and the rest drawn from the regions by selection or direct election.

Members would no longer be known as peers, and those who have been made peers through the honours list would not be members.

The composition of the chamber as a whole would be regularly adjusted to reflect the balance of political opinion within the country.

There would also be targets to reflect more closely the UK's gender, ethnic and faith mix, with the goal of including members from all over the country and "all walks of life".

The commission recommends the reformed chamber should be "at least as powerful as the present House of Lords" in providing a check upon the executive, with scope to examine human rights and constitutional issues.

Its elected element should "provide a voice" for the UK's nations and regions.

Overall the recommended upper house would be "authoritative, confident and broadly representative of the United Kingdom".

Guide to the new power house

Composition
The make-up, in particular the balance between elected and appointed members, was the most significant and most contentious issue the commission had to consider. Though the panel agreed on a mainly appointed chamber, with a minority of regional members chosen by selection or election, it failed to reach consensus on the number and selection method of regional members and instead offers three options.

After consultation and exploring options, the commission recommended a chamber of around 550 members - smaller than the unreformed house but not as small as many wished - with most appointed by an independent commission and a minority of between 65 and 195 to be elected or selected on a regional basis. Appointed members would serve for 15 year terms, and regional members for three electoral terms, with the possibility of being reappointed for a further period of up to 15 years.

An honours list peerage would no longer mean a place in the upper chamber, and members of the upper house would no longer be known as peers.

There would be an end to political patronage, the commission claimed, with the prime minister and government excluded from the appointments process ,and selection based on merit. The resulting house would be required to be broadly representative of British society, and would be free of domination by any one party, thanks to a statutory minimum proportion of crossbenchers. It would have to reflect the voting preferences of the electorate at the most recent general election.

Appointed members
There should be a "totally independent" appointments commission, the report argued, with no association with the prime minister or government. It would appoint all members bar the regional members, lords of appeal, and representatives of the Church of England, and there would be no parliamentary approval of appointments.

There would be eight members of the commission, each appointed according to the Nolan principles and serving a maximum of 10 years. Three would be nominees from the main political parties, one nominated by cross benchers, and four independents, of whom one should be the chairman.

This commission would be responsible for keeping the proportion of independents, or cross benchers, at around a fifth of the chamber's membership. It would be obliged to encourage appointments and nominations from under-represented groups, and report regularly to parliament on gender balance and minority ethnic groups. Commissioners would be charged with a "pro-active approach" to finding appointees, and the commission would be expected to consoutvocational, professional, cultural, sporting and other bodies, as well as publish criteria for appointment.

The panel, normally making appointments on a half-yearly cycle, would have a statutory duty to ensure that at least 30% of new members are women (and at least 30% men), with the aim of "steady progress" towards a 50:50 balance.

Among the politically affiliated members, it would secure an overall balance matching the political opinion of the country as a whole, based on share of the vote (not seats won) at the last general election.

According to the Wakeham commission, it should be impossible for any one party to secure a majority.

Regional members
Three options are proposed. Under Model A, 65 members selected by dividing up a regional allocation of seats according to each party's share of the vote in that region at general elections; one third of the regions would select regional members at each general election.

Model B (favoured by the majority of the commission) would see 87 members, directly elected at the time of each European parliament election according to PR similar to Euro elections.

Model C would provide for 195 regional members directly elected at the time of each European parliament election.

Existing life peers and hereditaries
Existing life peers should remain for life, the commission concluded, which means the new-look house reflecting every sector of society will be slow to be implemented; however, it predicted that only a handful of life peers will still be sitting in 20 years' time. The 92 remaining hereditaries would be dispensed with, but could return as appointees or regional members.

Religious faiths
A large majority of the commission recommended that religious representation be "broader and deeper" than in the existing Lords. Though the Church of England should continue to be explicitly represented, so too should other Christian denominations and other faiths.

The commission proposed 16 places for Anglican representatives, five for other Christian denominations in England, and five for Christian denominations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. At least five more should be selected to be "broadly representative" of non-Christian faiths.

Roles and powers
The commission concluded the current balance between the two houses is "about right and should not be radically disturbed".

It argued that the Commons should retain final say in respect of all public policy, while the second chamber should have sufficient power and authority to require the government and the Commons to reconsider proposed legislation and take account of cogent objections to it.

The chamber would retain the so-called "suspensory veto" set out in the parliament acts, giving it power to delay legislation but not permanently to block it. As now, the upper house would be unable to prevent the passage of a Commons bill backed by the Commons in two successive sessions of parliament.

While maintaining its right to delay flawed legislation, the second chamber would however continue to be obliged to consider government business within a reasonable time, and to observe the "Salisbury conventions" - the underlying principles obeyed by peers. As now, it would respect legislation in a governing party's manifesto, and would be expected to be sensible in using its powers to challenge the will of MPs.

The upper house would lose its absolute power to veto statutory instruments, on the grounds it was never used by peers. Instead, though the Commons would gain the final say, the chamber would gain more moderate but usable powers to delay, and demonstrate its concern about, specific statutory instruments.

Making law
The commission argued there should be no significant changes in the law-making functions. However, to prevent bad legislation rushed through the house thanks to limited parliamentary time, the report argues for more pre-legislative scrutiny of draft bills. It also suggests the second chamber should look at how to speed up consideration of law reform bills drawn up by the law commission.

In recognition of the growing volume of secondary legislation, the chamber should maintain and extend its power to scrutinise statutory instruments, the report said.

Protecting the constitution
The chamber's role in protecting the constitution should be "maintained and enhanced", the commission recommended. One of the most important functions should be to act as a "constitutional long-stop", ensuring changes are made to the consitution only with full debate and a clear idea of the consequences.

A restriction on further amendments to the parliament acts would reinforce the right of the upper house to veto any bill to extend the life of a parliament - preventing any government voting itself into permanent power.

The chamber would gain no extra powers over constitutional or human rights issues or legislation, but would set up a constitutional committee to scrutinise constitutional implications of all legislation.

There would also be a human rights committee to look at bills with such implications.With the imminent implementation of the 1998 human rights act, the report points out, parliament will need such a scrutiny procedure.

Representing the nations and regions
Whatever future developments in devolution or decentralisation, the chamber should "give a voice" to people from throughout the United Kingdom, the commission said.

Under proposals for a minority of elected members, the reformed house would have representatives from all over the UK, but these would not be drawn from the devolved administrations, or from the Scottish parliament and the other devolved assemblies.

However, the report stressed that the reformed chamber should not become a "federal legislature" supporting a "federal government", nor a forum for liasion be tween the government and the executives of the devolved Scottish parliament and Welsh and Northern Ireland assemblies. The house would not meet outside London, but some committees could meet in regional centres "from time to time".

Holding the government to account
The commission argued that ministers should continue to be drawn from, and be directly accountable to, the second chamber.

It recommended increasing ministerial accountability by requiring senior ministers based in the Commons to make statements to and take questions from second chamber committees when appropriate.

There should be more scrutiny of ministers' handling of European Union business, with additional resources for the European Union committee.

Though British MEPs would not be represented in the chamber, it should promote greater cooperation between MEPs and parliament.

More broadly, the commission recommended that the chamber continue to be "a relatively non-polemical forum for national debate", and that specialist committee work, drawing on the broad spread of expertise held by members, should continue.

It also proposes a committee to scrutinise treaties laid before parliament and to draw attention to any implications which might deserve consideration by parliament before the treaties are ratified.

The law lords
The commitee was asked to judge whether the chamber should continue to carry out judicial functions through committees of law lords.

It concluded that, as long as certain basic conventions were observed, there was no reason to change the present arrangements.

The report argued there were advantages in having senior judges in the legislature where they could be made aware of social developments and political balances that underlay most legislation.

However, in the light of controversy over the law lords' vote on the case of General Pinochet (which threw up concerns over the failure of one law lord involved in the judgment to declare his association with the human rights pressure group Amnesty International) the commission proposed requiring lords of appeal to set out in writing and publish a statement of the principles they intended to observe when participating in debates and votes and when considering their eligibility to sit on related cases.

Characteristics
The commission concluded that, taking account of its role and functions, the chamber should "above all, be authoritative, confident and broadly representative of the whole of British society".

Its members, according to the report, should have a breadth of experience and expertise outside the world of politics; particular skills and knowledge relevant to the careful assessment of constitutional and human rights issues; personal distinction; and the ability to bring a philosophical, moral or spiritual perspective and freedom from party domination.

Nevertheless, though authoritative, the reformed second chamber should not challenge the ultimate democratic authority of the Commons.

Titles and pay
The commission concludes that, since the link between the honours list and the Lords would be broken, members of the upper chamber would no longer be known as peers.

It floated the options of using the suffix LP (for Lord/Lady of Parliament) or the title senator, but made no recommendation. The report also stopped short of proposing a name for the second chamber, concluding that both titles "should be left to evolve".

The commission proposed increasing the remuneration received by members of the second chamber to ensure they were able to afford to attend from all over the country and not only from the south-east of England.

It argued that a clear link should be made between attendance and financial support, so that those who wished to devote significant time to parliamentary duties could afford to do so - without subsidising those who had a career and attended less frequently.

As now, the upper house would be unable to prevent the passage of a Commons bill backed by the Commons in two successive sessions of parliament. While maintaining its right to delay flawed legislation, the second chamber would however continue to be obliged to consider government business within a reasonable time, and to observe the "Salisbury conventions" - the underlying principles obeyed by peers. As now, it would respect legislation in a governing party's manifesto, and would be expected to be sensible in using its powers to challenge the will of MPs. The upper house would lose its absolute power to veto statutory instruments, on the grounds it was never used by peers. Instead, though the Commons would gain the final say, the chamber would gain more moderate but usable powers to delay, and demonstrate its concern about, specific statutory instruments. Making law The commission argued there should be no significant changes in the law-making functions. However, to prevent bad legislation rushed through the house thanks to limited parliamentary time, the report argues for more pre-legislative scrutiny of draft bills. It also suggests the second chamber should look at how to speed up consideration of law reform bills drawn up by the law commission. In recognition of the growing volume of secondary legislation, the chamber should maintain and extend its power to scrutinise statutory instruments, the report said. Protecting the constitution The chamber's role in protecting the constitution should be "maintained and enhanced", the commission recommended. One of the most important functions should be to act as a "constitutional long-stop", ensuring changes are made to the consitution only with full debate and a clear idea of the consequences. A restriction on further amendments to the parliament acts would reinforce the right of the upper house to veto any bill to extend the life of a parliament - preventing any government voting itself into permanent power. The chamber would gain no extra powers over constitutional or human rights issues or legislation, but would set up a constitutional committee to scrutinise constitutional implications of all legislation. There would also be a human rights committee to look at bills with such implications.With the imminent implementation of the 1998 human rights act, the report points out, parliament will need such a scrutiny procedure. Representing the nations and regions Whatever future developments in devolution or decentralisation, the chamber should "give a voice" to people from throughout the United Kingdom, the commission said. Under proposals for a minority of elected members, the reformed house would have representatives from all over the UK, but these would not be drawn from the devolved administrations, or from the Scottish parliament and the other devolved assemblies. However, the report stressed that the reformed chamber should not become a "federal legislature" supporting a "federal government", nor a forum for liasion be tween the government and the executives of the devolved Scottish parliament and Welsh and Northern Ireland assemblies. The house would not meet outside London, but some committees could meet in regional centres "from time to time". Holding the government to account The commission argued that ministers should continue to be drawn from, and be directly accountable to, the second chamber. It recommended increasing ministerial accountability by requiring senior ministers based in the Commons to make statements to and take questions from second chamber committees when appropriate. There should be more scrutiny of ministers' handling of European Union business, with additional resources for the European Union committee. Though British MEPs would not be represented in the chamber, it should promote greater cooperation between MEPs and parliament. More broadly, the commission recommended that the chamber continue to be "a relatively non-polemical forum for national debate", and that specialist committee work, drawing on the broad spread of expertise held by members, should continue. It also proposes a committee to scrutinise treaties laid before parliament and to draw attention to any implications which might deserve consideration by parliament before the treaties are ratified. The law lords The commitee was asked to judge whether the chamber should continue to carry out judicial functions through committees of law lords. It concluded that, as long as certain basic conventions were observed, there was no reason to change the present arrangements. The report argued there were advantages in having senior judges in the legislature where they could be made aware of social developments and political balances that underlay most legislation. However, in the light of controversy over the law lords' vote on the case of General Pinochet (which threw up concerns over the failure of one law lord involved in the judgment to declare his association with the human rights pressure group Amnesty International) the commission proposed requiring lords of appeal to set out in writing and publish a statement of the principles they intended to observe when participating in debates and votes and when considering their eligibility to sit on related cases. Characteristics The commission concluded that, taking account of its role and functions, the chamber should "above all, be authoritative, confident and broadly representative of the whole of British society". Its members, according to the report, should have a breadth of experience and expertise outside the world of politics; particular skills and knowledge relevant to the careful assessment of constitutional and human rights issues; personal distinction; and the ability to bring a philosophical, moral or spiritual perspective and freedom from party domination. Nevertheless, though authoritative, the reformed second chamber should not challenge the ultimate democratic authority of the Commons. Titles and pay The commission concludes that, since the link between the honours list and the Lords would be broken, members of the upper chamber would no longer be known as peers. It floated the options of using the suffix LP (for Lord/Lady of Parliament) or the title senator, but made no recommendation. The report also stopped short of proposing a name for the second chamber, concluding that both titles "should be left to evolve". The commission proposed increasing the remuneration received by members of the second chamber to ensure they were able to afford to attend from all over the country and not only from the south-east of England. It argued that a clear link should be made between attendance and financial support, so that those who wished to devote significant time to parliamentary duties could afford to do so - without subsidising those who had a career and attended less frequently.

fields.body:

fields.headline: Soccer's injured cry foul
fields.trailText: Soccer club doctors and physiotherapists can face "unacceptable" pressure to allow injured footballers to resume playing before they are fully fit it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Soccer club doctors and physiotherapists can face "unacceptable" pressure to allow injured footballers to resume playing before they are fully fit, while the players may be "inconvenienced" to encourage them to return to action, it was claimed yesterday.

A study of medical standards at English clubs concluded that there were causes for concern. The report, Managing Injuries in Professional Football: the Roles of the Club Doctor and Physiotherapist, was commissioned by the Professional Footballers' Association. Its authors, Ivan Waddington and Martin Roderick, of Leicester university, and Graham Parker, of Coventry business school, noted that playing with pain, or when injured, was a central part of the culture of professional football.

"Players who are unable to play as a result of injury... may be seen as being of little value to the club, and may be stigmatised, ignored or otherwise inconvenienced."

One player described the attitude of one of his former managers as: "You're not meant to be injured ... He totally ignored you when you were in the treatment room. His attitude was 'You're no use to me any more'."

Injured players are normally required to report to the training ground before players who are fit, and are kept there long after the others have departed. "The different routine for injured players cannot be explained simply in terms of their need for specialist treatment for, in many clubs, the routine is deliberately designed to 'inconvenience' injured players and thus to act as a disincentive to them to remain on the injured list."

One physiotherapist said: "I've frequently had it said to me: 'Inconvenience the injured player. We don't want them too comfortable in the treatment room'."

fields.trailText: Joaquín Almunia, [leader of the opposition PSOE], said today [on Canal Sur Radio] that political groups "must react democratically and in unison" against ETA. ? "We must not allow this subject to become part of the electoral debate, and we must remain united." He also expressed his hope that the PNV and EH "speak out against violence, because nationalists are very important when they're on the side of the democrats, but if they hesitate about whose side they're on, they become an instrument of fracture, and attempt to find arguments for killers." El Pais

El Pais

Rafael Hernando, spokesman for the ruling Partido Popular condemned the murder and said that "the only culprit is ETA, and the political wing of ETA, Herri Batasuna. He re-affirmed "the confidence which the PP has in the State's security forces in their struggle agianst the criminal terrorism of ETA" and expressed the repulsion he felt at "the savage methods used by these psychopaths? Those responsible for this outrage are going to end up paying for it" ABC

Ruiz Gallardón, President of the Autonomous Community of Madrid, talking to Spanish national radio RNE

"The most important values we can display at these times are calm and a fighting unity among all political forces, above ideas and territorial claims, since we all share a conception of what a person is - and according to that conception, the thought that it is permissible to take someone's life for a political objective is truly sickening."

PNV (Basque Nationalist Party) MP José Juan González de Txabarri Also on RNE

"For us, this murder is a failure on all our parts, a failure of sorts of strategies, the strategies of some and the strategies of others. Now, in the heat of the moment, everyone will be looking for someone to blame ? Now more than ever we must underline that the only people to blame in these situations are the terrorists themselves.

Perhaps the voice that should sound most clearly and most insistently today is that of the MPs of Herri Batasuna [ETA's political wing] ? making it clear to ETA that we can't go on like this, and that this must be the last time. ETA and HB are preaching abstention in this electoral campaign ? they have been active in the campaign in the only way in which they should have abstained."

Miguel Sanz, President of the Government of Navarra Diario de Navarra

Sanz pointed out that "the democratic parties must respond to the demands of society" and emphasised that "PNV and EA [Basque nationalist parties] are also to be counted" among these.

He reproached both parties for the "equidistance" they keep between "what they call the immobility of the central government and the ETA's attitude after calling an end to the ceasefire? They will have to make a public declaration that they were wrong.

The president of the PP in the Basque Country, Carlos Iturgaiz, said that the members of the terrorist group are "University Professors in doing harm to the Spanish people? I ask the Basque Government and the lehendakari [Basque first minister] Ibarretxe not to give one more second of political support to Herri Batasuna. Ibarretxe and the PNV cannot co-operate for a second longer with these murderers." ABC
