webTitle: Internet delivery may be future of video

fields.headline: Internet delivery may be future of video
fields.standfirst:
Also today, The big 4-0 is a big zero for Sharon Stone |
Rhys-Meyers tells of his Irish attack at gunpoint | Michael Jackson confirms he will produce and star in Edgar Allan Poe biopic | Hollywood's new bad boy Tom Cruise perfects woman-hater image | In brief | and the latest casting news
fields.trailText:
Also today, The big 4-0 is a big zero for Sharon Stone |
Rhys-Meyers tells of his Irish attack at gunpoint | Michael Jackson confirms he will produce and star in Edgar Allan Poe biopic | Hollywood's new bad boy Tom Cruise perfects woman-hater image | In brief | and the latest casting news
fields.body:
The next James Bond film could be downloaded from the internet at the same time as going on sale on video or DVD. MGM and Blockbuster have announced that they are to test and develop a system through which Blockbuster would make certain MGM films available for digital streamlining and downloading onto the web.

"Access to video-streaming rights for a portion of the world's largest modern film library underscores our goal as a company to provide quality, in-home entertainment in whatever form our consumers want it delivered, whether through our stores or other channels such as electronic delivery," said John Antioco, Blockbuster's CEO..

The move is a canny one on Blockbuster's part. Many industry analysts believe that once streaming video is perfected, it will be the standard for all video delivery, eventually replacing video stores. The deal ensures Blockbuster will remain a key player in video delivery.

In addition to making its films available on its own website, MGM said some films would also be available to download through Blockbuster's site, for a fee. It did not say which films would be accessible, but as MGM owns the entire Bond catalogue, Raging Bull and The Graduate, it has a number of options.

The big 4-0 is a big zero for Sharon Stone

Sharon Stone says
she is being denied roles because of an ageist Hollywood. The 41-year-old star told Now magazine: "When women hit 40 in Hollywood, they get punished. I'm being punished for doing that very bad thing - getting older, hitting 40". And Stone, who recently starred as a greek goddess in The Muse said that a number of actresses were lying about their age to get
the plum roles.

"I can't tell you their names because I don't want to wreck their careers, says the pious Stone, "But isn't it hideous?"

Rhys-Meyers in Irish Ride with the Devil

Jonathan Rhys-Meyers has told how he was terrorised at gunpoint by six armed robbers demanding £25,000.

The star of Ang Lee's Ride With the Devil said in a magazine interview that the robbers, whom he believed were "political people", were convinced there was a safe in the Irish farm house where he was staying.

They tied him up, put a shotgun in his mouth and threatened to kneecap him if he didn't tell them where the money was. The men eventually fled, leaving Meyers and the farm manager trussed up for half an hour before they managed to undo the ropes. And what was going through the chiselled one's mind? "The only thing I'd been thinking about, I'm afraid, was that I'd never live to have a movie career."

Jackson to play Poe

Michael Jackson is committed to bringing the life of Edgar Allan Poe to the big screen, according to the latest reports. Not only will the singer produce Nightmare of Edgar Allan Poe, he will also definitely play Poe himself.

Gary Pudney, who will co-produce the biopic with the pop star, says Jackson's "whole new thrust" is going to be movies: "He has sold the most records, made the most money on tours, and this is the one genre he has the desire to excel in."

Pudney said a script for the project is due next month and shooting is scheduled to begin next September. Official word promises that a major makeup job will turn the pop star into the living embodiment of the late horror writer - that alone should move the crowds.

Cruise walks on the wild side

Tom Cruise is clearly having a lot of fun with his new bad boy role. As reported in Wednesday's news, the clean-cut Hollywood star has dismayed a lot of his female fans by starring as a woman-hating TV evangelist, Frank TJ Mackay, in his new film Magnolia.

But the actor has been fooling the Hollywood public further by starring in a series of spoof "Learn how to make that lady friend your sex servant" TV ads to promote the film.

Broadcast in the early hours of the morning in Los Angeles, Cruise's character is seen between two underwear-clad models selling a guaranteed seduction system to help men bed the women they want, saying "Tap into her hopes, her wants, her fears, her desire - and her sweet little panties".

The title of this year's indie Oscar hope is not mentioned in the ad, which ends by asking people to phone 1-877-TAME- HER for more details.

In brief

Veteran Polish film-maker Andrzej Wajda is being tipped for an Oscar to honour his lifetime's work. The director who made Ashes and Diamonds and Danton was proposed by almost all 39 members of the academy's governing body which voted on Wednesday night, according to reports in the Polish media.

Casting couch

 Tom Hanks is to play Julius Caesar in a £70m epic directed by The Insider's Michael Mann. The as yet untitled film will recount Caesar's battle with his former friend and mentor, Pompey.

 Rachel Weisz and Brendan Fraser have agreed to join John Hannah and reprise their roles for The Mummy 2. Shooting will start this spring for a May 2001 release. Apparently, the script calls for Fraser and Weisz's characters to be married and have a nine-year-old son showing the same swashbuckling flair as his parents.

 Director Phillip Noyce, whose film The Bone Collector is currently doing the rounds at UK cinemas, is developing a film set against the backdrop of the Russia-Chechnya conflict. The £25m project, entitled Bloodline, will focus on two brothers, the sons of Russian emigrants, who return to Russia and become embroiled in the civil war.

webTitle: Business school puts its faith in ex-fundraiser

fields.headline: Business school puts its faith in ex-fundraiser
fields.trailText: Katherine Stevens is restless, again. Last year she was the European ChildrenÍs TrustÍs head of public affairs and had just masterminded its transformation from the Romanian Orphanage Trust. Now, at 34, she is one of London Business SchoolÍs new intake of two-year full-time MBA students.
fields.body:
Catherine Stevens is restless, again. Last year she was the European Children's Trust's head of public affairs and had just masterminded its transformation from the Romanian Orphanage Trust. Now, at 34, she is one of London Business School's new intake of two-year full-time MBA students.

She believes in her ability to change the world, and she is not alone. The Association of MBAs and Hobsons publishers have signalled their faith in her with a £10,000 scholarship, and LBS itself has given her a £12,500 scholarship. ItÍs not surprising. I listened to her for an afternoon and ended up sure that she could do anything.

The idealism which took her into the voluntary sector is still with her. 'I can effect greater change and benefit more people by working for a company than for a charity. I can make things happen on a bigger scale, and have a bigger impact on economic regeneration,' she says.

She learned from her work with Romanian orphanages that things are seldom what they seem. Why did children end up in these orphanages? Only about 5% of the children were really orphans. The rest had parents who did not have the money to look after them, because there was no unemployment benefit. So the trust opened daycare centres to enable children to live with their families, yet allow both parents to take part in the daily struggle to stave off starvation.

It was a classic management solution. 'It was about taking the orphanage budget and using it differently,' she says. 'If you say, we are stopping children going into an orphanage, people will give you money. Whereas if you say, find a social worker who will go to Romania for a month, they will yawn. Yet itÍs all really social work.'

The Romanian Orphanage Trust was 'about making something from nothing' she says. There was no evidence that people would support such a cause, but they did. In three years, she took fundraising income from £1m to £3.4m. Then she turned the charity into a new and wider-ranging organisation, the European Children's Trust. After that, challenges in the voluntary sector seemed a little thin. 'I had been working in a small, entrepreneurial, young charity with a very dynamic culture. To move on, I would need to go to a bigger charity with a more bureaucratic, less flexible culture,' she says.

The daughter of an army chaplain, Catherine Stevens studied theology at Trinity College, Oxford, graduating in 1987. She spent five months as an electronics analyst, 18 months running her own catering business, then trained as a teacher of English as a foreign language and spent a year doing voluntary work in Kenya. There she helped found a school just across the border in Uganda. 'The parents cleared the playground and built the lavatories, and I raised the money for the building, largely from my friends and family,' she says. The school now has eight classrooms and 50 children.

Back in Britain in 1991, Catherine became a fundraiser for a series of charities. As a full stop to that part of her life, she has written a book called The Goldfish Guide to Charitable Giving, published by TPD Publishing.

But what now? She isn't sure yet. It might involve extending internet use in third world countries but she wants 'an element of idealism in my work.' She has already promised her sponsors at the London Business School that she 'will achieve in a way and on a scale that will enhance the school's reputation internationally'.

I believe her. At the end of her two-year course, she will probably know how she is going to do it.

Last year she was the European Children's Trust's head of public affairs and had just masterminded its transformation from the Romanian Orphanage Trust. Now, at 34, she is one of London Business School's new intake of two-year full-time MBA students. She believes in her ability to change the world, and she is not alone. The Association of MBAs and Hobsons publishers have signalled their faith in her with a £10,000 scholarship, and LBS itself has given her a £12,500 scholarship. ItÍs not surprising. I listened to her for an afternoon and ended up sure that she could do anything. The idealism which took her into the voluntary sector is still with her. 'I can effect greater change and benefit more people by working for a company than for a charity. I can make things happen on a bigger scale, and have a bigger impact on economic regeneration,' she says. She learned from her work with Romanian orphanages that things are seldom what they seem. Why did children end up in these orphanages? Only about 5% of the children were really orphans. The rest had parents who did not have the money to look after them, because there was no unemployment benefit. So the trust opened daycare centres to enable children to live with their families, yet allow both parents to take part in the daily struggle to stave off starvation. It was a classic management solution. 'It was about taking the orphanage budget and using it differently,' she says. 'If you say, we are stopping children going into an orphanage, people will give you money. Whereas if you say, find a social worker who will go to Romania for a month, they will yawn. Yet itÍs all really social work.' The Romanian Orphanage Trust was 'about making something from nothing' she says. There was no evidence that people would support such a cause, but they did. In three years, she took fundraising income from £1m to £3.4m. Then she turned the charity into a new and wider-ranging organisation, the European Children's Trust. After that, challenges in the voluntary sector seemed a little thin. 'I had been working in a small, entrepreneurial, young charity with a very dynamic culture. To move on, I would need to go to a bigger charity with a more bureaucratic, less flexible culture,' she says. The daughter of an army chaplain, Catherine Stevens studied theology at Trinity College, Oxford, graduating in 1987. She spent five months as an electronics analyst, 18 months running her own catering business, then trained as a teacher of English as a foreign language and spent a year doing voluntary work in Kenya. There she helped found a school just across the border in Uganda. 'The parents cleared the playground and built the lavatories, and I raised the money for the building, largely from my friends and family,' she says. The school now has eight classrooms and 50 children. Back in Britain in 1991, Catherine became a fundraiser for a series of charities. As a full stop to that part of her life, she has written a book called The Goldfish Guide to Charitable Giving, published by TPD Publishing. But what now? She isn't sure yet. It might involve extending internet use in third world countries but she wants 'an element of idealism in my work.' She has already promised her sponsors at the London Business School that she 'will achieve in a way and on a scale that will enhance the school's reputation internationally'. I believe her. At the end of her two-year course, she will probably know how she is going to do it.

fields.headline: Harness the e-commerce explosion
fields.standfirst: Students clamouring to launch e-commerce start-ups are clamouring to learn the skills, says John Crace
fields.trailText: Hubris is not a word you generally associate with management experts. So when a senior academic in the field puts his hands in the air and acknowledges that the industry has missed a trick, itÍs time to pay attention.
fields.body:
Hubris is not a word you generally associate with management experts. So when a senior academic in the field puts his hands in the air and acknowledges that the industry has missed a trick, itÍs time to pay attention.

Over the past 10 years the MBA market has expanded massively both in this country and abroad, breeding a new race of management technocrats, whose salaries are measured in telephone numbers and who can downsize a multinational in a matter of minutes. And yet even some of these top players have been caught out by the speed of growth of the internet.

'The interest in e-commerce seems to have exploded exponentially in the last six months,' says Stephen Drew, lead tutor of strategic direction at Henley Management College. 'We have been inundated with requests to teach e-commerce, both by current students and, perhaps more surprisingly, by ex-students who want to come back to learn the new skills.

'Other strands of the MBA, such as marketing and strategy, have already been making use of the internet but up till now there has been no module that focused solely on e-commerce.'

To cope with the demand, Mr Drew has been drawing together the different strands necessary to introduce an e-commerce elective into the MBA programmes this March which will be taught almost entirely online. He refuses to be drawn into predicting how many students will take up the elective, but suggests that it may quickly run into the hundreds.

The United States has been way ahead of Britain in exploiting the potential of the internet. So while entrepreneurs on this side of the Atlantic are still keen to dip their toes into the dot.com world, the market is so mature stateside that we recently saw one of the biggest mergers in corporate history, between America Online and Time Warner.

Predictably, this transatlantic divide is reflected in the way the US business schools have latched on to e-commerce. Few colleges would dream of not offering an e-commerce module, while Amos Tuck in New Hampshire and Thunderbird in Phoenix, Arizona, have been doing so for three years or more.

But if Europe has been lagging behind, there is a growing determination to catch up, and to do so fast. Already INSEAD in Paris, IMD in Lausanne and the School of Management in Rotterdam offer e-commerce taught within MBAs  and British institutions are rushing to do likewise.

At the head of the queue in this country is the City University Business School in London. City has been running electives in e-commerce since 1995, but last autumn it launched its first specialist E-Business MBA.

'Two years ago we started to review the whole MBA in the light of e-commerce and the new economy,' says Clive Holtham, Bull Information Systems professor of information management at City, who made it a key objective to ensure contacts were kept up to date.

But as business and academia are now discovering, keeping pace with the speed of change in e-business is almost impossible. Playing catch-up is more often the norm.

Within a few weeks of starting the first course, Prof Holtham realised he needed to radically realign its focus. 'It became apparent once our first 15 students linked up that more than half already had e-commerce experience,' he says. 'So we immediately decided to put less emphasis on theory and more on real-world experience.'

In the first 10 weeks of the course, students were expected to complete a major project for a professional organisation and deliver a briefing on whether to establish a business-to-business or business-to-consumer website.

Which is not to say that there is no room for theory. The battle between the competing views of e-commerce  as either a tag on to the main business or a key delivery model  has been pretty much won, but there are still the central issues of vision, marketing plans and delivery logistics to be tussled with.

Much of the theory is now given a practical edge. The business planning course no longer requires students to suggest ways of raising the money for a dot.com start-up. Instead they have to go out and do it themselves.

'We provide access to the venture capitalists,' Prof Holtham says. 'ItÍs up to us and the students to give them the viable propositions.'

E-commerce has created a sea change in MBAs. Just two years ago only about 1% of City University students were looking to create their own internet start-ups. That figure is now between 25% and 30% and rising, and the shift in student expectations may cause further ripples through the sector.

Traditionally, MBAs have been populated by students sponsored by their companies. If businesses start to feel they are merely paying for the pleasure of giving their employees the nous and the contacts to start their own operations, they may not be so forthcoming with funding in the future.

But that need not worry course providers. Of the 15 students on the 53-week specialist City MBA, almost all had elected to jack in their jobs and pay their own way. Tuition fees of £15,000, not to mention associated living costs, might seem a prohibitive investment to some, but when you're measuring your future in tens of millions, this kind of outlay rather pales into insignificance.

webTitle: Case three: 'Discipline and hard work are essential - but I'm glad I did it'

fields.headline: Case three: 'Discipline and hard work are essential - but I'm glad I did it'
fields.standfirst:
June Neal
Age: 50
MBA: Aston Business School, 1995-97
Job: Senior administrative officer for the rent office, part of the department of the environment
fields.trailText: I decided to take an MBA as a way of updating my knowledge of management techniques. I had become aware, through contacts with local authorities, that some were preparing for the future in a much better fashion than others, and I wanted to learn about modern methods to benefit my organisation which, at that time, was called the rent officer service, part of the department of the environment.
fields.body:
I decided to take an MBA as a way of updating my knowledge of management techniques. I had become aware, through contacts with local authorities, that some were preparing for the future in a much better fashion than others, and I wanted to learn about modern methods to benefit my organisation which, at that time, was called the rent officer service, part of the department of the environment.

I looked at several local courses and was initially attracted to a university that offered housing studies as well as an MBA. However, I rejected it when I discovered that the programme was not accredited. The Aston staff course content and overall approach impressed me much more, so I chose to enrol on its two-year, part-time MBA in public services management. My employer was prepared to pay the tuition fees for all of the modules whose exams I passed, which I managed to do. However, I paid for my other expenses, like travel and books, and was not given time off to attend classes during the day. When I went to these I had either to make up the time at work or take holiday leave. Another condition was that, if I left my job within two years of finishing the MBA, I would have to repay all the fees.

I found that you must be incredibly disciplined to fulfil the demands of an MBA programme while holding down a full-time job. Two evenings a week at college, study assignments, projects and exams at the end of every module, all add up to a substantial amount of work. In particular, I found some of the maths and statistics hard to tackle, but the bulk of the course was much as I had imagined it would be.

One pleasant surprise was the high degree of camaraderie among the students. I had been a little worried that the other participants would be considerably younger than me. However, the gap turned out to be not so great.

I probably benefited most from those parts of the course that dealt with the management of change. I knew that my employer was about to become an executive agency, a shift that would create a good deal of change. I was especially interested in the human resource elements within that process Ü in fact, the transition to the rent service took place last October.

My MBA hasn't resulted in any promotion or increase in pay, but I never expected that it would lead to those things. It has given me a better idea of how organisations fit together and how they function holistically, which has made my job easier. Contacts I made through the course are particularly useful when you encounter a work problem and need advice.

Anyone thinking about studying for an MBA should research courses very carefully. I didn't want to spend a lot of energy gaining a qualification that wasn't widely recognised and rated highly. Accreditation by the Association of MBAs is important in that respect. It's wise to visit institutions with a preliminary interview, which I had to have because I don't possess a first degree. My MBA was a lot of hard work, but it was well worth it.

webTitle: Degree evolves to meet your needs

fields.headline: Degree evolves to meet your needs
fields.standfirst: Courses are available to more students than ever, says Paula Glason
fields.trailText: Thirty years ago, the MBA degree barely existed in Britain. Today you would be hard-pressed to find a university or business school that doesnÍt offer the MBA or at least some variant of the qualification.
fields.body:
Thirty years ago, the MBA degree barely existed in Britain. Today you would be hard-pressed to find a university or business school that doesnÍt offer the MBA or at least some variant of the qualification.

The MBA has truly come of age: a flagship management development programme with some 12,000 students a year studying in Britain.

The postgraduate and post-experience degree has diversified over the past few years to offer industry specific training for accountants, public-sector workers, lawyers and even footballers. Whatever the sector, there is an increasing need for efficient management of resources and strategic thinking.

Once seen as a full-time qualification for the City high flyer, the MBA is now increasingly studied part-time. Distance learning is also capturing an increasing share of the market. Many employers are sponsoring MBA students on part-time programmes and are seeing a return on their investment in highly motivated staff. The challenge is to provide sufficient opportunities for these staff to continue to develop.

The MBA has evolved to meet the changing demands of business, generating innovative approaches to learning. TodayÍs market is determining the type of programme on offer.

A by-product of such diversification is the difference in quality of the courses. Ultimately, any product developed in accordance with market demand needs to maintain standards, hence the need for MBA programme accreditation.

Programme accreditation goes beyond the simple validation of the course and looks at the value and quality of the MBA programme from the consumerÍs point of view. It takes into account physical facilities, size of faculty, staff qualifications and student admission standards as well as factors such as the availability of language teaching, library and computer facilities and international contacts.

Despite the fact that many schools continue to argue that management education is a face-to-face business, we are experiencing an increasing demand for communication via the internet. Few people can afford to take a year out for full-time study. Today US business schools are looking to successful distance-learning providers in Britain to see how they might copy their modes of delivery. Students should bear in mind that learning is an interactive experience, and the greater the opportunity for practical application and direct sharing of experiences, the stronger the outcome is likely to be.

MBA students on full-time programmes often profess that about 50% of what they gain from the MBA comes from contact with their peer group.

It is also no longer enough to graduate with an MBA: what matters is what you do afterwards to top up your knowledge. Business schools are responding to the demands of the 'aftercare market' with gusto.

Whether you are studying for an MBA to change career or as a longer-term means to an end, employers are increasingly looking for a commitment to personal and professional development. The key questions you will be asked at interview are a) Where did you get your MBA?, and b) What have you done since to update your skills and knowledge?

With the competitive business arena meaning fewer jobs for fewer people, showing initiative and keeping on top of changes will put you in the winning seat.

Paula Glason works for the Association of MBAs

webTitle: Case two: 'A long, hard, lonely road - but it helped me to progress'

fields.headline: Case two: 'A long, hard, lonely road - but it helped me to progress'
fields.standfirst:
Terry Standing
Age: 40
MBA: Henley Management College, 1996-97
Job: Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Hertfordshire Fire and Rescue Service
fields.trailText: Because I had gained a diploma in management studies from Cheltenham and Gloucester College, I was allowed to go straight into the second part of the distance learning MBA at Henley. I managed to complete it in 18 months, which is fairly quick.
fields.body:
Because I had gained a diploma in management studies from Cheltenham and Gloucester College, I was allowed to go straight into the second part of the distance learning MBA at Henley. I managed to complete it in 18 months, which is fairly quick.

My employer at that time  I was a divisional fire officer in Shropshire  paid for about half my MBA fees, and I contributed the rest. There is a general recognition in the fire service that exposure to external personal development opportunities makes a better senior officer.

I chose Henley as a likely institution after a colleague recommended it, having done an MBA there himself. When I looked more closely at the course, I found that the standards of text and documentation offered to distance learners was extremely high. The deciding factor was that it is a highly regarded business school which regularly appears in top ten lists. The timetable only required me to attend about four or five one-day workshops at Henley in a year, and I found these absolutely essential.

A distance learning MBA is often a long, hard and lonely road, so the prospect of meeting up with other students can act as a great stimulus. Working on your own for weeks on end can make your enthusiasm wane. On average, I devoted about three evenings a week, plus a whole day over the weekend, to my studies  maybe 20 hours in all.

The sheer quantity of research was something of a surprise, especially the breadth of reading required for a subject like strategic management.

But, on the whole, the programme was much as I expected because the induction process was very thorough and gave a very accurate account of what to look forward to.

I particularly enjoyed the module on the international business environment, which covered topics such as the problems of dealing with subsidiary companies in different countries.

I chose to do my project on the management of learning groups and undertook some research-based experiments involving about 100 fire officers. Some of the findings have since been adopted by the Fire Service College on programmes such as its divisional command course.

There is no doubt that the MBA has helped me progress to principal officer level  it's an important qualification to have on your CV. Much of the MBA programme was about interacting with others on the course, and any future students should make sure they capitalise on that element from the very start.

fields.headline: £100m to run school pay system
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The private sector firm chosen to run failing schools in Islington, north London, has been awarded a further government contract worth up to £100m to help administer the performance-related pay system for teachers.
fields.body:
The private sector firm chosen to run failing schools in Islington, north London, has been awarded a further government contract worth up to £100m to help administer the performance-related pay system for teachers.

Cambridge Education Associates (CEA) is being given responsibility for the deployment of at least 3,000 regional assessors who will monitor the controversial system when it is introduced in September.

Full-time and part-time advisers are being recruited to oversee head teachers' assessment of which staff will move on to a higher, performance-related pay scale by passing the so-called threshold.

They will also have the power to challenge the heads' decisions and assess the heads' own performance.

The department for education confirmed that the five-year contract was being awarded to CEA in a £25m deal. But education sources said its value depended on how many teachers passed over the threshold, which could make it worth as much as £100m.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, is expected to give more detail about how the appraisal will work at a conference next week.

The government has earmarked £1bn over the next two years for performance- related pay, which eligible teachers will get in addition to the basic rise of between 3% and 3.5% expected to be confirmed later this month by the school teachers' review body.

Teaching unions, which have expressed strong concerns about the huge amount of money needed simply to administer and monitor the new system, said the money would be better spent going into teachers' pay packets.

webTitle: PhD rewards are high if you don't lose your patience - or your mind

fields.headline: PhD rewards are high if you don't lose your patience - or your mind
fields.standfirst: Earning your doctorate can be a long, difficult and lonely process, writes Eugene Carey
fields.trailText: Embarking upon a PhD is a bit like buying a ticket for one of those old-fashioned seaside mystery tours: you do not know where it will take you and how long it will take, but you cannot wait to arrive.
fields.body:
Embarking upon a PhD is a bit like buying a ticket for one of those old-fashioned seaside mystery tours: you do not know where it will take you and how long it will take, but you cannot wait to arrive.

The main lesson a PhD student must learn is how to find inner reserves of patience: this is a long haul and you will find that keeping up your spirits and momentum become as important as keeping your eye on the topic of study.

The potential for losing your patience, losing your interest  and even losing your mind  is high, evidence of which is the dropout rate among researchers and the considerable number who take longer than the formal completion period. Add to this several years of living on poorly paid teaching work, and you get the picture. But the rewards can be equally high.

The first thing to do is to choose your academic supervisor and, by implication, the university at which you wish to register. Take great care in identifying and selecting a supervisor (or supervisors) because although it is possible to switch during the research period, it can be a difficult process, causing bureaucratic headaches and ill feeling.

Select a supervisor on the basis of suitability, accessibility and helpfulness. A suitable supervisor is one with a genuine academic interest in your project who, ideally, has also undertaken some work in this area. This does not mean that the supervisor has to be an expert in the topic: it may be better that he or she is not, as what you want is incisive and penetrating questions and an objective assessment.

It is also important to look at the facilities on offer at the department within which you will be registered. Some universities are far more helpful towards PhD students than others, providing infrastructure such as room space, help with funding, computer back-up and structured, methodological training. More poorly run departments simply ignore their PhD students and leave them feeling that they are simply there to bring in funds.

Once you have gained a formal place at a university you will need to seek funding, a science in itself. This is murky territory full of pitfalls, but the rule of thumb is that if your project is genuinely original and exciting, you stand a higher chance of getting the backing you need. But the grants for doctoral work are notoriously low and many students have to take on part-time work.

The loose structure of most PhDs means you are likely to begin with a period of background and preparatory investigation which allows you to plan and prepare your methodology.

The first step in the execution of this is a period of data gathering, followed by the analysis of your data and the writing of your thesis.

The preparatory stage involves much reading and note-taking. You may be required to organise some preliminary thoughts in a draft chapter, and you will almost certainly be required to plan a methodology.

But at this stage, and in the absence of your raw data, it will be hard  especially in the non-physical sciences  to come to any rigid conclusions about exactly what is the phenomenon you are seeking to investigate.

This may sound back to front, but it stands to reason that unless you are embarking upon a theoretical thesis, you will need to have some first-hand contact with the main subject of your study before you can hope to generate pertinent questions about it.

If you do not give top priority to what your data ultimately tells you, then you will fall into the trap of seeking to make your data fit the theory.

Data-gathering requires a host of practical skills, but here concentration really comes into play. This can be physically and emotionally demanding work requiring a mechanical adherence to a set of guidelines or procedures. Just grit your teeth and battle on in the knowledge that, once you have your data you have probably gone beyond the point of no return.

The analysis of your material may be simultaneous to the gathering of it, or it may form part of the writing up process  which itself can act as a device imposing order on your work and leading you in new directions. Supervisors put great emphasis on the writing up because this is the genuinely fertile period of intellectual endeavour.

Above all, writing up is the stage in which you will discover your own limitations, but also new faculties you never knew you had. It will demonstrate to you more than anything that has preceded it the central characteristic of a PhD: this is a process, a work in progress.

That process may only begin to gain momentum in the second or third year but, if you are true to yourself, you will find the essential reserves of patience to reach that stage.

webTitle: How to maximise your employment potential

fields.headline: How to maximise your employment potential
fields.standfirst: Official figures chart the winners and losers as graduates jostle for a prime slot in the workplace. Lee Elliot Major looks at the universities topping the tables.
fields.trailText: The latest official figures detailing the destinations of postgraduate students after university reveal a diverse range of experiences across the higher education sector in terms of how many postgraduates end up pursuing further study, getting a job or finding themselves at the end of the dole queue.
fields.body:
The latest official figures detailing the destinations of postgraduate students after university reveal a diverse range of experiences across the higher education sector in terms of how many postgraduates end up pursuing further study, getting a job or finding themselves at the end of the dole queue.

As with previous years, many former polytechnics share the top places with older universities in terms of the lowest unemployment figures for postgraduates qualifying in 1998.

The University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, the University of Wales, Lampeter, and the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside share the enviable distinction of reporting no postgraduates whatsoever still looking for jobs six months after finishing university. But it should be noted that both Lampeter, and Lincolnshire and Humberside have relatively small numbers of postgraduates on their books.

According to the figures, compiled by the Higher Education Statistics Agency, the University of Surrey also boasts some of the best academic and employment prospects for postgrads, with only 0.3% looking for work after graduating.

This confirms Surreyês reputation as an institution that excels in preparing students for the workplace. The university recorded the lowest percentage of postgraduates actively seeking jobs six months after leaving university in 1998, and runs most degree courses with a work placement year.

Some specialist institutions, such as the London Business School and the Royal Academy of Music, also come out well in the employment stakes, according to the figures, both registering no postgraduates on the dole half a year after finishing courses.

Other universities established in 1992, Liverpool John Moores, Kingston and Anglia Polytechnic, join more traditional research-oriented universities, including Manchester, Southampton and Warwick, in the top 10 institutions in terms of low postgraduate unemployment rates.

Overall, the figures suggest that postgraduate unemployment has fallen since the previous year, down by 0.2% for all the countryês higher education institutions, from 3.3% to 3.1%.

The worst unemployment rates are still mostly registered in the new university sector. The universities of Coventry, Teesside and Glasgow Caledonian all record at least 10% of postgraduates as looking for jobs after graduating in 1998. But they are joined by one of the oldest universities in the country, the University of Durham, which reports that 11.2% of its postgraduates were unemployed. This is the second year running that Durham has recorded that more than 10% of its postgrads are still on the dole six months after leaving university.

A number of health warnings, however, must be tagged to the conclusions drawn from these employment statistics.

Research reveals that A-levels, age, gender, social backgrounds and subjects studied by students all have a big influence in determining whether students end up on the dole queue or in fast-track graduate employment after university.

The study warns that, unless such factors are taken into account, the governmentês drive to use graduate jobs as performance measures for universities will end up misleading prospective students.

The institutional figures in particular obscure stark differences in the employment rates among postgraduates studying different subjects. A postgraduate business school, for example, is likely to improve a universityês overall employment figures.

Another problem is that the universities themselves carry out the destination surveys of past students. Some institutions claim that they carry out much more comprehensive surveys than other universities.

Figures can appear to look good when in fact they are the result of high numbers of postgrads whose destinations are reported as unknown.

Officials are also at pains to emphasise the diversity of the higher education sector, which comprises many types of universities, aiming to provide very different services. Some focus almost exclusively on training future researchers and academics, while others are concerned solely with vocational courses to prepare students for the workplace.

This rich diversity of institutions is reflected in the statistics for students entering further study or employment after finishing postgraduate degrees.

The new universities, for example, are at the head the university table in terms of the employment rates for postgraduates. More than eight in 10 postgraduates at Nottingham Trent, Anglia Polytechnic, North London, Wolverhampton, De Montfort and Portsmouth universities secured jobs after courses.

Cranfield University, an older university exclusively teaching postgraduates, also reported more than 80% of student leavers in jobs in 1998. This compares to the average employment rate for postgraduates from British universities in 1998 of 68.5%, up by 0.4% on the previous year's figures. The highest proportions of postgraduates pursuing further education or training, meanwhile, are to be found in many of the oldest universities, which are known for their strong research traditions.

More than 16% of postgraduates went on to another course after finishing in 1997 at the universities of Essex, Cambridge, St Andrews and Imperial College, London. Among British universities as a whole, 6% of 1998 graduates went on to further study.

webTitle: Case one: 'They told me it would change your life'... and it did

fields.headline: Case one: 'They told me it would change your life'... and it did
fields.standfirst:
Rachel Jenkinson
Age: 33
MBA: Cranfield School of Management, 1998-99
Job: Civil servant, currently working at the department of trade and industry
fields.trailText: I joined the civil service as a scientific officer in the home office direct from Oxford university with a first in physics in 1988. I had heard from a couple of my managers with MBAs that I should consider taking one and felt it was the right time to apply for the special civil service scheme in 1998.
fields.body:
I joined the civil service as a scientific officer in the home office direct from Oxford university with a first in physics in 1988. I had heard from a couple of my managers with MBAs that I should consider taking one and felt it was the right time to apply for the special civil service scheme in 1998.

I had reached a point where I thought it would be a good idea to be able to step back and gain a wider perspective on my world of work. I believed an MBA would be very useful to my department because it deals with all aspects of business and commerce.

I had a choice of three MBA institutions ã Imperial, Manchester and Cranfield ã and chose the last because the course director devoted the best part of a day to showing me around and explaining the course.

My employer paid for everything during the one-year, full-time course. People told me that the programme would require very hard work, and it certainly did. I hadn't anticipated how fast you have to get things done.

I particularly benefited from having to work alongside 200 other MBA students from a vast range of countries and backgrounds, most of whom were employed in the private sector.

About half of the course comprised electives, so I was able to select projects with a business content that also involved some practical experience. I was part of a four-strong team that undertook a business check-up on a small to medium sized enterprise. We came up with a set of recommendations which the company said it would adopt.

When I returned to the department after the MBA, I had a choice of work and opted for international trade and policy.

During the course I had studied quite a lot of economics which played a big part in that decision. Now I feel I am a better manager who is more confident. I felt sceptical about statements in MBA brochures saying: This will change your life." But, in my case, it has proved true. The course has radically changed me and the way I approach my work.

I would recommend anyone contemplating an MBA to check out how broad and deep the experience of fellow participants is likely to be on a specific programme.

An average age in the 30s usually indicates considerable working histories, which can benefit everyone on a course greatly.

webTitle: Labour in retreat over ethical foreign policy

fields.headline: Labour in retreat over ethical foreign policy
fields.standfirst: Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The government effectively abandoned any pretence of maintaining an ethical foreign policy yesterday when it confirmed it will give the go-ahead for the sale of spare parts for Hawk fighter jets to Zimbabwe.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Mona Eltahawy  in Cairo and  Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
The government effectively abandoned any pretence of maintaining an ethical foreign policy yesterday when it confirmed it will give the go-ahead for the sale of spare parts for Hawk fighter jets to Zimbabwe.

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, at a Downing Street briefing, insisted there was a commercial obligation to stand by contracts in all but "extreme circumstances".

He said that if the contract was revoked, the taxpayer would have to foot the bill for the compensation involved.

The Guardian disclosed yesterday that Tony Blair had sanctioned the supply of spares for BAE Systems Hawk jet fighters being used by Zimbabwe in the Congolese civil war.

Facing a mountain of criticism from inside the Labour party and out, Mr Campbell spelled out what the government meant by an ethical foreign policy.

"Our export criteria do not say, and have never said, you cannot export to countries involved in conflicts. What they do say is you cannot export any equipment that might be used for external aggression," he said.

But Zimbabwe, which has 7,000 troops, is involved in external aggression by playing a major part in keeping alive the conflict in Congo and destabilising the entire region.

President Robert Mugabe also stands accused of widespread human rights abuses inside Zimbabwe - a breach of the ethical foreign policy guidelines set out by Labour after the general election which Mr Campbell pointedly failed to mention.

Labour figures such as Donald Anderson, the chairman of the Commons foreign affairs committee, and Glenys Kinnock, the Euro MP, joined in widespread condemnation of the sale. Other Labour figures, such as Martin O'Neill, the Labour chairman of the Commons trade and industry committee, which has been investigating how Britain funds the arms trade, adopted a more cautious approach, stressing the needs of the British defence industry.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who privately opposed the sale to Zimbabwe, yesterday loyally supported the new government line while on a visit to Egypt.

Echoing Mr Campbell, Mr Cook implied the government's hands had been tied by the previous Tory administration, which had given the go-ahead for the sale of the Hawks in the 1980s.

He said: "We have inherited a commitment from the sale of the Hawks to Zimbabwe which is a commitment to continue to provide spare parts.

"That was suspended for a while during the fighting. We are now in a position in which there is no fighting and there is progress on the peace track."

But Mr Cook's assertion that fighting had stopped is contradicted by several recent reports from the Zimbabwean government of battles raging in eastern Congo.

The Zimbabwean army triumphantly reported last week that it had broken the siege of the eastern town of Ikela, where some 2,000 troops had been trapped.

The Hawks are important to Zimbabwe's war effort. Reports from Harare have thrown up doubts about the continued airworthiness of some of the planes, which explains the desperation for the spare parts.

Questions remain over how Zimbabwe, which is near bankruptcy, will pay for the spares, which are estimated at £5m to £10m.

Sales of British arms are usually underwritten by the government's export credits guarantee department, which said yesterday Zimbabwe had just paid the last instalment on the Hawks.

Zimbabwe defaulted on £1.7m in loans from the department but a spokesman said Harare had since paid back £1m.

webTitle: Britain accused of hypocrisy as war cripples economy

fields.headline: Britain accused of hypocrisy as war cripples economy
fields.standfirst:
Harare: Arms sale piles misery on poor population

Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The editor of Zimbabwe's leading non-governmental newspaper yesterday accused the British government of ignoring the poor human rights record of the Mugabe regime in deciding to sell spare parts to the military.
fields.body:
The editor of Zimbabwe's leading non-governmental newspaper yesterday accused the British government of ignoring the poor human rights record of the Mugabe regime in deciding to sell spare parts to the military.

Trevor Ncube, the editor of the weekly Zimbabwe Independent, said the decision smacked of hypocrisy. "The British government is opposed to Zimbabwe's involvement in the Congo war; it is opposed to the Mugabe government's flagrant spending, which is taking our economy to the brink," he said. "So when it makes this arms sale, that suggests its policy is determined by purely economic interests.

"The Blair government says it is opposed to human rights abuses perpetrated by the Mugabe regime, but it is willing to support the Mugabe government by selling it arms."

Mr Ncube said it was difficult for the Labour government to promote itself as having an "ethical foreign policy" when Britain was one of the world's biggest arms dealers.

No Zimbabwean government or army officials were available for comment yesterday. President Robert Mugabe is in Libya and due to travel to New York for the special United Nations conference to try to negotiate an end to the Congo war. News of the sale of equipment for Zimbabwe's 10 British Hawk fighter jets undercuts Britain's support for the UN talks, which are scheduled to start on Monday.

John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe, said: "People are walking 20km to work because there is no foreign exchange to buy fuel for cars and buses. They are asking why the government can find money for spare parts for the Congo war, when it cannot find funds for adequate supplies of petrol and diesel? They are angry.

"The Congo war is unpopular and now people see Britain as supporting Zimbabwe's involvement in the war," said Mr Makumbe. The spare parts for the Hawk fighter jets will cost about £5-10m, according to arms experts. The cost is relatively small compared to the debts of hundreds of millions of pounds that the Mugabe government has run up in the Congo war.

Fuel companies are refusing to sell on credit to Zimbabwe and the Mugabe government has not paid its bills to South Africa's Eskom, which supplies more than 40% of Zimbabwe's power, threatening its electricity supply.

Zimbabwe has also defaulted on numerous international loans so that South African, British and European banks have withdrawn lines of credit.

Last week Britain's export credits guarantee department (ECGD) revealed that the Zimbabwean government owed it £1.7m from losses incurred by British companies dealing with the country's state-owned corporations, in particular the National Oil Corporation of Zimbabwe.

Zimbabwe's total foreign debt is estimated at US$4bn (£2.5bn). The country's inflation is running at 57% and unemployment at 50%.

"The British government suggests that selling spare parts will help keep Zimbabwe's armed forces happy and will discourage the army from staging a coup," said Mr Makumbe. "No army can enforce political stability when an economy is collapsing and the population is angry."

News of the sale of equipment for Zimbabwe's 10 British Hawk fighter jets undercuts Britain's support for the UN talks, which are scheduled to start on Monday. John Makumbe, a political science lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe, said: "People are walking 20km to work because there is no foreign exchange to buy fuel for cars and buses. They are asking why the government can find money for spare parts for the Congo war, when it cannot find funds for adequate supplies of petrol and diesel? They are angry. "The Congo war is unpopular and now people see Britain as supporting Zimbabwe's involvement in the war," said Mr Makumbe. The spare parts for the Hawk fighter jets will cost about £5-10m, according to arms experts. The cost is relatively small compared to the debts of hundreds of millions of pounds that the Mugabe government has run up in the Congo war. Fuel companies are refusing to sell on credit to Zimbabwe and the Mugabe government has not paid its bills to South Africa's Eskom, which supplies more than 40% of Zimbabwe's power, threatening its electricity supply. Zimbabwe has also defaulted on numerous international loans so that South African, British and European banks have withdrawn lines of credit. Last week Britain's export credits guarantee department (ECGD) revealed that the Zimbabwean government owed it £1.7m from losses incurred by British companies dealing with the country's state-owned corporations, in particular the National Oil Corporation of Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe's total foreign debt is estimated at US$4bn (£2.5bn). The country's inflation is running at 57% and unemployment at 50%. "The British government suggests that selling spare parts will help keep Zimbabwe's armed forces happy and will discourage the army from staging a coup," said Mr Makumbe. "No army can enforce political stability when an economy is collapsing and the population is angry."

fields.headline: Blair attacked from all sides
fields.standfirst:
Decision to allow sale of military parts 'makes farce of ethical foreign policy'

Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The government was deluged with criticism last night over its decision to give the go-ahead for the export of spare parts for British Hawks used by Zimbabwe in the Congolese civil war.
fields.body:
The government was deluged with criticism last night over its decision to give the go-ahead for the export of spare parts for British Hawks used by Zimbabwe in the Congolese civil war.

The Labour chairman of the Commons foreign affairs committee, Donald Anderson, who is normally restrained in his criticism of the government, said he understood the need for British companies to meet contractual obligations, but added that in this case he thought the supply of spare parts should not be resumed.

He described the Congo war as futile and considered export inappropriate on the eve of peace talks at the UN.

In an indication of the extent to which the decision has divided the Labour party, Glenys Kinnock, the Labour Euro MP and wife of the former Labour leader, expressed concern that the sales could contribute to "exacerbating the tragic misery caused by the Congo conflict".

She said it was untenable and incomprehensible that the British government should assist the president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, in waging a war when his country was in such severe economic difficulty.

She also questioned whether the decision might put Britain in breach of the European code on arms exports.

The shadow foreign secretary, John Maples, readily joined in the condemnation, despite the fact that the Hawk fighter jets were sold to Zimbabwe under the Conservatives: "Zimbabwe has an appalling record on human rights, economic mismanagement, government corruption and abuse of aid.

"Tony Blair's decision to sell them parts for Hawk fighter jets shows what a shambles Labour's ethical foreign policy is in."

Menzies Campbell, the foreign affairs spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, who have been distancing themselves from Labour, said: "It is high time that the searchlight of public scrutiny was directed at the secretive Whitehall decisions on arms exports.

"It is simply not acceptable in a modern, democratic system that parliament should be unable to scrutinise decisions which have significant international consequences and are deeply damaging to Britain's reputation abroad."

The Labour backbencher Ann Clwyd, who is a member of the Commons international development committee, called for the creation of a Commons committee of MPs to scrutinise arms exports to contentious areas of the world.

Reflecting the view of many Labour backbenchers, the Cynon Valley MP added: "I feel that we raised expectations that we would have a different policy to the last government when we came into power, and I am extremely disappointed that we are selling arms to In donesia and now keeping the Hawks flying in the war in Congo.

"In the situation that country is in, with a terrible war in which so many people have died and are dying, I think anything that fuels the ability of a country to fight that war should not be supported."

Lord Avebury, the vice-chairman of the parliamentary human rights committee and a Liberal Democrat, said: "I think there should be no weapon sales to Zimbabwe. They cannot afford them. It is risking their economy. Every one knows it is almost bankrupt and defaulting on loans and, in the circumstances, we should not only withhold the Hawk spares but any parts."

Rachel Harford of the pressure group Campaign Against Arms Trade said: "It is lamentable that ultimately the buck stops with a prime minister who feels more obligation to do the bidding of arms companies than to uphold any commitment to human rights.

"He is enabling Zimbabwe to continue its military campaign by providing components for Hawk aircraft.

"We are now witness to several occasions when the prime minister has intervened personally on behalf of his powerful friends in the arms industry.

"This is at the cost of exacerbating division in his own government, creating embarrassment on the world stage for the UK, but most importantly fuelling conflict in war regions and aiding the abuse of human rights in Indonesia, the Congo, and several other countries."

The case for and against

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell

"The supply of Hawk spares is covered by a contract approved by the last government before the war in the Congo started.

"Such contracts can only be revoked in extreme circumstances. The taxpayer would be liable for compensation to be paid and [it would] undermine the credibility of British contractors and British suppliers.

"Our export criteria do not say, and have never said, you cannot export to countries involved in conflicts. What they do say is you cannot export any equipment that might be used for external aggression."

Donald Anderson, Labour chairman of the Commons foreign affairs committee

"My judgment, certainly on the reports we have had thus far, is that there should be delay, for this reason - at the moment, Zimbabwe is involved in a futile foreign war in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

"Over 10,000 soldiers are involved. There are going to be peace talks, brokered by the US, starting on Monday. Now is not the time to supply those spare parts.

"Certainly my judgment is that it would be wrong to resume the supply of spare parts at this time."

fields.headline: M&S chief under threat
fields.standfirst: Investors give Peter Salsbury three months to improve bottom line or face the chop
fields.trailText: Peter Salsbury, the beleaguered chief executive of Marks & Spencer, has been given three months to improve the group's fortunes before big shareholders move to try to oust him from power.
fields.body:
Peter Salsbury, the beleaguered chief executive of Marks & Spencer, has been given three months to improve the group's fortunes before big shareholders move to try to oust him from power.

The warning from major investors in the troubled retailer comes only a week after the disclosure of a poor Christmas sales performance.

The company suffered a 9% like-for-like fall in seasonal sales - the second worst outcome on the high street after the Dorothy Perkins and Wallis chain, Arcadia.

Increasing shareholder unrest will intensify the pressures on Mr Salsbury which have been mounting with speculation that the company may soon face a takeover assault, either from the retail entrepreneur, Phillip Green, or from supermarket chain Tesco.

Dismissing the prospect of a takeover, one major M&S shareholder said: "I've got no patience left." Referring to Mr Salsbury, another investment manager said: "I think he's got until early summer and then he's got to go."

Investors are becoming increasingly worried that Mr Salsbury's lacklustre performance is blighting the group's search for a new chairman. They fear that executives of sufficient calibre to contribute to reviving the prospects of M&S are unwilling to tie their fate to that of Mr Salsbury, who has failed to make any beneficial impression on the company's fortunes after more than a year.

Company insiders said yesterday that a chairman - believed to be Luc Vandevelde - should be appointed "sooner rather than later", although this has been the firm's position for the best part of two months now.

An M&S spokesman said there had been no official complaints from shareholders, while Cazenove, the group's stockbroker, has reported no approaches seeking to oust the chief executive.

Mr Salsbury has had to put his rolling programme of meetings with institutional investors on hold because the group is technically facing the prospect of a bid from Mr Green - and that restricts what it can usefully say to its shareholders.

The deadline for Mr Salsbury is timed to allow the results of the first fashion collection, which he masterminded himself. The spring range will be launched next Tuesday, and is believed to be offering prices at about 5% lower than products available in M&S today.

The collection will also be the first to include designer names such as Betty Jackson, and the company plans to introduce new items such as baby equipment and maternity clothes.

Mr Salsbury is also tipped to announce 90 store refurbishments. After a series of excuses for its failed sales performance, shareholders have decided that the outcome of the new collection will be make or break for Mr Salsbury.

Earlier attempts to reinvigorate the group have fallen flat: the company began advertising on television, decided to accept outside credit cards, started buying more from cheap overseas suppliers and mounted a series of senior management shake-ups. None of these initiatives has so far yielded results.

Speculative interest in the group has increased with the emergence of Franklin Resources and Brandes, the aggressive US fund managers, as big stakeholders in the group. Brandes is now the largest single investor in the company, with more than 6% of the shares, while Franklin recently took its stake to more than 5%.

M&S shares closed 1p higher at 306p.

'Blood on the hands' of retail veteran

"Salsbury's got blood on his hands. I wouldn't feel sorry for him - he's deeply implicated in all this." So said one of Peter Salsbury's retail rivals yesterday, writes Lisa Buckingham .

Mr Salsbury appears a gentle, somewhat nervous and stumbling executive - the least likely to attract personal opprobrium. But he is a lifelong M&S employee, a protege of the now tarnished former boss Sir Richard Greenbury, and a man who clearly signed up to all the major decisions which have contributed to the group's current malaise.

Pulling M&S back from the brink is a huge task for the postman's son who grew up in Walthamstow in north east London. A graduate of the London School of Economics, Mr Salsbury joined M&S as a trainee in 1960 and has worked in every department.

A fan of Eric Clapton and a passionate supporter of Arsenal football club, he took on the slow process of changing the autocratic M&S culture. But the innovations he has sanctioned have failed to deliver either in terms of sales or investor confidence.

The company is now openly talked of as a "basket case" and morale among its share-owning employees - many of whom have seen part of their life savings obliterated in the past couple of years - is low.

fields.headline: www.open.gov
fields.standfirst: The cabinet office is very keen on e-government, but although online services could save money departmental websites still need more work
fields.trailText: Alex Allan, former high commissioner for Australia (now there's a qualification for the top Whitehall IT job) has just started work as "e-envoy". His mission is "to drive forward e-commerce and e-government". The latter means putting the state online, a huge enterprise. Allan's chivvying of the private sector is going to be a lot more effective if government itself becomes a paragon of the new forms of electronic communication with the public.
fields.body:
Alex Allan, former high commissioner for Australia (now there's a qualification for the top Whitehall IT job) has just started work as "e-envoy". His mission is "to drive forward e-commerce and e-government". The latter means putting the state online, a huge enterprise. Allan's chivvying of the private sector is going to be a lot more effective if government itself becomes a paragon of the new forms of electronic communication with the public.

Recent weeks have been breathless... NHS online; £500m for IT learning centres; an audit of the state's websites; guidance on website design; and large rhetoric from Allan's boss, cabinet office minister Ian McCartney. (Pat Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, is also somewhere in the chain of command.) "Through the click of a button we can provide high quality services, health advice and help finding jobs, directly to citizens in a simple and convenient way." And to that end, quantitative targets: 100% of public services to be online by 2008.

But forecasts highlight the downbeat expectations of Whitehall's top brass; e-dealings between citizen and taxman will double within three years, but still represent only a fifth of total contact with the inland revenue. Burning a hole in Allan's desk is last month's sharp report from the national audit office entitled Government on the Web.

All allowances made for the fact its survey of Whitehall web use is 12 months old, it says Whitehall lost the plot between the period of early Tory enthusiasm for "government direct" in 1995-96 and now. Is Allan, a mere civil servant, to evangelise and push through changes that must profoundly alter the economy of official information? The web means more freedom of information. It is ushering in an era of "co-production" in government - by giving the public so much more access and involvement. Lip service is paid to the idea in the latest plan for Whitehall reform, but unless and until civil servants start putting their email addresses (the vast majority still don't have them) on accessible websites, the rhetoric is empty.

At the centre, a cast of hundreds divides responsibility. If the prime minister has other things on his mind, who is the minister with enough seniority to crack the whip on improving websites? The Central IT Unit - once the main Whitehall think tank on the web's wonders - has ceded place to the Performance and Innovation Unit. Ian McCartney's new media team services the Information Age Champions' Group, which is meant to be spearheading the departments' push: government by committee with a vengeance.

Out on left field is the Central Computer and Telecommunications Agency, responsible for the state's central portal, www.open.gov.uk - this ought to be a gorgeously-bedecked anteroom to the Aladdin's cave of official information but is in fact a pallid, poorly arranged thing scarcely changed since its inception in prehistoric times (ie 1995). One of the deficits on the open.gov site is how hard it is to follow policy around. There is no entry, for example, for "children" - a good example of the cross-cutting issue the cabinet office keeps saying must be joined up. The site does, however, support some little gems. There, nestling between the Scottish virtual teachers' centre and Sedgefield council is www.securityservice.gov.uk; MI5's is not a bad site as these things go.

In e-land, a little imagination goes a long way. GCHQ, the government centre for signals intelligence, won favourable publicity recently for putting a light-hearted crack-the-code quiz for job seekers on its web site ( www.gchq.gov.uk ). There is talk of citizens getting "personalised" home pages, based on their dealings with the state. But that would require lines between Whitehall and local government to be clearer than they are and for some constitutional theorist to advise the IT anoraks just what the boundaries of the state now are (BAA, a private company, is on the open government site for no explicable reason).

A besetting problem in our system is how to translate initiatives into delivery by disparate Whitehall departments, let alone all the peripheral bodies, local authorities and so on. There is talk of putting online targets in the "public service agreements" on which the treasury will in theory base spending allocations, but that will only work if the centre has a tight game plan. The web has to let a thousand flowers bloom.

Most of those paying tax under self-assessment can probably afford a computer and modem; most of those receiving income support from the department of social security cannot. DSS has its dedicated IT agency (ITSA) but it is the social exclusion unit in the cabinet office which is looking at paying for more computers in libraries or in kiosks in DSS offices to give poor people better e-opportunities. ITSA is, however, experimenting with letting people use information on its website to forecast their pension.

The national audit office shows how cost-effective the net can be for the state. Some 400,000 phone calls are placed each year to the department of trade and industry inquiry unit: if only 1% of calls were redirected to its website, it would save £6,400.

The DSS ITSA says it intends to put benefit claim forms online "as and when the public demand is there". In that phrase lies Alex Allan's (and Tony Blair's) problem. Is the state merely going to follow the curve in developing e-government, or is it going to innovate ahead of public opinion and behaviour and seek to lead us to the promised land?

fields.headline: Dyke sells Granada shares
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The incoming director-general of the BBC, Greg Dyke, yesterday averted a row which threatened to overshadow his first week in the job by bowing to increasing pressure to sell his shares in Granada. But he insisted it was entirely his own decision.
fields.body:
The incoming director-general of the BBC, Greg Dyke, yesterday averted a row which threatened to overshadow his first week in the job by bowing to increasing pressure to sell his shares in Granada. But he insisted it was entirely his own decision.

Mr Dyke, who takes over formally on January 31, disposed of his £6m holding because he did not want his early days as director-general to be dominated by controversy, he said in a statement.

Sources close to Mr Dyke added that he had been unwilling to comply with demands that he sell in case it seemed he had acted unethically.

The Conservative culture spokesman, Peter Ainsworth, earlier this week accused Mr Dyke of a conflict of interest by holding shares in a rival television company.

By pre-empting a meeting of the BBC board of governors due to be held next week, Mr Dyke has avoided being compelled to sell his holding. Although he had a written agreement with the governors that he would have until April to dispose of his various shareholdings, several were reported to feel that circumstances had changed significantly.

Last night a BBC spokesman confirmed that the governors had been informed of Mr Dyke's action and emphasised that they were "pleased" that he would be able to carry on unencumbered by any further embarrassment.

Calls for Mr Dyke to sell more promptly arose when the outgoing director-general, Sir John Birt, announced he would depart at the end of next week to take up a peerage, leaving his successor to take control two months earlier than planned.

The BBC code of ethics requires senior executives to declare and, where appropriate, relinquish any shareholdings which represent a conflict of interest.

The former BBC chairman, Lord Hussey, said earlier this week that one of his first acts on being appointed to the BBC was to sell all his shares in a commercial radio station. The chairman, Sir Christopher Bland, also sold millions of pounds worth of shares in Granada on joining the corporation.

Mr Dyke, whose personal wealth is estimated at £14m, declared several different shareholdings to the BBC board of governors during the appointment process, including stakes in Manchester United Football Club, Carlton Communications and Pearson which have all since been sold.

He said: "I have not sold these shares because I was asked to do so by the BBC, nor because I have in any way behaved unethically. I have scrupulously followed the terms of the agreement I reached with the BBC when I was appointed last June."

But he insisted it was entirely his own decision. Mr Dyke, who takes over formally on January 31, disposed of his £6m holding because he did not want his early days as director-general to be dominated by controversy, he said in a statement. Sources close to Mr Dyke added that he had been unwilling to comply with demands that he sell in case it seemed he had acted unethically. The Conservative culture spokesman, Peter Ainsworth, earlier this week accused Mr Dyke of a conflict of interest by holding shares in a rival television company. fields.headline: Most wanted
fields.trailText: Colds are very uncool. Yet, however good-looking you are and however stylish you may be, you still suffer like everyone else. Yes, 'tis true: even fashionistas catch them. There is light at the end of the tunnel, though - you can now sniff to your heart's content into leopardprint tissues (65p from Top Shop, enquiries 0800 731 8284) which are as cool as you are. In fact, they are so stylish that if you haven't got a cold, just pretend to sneeze so you can use them anyway.
