fields.headline: Couture the first time
fields.standfirst: From Top Shop to fashion's top drawer:  Namalee Bolle, winner of the Jackie Moore Award for aspiring fashion journalists, reports from the Paris collections
fields.trailText: From Top Shop to fashion's top drawer: Namalee Bolle, winner of the Jackie Moore Award for aspiring fashion journalists, reports from the Paris collections
fields.body:
What does the lady who has enough dosh to buy a mere ready-to-wear number a hundred times over choose to complement her coiffed, diamond-encrusted, perma-tanned persona? That was the vital question on my non-surgically enhanced lips as I made my pauper's entrance (Top Shop, jumble sale, picked nail polish) to the richest runways in fashion.

I lost my couture virginity on the first night, to Versace Atelier. It was a star-studded affair, with Liam and Patsy, All Saints, Baby Spice and Tara in the audience. A front row seat gave a perfect view of the acid fondant hues that coated Amber Valetta et al: figure-hugging knee-length dresses, violent violet leather pencil skirts and supersexy transparent evening gowns with strategically placed lace. All of glamma mamma Donatella's trademarks were there: trash, leather, sparkle. And though I would happily spend thousands (should I acquire a sugar daddy) on such an ensemble, I suspect most women beyond the age of 25 would not.

Givenchy staged a magical performance. It began with an androgynous, pants-clad model lying on a plinth. She was dressed by an aged butler who fumbled a lot before completing his mission, to clothe her, live on stage, in an exquisitely tailored grey suit. Low-slung trousers and sharp jackets were mixed in with romantic full skirts, feathers and intricate beading as Alexander McQueen made his edgy look accessible to all ages. He shredded skirts and sliced away at demi-gloves with a subtle ferocity.

Proving that lunacy remains the most effective headline-grabber in the fashion bible, Galliano went doolally for Dior. He rebelled against tradition with deconstructed anti-couture that resembled the work of a ga-ga genius. As one onlooker put it: "I'm lost for words to describe this." It was an inside out, topsy-turvy, trampy look full of deconstructed seams, with newspaper pages sewn in among jackets made into skirts. Rag and bone accessories, such as wire-rimmed specs, bottle tops, pegs and corks, trailed from the clothing. Eveningwear was just as outlandish: straitjacket-inspired linen dresses and harlot-esque hot red fishtails. Whether a single person will buy anything is another matter, but the fact that Galliano sent out such imaginative clothes makes me proud to be British.

We were late for Pascale Humbert and had to crawl across the catwalk to get to our seats. Everyone stared. Visions of my G-stringed bottom on fashion faux pas pages menaced my mind, until a simple, chic array of suitage in navy and shell pink slinked on to the runway. Clearly inspired by nature, there were also bird-like dresses with feathers dripping from sleeves and pale blue fitted coats adorned with cut-out butterflies.

Chanel couldn't have been more memorable if Karl Lagerfeld had removed his shades, let down his ponytail and replaced his token fan with a bullwhip. The show was held in a pony training centre in the middle of a forest, which provided a stark, neutral backdrop to the frothy angels who delighted the crowd in a sorbet palette of froufrou bell-shaped outfits. Nipped-in waists and wide skirts in apricot and citrus shades paid homage to Coco herself, while Alek Wek wore a roadsweeper of a gown with a feathered hem. Also rather cunning was the Chanel No 5 freebie handed over just as you were about to choke on the manure fumes. Up-and-coming designer and Lagerfeld fan Jeremy Scott was also lurking, sporting a most magnificent mullet.

Now I know why fashion types are so thin. It's easier to fit more people in the seats at shows. Let's just say my row had its share of ample buttocks (not telling whose) and Lacroix was a bit of a squeeze. The clientele went crazy for his Mondrian-inspired daywear and wild for eveningwear that was beautiful, experimental and lavish, combining long-line silhouettes with art-class weaved ribbons, bleached-out bits, crochet and lace.

Philip Treacy is the only hatter that matters. His sculptured, fantastical floral orchid hats were so sensual, they looked like 3D Georgia O'Keefe paintings. Shapes that sound clumsy on paper, such as the enormous sideways circle hat, stiff white seaweed waves or the flat tabletop hat that would make fitting through a door impossible, arched around supermodel heads as if they belonged there.

Yves Saint Laurent stunned with an elegant 80s-esque collection of loose boxy blazers and wide-leg trousers adorned with big gold buttons and massive bangles, coral necklaces and dangly earrings. Fabric was draped around curves; lace camisole tops and halternecks were worn with mannish double-breasted suits in stark black, fiery red and ivory. Model Esther Canadas epitomised the YSL look by glaring scarily while demonstrating a brilliant red pout of pleasantly poppable proportions. If only I'd had a pin on me.

Ask me what haute couture meant a year ago and I'd have said clothes made from oats. But now that I have witnessed the mink-coated madams checking out individual garments worth more than most salaries, I have been shocked into knowing better. Money, money, money. Must be funny, in a rich woman's world.

fields.headline: Most everywhere
fields.trailText: Something strange has happened in the wrist area. Until recently, the guidelines were simple: everyone wore a watch. Not wearing one was the preserve of the self-consciously eccentric or wilfully slack. But recently, perfectly normal people go about town skittishly watch-free.
fields.body:
Something strange has happened in the wrist area. Until recently, the guidelines were simple: everyone wore a watch. Not wearing one was the preserve of the self-consciously eccentric or wilfully slack. But recently, perfectly normal people go about town skittishly watch-free.

Maybe it's because watches just don't go with Jade Jagger beaded bracelets. Maybe it's the scarcity of desirable watches, now that we're bored of Baby Gs and classic Casios. (Unless, of course, you can afford Gucci or Fendi, in which case what are you moaning about?) Whatever the reason, no one ever seems to have the time (apart from on their phone, which is not the same thing at all). Which is annoying, because I don't have a watch.

fields.headline: Geek chic
fields.standfirst:
High street is out. Hi-tech is in. We set five clothes shoppers a test: to fulfil their fashion fantasies ... without leaving home. This is how they fared in the brave new world of the web

Get the most out of the net with Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText: High street is out. Hi-tech is in. We set five clothes shoppers a test: to fulfil their fashion fantasies ... without leaving home. This is how they fared in the brave new world of the web
fields.body:
Jemima Fitzgerald shops from a remote island

It's grim up north. Well, it is when it comes to clothes shopping. There are chain stores in abundance, but not a Pineal Eye, Tokio or Voyage in sight (and don't say Harvey Nichols in Leeds, I don't live near Leeds). So imagine my delight when I heard that trendier-than-thou, London-based Browns has a new website. Hurrah - I can be truly fashionable and live in the Shetlands.

What I want, what I really, really want, is a pair of brown and white slippers-cum-shoes, seen on everyone worth their salt. Logging on is easy: www.brownsfashion.com. Immediately I am faced with not only my dream slippers but Cambodian silk cushions, Miu Miu trainers and oh my God a Fendi baguette bag.

I click the "buy" button for the slippers and fill in my details. In five minutes, I get an email confirming my request, then in an hour a call taking my Switch number and saying I'll have my slippers in three days. And I do. Hurrah! I kiss the postman and try them on. Damn. I am a size four. I got a four, but they don't fit. Apparently they come up small. Don't you think someone should have told me? Don't you think it a vital detail for someone in the Shetlands?

Anyway they are nice and apologetic, and once I have sent the four back, they send me size five. I have to pay for postage to London, then wait a week, but it's worth it when you love a pair of slippers this much. Now, about that baguette bag ...

Jess Cartner-Morley seeks inspiration

Call me a dinosaur throwback, but I like shopping. At 5 o'clock on a Saturday afternoon, there is no sweeter sound than the rustle of tissue paper in a carrier bag. But that does not mean I have any desire to spend unproductive afternoons trawling miserably from shop to shop, feeling too hot in my winter coat, buying something that's, say, a six out of 10 and going home exhausted. No sirree. I wouldn't dream of going shopping without a picture in my mind of exactly what I'm looking for. I don't do browsing, just search, pay and go.

Shopping success is all in the preparation and this, I reasoned, is where the net would come in handy: it is an unbeatable tool for finding oddball reference material. Designers are renowned for coming up with the weirdest "inspirations" for their collections: no catwalk show is complete without a statement from the designer explaining that the clothes represent "Jackie O meets Snow White" or "Grace Kelly in Ibiza". Which can sorely test your knowledge of the details of sartorial history.

Deciding to start with something simple, I set about looking for pictures of three women who were clearly a major inspiration for two of the most influential Paris shows for spring/summer: Charlie's Angels. Both Louis Vuitton and Celine showed visored, lip-glossed, deep-tanned looks that had the theme tune running through the minds of the audience straight away, so swotting up on the look is clearly essential. The hair, of course, everyone knows, but the rest is surprisingly hazy. I think maybe one of them had a red satin blouson jacket - but that might have been my mum. And did they really wear white jeans, or is my memory playing tricks on me after all the white denim at Chloe?

I started with the lazy option, simply typing in www.charliesangels.com. This turns out to be a fan site, Angelic Heaven Online. There are just a few pictures, including one of Jaclyn Smith in jodhpurs, which just shows what a selective memory I have. But a link to the official Sony site (www.spe.sony.com) comes up trumps with no fewer than 49 pictures of the girls. In a few moments, I've got the Charlie's Angels look sorted. I think we can safely bypass the shirt-and-jacket wide-lapel fest, but those tight jeans are perfect. As are the chiffon scarves, which I'd forgotten about but which tie in beautifully with Prada's new bourgeois chic. Now I'm ready for some real shopping.

Peter Lyle looks for obscure trainers

Tired of the superior attitudes of snooty friends in reissued trainers, I had a simple task: find vintage tennis shoes from the early 80s.

First stop was the British version of vast online auctioneer ebay (www.ebay.co.uk). After miserable results, I headed to the American HQ (www.ebay.com) where I knew there would be more lots, more trainer freaks, more clarity around what to key in ("sneakers"). I clicked through to "Kev's WORN shoes". Not only were the pair of Adidas in question too modern and for running, they were also "far less clean than they look in the picture". I felt unable to top the existing best bid of $9.95.

The next pair that caught my eye, a nice pair of old Nikes, came with the affectionate comment: "They may smell of cats." I moved on. Vintage USA ( www.vintageusa.com) specialise in classic trainers, so navigating the site is easier. Plus the product looks cleaner (and dearer). Still no Adidas Stan Smiths, though. I follow a link to Shoe Trends ( www.shoetrends.com), but find the site entirely dedicated to the sale and study of Nike culture, so I go back to ebay. Each lot's deadline countdown clock adds an air of risk to browsing and the thrill of watching, waiting and wondering whether to bid or wait for a better lot to turn up has become addictive. Those Stan Smiths haven't turned up, but I'm sure, if I'm here for five more minutes, they will ...

Ruby Singh buys an outsize bra

The mission: to buy a bra for the larger lady, ill-served by the choice on offer in British department stores. And to buy it in half an hour. First stop: the altavista search engine. Type in "very large bras". Wait three minutes, then get bored. Exit to new window. Decide to "make up" bra website addresses in the hope that they're accurate. www.charnos.co.uk isn't up and running yet; www.triumph.co.uk throws up a motorbike website and www.janetreger.co.uk suggests you contact the store by telephone - hardly the point of a website.

Try altavista again, this time opting for "clothing and accessories". This offers the Victoria's Secret website (www.victoriassecret.com). Excellent, I think: a chance to find a broader range of bras not available in Britain. Opt to search "by bra size" and am told my search "found 17 bras in 40DD". Click on option to view said bras. Very nice they look, too, devoid of the thick straps and clumsy styling so often found on the larger boulder holder and down from $25 to a bargain $12.50 (you'd never find a bra this cheap in Britain).

When I try to drag the two nicest ones into the shopping basket icon, a panel flashes up: "There is a problem with the security certificate from that site. The identity certificate has expired. The information you send will be readable to others while in transit and may not go to the intended party". I quit the site.

Richard Benson buys a present for his dad

My dad is a big man, 6ft 2in tall with a 56-inch chest, and he has good taste, so it's hard to find clothes he likes in the shops. I had an idea the net was good for such unusual items.

My mum said he had seen some winceyette pyjamas he liked in High and Mighty in Leeds. "But you'd better say 'brushed cotton'," she said. "I don't think they'll call it winceyette." She was right, in a way: the website (www.highandmighty.co.uk) didn't specify pyjama fabric and given that the pictures of "big and tall men" in "nightwear" were too blurry to show the material, I couldn't risk it.

I clicked on knitwear instead. Here they specified materials and I ordered an XXXL charcoal V-neck sweater. The order invited you to specify a delivery address; it seemed a good use of the internet to send the package somewhere non-urban (my mum and dad live in a village 40 minutes from Leeds). Sadly, the next day, I got an email informing me that, for security reasons, they could send goods only to the credit card billing address. In which case why did they let me ... well, never mind.

Two weeks on, still no sweater, but a receipt turns up, thanking me for my order. I can't help thinking if this had been how we'd had to buy things for the last 200 years, and now a "visionary" retailer had invented the "shop", we'd be agog. Imagine! You look at the stuff before you buy! And take it home with you! Well, it's a thought.

Very nice they look, too, devoid of the thick straps and clumsy styling so often found on the larger boulder holder and down from $25 to a bargain $12.50 (you'd never find a bra this cheap in Britain). When I try to drag the two nicest ones into the shopping basket icon, a panel flashes up: "There is a problem with the security certificate from that site. The identity certificate has expired. The information you send will be readable to others while in transit and may not go to the intended party". I quit the site. Richard Benson buys a present for his dad My dad is a big man, 6ft 2in tall with a 56-inch chest, and he has good taste, so it's hard to find clothes he likes in the shops. I had an idea the net was good for such unusual items. My mum said he had seen some winceyette pyjamas he liked in High and Mighty in Leeds. "But you'd better say 'brushed cotton'," she said. "I don't think they'll call it winceyette." She was right, in a way: the website (www.highandmighty.co.uk) didn't specify pyjama fabric and given that the pictures of "big and tall men" in "nightwear" were too blurry to show the material, I couldn't risk it. I clicked on knitwear instead. Here they specified materials and I ordered an XXXL charcoal V-neck sweater. The order invited you to specify a delivery address; it seemed a good use of the internet to send the package somewhere non-urban (my mum and dad live in a village 40 minutes from Leeds). Sadly, the next day, I got an email informing me that, for security reasons, they could send goods only to the credit card billing address. In which case why did they let me ... well, never mind. Two weeks on, still no sweater, but a receipt turns up, thanking me for my order. I can't help thinking if this had been how we'd had to buy things for the last 200 years, and now a "visionary" retailer had invented the "shop", we'd be agog. Imagine! You look at the stuff before you buy! And take it home with you! Well, it's a thought.

fields.headline: Pepe Advanced Jeans
fields.trailText: Last year's prediction that Jeremy Clarkson was set single-handedly to kill off jeans turned out to be wide of the mark: denim has never been in better shape. Cult styles such as Earl Jean and Original Calvins brought designer jeans in from the cold, while the lust for boxfresh indigo has kept the cash rolling in - one hot wash and it's all over.
fields.body:
Last year's prediction that Jeremy Clarkson was set single-handedly to kill off jeans turned out to be wide of the mark: denim has never been in better shape. Cult styles such as Earl Jean and Original Calvins brought designer jeans in from the cold, while the lust for boxfresh indigo has kept the cash rolling in - one hot wash and it's all over.

Now denim has taken its first leap forward of the millennium, with Pepe Advanced Jeans, the first range to update the five-pocket template. The tiny fifth pocket, originally intended for a fob watch, has been replaced by a larger, detachable mobile phone pocket. Articulated knee-tucks help stop baggy knees, while traditional 14oz denim has been replaced by an ultra-dark 12oz version; copper rivets and the leather logo patch have turned into sleek, black rubber-treated detailing, gold stitching into a more subtle dark thread.

In straight cut and loose fit styles for men and women, Pepe Advanced Jeans will be available from spring, priced £50, tel 0171 836 8666.

fields.headline: Winning streak
fields.standfirst: Of naked waitresses and pampered pets
fields.trailText: Top stories
fields.body:
Top stories

Bowled over
Probably the most exciting event in the history of indoor bowls - possibly the only exciting event in the history of indoor bowls - occurred this week at Potters holiday and leisure centre in Hopton-on-Sea, Suffolk, when a match at the world bowls championships was interrupted by a streaker. After a sedate morning watching wooden balls rolling slowly back and forth along a length of green carpet, spectators were treated to something altogether more stimulating when 22 year old Tracy Seargeant stripped off and sprinted across the playing enclosure.

"Bowls has a reputation as a boring game," explained Miss Seargeant, a waitress at the leisure centre, "So I thought I'd liven it up a bit. I was due to leave my job anyway so I had nothing to lose."

Her display was greeted with cheers from the audience, several of whom later said it was the best match they'd ever seen. The players, however, were less enthusiastic.

Said Scotsman David Gourlay: "I ended up losing a double at the next end."

Doner goner
A piece of living history died this week in the form of centenarian Harry Jones, of Worcester. Mr. Jones, 103, was the final survivor of the last ever cavalry charge made by the British army. As a trooper in the Worcestershire Yeomanry Regiment in 1917, he took part in a mounted attack on a Turkish artillery position at Huj, Palestine.

"It was great fun," he later recalled. "We went at them with swords drawn, galloping at full pace. I was too excited to be scared."

After an eventful life, which included a spell with the Royal Flying Corps, he died peacefully in his sleep at a retirement home in Hungerford.

"He was never one to bear a grudge," commented one tearful care assistant. "He enjoyed a kebab just like the rest of us."

Scousers scuppered
These are not good days for Beatles fans. George Harrison is still recovering from a pre-Christmas stabbing attack. Paul McCartney has just brought out another album. And now, to top it all, the government has banned a series of motorway signs announcing: "Liverpool: The Birthplace of the Beatles." The signs, comprising white lettering on a brown background, were due to be erected on motorways leading into the city, but were rejected by the department of the environment on the grounds that they would distract drivers.

"It's ridiculous," fumed councillor Frank Doran of Liverpool's tourism committee. "If Stratford can be proclaimed Shakespeare Country, what's wrong with Liverpool highlighting the Fab Four."

Alternative signs will now be installed carrying the somewhat less inspiring logo 'Liverpool: Historic Waterfront'.

"We said to them if we come together we can work it out," sighed one council insider. "But they just wouldn't let it be."

Keeping up with the gnomes
It's been a traumatic week for garden gnomes. In Bolton retired policeman Bill Gilbertson woke up to find his entire collection of over 40 gnomes had been stolen, including a 3ft high fisherman and all the Seven Dwarfs.

"To a lot of people they're probably just garden ornaments," he said, "But to me they're part of the family."

In Keighley, meanwhile, thieves are the least of the little people's problems. Here they are facing an altogether more formidible adversary - giant fibre-glass dinosaurs. The dinosaurs are the creation of sculptor Bill Jordan, 56, who thinks they make a far more fitting garden ornament than fat little men on toadstools.

"There's nothing better than having a great big dinosaur's head popping out of the shrubbery," he enthused. "An Antasauraus really can do wonders for the hydrangeas."

Demand for his creations has been steadily growing, and he is now designing a flagstone dinosaur footprint for incorporation into garden paths.

"What would you rather have on your garden lawn?" he asked. "A concrete midget with a fishing rod, or a fifteen-foot high glow-in-the-dark Tyrannosaurus Rex?"

Weekly bestiary

Now fetch Rover his slippers
Chihuahuas on zimmer frames, poodles with bed pans, macrami for dachshunds - it could all become a reality with the opening this March of Britain's first ever retirement home for pets. Based at a farm in Great Shefford, Berkshire, the home will be run by the National Animal Welfare Trust and offer accommodation to up to 60 dogs and 40 cats. Lucky residents, as well as having their own room/kennel, will experience a level of comfort that puts most human retirement homes to shame, including breakfast-in-basket, and a special "oldies unit" with a TV, armchair and carpets so the ageing animals can while away their twilight years in a genuine home environment. Although designed exclusively for cats and dogs, it is hoped at a later date to welcome other Old Aged Pets to the farm, including, no doubt, geriatric gerbils, senile sheep and pensionable pot-bellied pigs.

"We want their final days to be happy ones," said a Trust representative. "They'll have the best creature comforts life can offer."

Breast left well alone
Customs officers at Glasgow Airport made a dramatic bust this week, intercepting a woman with a three-foot long reticulated python concealed inside her bra. The woman, a Dutch national, was boarding a KLM flight to Amsterdam when officials became suspicious at an unnatural rippling motion in the chest area of her blouse. Closer investigation revealed a four-month old python snuggled inside her brassiere.

"It gave us all a bit of a turn," admitted one customs officer. "It's just not the sort of thing you expect to find in Scotland in January."

Snake experts declared the animal harmless and it's owner was duly let off with an official warning, although the python itself was confiscated and has since begun a new, and doubtless less interesting life at Glasgow Zoo.

"You get some strange things coming through here," admitted one airport insider. "A couple of years ago we stopped a man with a suitcase full of baboon testicles."

Crows' feat
The term "Birdie" has assumed unexpected significance for a golf club in North Wales, where players are being terrorised by a squadron of delinquent crows. The feathered fiends have, apparently, taken to hovering above the fairway of Anglesey Golf Club waiting for a shot to be played. As soon as the ball has landed they then swoop down and steal it. To date several hundred pounds worth of golf balls have been lost in this manner, although one club member has come up with a novel solution to the problem.

"I've started painting my balls with pepper solution," he explained. "That keeps the birds away."

Pensioner of the week

WI wiggle it
The Women's Institute continues to confound those who regard it as an organisation dedicated solely to flower-arranging and baking sponge cakes. Last year the Rylstone and District branch caused a furore when members allowed themselves to be photographed naked for a saucy calendar. Now members of the Flackwell Heath Women's Institute, in Buckinghamshire, have taken to belly dancing. With their oldest member well into her eighties, they are being initiated into the arts of eastern eroticism by a professional teacher.

"People think that all we do is make jam," said president Elizabeth Dinnage, 61. "But there's more to us than that. Last year the vicar's wife gave a brilliant talk on the history of underwear."

The gyrating grannies are practising once a week, and hope in the future to be able to give public displays of their new-found skills.

"I don't have a diamond to stick in my belly button," admitted pensioner Joy Medland, 65. "But I'm sure I can find an old earring."

Letter of the week

Continental rift
When are the people in this country going to become aware that the French do not have our tastes for anything? My father fought in France in the first world war and he never had a good thing to say about them. He mainly referred to them as a treacherous bunch of so-and-sos who would throw anything in the pot as long as it didn't cost too much. He was a very honest and intelligent man who would never comment on anything unless he knew it to be true.

It seems that things haven't changed much since 1916. The best thing they could do would be to fill in the Channel tunnel with concrete.
VJ Fox,
Redfield, Bristol

webTitle: The Kohl scandal: what has happened?

fields.headline: The Kohl scandal: what has happened?
fields.standfirst: Tony Patterson in Berlin examines the allegations surrounding the former German chancellor
fields.trailText:
He wanted to be remembered as the unification chancellor and as the
nation's most significant leader since Bismarck. Instead Helmut Kohl has
plunged Germany's main conservative Christian Democratic Party (CDU) into
its worst political crisis since it was founded after the second world war.
fields.body:
He wanted to be remembered as the unification chancellor and as the nation's most significant leader since Bismarck. Instead Helmut Kohl has plunged Germany's main conservative Christian Democratic Party (CDU) into its worst political crisis since it was founded after the second world war.

Kohl, 69, was Germany's conservative chancellor for 16 unbroken years before being defeated by Gerhard Schröder's social democrats in Germany's 1998 general election.

The part he played in reunifying the two Germanys after the 1989 collapse of communism turned him into a universally respected figure and earned him the nicknames "unification chancellor" and "elder statesman of Europe".

But now Kohl is an ex-chancellor in disgrace after being forced to resign from his post as "honorary chairman" of the CDU. Leading party figures have also demanded that he quit politics altogether by resigning as an MP.

The former chancellor has admitted to running a series of illicit "secret" party bank accounts into which unnamed donors pumped millions in cash during his tenure. The secret accounts were deliberately set up to enable the party to avoid paying tax on all donations above DM20,000 (£6,600) as required under German law.

Kohl has admitted accepting up to two million marks-worth of secret payments during the latter half of the 1990s. But the beleaguered CDU leadership suspects that Kohl's refusal to name the donors may mean that he presided over a massive web of corruption involving secret bank accounts and illicit backhanders that permeated all levels of Germany's main conservative party.

Those fears have already been partially borne out by the admission by Kohl's former interior minister, Manfred Kanther, that the CDU in Hesse state ran a secret Swiss bank account to harbour more than DM17 million of illicit undisclosed party donations. Kanther resigned from politics in mid-January.

In addition Kohl's successor as party leader, his former close-adviser Wolfgang Schaüble has admitted accepting an illicit DM 100,000 payment from a German weapons dealer which was not declared in the party's official audit. Question marks also hang over payments made to other senior CDU figures.

Kohl is already subject to a criminal investigation by state prosecutors in Bonn. The homes of two of his close associates have been searched by justice officials. The ex-chancellor will also be called to give evidence before a parliamentary committee of inquiry.

Already faced with the prospect of having to pay back millions in unpaid tax, CDU officials fear that the slush fund scandal may be only the tip of an iceberg of much deeper government corruption. More serious allegations suggest that illicit payments may also have influenced key German government political and economic policy decisions during Kohl's tenure.

The parliamentary inquiry will also investigate whether a million-mark cash payment made to a former CDU party treasurer in a Swiss car park in 1991 influenced the Kohl government's decision to sell German armoured cars to Saudi Arabia during the 1991 Gulf war.

It will also examine allegations that the Kohl government took millions in bribes from the French oil giant Elf Aquitaine during the early 1990s, in payment for the company's takeover of the east German Leuna oil refinery and a chain of petrol stations in the former communist east.

The German chancellery has disclosed that all documents relating to the Leuna deal have "gone missing."

fields.headline: ETA: a chronology
fields.standfirst: Main events in the history of Basque  separatist group ETA in its 31-year campaign for independence from Spain which has cost more than  800 lives
fields.trailText: 1959: Euskadi Ta Askatasuna (ETA), or Basque Homeland and Freedom, founded by opponents of conservative leadership of Basque Nationalist Party exiled during dictatorship of Francisco Franco. ETA vows to fight for Basque self-determination.
fields.body:
1959: Euskadi Ta Askatasuna (ETA), or Basque Homeland and Freedom, founded by opponents of conservative leadership of Basque Nationalist Party exiled during dictatorship of Francisco Franco. ETA vows to fight for Basque self-determination.

1968: ETA carries out first planned killing: victim is Meliton Manzanas, chief of secret police in Basque city of San Sebastian.

1973: Prime Minister Luis Carrero Blanco, Franco's designated successor, killed by car bomb in Madrid.

1978: ETA political wing Herri Batasuna founded.

1980: ETA's bloodiest year - 118 killed in numerous incidents.

1983: Members of Spanish security forces set up Anti-Terrorist Liberation Groups (GAL) to fight covert war against ETA. GAL kills 28 people from 1983-1987, a third of them by mistake.

1987, June: ETA's bloodiest attack. 21 shoppers die after bomb hits Barcelona supermarket. ETA apologises for "mistake".

1989, January: ETA declares unilateral 15-day truce, extended twice amid secret talks in Algeria with Spanish government.

1991, May: Nine killed, 45 injured by bomb at Barcelona barracks.

1995, April: Popular Party opposition leader Jose Maria Aznar target of ETA car bomb. Saved by vehicle's armour plating.

August: Police foil ETA plot to kill King Juan Carlos in Majorca.

1996, June: ETA declares one-week truce in bid to start talks with new government led by Aznar. Truce ends without breakthrough.

1997, July: Basque town councillor Miguel Angel Blanco kidnapped then killed two days later after ETA's demands for convicted members to be transferred to the Basque country jails are not met. Six million people demonstrate against ETA.

1998, June: ETA kills town councillor Manuel Zamareno in Basque Country, last death before new ceasefire.

September: ETA announces truce.

November: ETA signals it considering definitive ceasefire. Government announces talks with ETA's political wing.

1999, June: Government says it held first direct talks with ETA since 1989.

August: ETA says talks with government suspended but reaffirms ceasefire. Aznar accuses ETA of being "afraid of peace".

September: First anniversary of ceasefire; France seizes three ETA suspects and haul of dynamite.

October: ETA sets out new terms for talks, including key demand of a referendum on self-rule in the Basque region; government dismisses the move as "propaganda".

November 28: ETA announces it will end its ceasefire from December 3.

December 20: Police stop van carrying nearly one tonne of explosives heading for Madrid; second similar load found in another van three days later.

3 January: Police in Bilbao say they foil an attempted car bomb attack on civil guard convoy.

21 January: Car bombs explode in Madrid, killing army official, less than two months before general election.

October: ETA sets out new terms for talks, including key demand of a referendum on self-rule in the Basque region; government dismisses the move as "propaganda". November 28: ETA announces it will end its ceasefire from December 3. December 20: Police stop van carrying nearly one tonne of explosives heading for Madrid; second similar load found in another van three days later. 3 January: Police in Bilbao say they foil an attempted car bomb attack on civil guard convoy. 21 January: Car bombs explode in Madrid, killing army official, less than two months before general election.

fields.headline: Dismay at Lords plan
fields.standfirst:
Lukewarm response to Wakeham's leisurely timetable for cautious reform
Lord Wakeham will be online on the Guardian network at 4pm today. Post your comments and questions at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/lords
fields.trailText: Lord Wakeham's royal commission on reform of the House of Lords last night outraged constitutional radicals by producing a cautious blueprint that is likely to ensure that just 87 of the 550 members of the new second chamber are elected by the voters - and not before 2004.
fields.body:
Lord Wakeham's royal commission on reform of the House of Lords last night outraged constitutional radicals by producing a cautious blueprint that is likely to ensure that just 87 of the 550 members of the new second chamber are elected by the voters - and not before 2004.

Tony Blair signalled the government's acceptance in principle of Lord Wakeham's call for an elected element in the reformed Lords, but on a leisurely timetable that will see the half-reformed chamber survive the rest of this parliament.

Yesterday's publication of the cautiously crafted report promptly angered radical constitutional reformers including Charter 88 and the Liberal Democrats - a "dismal" establishment stitch-up, they called it - and failed to inspire its potential allies to more than lukewarm enthusiasm. The Wakeham panel was asked 14 months ago to devise an acceptable compromise for stage-two reform of the Lords, to follow November's expulsion of all but 92 of the 750 hereditary peers.

As expected, it failed to agree on exactly how to pick the elected minority and proposed only a modest strengthening of the second chamber's powers to block controversial laws and hold governments to account.

To the dismay of critics, who bemoaned "a historic missed opportunity", it also rejected a totally elected chamber that might rival the Commons. Instead it published three options for further debate between the interested parties, including the Lords and the Commons in a joint committee, to lead to likely legislation after next year's general election.

Yesterday Lord Wakeham's majority-backed model B, the proposal to elect 87 members on regional lists like MEPs (one-third would be elected every five years, serving a single 15-year term). Model A is for 65 elected members; model C, for 195, is hardly a runner.

The members would be elected from Britain's 12 regions - probably at the same time as the next European elections, due in June 2004.

But radicals fear the Blairites might just pitch for the minimalist model A: 65 regional members elected indirectly from party lists on the base of votes cast for their party at the general election. That would outrage the Tories, who would lose their last 92 hereditary peers if the plan were implemented. Life peers may stay on if they want to, an insurance policy to discourage any attempt to wreck the bill.

Most of the 550 members - "not just another bunch of professional politicians" said Lord Wakeham - would be picked by an independent appointments commission, the report suggested.

The 12-strong royal commis sion even ducked the question of a new name for the House of Lords once the last 92 hereditary peers' depart and membership is no longer tied to the peerage. But Lord Wakeham defended the package as a practical answer to a "constitutional puzzle" than has defied reform for 100 years.

That cut little ice with critics. "This is probably the least persuasive royal commission report to have been issued in my political lifetime," said the Lib Dems' constitutional spokesman, Robert Maclennan. "It is neither informed by democratic principle nor a practical concern to strengthen parliament's capability to oversee the work of central government."

Lord Strathclyde, the Tory leader in the Lords, was also critical, but agreed that he would have to work to implement it. Labour leftwingers were dismayed, but not surprised.

Well aware of a century of stalemate, Lord Wakeham told his critics to grab what they could. "If interested parties choose to hold out for what they would ideally like, the opportunity may pass for another generation, maybe another century," he said.

But the signal that mattered to the former Tory cabinet minister and his colleagues was the one from Downing Street, where all speculation that his recommendations would join the electoral reform agenda in the long grass were emphatically denied.

"There is no question of shelving this report. The prime minister regards it as a sensible way forward," his spokesman said.

But the leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, said the government would need time to consider the recommendations.

Mr Blair is wary of what Lord Wakeham promises would be an "authoritative and confident" second chamber, but is anxious not to fulfil Tory jibes that he has replaced the ancient hereditary house with a version based on patronage, filled with "Tony's cronies".

The main points

Second chamber of about 550 members

Majority to be chosen by an independent commission

The rest - 65, 87, or 195 - to be elected from the 12 regions of the UK

Composition of the second chamber to be regularly adjusted to reflect political voting patterns

New targets to reflect the UK's gender, ethnic and faith mix

Link between the honours list and membership of the second chamber no longer to exist

Reformed chamber should be 'at least as powerful as the present House of Lords'

fields.headline: Chronicle of a death foretold
fields.standfirst: Today's bomb attacks in Madrid look like a                                                                   return to the bad old days of ETA violence                                                                   in the early 90s, says Adela Gooch in                                                                   Madrid
fields.trailText: The death of Spanish army Colonel Pedro Antonio Blanco Garcia in a massive car bomb explosion on his way to work this morning, was, according to one government official, the chronicle of a death foretold.
fields.body:
The death of Spanish army Colonel Pedro Antonio Blanco Garcia in a massive car bomb explosion on his way to work this morning, was, according to one government official, the chronicle of a death foretold.

When the Basque separatist group ETA declared that it was ending a 14-month ceasefire last November, security chiefs warned that it was just a question of time before the killing began. "ETA always does what it says it is going to do," said Spain's interior minister Jaime Mayor Oreja.

For the past two months, Spaniards had been hoping against hope that a breakthrough in the impasse blocking negotiations between the government and ETA might still be possible. Police foiled two planned attacks: one just before Christmas, one in the New Year. But today, ETA looks to have killed again for the first time since June 1998, when a local councillor died in a car bomb in the Basque country itself. No group has claimed responbility for the attack but police are in no doubt that ETA is to blame.

The attack in Madrid was a return to the bad old days of the early 90s when ETA frequently detonated car bombs in the capital during the early rush hour. After 1996, when Spain's present conservative government was elected, the group focused its attacks on local councillors representing the conservative Popular Party in the Basque country.

The bombing comes in the run-up to an election on March 12 which has only just been called. Announcing the date last Monday, the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, said he would not be swayed from the hardline stand he has adopted towards ETA ever since coming to power.

When the truce was announced, Mr Aznar authorised informal contact with the guerrillas which led to only one meeting between government representatives and members of the group. Mr Aznar promised to start moving Basque prisoners, scattered in jails around Spain, closer to home and said he would discuss a way of reintegrating the guerrillas in society, but he ruled out, categorically, any form of political concession.

Basques, he argued, enjoyed a strong measure of self-government granted under Spain's 1978 constitution which also guaranteed the unity of the Spanish state. Separatists and nationalists were free to pursue their aim of an independent Basque state to include the French Basque provinces in existing political institutions in the Basque country.

But that was not enough for the guerrillas who had been persuaded by the non-violent Basque Nationalist Party (PNV), the largest in the region, to declare the truce. They wanted formal talks and recognition of the "Basque right to self-determination", a deliberately loose term always taken to mean authorising a referendum on independence and which could lead to changes in the constitution.

To those who accused him of narrow-minded immobility after November's announcement that the truce was over, Mr Aznar replied that he had no room to manoeuvre on the political front short of granting Basques independence, which would be anathema to just over half of the Basque population who wants to remain Spanish.

Most Spaniards sympathise with the prime minister's plight, but 30 years after ETA began killing and in the aftermath of peace negotiations in Northern Ireland, they are tired of the violence. "Couldn't the politicians handle the truce more intelligently?" asked one caller to a radio show on the day ETA said it was breaking the ceasefire.

Two years ago, millions took to the streets in protests at some of ETA's bloodiest attacks. "Enough!" they chanted, "Enough!" This weekend, many seemed set to do so once more.

fields.headline: King William's college quiz
fields.standfirst:
Since 1905, the notorious General Knowledge Paper has blighted the festive break for students of King William's college in the Isle of Man. You are invited to complete this year's test in a spirit of sympathy. You'll have to wait until January 21 for the answers.

webTitle: Jury reforms will go through, vows Blair

fields.headline: Jury reforms will go through, vows Blair
fields.trailText: Tony Blair insisted today that the government would press ahead with its plans to restrict jury trials, confounding the "forces of conservatism" which defeated the bill in the House of Lords last night.
fields.body:
Tony Blair insisted today that the government would press ahead with its plans to restrict jury trials, confounding the "forces of conservatism" which defeated the bill in the House of Lords last night.

"We will now reintroduce the bill in the House of Commons in the near future and get it through," Mr Blair said in a speech to Forest Gate school in East London.

The prime minister argued that the measure to abolish the right of more than 18,000 defendants a year to elect for jury trial was vital to prevent the abuse of electing trial in crown court and would also free up £100 million for front-line policing.

Mr Blair described the coalition of lords who voted down the measures as an alliance of Conservatives who first proposed the idea, Liberal Democrats and leaders of the lawyers' trade union. He insisted his government would not be blown off its reforming course by such "forces of conservatism".

"Struggle is part of politics. Reform is hard, it causes dissent, it upsets vested interests - some very well meaning - it can seem unfair, even when its very purpose is greater fairness in the long term.

"It means taking on forces of conservatism and reaction, left or right, even when they have superficial popular appeal. The more radical of our reforms, the more they are resisted, but in the long run the better the rewards."

But Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes called the prime minister's argument "fundamentally flawed".

"Almost all the people he cited as supporters of restricting jury trials were criminal justice professionals - the judges, the magistrates and the police," Mr Hughes said. "They are hardly a representative cross-section of the British public... the argument that we must trust the government because they know best simply will not wash.

"If they go on with this bill the government will have the mother and father of all political battles in the year ahead."

webTitle: 'We were almost bounced out of bed'

fields.headline: 'We were almost bounced out of bed'
fields.standfirst: Emma Daly in Madrid talks to shocked residents of the district targeted in today's car bombings
fields.trailText:
Madrid awoke today to the roar of a huge explosion that killed an army officer
and marked, it seems, the definitive end of the 19-month ceasefire called
by the Basque separatist group ETA.
fields.body:
Madrid awoke today to the roar of a huge explosion that killed an army officer and marked, it seems, the definitive end of the 19-month ceasefire called by the Basque separatist group ETA.

Lt-Col Pedro Antonio Blanco Garcia, a 47-year-old father of two, was killed instantly and his body horribly mutilated by the force of the explosion, which destroyed several cars and blew the windows out of a dozen flats. Two teenage girls were slightly wounded in their home.

A second blast shook the area just minutes later, destroying a car parked two blocks away but causing no further casualties. Police believe the vehicle had been used by the ETA bombers.

Politicians of all shades united to condemn the attack, and many called on Herri Batasuna, ETA's political wing, to do the same. The authorities urged citizens to express their revulsion by joining a protest in the centre of Madrid this evening, and a march planned for Sunday.

The victim - apparently the intended target of the bomb, which was detonated by remote control, was walking along a street close to his house, in a red-brick neighbourhood full of military housing. Ninety minutes after the attack, a funeral parlour van pulled up among the wreckage of a red Renault Clio to collect his remains.

Juan Cotino, head of the national police, said that "of course" the bomb was the work of ETA. "Very probably the terrorists were in a car just at this corner, watching the colonel as walked past the car bomb," he said, gesturing at the shattered glass and twisted metal wreckage marking the fatal spot. "From this [second] car they detonated the car bomb and then fled. Then they set a second small explosion to set fire to their car and destroy it."

On a sunny but bitterly cold morning, forensic police wearing latex gloves picked through the ruins of the car bomb, bagging pieces of evidence, before calling a tow-truck to remove the charred and twisted metal, which was barely recognisable. Only the red bonnet, lying a few yards away, betrayed the make and colour of the vehicle.

Shocked neighbours leant out of windows and stood on balconies - though they have become all too used to such scenes. Before its year-long ceasefire, ETA had carried out eight attacks in this area, close to the river Manzanares. A senior officer who lost a leg in a previous attack lives in this very building, its brick front scarred by shrapnel.

Senior politicians, including the defence minister, Eduardo Serra, and the mayor of Madrid, Jose Maria Alvarez del Manzano, visited the site and addressed the dozens of television cameras and reporters held back by police tape. Mr Serra paid a visit of condolence to the dead officer's widow and her two children - a teenage girl and a younger boy. "She is being strong," Mr Serra said. "She is as well as can be expected after such a killing."

Madrid police have set up checkpoints around the city and are searching for the bombers. Some 500m away from the site of the first explosion, police and fireman picked through the charred remains of the getaway car, a white Renault Clio with Oviedo licence plates, which was blown up at 8.45, half-an-hour after the first bomb. Both the cars used and destroyed by the bombers had been stolen in Madrid in the past three months.

Emetrio Valiente, 32, who lives in the building over-looking the car-bomb site, was woken by the explosion. "There was no problem getting up this morning," he said. His sister had only just returned home from walking the dog. "She escaped by the skin of her teeth. When I looked out of the window there were at least six cars burning, but I didn't see anything else."

"My husband had left for work just five minutes earlier," said Rosa Maria Alonso, another neighbour married to a soldier. "I came out of the house, came to the corner and saw the cars burning. I didn't stay long because the police came, but there were people around, women taking their children to school and people going to work. I'm still shaken, because it was really very frightening. When I heard the explosion I said, that's a bomb. A few years ago, there was another bomb at number 45."

Rocio Casanova, a 22-year-old journalism student, was about to get up when the bomb went off. "We didn't see it but we felt it, we were almost bounced out of bed. There is a school nearby and everyone was walking their children to school - and there's a food market, so there is always a lot of traffic along here even though this street is very small," she said.

"Immediately the police and ambulances arrived, and that is what worried us, because we know a lot of people around here, my father has an architectural studio and this area is like a village."

Mr Cotino refused to say whether police had any details of the attackers, but planned to issue photos of suspects to the media, since police believe the bomb was placed by members of ETA's Madrid commando.

Security in Spain has been tightened since ETA called off its truce on 3 December, but some neighbours complained that police had not done enough to protect what is a favoured ETA target, because of the concentration of military housing.

"It is deplorable that anyone thinks they can achieve any of their objectives using violence," Mr Alvarez del Manzano said at the scene. "We must make sure that the terrorists do not disrupt our lives."

He added: "We are on the alert but people should stay calm - Madrid is not full of car bombs."

Josep Pique, the government spokesman, said Blanco was the first person killed in such an attack for more than a year. "Our only response to ETA will be to try to arrest its activists and prevent further attacks," he said.

Lt-Col Blanco's remains are now lying in a military chapel and he will be buried on Saturday in Madrid.

fields.headline: Car bombs rock Madrid
fields.body:
Two car bombings shook the centre of Madrid today, killing a Spanish army officer in an apparent resumption of terror attacks by the Basque separatist group ETA after it ended its ceasefire in early December.

"There have been two explosions and there is one victim killed and a girl slightly injured," a police spokesman said. There was no warning for the attack. The dead officer was identified as Lieutenant Colonel Pedro Antonio Blanco Garcia, 48.

He was blown to pieces as he walked past one of the cars - apparently detonated by remote control - on his way to work. About half-hour later another car exploded between about 400 yards away. It would be the worst ETA bombing since 21 people were killed in a Barcelona shopping centre in June 1987.

The blasts occurred during morning rush hour near a school in a neighbourhood where military personnel are housed. Timed for maximum political effect, the explosions came just four days after prime minister Jose Maria Aznar called a general election for March 12. They represented a lethal message to the Spanish government on its vulnerability to terrorist action.

Four people were reported injured including the girl hurt in the first explosion. No injuries were reported for the second blast. Authorities said they found a third car in the area believed to be booby-trapped and planned to blow it up in a controlled explosion.

It was the first action attributed to ETA since June 1998, when a Basque town councillor was killed in a car bombing in northern Spain. The Spanish government had been bracing itself for a renewed cycle of ETA violence ever since the guerrillas ended their 14-month ceasefire and told their fighters to prepare for action.

"This is what we had feared," said Jose Maria Alvarez de Manzano, Madrid's mayor. "We were on the alert. We are not surprised that it happened but we are surprised by the date and the location." Today's car bombings followed several attempted attacks by the guerrillas that were foiled by police. Civil Guards intercepted two vans loaded with almost two tons of explosive on their way to Madrid just before Christmas.

One car was completely destroyed in the first explosion and two others were set on fire, The blasts, which took place 30 to 40 minutes apart in southern Madrid, were heard in offices several miles away. The explosions rocked the south-eastern part of the capital where there are a number of military barracks and close to a school connected with the military, police said.

They immediately cordoned off the zone. Just two hours after the blasts, a man was shot and injured by police near the scene, but officials said it involved a crime unrelated to the car bombings. Spanish government officials had warned that ETA was likely to mount an attack before election day.

In announcing the end of their unilateral truce, the guerrillas accused the government of intransigence in its refusal to consider ETA's demands for Basque self-determination. Mr Aznar, in his election announcement on Monday, had promised to maintain a hardline stance against Basque separatists.

ETA frequently exploded car bombs in Madrid during the morning rush when it was more active in the early 1990s. The group has usually hit political and military targets in its 31-year campaign of shootings and bombings to back its demands for an independent Basque state. It has been blamed for more than 800 deaths.

fields.headline: Specialists seek the broader perspective
fields.standfirst: MBAs with a public service bias are not always the top choice of students from that background. Graham Wade explains why
fields.trailText: There is a continuing argument over whether specialist MBAs are a good idea or not. One view is that, above all, the qualification is a general management award whose fundamental strength resides in its breadth of perspective.
fields.body:
There is a continuing argument over whether specialist MBAs are a good idea or not. One view is that, above all, the qualification is a general management award whose fundamental strength resides in its breadth of perspective.

Others feel that specific groups - such as those working in the NHS, education, technology, and banking - can gain more from studying specialist programmes.

About a dozen business schools in Britain offer MBAs with a public service bias. However, on examination, some of these are less specialist than they may appear.

Pauline Weight, the director of Cranfield's public sector MBA, says: "The award our students receive at the end of the course is the Cranfield MBA, a general management qualification. It offers some specialisation in the public sector field, but it depends on how much you wish to opt for. Often people working in the public sector already know a great deal about it, so they prefer to gain breadth and don't want to spend too much time looking at their own area."

Cranfield's public sector programme developed largely from winning a competitive tendering exercise launched by the cabinet office in the mid-1990s. Since then, about 50 central government civil servants have passed through the course, mostly on the one-year, full-time version, with their fees, expenses and salaries paid by their employer.

Among departments sending significant numbers of their middle-ranking staff are the home office, the treasury, the department for education and employment and the ministry of defence.

Most participants on the Cranfield MBA come from the private sector, so the arrival of students from the public sector has been a valuable addition to the mix. Among the electives available with a public service angle are cross-sector partnerships, managing for social results and performance measurement in not-for-profit environments. Some civil servants on the course chose not to study any public sector modules.

Unlike Cranfield, Aston Business School graduates who choose to enrol for a specialist pathway come out with a qualification whose title reflects that slant. If you select an award like the MBA in public services management, you will have studied a significant number of public service options, although the extent of these can still vary.

Dr Paul Davis, director of the public services management MBA at Aston, says: 'We very much encourage our students from the public sector to integrate fully with students following the general MBA. Our approach is to give all of our participants a good overview. So with our course on best value, and the duty to consult under that, we don't just provide students with lists of survey types and similar material, we give them a way of thinking through the choice of consultation methods.

"We would consider the values of politicians, the balance of power and the structure of accountability, for example."

Both the Cranfield and Aston MBA programmes are accredited by the Association of MBAs, but their cost varies substantially. For the full-time Cranfield programme next autumn, the fees will be £20,000 - slightly more than double what Aston charges.

The gap between the schools' prices for part-time packages is even greater, so if finance is a critical factor, it is worth shopping around.

Regardless of one's views on the specialist versus generalist MBA debate, there can be little doubt that the demand for specialist programmes remains strong, and that is why they continue to be offered in considerable numbers.

fields.headline: Final whistle for Subbuteo
fields.trailText: Top players were today mourning the demise of the legendary table top football game Subbuteo which has been shown the red card by its makers.
fields.body:
Top players were today mourning the demise of the legendary table top football game Subbuteo which has been shown the red card by its makers.

Hasbro confirmed in a statement: "Production of Subbuteo will cease in January 2000 although Subbuteo games and teams will be available from retailers across the UK for the next few months.

"The decision to cease production has been made as a result of the huge number of football-related products which have flooded the market in recent years but the possibility remains that the Subbuteo brand may make a return at some stage in the future."

Sue Taylor, 51, of Lichfield, Staffs, formerly Britain's top woman Subbuteo player, said: "It is a great disappointment. It is the one make of table football equipment that everybody knows about and up until recently has been readily available in shops.

"It will obviously make it more difficult for youngsters coming into the game.

"Over the past six to 12 months Subbuteo sets have been steadily disappearing from stores and though this news may be a surprise to the public it does not surprise us. "There are other similar makes but they are more expensive and not so readily available."

When stocks finally ran out, enthusiasts would have to switch to an alternative, said Mrs Taylor, part owner of a shop selling table football equipment.

Her husband Tom, a 47-year-old retired firefighter, has played for England.

Hasbro said it had asked some of the biggest names in post war British football to vote for their favourite players to make up a team of Millennium Greats.

A framed team sheet of the players would be produced and sold for charity.

Among players who voted were England coach Kevin Keegan, former England keepers Gordon Banks, Ray Clemence and Peter Shilton, Scottish stars Gordon Strachan and Frank McLintock and Irish internationals Pat Jennings and Norman Whiteside. Subbuteo was invented by birdwatcher Peter Adolph in 1947 and named after the Latin word for the Hobby Hawk.

For many years it was a favourite game in more than 50 countries. Even today 50,000 of the miniature teams are sold in Britain each year. But experts say the tide of change will inevitably mean traditional games like Subbuteo being given the boot.

Statistics show last year traditional toys were still top of the league with £1.7 billion worth being sold compared with £1.4 billion of computer games.

But experts are predicting the sale of computer goods will double in the next two years.

webTitle: My life on the net: Johnny Davis, editor of Face magazine

fields.headline: My life on the net: Johnny Davis, editor of Face magazine
fields.trailText: We use the NME website, every day. We get interview biographies and band biographies from it. The good thing about it is that it won't let you forget about it as it stays on the screen, and it has loads and loads of links. You can flick through reviews from the night before as well as records the NME has reviewed - and then you can access the music. But the main reason people use NME is for the news pages. The quality is good, very fast, and it's updated daily.
fields.body:
We use the NME website, every day. We get interview biographies and band biographies from it. The good thing about it is that it won't let you forget about it as it stays on the screen, and it has loads and loads of links. You can flick through reviews from the night before as well as records the NME has reviewed - and then you can access the music. But the main reason people use NME is for the news pages. The quality is good, very fast, and it's updated daily.

Hint Magazine is basically a fashion magazine on the web. It's an irreverent look at the fashion industry and the media. As well as reviews, it looks at industry gossip - at what the editor of Harper's Bazaar or Gwyneth Paltrow is doing. There was an article about which model has the sexiest, prettiest and cutest eyes, which we extracted for our magazine; it listed the top 10 and then it let the people who accessed the website have a debate in the chatrooms. It ran for four or five days. I guess what I like about it is there's no pomposity, but it's also very informative and tells you when the fashion shows are on. The whole package is slickly done.

I suspect a journalist is behind www.tvgohome.com. It's a mock-up of the Radio Times, with all the same fonts and photos with bylines with the latest TV series and film premieres, but all the entries are made up. It's a satirical look at news programmes and a satire on news presenting on television - I think it's fair to say it wouldn't exist if it hadn't been for Chris Morris and Brass Eye. It's literally a page of television listings with a paragraph block for each programme (over Christmas, say, it had a billing that said: "4.00. Film Premiere: A Muppet Schindler's List. Harrowing drama starring Liam Neeson and Kermit the Frog.") It's not interactive, but it's incredibly humorously and rudely written. Kind of fun.

webTitle: Amnesty backs BMA attack on secret tests

fields.headline: Amnesty backs BMA attack on secret tests
fields.trailText: Amnesty International today welcomed the British Medical Association's criticisms of the secret medical tests which led Jack Straw to rule that former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet was not fit to stand trial.
fields.body:
Amnesty International today welcomed the British Medical Association's criticisms of the secret medical tests which led Jack Straw to rule that former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet was not fit to stand trial.

The chairman of the British Medical Association's medical ethics committee, Michael Wilks, said the results of the medical tests on General Pinochet should be made public and scrutinised in court.

"In the case of General Pinochet the experts appointed by the home secretary acted in a forensic capacity," Mr Wilks said in a letter to the Times this morning. "In being asked to provide an opinion on the general's fitness to stand trial, the reports compiled should be disclosable in any judicial procedures, and the opinion therein tested in court."

An Amnesty spokesman said: "This letter appears to support what we've said in our submission to the home secretary.

"The debate over the rights and wrongs of the medical tests has only underlined what we've said that they should have been conducted with proper judicial oversight and by medical specialists appointed by the courts."

But the home secretary remained unmoved. "I've made the decisions I've made in respect of senator Pinochet on the basis of very careful legal advice," Mr Straw told the Today programme this morning.

The home secretary is still studying submissions from human rights groups and Pinochet supporters before making a final decision on whether the former Chilean dictator can return to Chile.

He has been urged to order new tests on Gen Pinochet, amid criticism of the test's secrecy and warnings there could have been serious flaws in the examination conducted by a team of experts on 5 January.

One of the senior medical experts who examined Gen Pinochet, Oxford university professor Sir John Grimley Evans, told the Observer that the former dicatator could make a full recovery from the medical condition that has prevented his extradition to Spain to face torture charges.

Meanwhile, the Chilean military jet poised to fly Gen Pinochet home remains grounded on a runway in Bermuda, where it is not expected to take off until the home secretary gives his final decision on the 84-year-old's future.

webTitle: Boy on baby murder charge in court

fields.headline: Boy on baby murder charge in court
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old boy was today remanded to local authority secure accommodation charged with murdering his six-month-old brother, following his appearance at Bristol's youth court.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old boy was today remanded to local authority secure accommodation charged with murdering his six-month-old brother, following his appearance at Bristol's youth court.

The child, who cannot be named, sat beside a social worker during a 20-minute hearing. He whispered "yes" four times to confirm his name, date of birth, address and that he understood the charge.

His solicitor David Campbell sat next to the social worker to the boy's left. None of his family attended.

His six-month-old baby brother was found on Wednesday afternoon in the bedroom of a house on the city's run-down Hartcliffe estate. The baby had suffered multiple stab wounds and was taken to the Bristol children's hospital where he was pronounced dead.

The 12-year-old was arrested the same day.

Magistrates agreed to a request by prosecutor James King to remand him in secure local authority accommodation after deliberating for 10 minutes. The boy stood as the chairwoman of the bench told him he would be remanded for one week to be brought back before the court on January 28.

The hearing was delayed by almost half an hour as court officials brought in extra seats to accommodate the large number of reporters attending the hearing.

There was no dock in the specialist youth court. Instead, the 12-year-old sat at a single table in the court with his social worker, magistrates and the lawyers.

Neighbours living on the Hartcliffe estate said they were shocked by the incident at the four-bedroom housing association house where the baby lived with four other children and his mother.

They said the family had lived in the house for about four months.

fields.headline: Car bombs in Madrid
fields.trailText: Two car bombs exploded in Madrid today, reviving the spectre of terrorist violence by Basque separatist group ETA. One person was killed and four wounded, including a child..
fields.body:
Two car bombs exploded in Madrid today, reviving the spectre of terrorist violence by Basque separatist group ETA. One person was killed and four wounded, including a child..

The first bomb exploded shortly after 8am local time outside an apartment building in an area housing many military families. It was followed about 35 minutes later by a blast some 150m away.

Spain has been bracing itself for such an attack since ETA broke off peace talks with the government in December and declared an end to its 14-month ceasefire. Following the end of the truce, police seized much bomb-making material, leading to speculation that renewed violence was in the works. The interior ministry has warned for weeks that ETA was planning an attack.

The explosions occurred some 800m from the Vicente Calderon football stadium alongside the Manzanares River in west Madrid. The victim was identified by police as Lieutenant Colonel Pedro Antonio Blanco Garcia, 47.

National Police said they believe the second vehicle was the getaway car. ETA frequently employs two cars in such attacks, one for the main explosion and the second for escape and to blow up to create maximum confusion.

"I heard a tremendous noise. It was just below my window and when I heard it my whole life fell apart," said a shaken resident who identified herself only as Rosa, 28. Police and rescue workers were arriving at the smoking scene when the second car exploded and burst into flames, causing alarm but no damage.

The emergency services arrived at the scene within minutes of the first blast. Residents were evacuated as police cars, fire trucks and ambulances moved in.

ETA advocates a Basque homeland in northern Spain and southern France. In its campaign for independence, the commando group has killed nearly 800 people since 1968.

Last December, civil guards intercepted two vans loaded with almost two tons of explosive on their way to Madrid. One of the drivers arrested was suspected of being an ETA member.

In what has now been confirmed as an unrelated incident, a police officer was killed in a gun battle that broke out about two hours after the car bombs.
