fields.headline: Net prophets
fields.standfirst: Will the net prove to be a brave new world for record companies or will it sound their death knell? Adam Sweeting investigates
fields.trailText: Will the net prove to be a brave new world for record companies or will it sound their death knell? Adam Sweeting investigates
fields.body:
Historically, writers and critics have recorded the development of the music industry in terms of its most significant artists. The Beatles, Madonna or the Artist have been lauded for the way they transformed pop or triggered fresh musical directions. Genres like rap or grunge have been hailed for their galvanising sociological or political impact.

But suddenly, that traditional perspective has been upended by the arrival of the internet era. The creeping corporatisation of the entertainment industry has been steadily relegating artists to the status of mere software, as noted by an aggrieved George Michael in his legal struggle against Sony.

But the eruption of the internet and e-commerce is making George's servitude at Sony look like the good old days. With stunning speed, the emphasis has swung away from the performers who make music towards the companies and delivery systems which package and market it. The most hotly debated topics in today's record industry aren't which musical genres are going to be big in 2001, but how will record companies cope with the challenge of music that can be downloaded over the internet, and will it mean the end of retailing?

Which current acts can command the kind of sustained news coverage lavished on the merger of internet service provider AOL and multi-media conglomerate Time-Warner? Not even George Harrison's encounter with a knife-wielding intruder, or the Jennifer Lopez/Puff Daddy firearms arrest, came close.

In this new era, the stars seem tame and anonymous."In the record company environment, the real stars are the technical people and the marketers," claims Charly Prevost of Liquid Audio, a company which has developed its own online digital audio software to challenge the popular MP3 digital audio format which first made it possible to make music downloadable from the web. "They're like the artists now. The artists are almost secondary. The marketers are media artists."

Technological change and shifts in consumer behaviour are forcing the business to rethink its entire commercial strategy. Since the music business began, record companies and retailers have been mutually supportive in the quest to lure more buyers to the tills, and they've been careful to preserve generous profit margins. Far too generous, as they're discovering.

The rules are being rewritten. Online retailers are taking advantage of low overheads to offer CDs at prices closer to their real worth. Record companies are panicking about illegal websites offering pirate copies of their own copyrighted material. And musicians are beginning to wonder if they need record companies.

"I think what the record companies are being short-sighted about is not that they're losing control of the distribution, but about the demystification of what was once a tool against the establishment," postulates Malcolm McLaren, pop manager turned cyber-age soothsayer and renegade candidate for mayor of London. "That was where pop culture all emanated from and that has already gone. There's no game left. There's no need for managers any more. Rock 'n' roll bands can make music and put it on their own website."

McLaren's rockbiz apocalypse won't come to pass for a while yet. Record companies were caught on the hop by internet-frenzy, but it's impossible to over-estimate their ferocious instinct for self-preservation. The companies are well aware of catalogue copyrights. They have no plans to let some pesky technological revolution stop them now.

The net offers them ever-expanding opportunities to make yet more profit. For instance, they're countering the threat from available-to-all MP3 downloads by embracing more sophisticated digitised music formats like Liquid Audio or Microsoft's Windows Media Audio. These enable files to self-destruct after a pre-set period unless customers pay the required download fee. The companies can make their catalogues available online and ensure they get paid for doing so.

While it's true that the net offers access to all, and lets you distribute music without A&R men, that creates its own problems. Click on a site like peoplesound.com and you're confronted with a barrage of unknown names like Prince Albert, Lazydog, 750cc, the Cheetahs and the Dukes of Hang-Gliding.

How much time have you got to spend ploughing through a phone-directory of acts you've never seen or read about? It looks suspiciously like the post-punk era of esoteric independent labels, who made music mostly for themselves and a coterie of friends. Superstardom requires investment and promotional machinery to push you there. Only a big record label that can supply these.

Hence, there still hasn't been a major artist launched exclusively via the web. Public Enemy was the first act to make a whole album, There's a Poison Goin On, downloadable from the net, but try finding it on the Billboard charts. The Artist's attempts to circumvent record companies and distribute his music online have merely assisted his steady commercial decline. David Bowie's online release of Hours stirred up more media interest than actual sales. Tori Amos and Puff Daddy, however, have used the net more selectively and more successfully, by making singles available for download to whet the punters' appetites for a subsequent album release.

Yet it's change-or-die time for the industry. The Top Internet Album Sales chart in Billboard magazine at the end of October had Honky Tonk Union by Roger Clyne & The Peacemakers at number one. When they come to write the history of what happened when the net met the music biz, Roger Clyne will get his very own footnote, because he's one of rock 'n' roll's online pioneers.

"This is a guy from Ohio who recorded his little bar band in a club, made a record that sounds just like a bar band in a club, and sold it as digital downloads," explains Charly Prevost. "But every T-shirt Roger Clyne had, and every card he handed out, had Liquid Audio's URL [internet address] on it. I think the album only picked up about 1,200 internet sales, but Clyne marketed himself using the internet. I think the fact that at the same time he kept touring and had a physical CD released gave him visibility and allowed him to start a career."

Clyne's story illustrates the rise of the net as a marketing tool. Merely plonking yourself on the internet won't make you a star, but internet plus touring plus TV plus press interviews might. It's when major artists start getting net-smart that the hysteria begins.This may be OK for record companies, whose position as copyright-owners ensures they'll take their cut of sales in whatever medium they're achieved, but it puts the wind up retailers, who could rapidly become surplus to requirements.

A few weeks ago, HMV Europe's managing director Brian McLaughlin - in his role as chairman of the retailers' association, Bard - was strongly critical of record labels who make music available for download from the internet before the product is on sale in stores. The focus of his ire was David Bowie's latest album, Hours, which was offered to American internet customers two weeks before its official release date. "We're obviously responsive to the huge opportunities offered by e-commerce," McLaughlin argued, "but we must be alert to record companies possibly paying no regard to the relationship between suppliers and retailers in the UK."

McLaughlin's humour won't have been improved by the news that EMI is proposing to sell its stake in HMV, as it plans for an increasingly internet-orientated future. Already, EMI has entered an agreement with Liquid Audio to digitise its catalogue for potential download. This makes perfect sense for a record company, which can make its archive of material available on demand without having to keep manufacturing copies on CD. This could prove particularly attractive in classical music, where there's a rich tradition of historic recordings stretching back to the beginning of the century.

There may even be benefits for retailers, too. Record stores could become the access point for customers wanting to order so-called "deep catalogue" material, not currently available but accessible as digital downloads from a central database. The material could be recorded on to CD on demand, or transferred to any number of emerging new audio formats. American company Digital On-Demand has been testing download kiosks in selected locations, enabling customers to walk in, order catalogue material and have it burned on to a recordable CD while they wait. New Media Network plans to start a similar venture this year.

It's going to be a risky, unpredictable process. Charly Prevost remembers the furore which greeted the arrival of MP3.

"There was a great fear that the internet would cannibalise physical record sales, and that people would stop going to record stores," Prevost remembers. "Overnight, human nature would change! But when you explain it to people, and give them examples of how the net has helped sell more records and launched careers, then suddenly they don't see it as a threat any more."

The Americans responded to the net invasion with a characteristic display of hard-nosed entrepreneurialism. Internet retailers - most famously Amazon.com - sprang up and began to get rich quick. Existing stores started their own net operations and adapted their businesses accordingly. The giant retail chain Musicland originally refused to stock albums with a URL listed, but last June it launched four websites of its own and has been marketing them aggressively in its stores.

Meanwhile, the Best Buy chain has invented a fresh sales strategy with its Find 'Em First line of albums which it sells both online and in-store, and boosts with its own TV ads. These aren't necessarily new releases, just ones which Best Buy has decided it likes and can promote effectively. Among its current favourites are Robbie Williams, Kelly Willis, Rufus Wainwright, Mercury Rev and The Freestylers, which Best Buy insists are "incredible musicians that aren't well known but who deserve more press and a place in your music collection!"

Yet the net is by no means the preserve of the hippest and youngest operators. Veteran music fans have found it a perfect place to track down obscure albums, while the freakish success of Cliff Richard's Millennium Prayer was fuelled not only by the net, but also by making the song downloadable from the remotemusic.com website at 99p a throw.

"The net is going to be an interesting additional means of delivering music in the future," commented Malcolm Smith, managing director of the Cliff Richard Organisation. "It won't replace any of the traditional outlets, but it will supplement them." Which is a refreshingly unhysterical way of looking at it.

 Comprehensive guide to how to get the most out of the net: Life Online

10 music websites

Liquid Audio

Excellent quality streaming and try-before-you-buy downloads. Links to swarms of affiliated sites.

NME

Online version of the veteran music paper. Better (some say) than the printed artefact.

MP3

Millions of tracks by people you've never heard of for preview or download. CDs for sale for $8.

Music 365

Rolling online music paper, with news, reviews, features, charts etc.

Hyperion Records

Superbly designed site for classical buffs, with artist and composer info and generous Real Audio extracts from many Hyperion releases.

Clickmusic

Charts, news, gig listings, online shopping and MP3 downloads.

Peoplesound

Net democracy in action, with oodles of unsigned acts putting their music on the web. Sample for free, or buy a CD.

Best Buy

Innovative US retailer sells bestselling CDs for 12 and a half bucks, offers a free download section and plugs its own hand-picked Find 'Em First artists.

Remotemusic

Home of Cliff's Millennium Prayer for download. Still primitive, but aims to be "the fastest and most fluent online music company of the 21st century".

Songplayer

Ingenious online tuition system to teach keyboards and guitar.

But the eruption of the internet and e-commerce is making George's servitude at Sony look like the good old days. With stunning speed, the emphasis has swung away from the performers who make music towards the companies and delivery systems which package and market it. The most hotly debated topics in today's record industry aren't which musical genres are going to be big in 2001, but how will record companies cope with the challenge of music that can be downloaded over the internet, and will it mean the end of retailing? Which current acts can command the kind of sustained news coverage lavished on the merger of internet service provider AOL and multi-media conglomerate Time-Warner? Not even George Harrison's encounter with a knife-wielding intruder, or the Jennifer Lopez/Puff Daddy firearms arrest, came close. In this new era, the stars seem tame and anonymous."In the record company environment, the real stars are the technical people and the marketers," claims Charly Prevost of Liquid Audio, a company which has developed its own online digital audio software to challenge the popular MP3 digital audio format which first made it possible to make music downloadable from the web. "They're like the artists now. The artists are almost secondary. The marketers are media artists." Technological change and shifts in consumer behaviour are forcing the business to rethink its entire commercial strategy. Since the music business began, record companies and retailers have been mutually supportive in the quest to lure more buyers to the tills, and they've been careful to preserve generous profit margins. Far too generous, as they're discovering. The rules are being rewritten. Online retailers are taking advantage of low overheads to offer CDs at prices closer to their real worth. Record companies are panicking about illegal websites offering pirate copies of their own copyrighted material. And musicians are beginning to wonder if they need record companies. "I think what the record companies are being short-sighted about is not that they're losing control of the distribution, but about the demystification of what was once a tool against the establishment," postulates Malcolm McLaren, pop manager turned cyber-age soothsayer and renegade candidate for mayor of London. "That was where pop culture all emanated from and that has already gone. There's no game left. There's no need for managers any more. Rock 'n' roll bands can make music and put it on their own website." McLaren's rockbiz apocalypse won't come to pass for a while yet. Record companies were caught on the hop by internet-frenzy, but it's impossible to over-estimate their ferocious instinct for self-preservation. The companies are well aware of catalogue copyrights. They have no plans to let some pesky technological revolution stop them now. The net offers them ever-expanding opportunities to make yet more profit. For instance, they're countering the threat from available-to-all MP3 downloads by embracing more sophisticated digitised music formats like Liquid Audio or Microsoft's Windows Media Audio. These enable files to self-destruct after a pre-set period unless customers pay the required download fee. The companies can make their catalogues available online and ensure they get paid for doing so. While it's true that the net offers access to all, and lets you distribute music without A&R men, that creates its own problems. Click on a site like peoplesound.com and you're confronted with a barrage of unknown names like Prince Albert, Lazydog, 750cc, the Cheetahs and the Dukes of Hang-Gliding. How much time have you got to spend ploughing through a phone-directory of acts you've never seen or read about? It looks suspiciously like the post-punk era of esoteric independent labels, who made music mostly for themselves and a coterie of friends. Superstardom requires investment and promotional machinery to push you there. Only a big record label that can supply these. Hence, there still hasn't been a major artist launched exclusively via the web. Public Enemy was the first act to make a whole album, There's a Poison Goin On, downloadable from the net, but try finding it on the Billboard charts. The Artist's attempts to circumvent record companies and distribute his music online have merely assisted his steady commercial decline. David Bowie's online release of Hours stirred up more media interest than actual sales. Tori Amos and Puff Daddy, however, have used the net more selectively and more successfully, by making singles available for download to whet the punters' appetites for a subsequent album release. Yet it's change-or-die time for the industry. The Top Internet Album Sales chart in Billboard magazine at the end of October had Honky Tonk Union by Roger Clyne & The Peacemakers at number one. When they come to write the history of what happened when the net met the music biz, Roger Clyne will get his very own footnote, because he's one of rock 'n' roll's online pioneers. "This is a guy from Ohio who recorded his little bar band in a club, made a record that sounds just like a bar band in a club, and sold it as digital downloads," explains Charly Prevost. "But every T-shirt Roger Clyne had, and every card he handed out, had Liquid Audio's URL [internet address] on it. I think the album only picked up about 1,200 internet sales, but Clyne marketed himself using the internet. I think the fact that at the same time he kept touring and had a physical CD released gave him visibility and allowed him to start a career." Clyne's story illustrates the rise of the net as a marketing tool. Merely plonking yourself on the internet won't make you a star, but internet plus touring plus TV plus press interviews might. It's when major artists start getting net-smart that the hysteria begins.This may be OK for record companies, whose position as copyright-owners ensures they'll take their cut of sales in whatever medium they're achieved, but it puts the wind up retailers, who could rapidly become surplus to requirements. A few weeks ago, HMV Europe's managing director Brian McLaughlin - in his role as chairman of the retailers' association, Bard - was strongly critical of record labels who make music available for download from the internet before the product is on sale in stores. The focus of his ire was David Bowie's latest album, Hours, which was offered to American internet customers two weeks before its official release date. "We're obviously responsive to the huge opportunities offered by e-commerce," McLaughlin argued, "but we must be alert to record companies possibly paying no regard to the relationship between suppliers and retailers in the UK." McLaughlin's humour won't have been improved by the news that EMI is proposing to sell its stake in HMV, as it plans for an increasingly internet-orientated future. Already, EMI has entered an agreement with Liquid Audio to digitise its catalogue for potential download. This makes perfect sense for a record company, which can make its archive of material available on demand without having to keep manufacturing copies on CD. This could prove particularly attractive in classical music, where there's a rich tradition of historic recordings stretching back to the beginning of the century. There may even be benefits for retailers, too. Record stores could become the access point for customers wanting to order so-called "deep catalogue" material, not currently available but accessible as digital downloads from a central database. The material could be recorded on to CD on demand, or transferred to any number of emerging new audio formats. American company Digital On-Demand has been testing download kiosks in selected locations, enabling customers to walk in, order catalogue material and have it burned on to a recordable CD while they wait. New Media Network plans to start a similar venture this year. It's going to be a risky, unpredictable process. Charly Prevost remembers the furore which greeted the arrival of MP3. "There was a great fear that the internet would cannibalise physical record sales, and that people would stop going to record stores," Prevost remembers. "Overnight, human nature would change! But when you explain it to people, and give them examples of how the net has helped sell more records and launched careers, then suddenly they don't see it as a threat any more." The Americans responded to the net invasion with a characteristic display of hard-nosed entrepreneurialism. Internet retailers - most famously Amazon.com - sprang up and began to get rich quick. Existing stores started their own net operations and adapted their businesses accordingly. The giant retail chain Musicland originally refused to stock albums with a URL listed, but last June it launched four websites of its own and has been marketing them aggressively in its stores. Meanwhile, the Best Buy chain has invented a fresh sales strategy with its Find 'Em First line of albums which it sells both online and in-store, and boosts with its own TV ads. These aren't necessarily new releases, just ones which Best Buy has decided it likes and can promote effectively. Among its current favourites are Robbie Williams, Kelly Willis, Rufus Wainwright, Mercury Rev and The Freestylers, which Best Buy insists are "incredible musicians that aren't well known but who deserve more press and a place in your music collection!" Yet the net is by no means the preserve of the hippest and youngest operators. Veteran music fans have found it a perfect place to track down obscure albums, while the freakish success of Cliff Richard's Millennium Prayer was fuelled not only by the net, but also by making the song downloadable from the remotemusic.com website at 99p a throw. "The net is going to be an interesting additional means of delivering music in the future," commented Malcolm Smith, managing director of the Cliff Richard Organisation. "It won't replace any of the traditional outlets, but it will supplement them." Which is a refreshingly unhysterical way of looking at it.  Comprehensive guide to how to get the most out of the net: Life Online 10 music websites Liquid Audio Excellent quality streaming and try-before-you-buy downloads. Links to swarms of affiliated sites. NME Online version of the veteran music paper. Better (some say) than the printed artefact. MP3 Millions of tracks by people you've never heard of for preview or download. CDs for sale for $8. Music 365 Rolling online music paper, with news, reviews, features, charts etc. Hyperion Records Superbly designed site for classical buffs, with artist and composer info and generous Real Audio extracts from many Hyperion releases. Clickmusic Charts, news, gig listings, online shopping and MP3 downloads. Peoplesound Net democracy in action, with oodles of unsigned acts putting their music on the web. Sample for free, or buy a CD. Best Buy Innovative US retailer sells bestselling CDs for 12 and a half bucks, offers a free download section and plugs its own hand-picked Find 'Em First artists. Remotemusic Home of Cliff's Millennium Prayer for download. Still primitive, but aims to be "the fastest and most fluent online music company of the 21st century". Songplayer Ingenious online tuition system to teach keyboards and guitar.

fields.headline: The world's your oyster
fields.standfirst:
Fancy a dozen oysters fresh from the sea for supper? Or delicious organic icecream from Devon? The net can fulfil even the fussiest foodie's wildest dreams - with delivery straight to the door. Claire Phipps tracks down Britain's top gourmet shopping sites

Get the most out of the net with Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText: Fancy a dozen oysters fresh from the sea for supper? Or delicious organic icecream from Devon? The net can fulfil even the fussiest foodie's wildest dreams - with delivery straight to the door. Claire Phipps tracks down Britain's top gourmet shopping sites
fields.body:
Not so long ago, the fine food fanatic would view the hunt for authentic but elusive foodstuffs such as truffles and Norwegian goat's cheese as proof of culinary dedication. He or she would think nothing of driving miles up muddy farm tracks in search of, say, Gloucestershire Old Spot dry-cure bacon from a rare-breed piggery.

For the rest of us, who only fancied the occasional nibble of foie gras or wind-dried tuna, such a prospect was enough to send us running for the supermarket and a ready-made lasagne. But those were the days when finding anything more exciting than a button mushroom on the high street involved as much sweat and toil as sniffing out truffles in the woods of Piedmont.

Today the internet can deliver even the most exotic foods straight to your doorstep. You need pomegranate seeds or ewe's milk cheese for that recipe? You fancy caviar for supper but the corner store doesn't stock it? You want haggis direct from the Highlands? You want to know how the lamb was reared before it became chops? You prefer your oysters fresh from the sea? You need to be 100% sure that your tomatoes are organic? Then go online - where you'll find pretty much anything you want in a matter of minutes.

There is a downside, of course. Unlike other online shopping, you'll rarely find decent discounts. But at least you'll be paying handsomely for food you can't pick up on the average high street. And don't truffles from Alba sound so much more interesting than mushrooms from Asda?

Fine foods

www.gourmet-tradition.com Gastro-geek heaven, home to caviar, truffles, foie gras and fine wines shipped direct from France within 48 hours. A single black truffle can be with you, season permitting, for £37, although information on delivery costs is elusive.

www.jayfruit.com More French delicacies from Le Gourmet Francais Online: try a partridge stuffed with foie gras at £27 or crayfish soup with saffron at £4. Delivery within 48 hours is £4.99, minimum order £20.

www.gourmetconnect.com The easy way to home-made French cuisine: someone else does it for you. Buy pre-stuffed, pre-marinated joints of meat or, simpler still, boeuf bourgignon or coq au vin for two. Ready meals with a bit of class will arrive the next day, but the minimum order is £40.

Try also: www.morel.co.uk
www.gourmet-world.co.uk

Farm shops

www.graigfarm.co.uk Save cash and help British farmers with a click of the mouse. Graig Farm supplies certified organic and additive-free meat, plus details of how the animals are reared. No online ordering yet, but email for a catalogue. Free delivery for orders over £40.

www.gratton.co.uk/hacknell Organic meat direct from the farm; beef is £7.20/kg and lamb £6.50/kg. Be warned - it's sold in 10kg parcels. Nationwide delivery, £5.

www.rocombefarm.co.uk Soon to be selling online, this Devon farm makes organic ice cream. Register for information on when net shopping is launched; if you can't wait, check out the list of real world stockists.

Try soon: www.healfarm.co.uk (site in progress)

Luxury buys

www.wildmushrooms.co.uk Ditch the button mushroom and go for a New Forest cep, picked by old hand Mrs Tee. You'll have to buy at least a kilo of girolles, shitake, etc, but they will arrive pre-prepped, if you request it at no extra cost. From £7.70/kg for oyster mushrooms.

www.jams.co.uk Fully online soon, Beehive Preserves might persuade you to upgrade from seedless raspberry jam. Luxury rhubarb and gooseberry preserve is £2.25 for 340g; or try clear Cheshire honey for £3.25, or passionfruit and rosehip chutney for £2.50. Delivery is free with 30 jars or more; for the less jam-fixated, charges start at £3.30 for two jars.

www.teddingtoncheese.co.uk A better class of cheese -130 varieties, in fact - gathered from farms across Britain and Europe. Try Gjetost (a Norwegian goat's cheese with a fudgey appearance) at £1.43/100g, or French Epoisses at £6.97/200g. Next day delivery, £5.95.

Try also: www.irishcheese.com
www.cheesemongers.co.uk

Special ingredients

www.sweetmart.co.uk Don't be caught out without ground mango powder or tamarind concentrate. Bristol-based Sweetmart ships spices and ethnic foods countrywide.

Minimum order £10; delivery from £3.50.

www.nwi.co.uk/seasalt A site devoted exclusively to Anglesey Halen Mon sea salt. Get 250g of pure, additive-free crystals for £3.50, UK-wide.

www.jekkasherb.demon.co.uk No-frills site of Jekka's Herb Farm, offering plants and seeds for sale. If that sounds simple, check out the extensive range - there are 24 varieties of mint alone. Order online or ask for a catalogue.

Try soon: www.hambledenherbs.co.uk (Britain's only organic dried herb specialist; online shop opening soon).

Rare breeds

www.angus.co.uk/haggis Genuine Scottish sheep's stomach and other Highland delicacies from this butcher's site. Prize-winning haggis starts at £3.50 plus standard postage for 1.5lbs; a 20lb monster (well, Burns Day is next Tuesday) is £32. Or try black pudding or mealie pudding: both £1.45 for 16oz.

www.smokedproduce.co.uk Macdonald's smoke just about anything, from salmon (from £9.85/lb) to quail (£2.60 each), venison (£4.95/4oz) and the more exotic alligator, ostrich and kangaroo (all £3.75/2oz). Delivery cost according to weight.

www.thefishsociety.co.uk Extensive range of frozen fish - try soft shell crab (£24.90/285g) or whole seabass (£14.90/435g). They only deliver once a month; it costs up to £10 depending on the size of the order.

Try also: www.qinglung.co.uk (online Chinese shopping centre)

Organic

www.organicsdirect.com The real reason to get online for shopping - you'll realise that there's more to organic food than overpriced carrots and milk from the supermarket. Subscribe to Organics Direct's weekly box scheme (from £12.95 including delivery). Your veg will be earthy, your self-satisfaction complete.

www.essentiallyorganic.co.uk Offering branded organic goods, from dried fruits to pté and pasta, in gift boxes, priced between £50 to £100. Delivery is £5 and takes three weeks.

www.cooksdelight.co.uk Organic, biodynamic, macrobiotic online grocer. Expect to pay a premium: organic whole brown rice is £9.99/kg; salty popcorn a mere 90p/50g. Delivery costs from £7, and there's a good line in organic vegan booze.

Try also: www.hdra.org.uk (learn how to become an organic herb-grower; window-box gardeners welcome)

Couch potatoes

www.foodferry.com Does basic grocery shopping - you provide a list and they gather items from central London retailers, notably New Covent Garden market. Food can be with you the same day; cost varies. Central London only.

www.mylocalshop.co.uk Similar scheme, making use of small local shops in the Birmingham area.

www.groceries.org The site for this Glasgow-based shopping service is currently being redeveloped; customers select groceries from any number of supermarkets; groceries.org trolley-pushers collect and deliver.

 All the reports from Life Online week plus a comprehensive guide to how to get the most out of the internet can be found at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/lifeonline. Pass Notes returns next week

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.trailText: Football Unlimited scours the papers and finds that it's a quiet day for rumours. Although tell that to Newcastle fans.
fields.body:
Daily Mail
Newcastle have completed a £2.4m deal for Argentinian international playmaker Christian Bassedas. They will also spend £1m on Paraguayan midfielder Diego Gavilan.

Ceri Hughes will complete a £100,000 move from Wimbledon to Portsmouth in time to play for Pompey at Stockport tomorrow.

The Mirror
Titi Camara's cousin Momo Camara will sign for Leicester. Momo, a left-back, will sign on loan from Le Harve until the end of the season.

The Star
Peterborough manager Barry Fry faces legal action from his own fans after calling them "sponging ponces".

fields.headline: England expects...ten things
fields.standfirst: Tim de Lisle with a list of ten goals for the England one-day side in South Africa
fields.trailText: England expects... not very much these days on the cricket field, if it has any sense. And especially when it comes to one-day cricket and a foreign field: England have won no one-day series or trophy overseas since 1992 apart from the Sharjah tournament of 1997-98, a triumph which was subsequently tarnished by rumours of alleged match-fixing.
fields.body:
England expects... not very much these days on the cricket field, if it has any sense. And especially when it comes to one-day cricket and a foreign field: England have won no one-day series or trophy overseas since 1992 apart from the Sharjah tournament of 1997-98, a triumph which was subsequently tarnished by rumours of alleged match-fixing.

But we can still hope. Here are 10 things that England supporters can reasonably demand of their team in the one-day series against South Africa and Zimbabwe.

1. Reach the final
England's last one-day appearance was in the World Cup, when they crashed out against India at Edgbaston on that shamefaced Sunday morning. Their last outing in South Africa, four years ago, was a 6-1 drubbing. So mere respectability would be a major advance. It's too much to ask that they beat South Africa, who are the world's most effective one-day team outside of major tournaments. But they must see off Zimbabwe, who have history on their side (five wins out of seven in one-dayers against England) but not form - England beat them comfortably, too comfortably as it turned out, at Trent Bridge in May, and although Zimbabwe squeezed into the Super Six stage of the World Cup, they have done nothing since except lose their captain, Alastair Campbell.

2. Bed in a new opening pair
England discovered a new one-day opener in the World Cup: fellow by the name of Hussain. Unfortunately this was at the expense of Nick Knight, the one batsman in the team with a world-class one-day record. Now, with Alec Stewart apparently consigned to history, these two must form a partnership. They have all the balance you could ask for: left and right hander, blaster and barnacle. But does Hussain have any runs left in him at the end of a long tour, and will he manage to refrain from running Knight out?

3. Field as well as...
I was going to say the South Africans, but some observers, amazingly, felt that England had the edge in this department as the Test series went on. Knight, Hussain, Vikram Solanki and Craig White are all outstanding fielders, but if England play all three of their strike bowlers (Gough, Caddick, Mullally), which looks necesary from the penetration point of view, that will put the donkey among the gazelles.

4. Get runs out of Chris Read
The forgotten man of the Test tour - well, one of the many - is a strange choice for this game, and I say that as a Read fan. Read for the Tests and Rob Turner for the one-dayers would have made more sense. But he's there, he's the only keeper, and so he should get the run in the side that he has been denied at Test level. And Duncan Fletcher has got to find a way of squeezing some runs out of him. He will be batting at No.8 or 9, and while he is clearly no Boucher, he mustn't be a front-line tailender either. Needs to improvise like his glove-mentors, Alan Knott and Jack Russell, and be good for a bustling 20.

5. Set attacking fields
The one disappointment of Nasser Hussain's captaincy in the Tests was a tendency to go onn the defensive. It may have been an infection picked up from Hansie Cronje (until he suddenly turned into Father Christmas). But with captaincy, the old when-in-Rome rule does not apply. When in Rome, behave in a way the Roman isn't used to. Keep a slip in throughout a one-day innings. For one thing, it will save the most annoying kind of runs. For another, it will cut out the dreaded open-face push. And it worked for most teams in the World Cup.

6. Get Gough's reverse-swing going again
Darren Gough's bowling don't mean a thing if it ain't got that late jag in. South Africa ought to be made for reversing: the grounds are hard (torrential rain permitting) and the grass is crunchy. But Gough got less reverse-swing in the Tests than Hansie Cronje, and the result was that the South African tail wagged like Shaun Pollock's finger. The England bowling coach, Bob Cottam, is still out there: they didn't know what reverse-swing was in his day, but it's part of his job to be able to locate it now.

7. Name a vice-captain
President Nasser has a poor record in this area, having already shared the job out between Graham Thorpe, Mark Butcher and Alec Stewart in the space of nine Tests, as well as giving Graeme Hick a go, on the pusillanimous grounds that it might go to Michael Vaughan's head if he was groomed for the captaincy. So come on Nasser, stop messing about and give the job to someone who is articulate, assertive and hard to faze: Nick Knight.

Once again, they are going into battle with a team that Alan Hansen would say you can't win anything with. Ten of England's players - Chris Adams, Darren Maddy, Solanki, White, Mark Alleyne, Gavin Hamilton, Read, Ashley Giles, Graeme Swann and Caddick - have 42 one-day caps between them. Even Mark Boucher has more than that, after two years in international cricket. Cronje said recently that he doesn't want to go into the next World Cup with a single player who has less than 50 caps. He didn't manage one in the Test series, poor man: his debut made Graham Gooch's look handy. But he had a great World Cup, in a star-of-a-hopeless-team kind of way. So he should be fully equipped to pull on the mid-blue shirt of England.

One of England's many crimes in the World Cup was to do their numbering alphabetically, so that the number was meaningless. This was bovine in itself, and plain rude to the spectator, who is entitled to think that if a man has No.6 on his shirt, then there is at least some chance that he will come in to bat after No.5. fields.headline: Beethoven: Hammerklavier
fields.standfirst: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording Beethoven's Hammerklavier
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Beethoven's Hammerklavier
fields.body:
Piano Sonata in B flat Op 106

In its sheer scale, density of thought and technical requirements, the Hammerklavier presents a more severe test of a pianist's capabilities than any other of Beethoven's 32 piano sonatas. The trio of sonatas that followed it - Op 109, 110 and 111 - may be more elusive and require a very special musical eloquence to illuminate all their facets, but Op 106, composed in 1817 and 1818, tests every aspect of a pianist's art, almost to the point of destruction.

If the last three sonatas are about reflection and the different kinds of poetic resolution a composer can achieve, this work deals unashamedly in confrontation, generating tensions that can't be resolved in any other way than in the gigantic explosion of the final fugue, whose deliberately clashing sonorities and raw-edged piano sound create a music that it is impossible to prettify. Yet the great slow movement, with its arching melodic lines and bewitching harmonic shifts, demands a different kind of authority altogether; and it's the fusion of these two worlds in the sonata that is unique even in late Beethoven.

The work has inevitably tempted almost all the significant pianists of the last 100 years, yet even some of the greatest fail to bring it off triumphantly; Artur Schnabel, for instance, whose reputation rests, in large part, upon his recordings of the Beethoven sonatas, is not at his most convincing in the Hammerklavier (EMI), where the sheer difficulties of the piano writing seem to destroy his poise.

Of all the more or less "historic" versions, the one by Solomon (EMI) recorded in 1956, comes closest to the ideal, centered upon the most moving account of the slow movement yet put on disc, and with sound that has come up miraculously well in its CD transfer.

I would be more than happy to live with that version to the exclusion of all others, but there are a number of more modern versions that match its profoundity and have a marginally better piano sound, with a list of contenders that includes many of the supreme keyboard artists of our time - Svitatoslav Richter, Emil Gilels, Alfred Brendel, Maruzio Pollini, Daniel Barenboim, Claudio Arrau and Richard Goode.

For my taste, it comes down to a close call between the first three of those: both the Richter (Praga) and the Brendel (Philips, the last of his three recordings) are live accounts, full of unrepeatable insights, but Gilels's studio version from 1983 has a considered majesty and presence that outshines all rivals, even if the recording does not quite do full justice to his glowing piano sound.

· Key Recording: Gilels, Deutsche Grammophon 410 527-2.

webTitle: Telekom's T-Online may go to market

fields.headline: Telekom's T-Online may go to market
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
T-Online
fields.trailText: Hopes that Deutsche Telekom will float its T-Online subsidiary were raised yesterday when the German telecom group reported that its internet business was growing rapidly.
fields.body:
Hopes that Deutsche Telekom will float its T-Online subsidiary were raised yesterday when the German telecom group reported that its internet business was growing rapidly.

Investors believe the group will soon change its "wait and see" policy towards floating T-Online, given that the business is growing by 200,000 customers a month.

T-Online's performance helped offset reaction to the 45% decline in Deutsche Telekom's 1999 profits.

The group said net profits had fallen to €1.2bn (£740m), largely as a result of price cuts, fierce competition and the cost of acquisitions.

Sales were just 0.3% higher at €35.3bn, and the board is planning to pay an unchanged dividend of 61 cents.

"T-Online will have huge demand and Telekom will be able to command a high price and have a large capital inflow, which I hope they will use for acquisitions," said Theo Kitz, analyst at Merck Finck & Co in Munich.

Analysts believe that the time is right to float T-Online because internet stocks are heavily in demand.

Deutsche Telekom is already raising funds through the sale of its 10% stake in Sprint, the American telecoms group, and the disposal of its cable television network. It also intends to float its T-Mobil mobile phone business in the autumn.

webTitle: Hamilton fails to raise cash for promised libel appeal

fields.headline: Hamilton fails to raise cash for promised libel appeal
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton finally conceded defeat in his legal battle with Mohamed Al Fayed last night when he announced that he would not appeal against the "cash for questions" libel trial verdict which branded him corrupt.
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton finally conceded defeat in his legal battle with Mohamed Al Fayed last night when he announced that he would not appeal against the "cash for questions" libel trial verdict which branded him corrupt.

Claiming that the case had left him penniless, Mr Hamilton said he could not afford a fresh court action. The disgraced former minister is struggling to pay a legal bill which has already reached £2m.

"I have paid a high price to try to clear my name. But in my current circumstances, it is simply unrealistic to imagine I can withstand further the financial firepower ranged against me," Mr Hamilton said.

He attacked the Harrods owner's determination to recover his costs. The trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, ordered Mr Hamilton to pay Mr Fayed's fees, and to provide the names of supporters who had put up more than £5,000 to help him fight the original case. By the deadline on Tuesday night, Mr Hamilton had supplied only one name. Mr Fayed's lawyers go back to court next week.

After defeat last month, Mr Hamilton said he would have no problems raising cash for an appeal. But he said last night: "The wealthy owner of Harrods now threatens the many public-spirited individuals of modest means who have helped me financially so far, obviously diminishing the prospects of financing an appeal."

Mr Hamilton also claimed the judge's strong criticism of Mr Fayed's evidence, delivered during his summing-up, made it difficult to argue that the jury had been misdirected.

The former MP went on to call for the police to investigate Mr Fayed, who admitted paying Mr Hamilton to ask parliamentary questions on behalf of Harrods.

Mr Fayed was bullish last night. His spokesman, Laurie Mayer, denounced Mr Hamilton's attacks on the Harrods owner as disingenuous, and pledged that Mr Fayed would continue to pursue the former MP and his backers.

"Mr Hamilton is totally discredited and his continuing attempts to smear Mr Al Fayed are unworthy," he said.

But in my current circumstances, it is simply unrealistic to imagine I can withstand further the financial firepower ranged against me," Mr Hamilton said. He attacked the Harrods owner's determination to recover his costs. The trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, ordered Mr Hamilton to pay Mr Fayed's fees, and to provide the names of supporters who had put up more than £5,000 to help him fight the original case. By the deadline on Tuesday night, Mr Hamilton had supplied only one name. Mr Fayed's lawyers go back to court next week. After defeat last month, Mr Hamilton said he would have no problems raising cash for an appeal. But he said last night: "The wealthy owner of Harrods now threatens the many public-spirited individuals of modest means who have helped me financially so far, obviously diminishing the prospects of financing an appeal." Mr Hamilton also claimed the judge's strong criticism of Mr Fayed's evidence, delivered during his summing-up, made it difficult to argue that the jury had been misdirected. The former MP went on to call for the police to investigate Mr Fayed, who admitted paying Mr Hamilton to ask parliamentary questions on behalf of Harrods. Mr Fayed was bullish last night. His spokesman, Laurie Mayer, denounced Mr Hamilton's attacks on the Harrods owner as disingenuous, and pledged that Mr Fayed would continue to pursue the former MP and his backers. "Mr Hamilton is totally discredited and his continuing attempts to smear Mr Al Fayed are unworthy," he said.

webTitle: Chip trip Crusoe seeks life amid the palm-tops

fields.headline: Chip trip Crusoe seeks life amid the palm-tops
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Transmeta Corporation
fields.trailText: Linus Torvalds, founder of the Linux computer operating system, plays a game as he demonstrates the new Crusoe chip from Transmeta Corporation for laptops and mobile internet applications in California yesterday.
fields.body:
Linus Torvalds, founder of the Linux computer operating system, plays a game as he demonstrates the new Crusoe chip from Transmeta Corporation for laptops and mobile internet applications in California yesterday.

The market response was to push shares in palmtop computer group Psion and microchip designer ARM sharply down as investors worried about the effect of the new low-power mobile chip on their business. Transmeta's new chips, used with the Linux system, were introduced as "revolutionising the field of mobile computing".

ARM, which fell sharply on Wednesday before the new chips were made public, was off more than 7% on the previous day's close. Psion fell 5.7%.The chips, which IBM will make, are likely to challenge Intel's domination of the microprocessor market.

Low power use will drive consumer take-up of a coming array of new mobile Internet devices. The Crusoe chips use 1.2 to 1.65 watts of power, a fraction of the 7 watts for comparable Intel Pentium III processors. Photograph: Paul Sakuma

fields.headline: $2.9bn for online ad firms
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Engage Technologies
fields.trailText: Engage Technologies, a US company which collects profiles of internet users, announced the purchase of two online advertising companies yesterday in a combined bid that was worth $2.9bn (£1.8bn) by mid-morning.
fields.body:
Engage Technologies, a US company which collects profiles of internet users, announced the purchase of two online advertising companies yesterday in a combined bid that was worth $2.9bn (£1.8bn) by mid-morning.

The acquisition of Adsmart and Flycast from CMGI, the internet investment group that owns a majority of Engage, is set to improve the group's position in the online advertising market.

Forrester Research expects this market to almost double from $3.3bn in 1999 to $6.5bn this year. Just 2% of the total US corporate advertising budget is already spent online. The merger creates a bigger online rival to Doubleclick, the established market leader in online advertising.

Investors welcomed the deal yesterday. By midday in New York, shares in Engage had risen $13 to $90, adding more than $400m to the total value of the all-share deal based on Wednesday night's closing price.

Engage will pay CMGI with 32m shares for the two companies, increasing CMGI's stake in Engage from 80% to 87%. CMGI, which holds large stakes in 60 internet companies including portal outfits AltaVista and Lycos, announced yesterday that if the acquisitions go ahead its investments in publicly listed companies will be worth more than $11bn.

David Wetherell, chairman and chief executive of CMGI, said: "Today we have begun to fulfil our larger vision for a single, highly integrated internet marketing company that represents the next generation in online marketing solutions."

The combined company is expected to help companies target specific audiences with their advertising by pooling their resources.

Adsmart has worked on more than 400 websites, while Flycast measures the effectiveness of online ads. CMGI only bought San Francisco-based Flycast last week.

Engage has compiled profiles of 35m web users based on which sites they visit.

The company has said that it does not store personal information such as credit card numbers, a privacy issue which has exercised American regulators.

Kevin O'Connor, chief executive of Doubleclick, said in New York this week that the web-based ads could be more effective than television ones.

The acquisitions, which are expected to close in the spring, pushed the market value of Engage to more than $4bn yesterday.

Paul Schaut will remain as president and chief executive of the combined company, while the respective heads of Flycast and Adsmart will join the president's office to oversee strategic operations.

fields.headline: Canadian smokers face shock tactics
fields.trailText: The Canadian government believes that smokers have become immune to written warnings and hopes that graphic photos of diseased mouths, lungs and brains plastered on cigarette packages will shock them into kicking the habit.
fields.body:
The Canadian government believes that smokers have become immune to written warnings and hopes that graphic photos of diseased mouths, lungs and brains plastered on cigarette packages will shock them into kicking the habit.

The health minister, Allan Rock, proposed regulations yesterday that would require cigarette companies to cover 50% of each pack with colour photos of cigarette-damaged organs or the image of a drooping cigarette to symbolise the impotence that smoking can cause.

"Canadians who use tobacco products need to fully understand the serious health hazard inherent in this lethal product," Mr Rock said. "Let's take on smoking for the national evil that it is. With these hard-hitting health messages and compelling graphics, we will reach smokers directly and effectively."

If approved by the government after public hearings and other steps in the lengthy regulatory process, the rules would also require tobacco companies to list the toxic chemicals in cigarettes and second-hand smoke.

It would be the first time cigarette makers have been required to put graphic photos on their packages.

Dom Caruso of a Toronto-based advertising agency said the current batch of health warnings have become invisible to smokers because everyone is used to them.

"The graphic impact [of the new messages] is probably going to have a lot more life than what they did before," Mr Caruso said.

Canada has stiffened anti-smoking regulations in recent years.

Health warnings on cigarette packages were required until the supreme court in 1995 struck down portions of the Tobacco Products Control Act as unconstitutional. But cigarette makers have continued including health warnings voluntarily, and a new tobacco act passed in 1997 left it to the government to impose any regulations on health warnings.

A tobacco industry spokesman said cigarette-makers may choose to challenge the new regulations proposed by Mr Rock, but have not made a final decision.

But Mr Rock said the new regulations have been carefully drafted and he is convinced they will withstand a court challenge.

webTitle: Chelsea to get a battering at Villa Park

fields.headline: Chelsea to get a battering at Villa Park
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man who's lost his subscription to Personal Finance Monthly, offers his pick of the Premiership bets
fields.trailText: There's an interesting ruck between recent form and historical success kicking off at Villa Park this weekend - a tough call for the bookmakers.
fields.body:
There's an interesting ruck between recent form and historical success kicking off at Villa Park this weekend. Aston Villa have won five of their last seven matches but this Saturday they face a Chelsea side who have returned victorious from their last four excursions to Villa Park - without conceding a goal. The bookmakers can't really split this pair, so you're best off taking the home side. The 6-4 generally on offer seems about right.

Leicester, lacking four first-choice midfielders, had Chelsea's measure at Stamford Bridge last weekend, prompting further bouts of grumbling from Gianluca Vialli. There's no reason why John Gregory's men can't frustrate the Londoners in similar fashion. The point they claimed at Upton Park last week should have been three - a costly blunder by David James let in Paolo Di Canio 12 minutes from time. Expect another hustling, untidy encounter - with a win for Villa.

Despite their recent run of draws away from Goodison, Everton should be backed at 7-5 with Hills to beat Southampton at the Dell. American substitute Joe-Max Moore rescued Walter Smith's side from defeat against Spurs last weekend. Up at St James's Park 24 hours later, the Saints lost by five goals to nothing - a catastrophic result which left Dave Jones on the end of a vote of confidence from his chairman.

Southampton are ripe for the picking, and Everton have the qualities to take advantage. The Toffees have lost only one in twelve, and are unbeaten since they lost at Old Trafford in early December. Veteran defender Richard Gough will be looking forward to returning against the Saints - he scored the only Premiership goal of his career against them earlier this term. If that wasn't bad enough for the home side, Matthew Le Tissier, Claus Lundekvam and Jason Dodd will all watch the game from the sidelines.

The big match on Sunday is Sunderland v Leeds. At odds against, the visitors can turn over their hosts who have been stumbling around in the dark for several weeks now. Peter Reid's men are winless in four games and will be without one half of the Quinn-Phillips strike partnership - the taller one of the two is suspended. They also got stuffed at Highbury last week, which can't have done too much for their confidence.

After two successive league defeats, the Premiership leaders will charge into the fixture with even more than their usual determination. Michael Bridges should start against his old club and is definitely worth a first-scorer punt - bluesq.com are offering 11-2. fixture - Sunderland have lost their last eight league games against Leeds. On Sunday, it'll be nine.

Recommended treble
Aston Villa v Chelsea - home win
Southampton v Everton - away win
Sunderland v Leeds - away win

webTitle: Sinn Fein fury at attack on graves

fields.headline: Sinn Fein fury at attack on graves
fields.trailText:
One day on from Peter Mandelson's announcement of sweeping reforms
   to the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Sinn Fein suggested that RUC officers
   were responsible for overnight attacks on a republican plot at Milltown
   Cemetery in west Belfast. The RUC furiously rejected the claims.
fields.body:
One day on from Peter Mandelson's announcement of sweeping reforms to the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Sinn Fein suggested that RUC officers were responsible for overnight attacks on a republican plot at Milltown Cemetery in west Belfast. The RUC furiously rejected the claims.

As temperatures remained high after Mr Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, indicated he would implement virtually all Chris Patten's recommendations on policing reform, Sinn Fein said the attacks on 20 graves were deeply suspicious. It pointed out that Wednesday saw a huge turnout for the funeral of the IRA man Tom Williams, executed in 1942 for murdering an RUC constable.

At least 18 marble plaques were damaged, including those commemorating the hunger striker Bobby Sands, who died in May 1981, and the three IRA members shot dead by the SAS in Gibraltar in March 1988, Mairead Farrell, Sean Savage and Danny McCann.

Tom Williams's grave was undamaged. He was buried with family members elsewhere in the cemetery.

The RUC is investigating the attacks. A spokeswoman said the accusations were "scurrilous and without foundation."

David Trimble, Ulster Unionist leader, said yesterday he was considering a call from senior figures in the party for an early meeting of its 110-member executive to discuss the Patten proposals. Mr Mandelson's announcement has sparked demands for Mr Trimble to pull out of Northern Ireland's government now.

Mr Trimble met Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, in Dublin yesterday to discuss decommissioning. While Mr Ahern was optimistic the IRA might soon make a move, Mr Trimble wanted him to step up pressure on the republican movement.

His 860-member party council is to reconvene on February 12; he has said Ulster Unionists will quit the power-sharing executive if the IRA has failed to start decommissioning by then. The policing reforms have added to the pressure on him.

fields.headline: Smoking gun
fields.standfirst: He specialises in brutal male dramas. But in The Insider Michael Mann's protagonists aren't gunslingers, angry Mohicans or serial killers - they're corporate Americans. Stuart Husband reports
fields.trailText: He specialises in brutal male dramas. But in The Insider Michael Mann's protagonists aren't gunslingers, angry Mohicans or serial killers - they're corporate Americans
fields.body:
There's a scene midway through Michael Mann's new movie The Insider where would-be whistleblower Jeffrey Wigand, played as a sombre obsessive-compulsive by Russell Crowe, is walking around a lawn, locked in internal debate as to whether or not he should testify that his former employers, tobacco giant Brown & Williamson, knowingly added cancer-causing chemicals to its cigarettes. Attorneys and police look on; the atmosphere is hushed; the tension excruciating. Eventually, Wigand walks up to his confidante, 60 Minutes producer Lowell Bergman (played by Al Pacino), and says simply: "Let's go to court".

This, in many ways, is a quintessential Michael Mann moment, as heartstopping as any death-defying Die Hard or Bond stunt. It's also a perfect illustration of the singular genre that Mann has carved out for himself - the cerebral action movie. True, he's as adept at choreographing bullet ballets as any number of John Woos - those who cowered and flinched through the protracted heist in Heat will testify to that. But the key scene in that movie was the verbal face-off between Robert De Niro's career criminal and Al Pacino's driven cop; two men painted into opposite but complementary corners by the force of their passions and their determination to pursue them, at whatever cost.

Mann has been called a "hard-boiled sensualist", a sort of feng-shui'd Hemingway, and the term could equally apply to any of his anti-heroes, from James Caan's high-class burglar in 1981's Thief; through William Petersen's empathic detective in Manhunter, Mann's 1986 take on Thomas Harris's Red Dragon; to the cigarette-industry deep throat Wigand. Though, as Mann says in his throaty Chicago rasp, "Jeffrey has to be the most confused and unclear character I've ever worked with."

The Insider is based on the real events sparked when Wigand, former head of research and development at Brown & Williamson, violated the confidentiality clause in his severance agreement by going public with his knowledge of the carcinogenic properties of B&W's products to Bergman; Bergman then put his devastating testimony on tape in an interview with 60 Minutes' silky anchor Mike Wallace (played with brilliantined brio by Christopher Plummer).

However, by the time the segment was due to air, Wigand had become a central witness in the lawsuits filed by Mississippi and 49 other states against the tobacco industry, and his marriage had fallen apart in the face of intimidation and threats of imprisonment from his former employers; at the 11th hour, CBS, fearing litigation, decided to pull the interview, to Bergman's dismay and Wigand's disgust. Eventually, the opprobrium heaped on the network forced them to backtrack, but not before Bergman had resigned, Wigand had succumbed to a near-breakdown, and 60 Minutes' vaunted journalistic ethics were left in tatters.

It's far from a classic two-line Hollywood pitch: a Vanity Fair article on the case ran to 24 pages, and was filled with arcane references to tobacco industry practice and obscure points of law.

What, then, did Mann see in it? He clasps his hands and furrows his already knotted brow. "I thought the story was less about big tobacco," he says, "than the effect on your life when someone decides to go after you, though in this case it was a large corporation rather than a gunslinger. Way back in Thief, you had James Caan getting into these mob-sponsored heists, and when he wants out, the don says he can't; he, the don, now owns the paper on this guy's life. That's also what you have here; the company owns the paper on Wigand, and is trying to destroy him, completely legally. It's brutal, and it's terribly dramatic."

Mann locates the film in paranoid political thriller territory; a kind of sweatier-palmed All the President's Men, with Pacino's Bergman standing in for Woodward & Bernstein. It's one of the few major Hollywood products of recent years that's actually about something - morality, conscience, culpability - and which also has the temerity to prod American apathy in the face of corporate condescension.

Given that it's also a drama about credibility - Can Bergman trust the insular and tormented Wigand? Can Wigand trust the story-fixated Bergman? Can anyone trust 60 Minutes not to bottle out? - some of the film's de facto participants have criticised Mann for being too close to Bergman, the one-time radical firmly ensconced among the New York media elite. Bergman acted as "consultant" on the movie, and, while Pacino forgoes his usual grandstanding theatrics, Mann admits that certain events have been re-jigged in Bergman's favour - while, for instance, Wallace is seen to capitulate at CBS's decision to kill the interview, it was actually he, and not Bergman as the film has it, who called Wigand to break the traumatic news.

Mann concedes that "there may be something" in these criticisms. "I've known Lowell for a long time, and he would occasionally bring me stories. In fact, we started thinking about a movie based on this arms merchant in Marbella that he knew. Then he began living through the Wigand thing, and it was my idea to do this film rather than his. You know, Lowell's integrity as a journalist is a function of his accuracy and his refusal to compromise, and that doesn't make for a real pleasant guy to be around sometimes. He's not real negotiable, and he can be a little irritating. We may have skimped on the irritation, but I was introduced to him by someone in law enforcement, who said Lowell was one of the three journalists in America that he trusted, because of that integrity. He could have stayed at 60 Minutes and cut himself a good deal, but he's now freelance, because he didn't want to tell his next source: 'Hang with me, you'll be fine - maybe.' Comparatively, everyone around him is shameless."

It's safe to say that The Insider will not be on heavy rotation in Mike Wallace's home cinema - the veteran newsman has already informed the likes of the Los Angeles Times of his displeasure at scenes such as the one where he watches, rapt, a recording of one of his own interviews. "I respect Mike Wallace," Mann insists. "But a crisis like this throws what you're made of into high relief and, you know, even Mike Wallace makes mistakes, and guess what, there's nothing wrong with that. I think he doesn't like the film because it makes him seem too human; he has this idea of what his image ought to be which is very adamantine and two-dimensional.

"Actually," he continues, "the thinness of these people's skins surprised me. I was like, what, they never faced a little criticism? They stick cameras in people's faces every day for the last 32 years and they don't like the attention turned back on them."

More important, he says, was Wigand's reaction. "That was the real responsibility, because Jeffrey is complex and awkward, and we had to construct his character on all these disharmonious elements. Like, he loves his wife, but can't bring himself to say as much; there's a lot of dysfunctionality in him. He's a proud man, which I think is why he did what he did. "Brown and Williamson leaned on him like thugs, whereas if they'd finessed him, offered him a couple of hundred thousand dollars never to tell, I think they could have bought him. They challenged his dignity and his image of himself; they manufactured him to some degree. So the day of reckoning came when I screened the film for him; if he could say that that was how he felt, that the intensity of what he felt was captured, then that was my baseline. Same thing with Lowell. And they were both positive, which was gratifying. Because every other character is kind of secondary."

Maybe so, but nothing is extraneous in Mann-land; the director likes to refer to a movie's "genetic coding" - an all-embracing helix of image and sound, character and story, that fuses everything, from the way a character dabs sweat off his forehead to the lighting of a suburban street to the music on the soundtrack, into a seamless whole. This exacting scrutiny elevates the pulpy, noirish elements of his material into something more elemental.

Can you think of South Beach without thinking of the pastel slacks, avant-garde vehicles and skittish Harold Faltermeyer soundtrack Mann layered over it in Miami Vice? Can you hear In-a-Gadda-da-Vida without recalling the bleached-out, brutalist architecture of Manhunter and running to bolt the doors? The Insider's visual architecture is fittingly dense; blizzards of coded messages racing through buzzing networks, and portentous decisions taken in claustrophobic boardrooms (though they're not smoke-filled; this could be the most conspicuously cigarette-free movie about the tobacco industry yet made).

"Everything in a film is a part of the whole and acts on it, every colour, every object," Mann enthuses. "You've got to get it right. To research this film, Al and I hung with reporters from Time magazine, and spent time inside a news operation: ABC, actually," - he smiles wryly - "to imbibe that excitement, the way they'll put tapes on the air in minutes and field their worldwide correspondents on conference calls. And I had Russell do chemistry experiments," he chortles.

Mann and his actors are a mutual admiration society. Crowe, in particular, respects his bravery, both in his refusal to glamourise the truth, putting all Wigand's ambivalence up on screen - "We're programmed to accept the guy in the white hat as the hero and the guy in the black hat as the villain," he says, "and that's just not the reality of the human condition" - and his creative approach to casting.

At an initial meeting, Crowe was painfully aware that he was a 34-year-old Australian reading for the part of a 52-year-old American; on telling Mann that he thought it was a waste of time, the director stared at him, before leaning forward and jabbing his finger into the actor's chest, saying: "I'm talking to you because of what you've got in here." For his part, Mann is modest. "I've got tremendous respect for actors," he says, "but I don't know if that's unusual among directors, because I don't know how any other director operates. But no, I love actors; they produce incredible stuff."

Actresses, however, are a thornier question. Mann has been castigated for relegating his female characters to anaemic secondary roles - usually that of Frustrated Wife, as played by Ashley Judd to Robert De Niro in Heat, and Diane Venora to Crowe in The Insider - particularly when there are few directors as good at catching the seesawing rhythms of male-female intimacy.

Perhaps it's a legacy of his upbringing in The Patch, one of the roughest areas of Chicago, which he describes as "very aggressive, very masculine and very heterosexual" (Mann has a certain Norman Mailer-esque academic pugilist feel about him); or his penchant for guy milieux, from the Chicago PD of Crime Story to the wild frontier of Last of the Mohicans. A mooted future project, a biopic of Howard Hughes starring Leonardo DiCaprio, is unlikely to redress the gender imbalance. "I just go with things that consume my interest," he shrugs. "It's not something I even think about."
