fields.bodyText: There's a scene midway through Michael Mann's new movie The Insider where would-be whistleblower Jeffrey Wigand, played as a sombre obsessive-compulsive by Russell Crowe, is walking around a lawn, locked in internal debate as to whether or not he should testify that his former employers, tobacco giant Brown & Williamson, knowingly added cancer-causing chemicals to its cigarettes. Attorneys and police look on; the atmosphere is hushed; the tension excruciating. Eventually, Wigand walks up to his confidante, 60 Minutes producer Lowell Bergman (played by Al Pacino), and says simply: "Let's go to court". This, in many ways, is a quintessential Michael Mann moment, as heartstopping as any death-defying Die Hard or Bond stunt. It's also a perfect illustration of the singular genre that Mann has carved out for himself - the cerebral action movie. True, he's as adept at choreographing bullet ballets as any number of John Woos - those who cowered and flinched through the protracted heist in Heat will testify to that. But the key scene in that movie was the verbal face-off between Robert De Niro's career criminal and Al Pacino's driven cop; two men painted into opposite but complementary corners by the force of their passions and their determination to pursue them, at whatever cost. Mann has been called a "hard-boiled sensualist", a sort of feng-shui'd Hemingway, and the term could equally apply to any of his anti-heroes, from James Caan's high-class burglar in 1981's Thief; through William Petersen's empathic detective in Manhunter, Mann's 1986 take on Thomas Harris's Red Dragon; to the cigarette-industry deep throat Wigand. Though, as Mann says in his throaty Chicago rasp, "Jeffrey has to be the most confused and unclear character I've ever worked with." The Insider is based on the real events sparked when Wigand, former head of research and development at Brown & Williamson, violated the confidentiality clause in his severance agreement by going public with his knowledge of the carcinogenic properties of B&W's products to Bergman; Bergman then put his devastating testimony on tape in an interview with 60 Minutes' silky anchor Mike Wallace (played with brilliantined brio by Christopher Plummer). However, by the time the segment was due to air, Wigand had become a central witness in the lawsuits filed by Mississippi and 49 other states against the tobacco industry, and his marriage had fallen apart in the face of intimidation and threats of imprisonment from his former employers; at the 11th hour, CBS, fearing litigation, decided to pull the interview, to Bergman's dismay and Wigand's disgust. Eventually, the opprobrium heaped on the network forced them to backtrack, but not before Bergman had resigned, Wigand had succumbed to a near-breakdown, and 60 Minutes' vaunted journalistic ethics were left in tatters. It's far from a classic two-line Hollywood pitch: a Vanity Fair article on the case ran to 24 pages, and was filled with arcane references to tobacco industry practice and obscure points of law. What, then, did Mann see in it? He clasps his hands and furrows his already knotted brow. "I thought the story was less about big tobacco," he says, "than the effect on your life when someone decides to go after you, though in this case it was a large corporation rather than a gunslinger. Way back in Thief, you had James Caan getting into these mob-sponsored heists, and when he wants out, the don says he can't; he, the don, now owns the paper on this guy's life. That's also what you have here; the company owns the paper on Wigand, and is trying to destroy him, completely legally. It's brutal, and it's terribly dramatic." Mann locates the film in paranoid political thriller territory; a kind of sweatier-palmed All the President's Men, with Pacino's Bergman standing in for Woodward & Bernstein. It's one of the few major Hollywood products of recent years that's actually about something - morality, conscience, culpability - and which also has the temerity to prod American apathy in the face of corporate condescension. Given that it's also a drama about credibility - Can Bergman trust the insular and tormented Wigand? Can Wigand trust the story-fixated Bergman? Can anyone trust 60 Minutes not to bottle out? - some of the film's de facto participants have criticised Mann for being too close to Bergman, the one-time radical firmly ensconced among the New York media elite. Bergman acted as "consultant" on the movie, and, while Pacino forgoes his usual grandstanding theatrics, Mann admits that certain events have been re-jigged in Bergman's favour - while, for instance, Wallace is seen to capitulate at CBS's decision to kill the interview, it was actually he, and not Bergman as the film has it, who called Wigand to break the traumatic news. Mann concedes that "there may be something" in these criticisms. "I've known Lowell for a long time, and he would occasionally bring me stories. In fact, we started thinking about a movie based on this arms merchant in Marbella that he knew. Then he began living through the Wigand thing, and it was my idea to do this film rather than his. You know, Lowell's integrity as a journalist is a function of his accuracy and his refusal to compromise, and that doesn't make for a real pleasant guy to be around sometimes. He's not real negotiable, and he can be a little irritating. We may have skimped on the irritation, but I was introduced to him by someone in law enforcement, who said Lowell was one of the three journalists in America that he trusted, because of that integrity. He could have stayed at 60 Minutes and cut himself a good deal, but he's now freelance, because he didn't want to tell his next source: 'Hang with me, you'll be fine - maybe.' Comparatively, everyone around him is shameless." It's safe to say that The Insider will not be on heavy rotation in Mike Wallace's home cinema - the veteran newsman has already informed the likes of the Los Angeles Times of his displeasure at scenes such as the one where he watches, rapt, a recording of one of his own interviews. "I respect Mike Wallace," Mann insists. "But a crisis like this throws what you're made of into high relief and, you know, even Mike Wallace makes mistakes, and guess what, there's nothing wrong with that. I think he doesn't like the film because it makes him seem too human; he has this idea of what his image ought to be which is very adamantine and two-dimensional. "Actually," he continues, "the thinness of these people's skins surprised me. I was like, what, they never faced a little criticism? They stick cameras in people's faces every day for the last 32 years and they don't like the attention turned back on them." More important, he says, was Wigand's reaction. "That was the real responsibility, because Jeffrey is complex and awkward, and we had to construct his character on all these disharmonious elements. Like, he loves his wife, but can't bring himself to say as much; there's a lot of dysfunctionality in him. He's a proud man, which I think is why he did what he did. "Brown and Williamson leaned on him like thugs, whereas if they'd finessed him, offered him a couple of hundred thousand dollars never to tell, I think they could have bought him. They challenged his dignity and his image of himself; they manufactured him to some degree. So the day of reckoning came when I screened the film for him; if he could say that that was how he felt, that the intensity of what he felt was captured, then that was my baseline. Same thing with Lowell. And they were both positive, which was gratifying. Because every other character is kind of secondary." Maybe so, but nothing is extraneous in Mann-land; the director likes to refer to a movie's "genetic coding" - an all-embracing helix of image and sound, character and story, that fuses everything, from the way a character dabs sweat off his forehead to the lighting of a suburban street to the music on the soundtrack, into a seamless whole. This exacting scrutiny elevates the pulpy, noirish elements of his material into something more elemental. Can you think of South Beach without thinking of the pastel slacks, avant-garde vehicles and skittish Harold Faltermeyer soundtrack Mann layered over it in Miami Vice? Can you hear In-a-Gadda-da-Vida without recalling the bleached-out, brutalist architecture of Manhunter and running to bolt the doors? The Insider's visual architecture is fittingly dense; blizzards of coded messages racing through buzzing networks, and portentous decisions taken in claustrophobic boardrooms (though they're not smoke-filled; this could be the most conspicuously cigarette-free movie about the tobacco industry yet made). "Everything in a film is a part of the whole and acts on it, every colour, every object," Mann enthuses. "You've got to get it right. To research this film, Al and I hung with reporters from Time magazine, and spent time inside a news operation: ABC, actually," - he smiles wryly - "to imbibe that excitement, the way they'll put tapes on the air in minutes and field their worldwide correspondents on conference calls. And I had Russell do chemistry experiments," he chortles. Mann and his actors are a mutual admiration society. Crowe, in particular, respects his bravery, both in his refusal to glamourise the truth, putting all Wigand's ambivalence up on screen - "We're programmed to accept the guy in the white hat as the hero and the guy in the black hat as the villain," he says, "and that's just not the reality of the human condition" - and his creative approach to casting. At an initial meeting, Crowe was painfully aware that he was a 34-year-old Australian reading for the part of a 52-year-old American; on telling Mann that he thought it was a waste of time, the director stared at him, before leaning forward and jabbing his finger into the actor's chest, saying: "I'm talking to you because of what you've got in here." For his part, Mann is modest. "I've got tremendous respect for actors," he says, "but I don't know if that's unusual among directors, because I don't know how any other director operates. But no, I love actors; they produce incredible stuff." Actresses, however, are a thornier question. Mann has been castigated for relegating his female characters to anaemic secondary roles - usually that of Frustrated Wife, as played by Ashley Judd to Robert De Niro in Heat, and Diane Venora to Crowe in The Insider - particularly when there are few directors as good at catching the seesawing rhythms of male-female intimacy. Perhaps it's a legacy of his upbringing in The Patch, one of the roughest areas of Chicago, which he describes as "very aggressive, very masculine and very heterosexual" (Mann has a certain Norman Mailer-esque academic pugilist feel about him); or his penchant for guy milieux, from the Chicago PD of Crime Story to the wild frontier of Last of the Mohicans. A mooted future project, a biopic of Howard Hughes starring Leonardo DiCaprio, is unlikely to redress the gender imbalance. "I just go with things that consume my interest," he shrugs. "It's not something I even think about." Whoever's peopling them, however, there's no denying the power of Mann's movies; now that the US tobacco industry is on its knees - the state lawsuits were eventually settled for $246bn, and others are pending - does he feel vindicated? "This was never about getting the tobacco industry," he says, a little testily. "This was about telling the very human story of these guys caught up in extraordinary circumstances. fields.headline: Got it maid
fields.standfirst: Can Luc Besson's $60m historical epic Joan of Arc succeed where previous versions have failed? Michael Atkinson on the most ambitious attempt yet to export the appeal of France's national icon
fields.trailText: Can Luc Besson's $60m historical epic Joan of Arc succeed where previous versions have failed? Michael Atkinson on the most ambitious attempt yet to export the appeal of France's national icon
fields.body:
It's not hard to see why movie-makers are periodically drawn to the story of Joan of Arc. There have been, by our count, 18 Joan films (starting in 1899) - probably more than there are about all the other saints combined. (And it's not for lack of thrills and dramatic punch. Pick up a History of the Saints some day, and you'll get a faceful of persecutions, executions, miracles, heroism and medieval intrigue.) St Bernadette has had a few shots at matinee infamy (and won an Oscar for Jennifer Jones), St Therese had a low-grade moment or two in the projector beam, and the apostles have played second banana in scores of Christ films.

But in terms of pure allure, generational cool, sex appeal, bloodshed and merciless injustice, the Maid rules. Luc Besson's new Joan of Arc movie is simply the most visually hellzapoppin of the saintly subgenre, and the frankest when it comes to many of Joan's more puzzling aspects. As in, how could she have been canonised after she'd engineered and spearheaded so many episodes of limb-hacking warfare? Not to mention, as Joan's own conscience asks, why would God touch down and grace her for France's benefit?

The Joan story is as familiar to us as Gérard Depardieu's nose, but for some reason no Joan film has asked these questions before. Most famously, Joan was a beatific martyr (in Carl Dreyer's still-great 1928 film The Passion of Joan of Arc); as a fiery pre-feminist battling the masculine ramparts (a little-too-long-in-the-tooth Ingrid Bergman in 1948's Joan of Arc), and a teenager in way over her head (Jean Seberg in Preminger's 1957 bungling of Shaw's Saint Joan).

In each, Catholic ardour was a given, as was Joan's righteousness. Besson updates the scenario considerably and withholds any inkling of inherent spirituality and saintliness: he gives Joan a motive (the sister Joan may or may not have had is killed and raped, in that order, in front of her). He makes the battles hurt; he makes her heavenly visions subjective and palpable; and he ends up trying to settle the big questions once and for all by presenting Joan as a ranting, fiery-eyed zealot.

After all, having visions can only mean two things: you're touched by God, or you're as daft as a shithouse rat. But we'll never know for sure what happened, how she was motivated, why the armies followed her, whether she was indeed mad. Besson's answers, despite all the Sturm und Drang , are hardly satisfying (though Milla Jovovich's hyperventilating performance remains startling and convincing). The problem might lie in the Joan story itself. Despite a flow of dramatic incident that would shame Stephen King, Joan's saga builds to a dead end, and if the crisis isn't spiritual (and here Catholic readers may leave us), it amounts to power run amok, piles of corpses, court betrayals and a final auto da fé. In Besson's movie, Joan is simply a runaway bus, and it takes an awfully long time for her to crash.

Biopics often run into this dilemma - nobody would film the life of Christ or Frances Farmer or Buddy Holly or Michael Collins or Malcolm X or Andy Kaufman or whomever - unless it ended with a crucifixion of one kind or another. Thus, we know going in that a brick wall is in the offing, and we're headed straight toward it. Joan lived hard, died young and left a bad-looking corpse, which is the required arc of all pop biography. (Had Elvis died young, there would be a helluva lot more than a puny handful of TV movies about his life.)

This formula is all fine and good, but also predictable - each of these martyr stories is, essentially, the same - and, finally, questionable: is tragic death the only justification we need to erect another pious narrative monument to Fate, Injustice and Humanity? Is that all a life needs to become a movie-story? More to the point, Joan seems to fascinate film-makers in directly inverse proportion to how much she fascinates audiences. In France, of course, she has humongous cachet, but elsewhere she's just a French-fried waif with a celestial twinkle in her eye. From a film producer's point of view, the hope that Besson's movie would fly in the US was foolhardy. All Joan films have been, outside of France, box-office stinkers. The American ones stank everywhere. (Poor Jean Seberg never recovered from the derision her debut garnered.)

As a figure emblematic of French history and culture, Joan is unique; but since when did figures emblematic of French history and culture mean much to the rest of the world? (You must wonder, in addition, if the French recognise the irony of identifying with a 500-year-old warrior virgin either plagued by Christian fanaticism or old-school lunacy, or both.) Her story is indisputably juicy, but does it mean anything? Is it just another Middle Ages freak tale? (Take St Edmund Arrowsmith who, after renouncing an incestuous marriage, was named to the anti-Catholic British government as a priest, and was drawn and quartered for his trouble. Or St Wenceslas, an evangelising Slavic duke murdered by his own throne-hungry brother. Both of which, incidentally, have been forgotten by their nations, and neither of which has been portrayed in a single movie.)

The popular opinion about French culture in the US, at least, falls into two categories: who cares; and who cares less. French movies are of little interest except for remakes; the market for foreign films in general has all but dissolved into the ether. French films - the reigning fashion in the 60s and 70s thanks to Godard, Truffaut and co - are in even less demand now than movies made in Belgium. English-speaking readers in the US have as much use for French authors as they do for French pop music. If you ask the average American to locate France on a map, you'd probably get pointed toward Moldova. Not that this is to his or her credit, God knows, but it certainly is a question the producers of Joan of Arc might have asked before writing out that deep-eight-figure check.

Not that Joan of Arc is even, by any strict definition, a French movie. Besson is the most spectacular current task-master of the "international film", which has come a long way since David Lean took over Saudi Arabia with British actors for a year. Lawrence of Arabia was indisputably a British movie, but what is The Fifth Element? A Metal Hurlant -derived piece of nuttiness strangely, hypnotically, peopled with American actors, most conspicuously Bruce Willis with a gay bleach job. Besson's sci-fi epic had more French money in it than American. It was in every other way as French as garlicked snails, and while it made money everywhere, the freakiness of the thing did not go unnoticed. (That long interlude featuring the opera-singing blue octopus lady wasn't what most Texans expected to see in a Bruce Willis sci-fi movie.) Joan is just as scrambled: a French movie about a sacred French subject, with American, Russian and French actors, spoken in English. Who is Besson making the film for, exactly?

Everyone and therefore no one, of course, just as his countryman Jean-Jacques Annaud has made a number of his "international" epics (The Bear, The Lover) without original soundtracks, all the better to be dubbed into every market. (It's a prevalent casualty of the pan-European film industries; there is no version of, say, Bertolucci's 1900 in which Robert De Niro, Gérard Depardieu and Stefania Sandrelli are all speaking with their own voices.) One cannot imagine the French appreciating the fact that most of the key roles in this newest and most lavish Joan movie have to be dubbed into French.

Besson's movies (think La Femme Nikita and Léon, too) aren't French, and they're not quite wannabe-Hollywood, either. They're a lost hybrid, a prototype for a global commodity, designed to answer the entertainment needs of the whole planet. (Joan, seen this way, is even more of an uneasy choice of subject.) By the same token, the fact that Hollywood depends upon export markets for 50% of its profits has deracinated and homogenised its product as well. In the future, movies may have no country of origin and reflect no culture with integrity. Outfitted with cultural specifications from around the globe, they will have the featureless universality and acultural accessibility of rubber balls. (Or the Big Mac.)

The irony of the matter is that film once naturally had a universal accessibility - before talkies. Silent films needed to switch only the title cards as they travelled from culture to culture. Otherwise, it was a matter of people and cinematic fluency, which is in its essence universal. In their desperate bid for commerce, the world's overgrown film industries are trying to return to the womb. Compare Besson's new film with Dreyer's old one; while the former struggles to sell its iconography to a world that's not buying, the latter tells us a simple, graceful truth we'll always need to hear.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Austin Powers: The spy who shagged me | 10 Things I Hate about You | Dark Star
fields.trailText: Austin Powers: The spy who shagged me | 10 Things I Hate about You | Dark Star
fields.body:
Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me Rental and DVD (£24.99) Entertainment in Video Cert 12 ***

Agent 00-behave returns in his Shaguar and achieves the world domination Dr Evil craves - at the box office. As before, Mike Myers's spoof of a spoof is awash with bad puns, movie parodies and huge affection for all things 60s and silly. In addition to the return of his early Kinks outfit, Myers dons a lard suit in his third incarnation, Fat Bastard. This is one of many instances of familiar Brit humour - did Alexei Sayle and Paul Gascoigne forget to copyright the phrase? - which will be as novel to Americans as the word "shag". There's even "dirty pillows" (Sid the Sexist circa 1990).

It's as scattershot as a Comic Strip spoof, and as scatalogical as a Carry On: his tent sketch could have graced Carry On Camping. The film dismisses the 70s and 80s in a phrase: "There's a gas shortage and a Flock of Seagulls and that's about it."

So what's different from Powers 1? Less jokes against British dentistry and a lot less Liz Hurley - whose replacement Heather Graham is always a plus - and the addition of Mini-Me, the miniature clone Dr Evil lives with in his inactive volcano - a new rival to Scott Evil, the "Diet Coke of evil" according to his dad. This is a natural next stage for dictators bent on world domination: expect a Mini-Alex Ferguson on the touchline by April.

As before, the painstakingly groovy dance sequences are often the funniest parts. Myers throws in a Berkeley-style swimming pool number too. But it's worrying, since Powers 2's huge success demands further sequels, that jokes are already repeating. There's another strategically-obscured nude sequence for Myers to display his Ryan Giggs chest-wig and the penis gag leading up to a celebrity cameo is funny once, but not twice in the same movie. And the product placement is shockingly blatant. Powersophiles will find lots of extras on the DVD as Myers, co-writer Michael McCullers and director Jay Roach talk you through the movie and point out things you may have missed - like the Hollywood hills visible at the end of swinging Carnaby Street.

10 Things I Hate About You Rental and DVD (£15.99) Buena Vista Cert 12 ****

It's so unfair. Our teens are supposed to make do with Human Traffic, Hollyoaks and boy bands while the US equivalent keeps getting these sparky, fast-moving , classics subversively updated for slaves of the high school and mall. 10 Things is set in a Seattle suburb called Padua, in which Patrick Verona is bribed to go out with the "heinous bitch" Kat Stratford after Dad decides her younger sister can't date until she does. If that isn't enough verbal nudges for you, it's The Taming of the Shrew 90s-style, slyly mixing bits of original text ("I burn, I pine, I perish") with teenspeak: "Put her in your spank bank. Move on." And why not? Shakespeare nicked all his plots. It's deftly done by two female writers and director Gil Junger, a TV regular on Ellen. The only cast member you might know is Joseph Gordon-Levitt from 3rd Rock From the Sun, but the one we're bound to see again is Julia Stiles, who creates a surprisingly touching Kat and is back on the Shakespeare beat as Ophelia in Hamlet this year.

A title to bring a smile to anyone familiar with John Carpenter's 1974 space oddity in which four hippie lookalikes of the Fast Show's Dr Denzil Dexter, their cryogenically-frozen commander and their space pet (a beachball with claws) float around space destroying unstable planets ("Don't give me any of that intelligent life stuff, find me something I can blow up"). fields.headline: Limbo
fields.standfirst: Xan Brooks picks John Sayle's solid and weighty tale of Alaskan lives in the balance for his film of the week
fields.trailText: Xan Brooks A tough, honest and unadorned little enterprise. Some thrills, few frills
fields.body:
"Welcome to America's last frontier," brays the tourist-brochure voice-over at the start of Limbo, John Sayles's solid, weighty tale of Alaskan lives in the balance. To your left lie the fish canneries, to your right the forlorn marquee on its gravelly bit of beach. The natives boast beards and 'tashes, and tattooed arms inside chambray shirts, while the local saloon is full of little men telling the tallest of tales. This, then, is Sayles's Alaska: the final frontier, the end of the West, but just another stop along the director's career-long journey through the collective American experience.

The great truism of Westward expansion is that the original pioneers ran away from the past as much as towards the future, and kept going until the continent simply fell away into the sea. Two centuries on, not much seems to have changed. The inhabitants of Limbo come across as a sort of Alaskan Foreign Legion. They're here to start afresh, to put their past behind them.

Take country and western singer Donna De Angelo (Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio), fleeing a string of duff relationships with her troubled teenage daughter (Vanessa Martinez) in tow. Or shy handyman Joe Gastineau (Sayles regular David Strathairn), who gave up his fisherman gig after a tragic accident 20-odd years before.

Their shifting, three-pointed relationship (mum, daughter, interloper) opens up in the scrubby town of Juneau. But Alaska is a land of wilderness; of mountains and forest and rocky islands stalked by grizzly bears. It's only a matter of time before Limbo trudges out to find it.

In its second half, Sayles' film moves from coarse-grained social snapshot to tense thriller to a Swiss Family Robinson-esque drama about an fledgling family adrift in the great outdoors. It gives us three pictures for the price of one

Not that Limbo is ever quite as mercurial, playful or dashing as this might suggest. In a career that began script-writing for schlock producer Roger Corman, Sayles has turned his hand to a variety of stories in a myriad of genres. He's worked on alligator films, cockroach films, sci-fi pictures and Oirish fairytales. Yet at heart the man remains a sober and high-minded social chronicler: John Steinbeck with a dose of Bruce Springsteen. His most accomplished films (City of Hope, Lone Star) map out American tensions with a painstaking attention to detail, but with little in the way of filmic frivolity. Limbo, likewise, can seem a shade stiff and earnest at times, its cumbersome liberal agenda dragging behind.

What loosens Limbo up is the undeniable authenticity of Sayles's vision (all framed by Haskell Wexler's ice-chip cinematography), plus some startlingly red-blooded acting from the two leads. Mastrantonio's bright, brittle singer moves as if her shoes are on too tight. Meantime, Strathairn's brilliantly subtle, soulful performance turns his odd-jobbing hero into a man choked by a perpetual low-lying grief.

Most crucially, the director saves the best 'til last. His Limbo bows out with a devastating coup-de-grace - a cruel, dangling ending that sends you out of the cinema in a funk of mixed emotions. Does it mean triumph or disaster? The lady or the tiger? With this audacious finale, Sayles belatedly embroiders his worn-leather portrait with a sudden rash of colour. Elsewhere, this is a tough, honest and unadorned little enterprise. Some thrills, few frills.

fields.headline: Strange Planet
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw A deeply so-so relationship/ensemble movie
fields.body:
Strange Planet is a deeply so-so relationship/ensemble movie from Australia about three guys, Ewan, Joel and Neil, and three girls, Judy, Alice and Sally, who have hang-ups and problems and issues with relationships - older men, commitment, letting go, opening up - all of which are dissected and picked over with ersatz humour, with the exception of Sally's Sapphic experiments, which are met with odd, blank silence. (But she gets on the heterosexual straight and narrow by the end.)

Strange Planet does not resemble TV's Friends so much as those icky little instant coffee sponsorship micro-scenes that top and tail each episode, the ones where the guy cheers his girlfriend up by hanging a spoon from the end of his nose.

fields.headline: Music of the Heart
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw It browbeats us with good intentions and parades wooden performances from real-life classical music stars
fields.body:
Meryl Streep's Undead Career continues to be a mystery and now she's in Music of the Heart, directed by, of all people, Wes "Scream" Craven, unblushingly playing the same age as her co-star, Aidan Quinn. Like Michelle Pfeiffer recently in Dangerous Minds, Streep is a white teacher lady wading into the ghetto, inspiring the black and Latino kids to make something of their lives, teaching them violin, while coping feistily with a troubled private life.

The movie, based on an inspirational true story, is structured around the emotional climaxes provided by two or three increasingly important concerts, like a concatenation of two or three TV episodes of Fame.

Naturally, the socio-economic situation of her pupils is a problem - one of them fails to show up for rehearsal on account of having been popped in a drive-by - but the poverty seems notably less pressing as the story proceeds and Meryl's class thrives, some scholars being driven up in quite nice automobiles. Is this because a successful state facility will start attracting the middle classes? Anyway, I fear this picture browbeats us with good intentions and parades wooden performances from real-life classical music stars.

fields.headline: Rancid Aluminium
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw A terrible mess this film succeeds in getting its cast - some of the brightest and best of British character actors - to give the worst performances imaginable
fields.body:
Rancid Aluminium is a terrible mess from first-time feature director Ed Thomas, with a screenplay by James Hawes adapted from his own bestselling novel.

It's about a young guy Pete (Rhys Ifans) and his dodgy accountant mate Deeny (Joseph Fiennes), who, to save their failing London business, get involved with the Russian mafia. This film succeeds in getting its cast - some of the brightest and best of British character actors, young and old - to give the worst performances imaginable.

Joseph Fiennes does a one-eyebrow-raised smirk, with a bad Irish accent. Tara Fitzgerald plays a beautiful Russian woman whose accent veers wildly around and appears, at some stages, to be dubbed. The plot is all over the place, eventually incomprehensible, and very, very boring. The film-makers clearly have not the slightest interest in how the Russian mafia really look or behave, remaining content with a silly, uninteresting vodka-commercial caricature. This film wastes a lot of talent.

fields.headline: Stigmata
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw A queasy, cacophonous sub-MTV ordeal
fields.body:
Patricia Arquette is Frankie, a funky young hairdresser - whose parlour does tattoos - who goes out with her way cool buddies to clubs where they toast each other with phrases like: "Hey! Here's to Friday night!" But then she gets these really gross bleeding wounds in, like, her wrists and feet and stuff and that's a bummer.

Such is the narrative burden of Stigmata, a supernatural thriller also starring Gabriel Byrne as the deeply concerned Father Andrew Kiernan, the Vatican's phenomenon investigator, dressed in severe black, occasionally removing his dog-collar to disclose a manly glimpse of neck, and sometimes sporting rather spiffy designer spectacles.

Frankie's a woman and, hey, why shouldn't women be distinguished in this way? But she's also an atheist who appears to have attained these marks of especial grace by accident, and Stigmata doesn't bother rustling up anything in the way of a spiritual journey for Frankie, as she thrashes around her apartment, hollering and spraying blood from the relevant orifices. Sitting through this queasy, cacophonous sub-MTV ordeal will certainly teach you the meaning of suffering.

fields.headline: Limbo
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw An intriguing winter's tale of a film with sympathetic, credible performances this lingers in the mind long after the final credits
fields.body:
John Sayles's new picture, Limbo, is an intriguing winter's tale of a film with sympathetic, credible performances from David Strathairn and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio. They are ex-fisherman Joe Gastineau, and lounge singer Donna De Angelo, in a Godforsaken no-horse town in Alaska, who are thrown together through loneliness and a troubled past, and whose fledgling relationship is re-railed by an extraordinary fate into a dramatic, even melodramatic situation, which it would be unsporting to reveal.

Compared to the hyper-real sunniness of much American cinema - when it isn't ostentatiously raining or snowing, that is - the cold, clear, everyday cloud cover of Sayles's film-making here is a tonic. The light and the grain of his movie has the unassuming feel of ordinariness, like a documentary about fictional characters: so when a big star moseys into shot, as Kris Kristofferson does here playing the sinister local dude Smilin' Jack, Sayles allows us access through the celebrity mask.

And it means that when Sayles dextrously guides the movie into the realms of thriller, it is all the more plausible and compelling. It must be said that the ending of Limbo is a disappointment, but this is a film which lingers in the mind long after the final credits.

fields.headline: Scarlet Street
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A racy melodrama of corruption and falsityÉ dashingly presented by Fritz Lang
fields.body:
A racy melodrama of corruption and falsity, Fritz Lang's 1945 noir drama Scarlet Street appears in a new print, minus 30 seconds (apparently not recoverable) cut by the British censor, showing an innocent man being dragged screaming to the electric chair. Edward G Robinson plays Chris Cross, a humble bank cashier and amateur painter, who, after a company dinner, is overwhelmed with envy by the illicit sight of his wealthy boss, dallying with a beautiful mistress. He then conceives an amour fou for droll femme fatale Kitty (the excellent Joan Bennett), who, along with her violent boyfriend, Johnny, cons him for almost every penny - without ever letting him into her bed.

Robinson's cowed performance, with his strange, leonine, almost womanish face, is a wonderful mask of clenched yearning. The manipulation, erotic obsession and vulgar bad faith of this world is dashingly presented by Fritz Lang. Also, Dudley Nicholas's screenplay crackles. "You wouldn't know love if it hit ya in the face!" declaims Kitty to her room-mate. "If that's where it hits ya, you oughtta know!" she replies. Later, Kitty purrs to poor would-be artist Chris: "Paint me, Chris" and points to her toenails with the varnish brush, " ... they'll be masterpieces ... "

fields.headline: Robo flop
fields.standfirst: Robin Williams plays a robot who becomes human in his latest comedy. Peter Bradshaw   says enough is enough
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The time has come to admit the truth: Robin Williams is the Antichrist of sentimental screen comedy
fields.body:
Followers of the career of Mr Robin Williams - and the stunned and traumatised professional witnesses in the cinema auditorium - have detected no obvious lack of self-esteem in the great man. Each of his recent comedic offerings has, in its own distinctively spine-chilling way, been remarkable. There was Patch Adams, in which Mr Williams suggested that gravely ill children can be cured by the healing power of laughter. Then there was Jakob the Liar, a sort of Mork-in-Auschwitz turn from Robin, about how the Jews in the Polish ghetto awaiting deportation to the death camps were able to keep their peckers up on account of Mr Williams's gregarious flights of iridescent fancy - rather than, say, because of their religious faith.

Now, with his comedy Bicentennial Man, Robin has topped everything. He's gone one shattering step beyond. When the house lights came up at the end, the audience I was in just sat there, slack-jawed with silent horror, like the man in Edvard Munch's The Scream. I am virtually having to write this on an IV drip. Because Robin plays a cute android robot - that face dismayingly recognisable, though cased in metal - serving as a household butler in the year 2005, in whom manufacturing blips have induced lovely, quirky human character traits that make this cyber-Jeeves simply adorable. But he lives for ever, being a robot, and has to see all the people he loves, and who love him, grow old and die. This makes him real sad.

Eventually, at the end of 200 long, long years, Robin has gained a sleek, realistic ultra hi-tech latex face and the great-granddaughter of his original owner falls in love with him, and just for her, Robin has a quasi-human corporeal obsolescence hard-wired into him so that, wrinkled and snowy-haired at last, they can shuffle off this mortal coil together on a his'n'hers death bed. That's right, everyone. He renounces his immortality for humanity: for you and me .

The time has come to admit the truth: Robin Williams is the Antichrist of sentimental screen comedy. At the beginning of the picture, it all seemed so modest, just a little household drama. Sam Neill unveils this tin helpmeet to his suspicious family, and Robin starts clanking hilariously around, his limbs making those hydraulic whirring noises as he puckishly questions authority. The brattish daughter com mands him to throw himself out of an upstairs window; he instantly obeys, and then comes back in through the front door - but his motor functions are all screwed up! This is the cue for a bravura display of unfunny robotic acting from Robin: eyes blinking out of synch, jerking round, buzzy voice. It's a masterclass in being supremely irritating.

A word about Robin's metal facial expressions. Basically, these denotations of sweetness, compassion, sorrow, and impish mischief, are all achieved by having his metal eyebrows arch quizzically upwards. This is unfortunate because it actually has the effect of underscoring how robotic Robin's expressions are in reality.

As time goes on, Robin the sweetly non-paranoid android is allowed to make money making and selling wooden handicrafts, and then wants to buy his freedom from the master of the house. This is met primarily with gruff refusal, and perhaps it is some tiny unexpected restraint which stops director Chris Columbus putting a tin whistle rendition of Dixie on the soundtrack here. But, eventually, he's allowed his freedom, because the grown-up children shout things like: "He's every bit as complex as we are!"

The real moment of horror arrives when technical innovations mean that Robin, who has hitherto had only a smooth Action Man-type groin, is allowed to be a "com plete" man. So he is allowed to get it on with Portia, his one true love. In the afterglow of robot-human love-making, they lie in one another's arms, and Robin farts, and they both giggle, babes in the post-coital wood. It is the kind of heart-warming, life-affirming moment that made me want to put my fist in my mouth and bite it off. (The mechanics of sex are shrouded in mystery, incidentally: Robin has gastric juices to digest food, so he presumably has other juices, with the usual consequences. A sort of Bride of Chucky situation? One very much hopes not.)

And, all the while, 200 years go by, with no obvious historical upheavals such as war or plague, just futuristic cars whizzing over tall buildings in establishing shots. So Robin bestrides time and fate like a colossus, transcending the human condition, only to make a magnificent gesture for love.

What next for Robin Williams? Perhaps, with a large moustache, he could be Friedrich Nietzsche, sobbing and embracing that horse in the final scene with many an acid quip. Or maybe he could portray Stephen Hawking's tragic decline from walking stick to motorised wheelchair, that uproarious routine buzzing out of the voicebox, using laughter as a solvent for the unified field theory. But I have a horrible feeling that great, mobile lantern-jawed face will not come seraphically to rest until it is framed by a crown of thorns.

When the house lights came up at the end, the audience I was in just sat there, slack-jawed with silent horror, like the man in Edvard Munch's The Scream. I am virtually having to write this on an IV drip. Because Robin plays a cute android robot - that face dismayingly recognisable, though cased in metal - serving as a household butler in the year 2005, in whom manufacturing blips have induced lovely, quirky human character traits that make this cyber-Jeeves simply adorable. But he lives for ever, being a robot, and has to see all the people he loves, and who love him, grow old and die. This makes him real sad. Eventually, at the end of 200 long, long years, Robin has gained a sleek, realistic ultra hi-tech latex face and the great-granddaughter of his original owner falls in love with him, and just for her, Robin has a quasi-human corporeal obsolescence hard-wired into him so that, wrinkled and snowy-haired at last, they can shuffle off this mortal coil together on a his'n'hers death bed. That's right, everyone. He renounces his immortality for humanity: for you and me . The time has come to admit the truth: Robin Williams is the Antichrist of sentimental screen comedy. At the beginning of the picture, it all seemed so modest, just a little household drama. Sam Neill unveils this tin helpmeet to his suspicious family, and Robin starts clanking hilariously around, his limbs making those hydraulic whirring noises as he puckishly questions authority. The brattish daughter com mands him to throw himself out of an upstairs window; he instantly obeys, and then comes back in through the front door - but his motor functions are all screwed up! This is the cue for a bravura display of unfunny robotic acting from Robin: eyes blinking out of synch, jerking round, buzzy voice. It's a masterclass in being supremely irritating. A word about Robin's metal facial expressions. Basically, these denotations of sweetness, compassion, sorrow, and impish mischief, are all achieved by having his metal eyebrows arch quizzically upwards. This is unfortunate because it actually has the effect of underscoring how robotic Robin's expressions are in reality. As time goes on, Robin the sweetly non-paranoid android is allowed to make money making and selling wooden handicrafts, and then wants to buy his freedom from the master of the house. This is met primarily with gruff refusal, and perhaps it is some tiny unexpected restraint which stops director Chris Columbus putting a tin whistle rendition of Dixie on the soundtrack here. But, eventually, he's allowed his freedom, because the grown-up children shout things like: "He's every bit as complex as we are!" The real moment of horror arrives when technical innovations mean that Robin, who has hitherto had only a smooth Action Man-type groin, is allowed to be a "com plete" man. So he is allowed to get it on with Portia, his one true love. In the afterglow of robot-human love-making, they lie in one another's arms, and Robin farts, and they both giggle, babes in the post-coital wood. It is the kind of heart-warming, life-affirming moment that made me want to put my fist in my mouth and bite it off. (The mechanics of sex are shrouded in mystery, incidentally: Robin has gastric juices to digest food, so he presumably has other juices, with the usual consequences. A sort of Bride of Chucky situation? One very much hopes not.) And, all the while, 200 years go by, with no obvious historical upheavals such as war or plague, just futuristic cars whizzing over tall buildings in establishing shots. So Robin bestrides time and fate like a colossus, transcending the human condition, only to make a magnificent gesture for love. What next for Robin Williams? Perhaps, with a large moustache, he could be Friedrich Nietzsche, sobbing and embracing that horse in the final scene with many an acid quip. Or maybe he could portray Stephen Hawking's tragic decline from walking stick to motorised wheelchair, that uproarious routine buzzing out of the voicebox, using laughter as a solvent for the unified field theory. But I have a horrible feeling that great, mobile lantern-jawed face will not come seraphically to rest until it is framed by a crown of thorns.

fields.headline: 'I think anger's a good thing'
fields.standfirst: The combative Douglas Henshall goes back to his roots in Fast Food. He talks to Libby Brooks
fields.trailText: The combative Douglas Henshall goes back to his roots in Fast Food
fields.body:
Charisma is too wee a word for it: his is a vertiginous presence. There is a violence about him that changes the quality of the air. He's not acting. Douglas Henshall is stormy weather.

After a decade of notable stage work, it is in the last 12 months that the 32-year-old Scot has enjoyed mainstream success. But if you've watched him you'll remember that luminous energy. When he's out of shot you miss him like a lover.

It was his year of screen in 1999. He was with Kathy Burke and Jennifer Ehle in David Kane's Camden-set comedy of sexual manners This Year's Love and starred in Peter Mullan's award-winning Orphans as Michael Flynn, one of four siblings embarking on a night of destruction and redemption.

On the small screen, he made distinctive contributions to two of Channel 4's flagship drama series, playing the mercurial Dr Danny Nash in Psychos, set in a Glasgow psychiatric ward, and in Tony Marchant's Kid in the Corner, as the father of a child with severe behavioural problems.

Today he looks like a hero. The suit fits. Fresh back from Warsaw, where he is filming Channel 4's Anna Karenina, in which he plays the Tolstoy alter ego Levin, his broad features and fierce eyes are all but obscured by a sooty flame beard. His pale red hair is probably softer than it looks.

When he tells a story, his whole body animates. His hands were made for sweeping glasses off tables. "I tell you what, I had a fab night..." Two Polish bit-parters on Anna Karenina had taken him along to their drama school show. "It was a smashing thing to go and see, because drama school in this country is such a microcosm of the business itself, really nasty and bitter and backbiting, but there it was really supportive. It touched me, just the warmth and respect they had for what they did."

His own recollections of drama school are clear of rosy tint. More by accident than design, Henshall ended up at Mountview college in north London, after originally applying for courses in journalism and then art in Scotland. He was disappointed by the petty jealousies of the people there, he says. It taught him what not to expect. "And also that I wasn't as bad as I thought I was."

After six months of industry indifference following graduation, he headed north again, broke and unemployed. Following a stint with Glasgow-based touring company 7:84, he returned to London, basing himself in Brixton, where he earned a redoubtable reputation for his stage work.

At the Royal Shakespeare Company, he says, there were "great plays, two directors I wanted to kill". He describes the RSC as "a cross between an ivory tower and a sausage factory. I went up there with great aspirations and it's nothing like that. Bring 'em in, roll 'em out, directors who have been there too long and are too comfortable, or are purely there trying to make a name for themselves, which is no bad thing so long as its not at the expense of everything else."

He prefers company work on films, he says. "You get your joiners, your electricians, your painters, folk from the whole social spectrum, and I like going in every day and just being a member of the crew. I like the feeling that we're all working towards the same thing."

That acting is his deep passion is palpable. Talking about his stage work, the vowels become rounder, as though they were almost too huge for his mouth. "When you've got an audience, there's a silence in there that you don't find anywhere else. And it's really powerful. People are there listening with you and you're affecting them in some way." That passion for engagement, and the energy, confidence and control that it demands mark him as an actor.

The son of a salesman and a nurse, Henshall grew up in Barrhead, south of Glasgow. "Where I was brought up, if you were walking down the street and you looked at someone and they looked at you, you acknowledged them. I used to do that when I came down here and people would look at me like I'd just got out of somewhere. I hated losing that and now when I get back up to Scotland it takes me a couple of weeks before I stop being a wanker." Why didn't he stay? "Because I didn't want to be in Barrhead for the rest of my life; nothing against the place but it was just limiting." The words explode in a torrent.

There are two kinds of Scot, those of us who stay and those of us who leave. Henshall's is no heart-tugging tale of the lad o' pairts who departed the kailyard to toil and triumph before the southern footlights. It is about the size of the dreams your childhood gives you.

Like many who refuse to subscribe to the notion of incorporeal, mythologised "Scottishness", he doesn't believe in a national identity.

"I do believe in my national identity. I'm very proud," he stresses, "of what I come from and where I come from, and there are values up there that I like and that I hold on to: loyalty I suppose, and a sense of humour, and a lack of self pity. I've thought about being Scottish a lot since I left. I still find this incredible racism - you open up the [Evening] Standard or the Daily Mail on any given day and if you put black or Jewish there'd be a public outcry but because it's Scottish, it's OK." Does it make you angry? "Yeah. But then I think anger's a good thing." It depends how you use it, I suggest. "I put it in my work." he says lightly.

His voice is the most beautiful thing about him. It is surprising like a landscape, it rolls from heathery to heinous in the same phrase. Henshall does not take kindly to having his personality interrogated. I am used to that peculiarly Glaswegian combativeness in conversation - I grew up with it. But with Henshall there is something more that is difficult to describe, although the things that make him angry - ego, stupidity, lack of imagination, most of my questions - are fairly easy to enumerate. It's not about power. Honesty can be violent. When he engages, it's like electricity in its focus and immediacy. When he doesn't, it's like a cuff round the ear.

Henshall's latest cinematic excursion is the low-budget fable Fast Food. He plays Benny - "someone who's doing his best" - who returns to his childhood stamping ground and becomes embroiled in thuggery and thwarted redemptions. Henshall took the role on the strength of the screenplay and one meeting with director and writer Stewart Sugg. It's a revealing choice. "There's something about Dougie that's very raw and very personal," Sugg says. "He has a deep-thinking side to him and when you look at him, there is an anger. He likes to look for answers, he likes to be challenged, and he really engages with you. That's unusual in a person and even more unusual in an actor."

"Raw" isn't always a compliment: there is a subtext of out-of-control. But those who have worked with him praise his professionalism to the skies. Screenwriter Simon Ings remembers Henshall recording the over-dubbed soundtrack to a short film: "He had absolute control over his voice, like a singer. He would change a single inflection and it would be the right one. He's very economical."

Raw is also about where he comes from. Over the past five years, there has been a growing metropolitan media interest in an alleged "new breed" of young Scottish actor. "With Shallow Grave people realised that you could set a film in Scotland and it didn't have to be about leaky boats in the Highlands," he explains. "Then Trainspotting made it fashionable. But then you started seeing actors not because of fashion, because they're great. Look at Peter Mullan - fucking fantastic."

Henshall first acted with Mullan in 1990 when William Boyd directed the pair in an acclaimed double-hander based on the Ted Hughes poem Crow at Glasgow's Tron theatre. Now associate director of the RSC, Boyd remembers Henshall as "Very quick, very sharp, very brave and very confident. Outrageously confident. He knows the effect he's creating."

But ask Henshall about "the Scotpack" and you'll be lucky to finish the question uninterrupted. "That's just a divisive thing made up by the media. It used to be Tim Roth, Gary Oldman, Dan Day-Lewis were called the Brit pack, then suddenly because they weren't all English any more they became the Jock pack, or the Taff pack, or the Mick pack. I've always wondered 'Where's the Sassenach pack?' or are there just not enough of them around to make one?"

How much of it is an accent thing? "How much of it is a class thing?" he counters. "Scottish accents are still rough hewn beasts down here. I grew up watching EastEnders and Coronation Street and I never had a problem understanding a Manchester accent or a Geordie accent. I always thought it was my job to and if you're not quite catching it, then you listen harder," he spits. "Whereas people down here say 'oh sorry can't understand it', and it's not my fault, it's your fault. But people always seem to understand 'Go fuck yourself', they understand that really easily." He leans forward. He's menacing.

But there remains an expectation that Scottish actors are somehow edgier? "That's a generalisation." He sighs. "I can't believe you think that." I don't think it, I'm putting it to you. "Well, I don't think it for the same reasons as you don't. Why would you be edgier because you're Scottish? Fuck 'em. I don't care." He could sound defeated, but he's not.

There is a line in Mel Gibson's faux-Scots folly Braveheart that really rankles this man. It's the moment when William Wallace is rallying his troops, telling them that even if they don't beat the English, they can accept defeat with dignity. "It's not good enough to win, you have to lose well," he mocks. Douglas Henshall, you win.

 Fast Food is released on January 28.

fields.headline: Scorsese epic signals Italian renaissance
fields.standfirst: After three decades of staging spaghetti westerns, Rome's Hollywood on the Tiber lands latest diCaprio blockbuster
fields.trailText: Director Martin Scorsese, actor Leonardo diCaprio and a fist full of dollars will cross the Atlantic to film an epic which Italy hopes will rekindle the glamour, glory and clout of what used to be called the Hollywood on the Tiber.
fields.body:
Director Martin Scorsese, actor Leonardo diCaprio and a fist full of dollars will cross the Atlantic to film an epic which Italy hopes will rekindle the glamour, glory and clout of what used to be called the Hollywood on the Tiber.

Cinecitta, a vast Mussolini-built studio in Rome that became Europe's film capital on the back of classics such as Cleopatra, Ben-Hur and La Dolce Vita, has clinched a deal which could herald a second golden age.

Veteran set designers who seemed consigned to film folklore are preparing to recreate miles of 1840-era New York slums in a giant construction project the scale of which has not been seen since Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor trekked through an artificial Nile valley for Cleopatra.

Scorsese will direct and heart-throb diCaprio will star in the $85m epic, The Gangs of New York, which will also star Willem Dafoe. It will be an injection of star-power, cash and confidence that the recovering Italian film industry hopes will fuel a renaissance.

The privatisation of Cinecitta and the amending of tax laws that chased away film-makers in the past have coincided with Hollywood's quest for cheap, foreign locations.

Dante Ferretti, the Oscar-nominated cinematographer, said yesterday that pre-production will start in March and the 22-week shoot will start in June.

Conceived by the dictator, Benito Mussolini, as a vehicle for fascist propaganda, Cinecitta was built in 475 days, inaugurated in 1937 and reborn after the war as the cradle of Europe's best talent.

"It is wonderful news. This could be the turning point not just for Cinecitta but for Italian cinema," said Tony Villani, film professor at the American University of Rome. "By coming here, Scorsese has sent out the message that Italy is okay again."

The 243-hectare (600-acre) site off Via Tuscolana, east of Rome's Appian Way, nurtured directors and producers such as Federico Fellini, Pier Paolo Pasolini, Carlo Ponti and Dino De Laurentis. But unfavourable tax and employment laws punctured the bubble and Cinecitta shrunk to 12 hectares (30 acres) as it descended into three decades of spaghetti westerns, television films and soap operas.

However, the centre-left government, elected in 1996, declared itself a friend of film and introduced reforms, which are now reaping benefits. "Italian film-making is beginning to pick up. This has come at just the right time," said Prof Villani.

Sylvester Stallone's decision to film sequences of the thriller Daylight in Rome emboldened others, said Antonio More, a studio manager.

But, despite the fillip, Hollywood's famed attention to detail has not neglected that ingredient of all recent blockbusters: the lawsuit. Alberto Grimaldi, an Italian impressario, has filed for $10m in damages against Universal Studios and Disney for allegedly stealing his idea.

webTitle: The long walk to box-office freedom

fields.headline: The long walk to box-office freedom
fields.trailText: The long walk to box-office freedom
fields.body:
As a public holiday, Martin Luther King Day gets treated like a second-class citizen. Half the states in the old Confederacy ignore it altogether, and so do many employers, or at least many white employers. I've spent MLK Day at home only once in the last nine years - and that was because the 1994 Northridge Earthquake demolished my office (remember when the school got bombed in Hope and Glory? This was better).

Similarly, every major city has a street named Martin Luther King, Jr. Boulevard, but you - and the people who have to live there - wouldn't want to walk down it after dark. And next month, February - the Tuesday of the year - is Black History Month. As any black comedian worth their salt will point out: "February - the shortest month. Same old shit."

So it's encouraging to report that the star, screenwriter and producer of this week's straight-outta-nowhere chart-topper, Next Friday, is Compton's own Doughboy, ex-Nigga With Attitude and rapper Ice Cube. Cube once opened one of his solo albums with a dramatisation of himself being strapped into the electric chair. Just before he gets juiced, the Man asks if he has anything to say before he's dispatched into the hereafter. I imagine Cube reading last weekend's box-office figures, raising a glass and saying exactly the same words: "Yeah. Fuck alla y'all!"

No one expected this last Friday, that's for sure. Next Friday is the sequel to the middling hit Friday, which cleaned up a couple of years ago, especially on video. Neither of them exactly got rave reviews, but then again its intended audience, junior high school kids, is one that rarely if ever genuflects in the general direction of Pauline Kael, so big deal on that score. Next Friday is genially dirty-minded fun, following the laid-back Craig (Cube) as he moves from South Central to the white suburbs to live with his lottery-winning uncle and cousin, and to get away from the bad guy from Friday, who's now out of jail and in a vengeful mood.

Ice Cube is settling comfortably into dual roles as an actor. On the one hand he appears in big budget movies as a mid-cast character actor (last time I saw him he was getting squeezed to death in Anaconda), and on the other he finances, stars in and even directs small, amiable movies likely to make a quick return if marketed right, particularly to the young urban audiences who already know him through his albums. This one made $17m on a minuscule $9.5m outlay - how's that for black economic self-determination?

Cube also directed The Players Club last year and Next Friday's success may encourage him further in that direction. fields.headline: Labour's arms scandal
fields.standfirst: It's not just Hawks, it's the failure to implement Scott's recommendations
fields.trailText: The expression of scholarly frustration this week by Sir Richard Scott, the high court judge who conducted the arms to Iraq inquiry, that one of the principal recommendations of his wide ranging and exhaustive examination of that scandal had not yet been implemented, is both timely and embarrassing.
fields.body:
The expression of scholarly frustration this week by Sir Richard Scott, the high court judge who conducted the arms to Iraq inquiry, that one of the principal recommendations of his wide ranging and exhaustive examination of that scandal had not yet been implemented, is both timely and embarrassing.

Timely because it reminds us that it is only four years since he concluded that parliament had been misled over the reckless supply of equipment to Saddam Hussein, and embarrassing because it reminds the Labour party, which reaped such a rich harvest from the debacle, that the pledges of opposition have not been followed by the actions of government.

It is worth reminding ourselves what the judge actually said. Readers whose copy of his report is still in the basement (as mine was until Sunday evening) need only refer to Section K 2.1 at page 1759, but for those who don't have that opportunity Sir Richard said that a comprehensive review of the power of government over arms exports was "long overdue" and that the provisions contained in the import, export and customs powers (defence) act of 1939 were "based on wartime emergency legislation lacking the provisions for parliamentary supervision and control that would be expected and are requisite in a modern parliamentary democracy".

What could be clearer? The law needs to be changed. And what could be a more pressing invitation to a party dedicated to "new Britain" to do it?

What a modern parliamentary democracy requires is access to information and the power of scrutiny, for citizen and MP alike, and some control over what we export and to whom. Legislation, it is claimed, is in preparation, but in this the last full parliamentary session before the widely expected general election of spring 2001 there is no place for it. And if by some miracle a bill were to be published, who is prepared to bet that the currently opaque regime of controls would be clarified and the impotence of parliament replaced by real influence?

But is there any legitimate reason why we should not, in the aftermath of the Scott inquiry, have legislation that allows us to examine a public register which contains details in plain language of what has been sent and to which destinations?

Is there any legitimate reason why there should not be a House of Commons select committee with the express responsibility to keep arms export policy under review and with the power to monitor individual applications?

If we can trust, as we now do, Tom King and Alan Beith to keep tabs on MI6 and MI5 and GCHQ, could we not find similarly well-disposed members of the Commons to watch over the business of dealing in arms and arms related equipment?

Transparency, scrutiny and accountability are not enemies of government, they should be its allies in the sometimes murky world of arms dealing. Without such openness how does Sir Richard Scott's modern parliamentary democracy inform itself of the tension between the ministry of defence and the DTI on one hand and the foreign office and the department of international development on the other which surfaced last week over the over hasty resumption of arms sales to Pakistan?

Is not the public entitled to know that the defence and trade secretaries have a different view from their cabinet colleagues at the foreign office and international development, and why? And should parliament not be given a full explanation as to why the decision was taken by the PM, apparently against the wishes of his foreign secretary, to approve the sale of Hawk jet parts to Zimbabwe despite their well-documented involvement in a conflict that has cost thousands of civilian lives? A modern parliamentary democracy should not have to rely on the leaking of internal memoranda to see where the balance of such arguments lies.

Is not parliament entitled to express a view and have influence over the decision to resume arms sales to Indonesia? If there was proper transparency, would the incoming Labour government ever have got itself into such embarrassment and caused such disappointment to its supporters over the supply of Hawk aircraft to Indonesia? Why should the public and MPs not know the nature of the legal advice that the government claimed did not permit the cancelling of the delivery of the remaining aircraft?

In arms exports, as in so many other areas of government, it is not the facts which are controversial but the means used to conceal them. Why has the Labour government not done anything to fulfil Sir Richard Scott's unambiguous recommendations? You may argue that a party which profited politically so much from arms to Iraq had a moral obligation to put things right as soon as it got the opportunity.

Menzies Campbell is Liberal Democrat MP for Fife North East

webTitle: Lords kill Straw's bill ending right to jury trial

fields.headline: Lords kill Straw's bill ending right to jury trial
fields.standfirst: Are your rights at risk? Find out here
fields.trailText: The "Hampstead liberals" last night took their revenge on Jack Straw when the House of Lords killed the home secretary's bill to abolish the right of more than 18,000 defendants a year to elect for jury trial.
fields.body:
The "Hampstead liberals" last night took their revenge on Jack Straw when the House of Lords killed the home secretary's bill to abolish the right of more than 18,000 defendants a year to elect for jury trial.

Although Tony Blair will today vent his anger at what he regards as the "profoundly undemocratic" action by the House of Lords, a unique coalition spanning the radical Labour human rights lawyer, Baroness Kennedy, Lord Jenkins and Baroness Thatcher last night buried Straw's plan which he himself once condemned as "wrong, short-sighted and likely to prove ineffective." The attorney general said they had put a "torpedo through the heart of the bill."

The home secretary who last week condemned his critics on the issue as "Hampstead liberals" confirmed that he was abandoning the bill after peers backed a cross-party amendment restoring the right to choose jury trial by 222 votes to 126, a majority of 96.

The scale of the defeat is all the more embarrassing for the home secretary because it is the first real test of voting strength since the "inbuilt" Tory majority was removed when the hereditary peers were expelled just before Christmas. It is the first time a government bill has been killed outright by the House of Lords since their defeats over Sunday trading more than 10 years ago.

"It is now crystal clear that a majority in the House of Lords is determined to prevent the elected House of Commons from making timely decisions on this measure. The present bill in the Lords will not be proceeded with," said Mr Straw before announcing his intention to try again with a criminal justice (mode of trial) no 2 bill later in the year and so setting up a constitutional battle with the new upper house.

After the vote it became clear that government ministers had been fully expecting the defeat raising speculation that the measure - which was never a central part of Labour's criminal justice plans - might be regarded as expendable in the battle over the future of the House of Lords.

The fact that it happened on the same day that the plans for reform of the upper chamber were published was claimed by ministers to be "a cock-up, not a conspiracy" but the strength of their determination to reintroduce the measure in the 18 months that remain before the general election will be questioned by their critics. The Tory party said an attempt to revive the plan would "create horror up and down the country."

A handful of Labour peers voted against the government, including Baroness Kennedy and Baroness Mallalieu, but only 126 out of 180 Labour peers turned out to support Jack Straw's measure. Baroness Kennedy made an impassioned plea during the debate saying while its aims in cutting delays and abuse were laudable she opposed it with "some pain in my heart because it will be socially divisive and discriminatory.

"It removes an important citizen's right and will reduce the number of jury trials. The magistrates will be put into the invidious position of having to pick and choose those who should be deemed worthy of the privilege of a jury trial. It is wrong in principle and this is why it is opposed by even those who are the friends of the government."

The former home secretary, Lord Jenkins of Hillhead, said he hoped Mr Straw would now take "less of a knee-jerk Daily Mail attitude to crime and punishment and then his reputation for humane sagacity might gleam a little more brightly before the end of the parliament."

webTitle: Lords torpedo wrecks Straw's jury bill

fields.headline: Lords torpedo wrecks Straw's jury bill
fields.standfirst: Are your rights at risk? Find out here
fields.trailText: A government bill was wrecked last night when the Lords voted by 222 to 126 to keep defendants' right to choose trial by jury. The vote came during debate on the criminal justice (mode of trial) bill, despite a warning from the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, who said the bill would be ruined if the rebel amendment was passed.
fields.body:
A government bill was wrecked last night when the Lords voted by 222 to 126 to keep defendants' right to choose trial by jury. The vote came during debate on the criminal justice (mode of trial) bill, despite a warning from the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, who said the bill would be ruined if the rebel amendment was passed.

"This isn't really a wrecking amendment - it's a torpedo amendment and there's nothing left of the bill ... if this amendment is passed there's nothing left at all at this stage."

He insisted he himself would have been unable to support the bill if it did not include a right of appeal. But he shared the "overwhelming, virtually unanimous view" of the judiciary that it was a "proportionate outcome in difficult circumstances".

He urged peers to consider the issue "in a way that is unencumbered by professional, social and historical baggage".

Opponents of the change were operating on the "unspoken, insidious basis" that magistrates courts automatically provided lower quality justice, he declared.

But the foremost Labour critic of the bill, Lady Kennedy, told peers: "This bill is wrong. It's wrong in principle and that is why it is opposed even by those who are friends of the government."

The Conservative home affairs spokesman, Lord Cope of Berkeley , opening the debate, argued that the partly reformed House of Lords, comprising appointed peers and elected hereditaries, had the authority to vote down the bill.

Lord Cope, a life peer and former MP, added: "Perhaps in due course there will be a different second chamber in the United Kingdom. Meanwhile we must do our duty for which we were selected, and each of us must decide the issue and vote accordingly."

Lord Jenkins of Hillhead attacked the home secretary for claiming the Liberal Democrat peer had endorsed the ending of trial by jury.

He said Mr Straw had "called in aid" the 1967 criminal justice act - which brought in majority verdicts for criminal trials - that Lord Jenkins piloted through parliament when home secretary in the Wilson government.

That was done because trials were being undermined by the growing practice of criminals targeting the most "vulnerable or amenable" members of a jury in order to ensure there was no unanimous verdict, Lord Jenkins told peers. "I cannot allow, I'm afraid, Jack Straw to claim my endorsement for this ill-conceived little bill so directly contradictory to everything which he and his spokesmen said in opposition," he said. "I utterly reject the view that this proposal is in any way the equivalent of my majority verdict proposals."

Mr Straw did not have much of a reputation as a liberal, Lord Jenkins noted.

But he added: "If he will accept the defeat of this measure ... with a good grace, if he will be less grudging on freedom of information, and if he will take less of a knee-jerk Daily Mail attitude to the whole complex issue of crime and punishment, then maybe by the end of this parliament his reputation for humane sagacity might begin to gleam a little bit more brightly."

Labour's Lord Lipsey said the case for the government's proposals was "overwhelming - not from a lawyerly perspective but from a wider perspective".

On the argument that "black people do not trust magistrates", Lord Lipsey said: "Some of them at least may opt for jury trial in the hope that they will get an OJ Simpson.

"What they hope is that there will be enough black jurors who are fundamentally hostile to the criminal justice system. In my view they will be disappointed in this because I think all black jurors are absolutely as fair as white jurors but I think there is a tendency to do that and I don't think we should encourage it."

Lady Kennedy accepted the need for more efficiency and cost effectiveness "while protecting the rights of defendants". Steps should be taken to crack down on abusers of the system - although Lady Kennedy questioned whether "they are in anything like the number being suggested".

"The aims I agree with are laudable. The reason I oppose this bill and the reason I have supported this amendment, which I did with some pain in my heart, is because I think it is an issue of principle.

"I believe that the impact of this bill will be socially divisive and discriminatory ... and I think it does remove an important citizen's right." It would reduce the number of jury trials which was "an awe-inspiring act of citizen participation".

Magistrates would be put in the "invidious" position of having to "pick and choose those deserving of trial, so that trial becomes a privilege".

Lady Kennedy suggested there were administrative changes that could be made to the legal system to produce the same result the government wanted from the bill. She said: "The reason why the amendment is put in this form is because we would have wanted to find another way but there is no other way. This bill is wrong. It's wrong in principle and that is why it is opposed even by those who are friends of the government."
