The reason I oppose this bill and the reason I have supported this amendment, which I did with some pain in my heart, is because I think it is an issue of principle. "I believe that the impact of this bill will be socially divisive and discriminatory ... and I think it does remove an important citizen's right." It would reduce the number of jury trials which was "an awe-inspiring act of citizen participation". Magistrates would be put in the "invidious" position of having to "pick and choose those deserving of trial, so that trial becomes a privilege". Lady Kennedy suggested there were administrative changes that could be made to the legal system to produce the same result the government wanted from the bill. She said: "The reason why the amendment is put in this form is because we would have wanted to find another way but there is no other way. This bill is wrong. It's wrong in principle and that is why it is opposed even by those who are friends of the government." Government's friends defy attorney general's warning Lord Jenkins "I cannot allow, I'm afraid, Jack Straw to claim my endorsement for this ill-conceived little bill so directly contradictory to everything which he and his spokesmen said in opposition." Lady Kennedy "I believe that the impact of this bill will be socially divisive and discriminatory ... and I think it does remove an important citizen's right." Lord Lipsey "Some of them[black defendants] at least may opt for jury trial in the hope that they will get an OJ Simpson. What they hope is that there will be enough black jurors who are fundamentally hostile to the criminal justice system. I think there is a tendency to do that and I don't think we should encourage it." Lord Williams "This isn't really a wrecking amendment - it's a torpedo amendment and there's nothing left of the bill ... if this amendment is passed"

fields.headline: Scientists patent cloning technique
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: The technology that led to the cloning Dolly the sheep has finally been awarded patents in Britain.
fields.body:
The technology that led to the cloning Dolly the sheep has finally been awarded patents in Britain.

The Geron corporation of California, which shares the licences on the cloning knowledge with the Roslin institute in Scotland, will work with British scientists in search of treatments for degenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and osteo-arthritis.

The inventors of Dolly - Ian Wilmut, Keith Campbell and other scientists at the Roslin institute - applied in 1995 for a patent on the new science that led to successful clones. Dolly, developed from the preserved udder cell of a dead mother-twin, was born late in 1996, but not announced until early 1997. Although her arrival was greeted with worldwide alarm about human cloning, the Dolly scientists intended cloning to advance medicine and the genetic engineering of animals for medical use.

Roslin, a not-for-profit laboratory working for the UK government, created a biotech start-up company called Roslin Bio-Med in 1998. Later that year, Geron announced that it had made a breakthrough in cultivating embryo stem cells - the "fount" of the 200 or so specialist cells of blood, bone, skin, liver, heart, brain and other tissues. Almost immediately, it was realised that cloning science and embryo stem cells could together open ways of treating hitherto untreatable human diseases - patients with faltering heart muscle or failing brain cells could have their own tissue grown in a laboratory dish and transplanted, bypassing all the problems of immune rejection. Geron and Roslin Bio-Med announced a merger early in 1999.

To go ahead, the scientists need to experiment with early stage human embryos, and with human eggs donated for IVF research. The US government has forbidden the use of federal funds for human cloning research. The UK government is considering the ethical problems and has yet to authorise the research. But Geron and the Roslin scientists could at last assure investors that the patent question was finally settled. UK patents were awarded, and the US patent office said it would follow suit.

The patents go jointly to Geron, Roslin, Britain's biotechnology and biological sciences research council, and the ministry of agriculture.

Yesterday there were immediate claims that the patents would hold up research, because of fears other researchers would have to pay to use the science.

Harry Griffin of the Roslin institute responded that the fears were unfounded: "The idea that this is holding up research is quite bizarre.

"We were able to publish this work as a result of patent applications having been submitted and everybody has said, 'we are going to try and clone animals' using the information.

"There is an exemption in patent law that allows people to conduct research using the information released. If it is directed towards commercial gain then we have exclusive rights to this particular part of cloning technology."

Simon Best, managing director of Geron Bio-Med in Scotland, said that patents gave investors security for what would be years of research. "It creates the pressures to make sure this technology is applied and developed.

"We have absolutely no desire not to see every possible application of this technology made use of."

webTitle: Calling Germany's Don Kohleone to account

fields.headline: Calling Germany's Don Kohleone to account
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor of unity failed his party, his country and his people

German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: There is a certain historical piquancy in watching the public disgrace of Helmut Kohl just a week after Egon Krenz, East Germany's last communist leader before the fall of the Berlin wall, started a prison term. Not that there is a direct parallel between the two men and their various wrongdoings, let alone between the political systems they represented. Rather it is that, in spite of their many differences, both are creatures of the same lost world. They are relics of a habitat which emerged at the end of the second world war, became set in concrete during the cold war and is now gone.
fields.body:
There is a certain historical piquancy in watching the public disgrace of Helmut Kohl just a week after Egon Krenz, East Germany's last communist leader before the fall of the Berlin wall, started a prison term. Not that there is a direct parallel between the two men and their various wrongdoings, let alone between the political systems they represented. Rather it is that, in spite of their many differences, both are creatures of the same lost world. They are relics of a habitat which emerged at the end of the second world war, became set in concrete during the cold war and is now gone.

Kohl liked to be known as the chancellor of unity. He saw himself as the man who overcame the cold war and re-united the German state, in the teeth of doubts from Margaret Thatcher and Francois Mitterrand, though with strong help from the Americans. Yet now, as the system which he incarnated begins to implode in a welter of evidence of secret donations and campaign slush funds, we may come to see him, more accurately, as a figure of the past just as much as Egon Krenz. Far from being the first chancellor of a united Germany, Kohl's enduring label in history may be as the last leader of the Bonn republic and the last chancellor of West Germany.

As the huge scandal unfolds some commentators in Germany are predicting that the party which Kohl led, the Christian Democratic Union, may be so damaged that it will split into a thousand pieces. They look to the fate of the CDU's sister party in Italy, which fell apart seven years ago under the weight of corruption. In the Italian case, the party was revealed to have taken cash for contracts in a mountainous tangle of kick-backs and influence-peddling, in some cases linked to the mafia.

The allegations surrounding the German CDU have not yet gone that far. The fact of secret donations to the party from wealthy businessmen is clear, but inquiries are under way into who made them and what, if any, the paybacks were. The tag of "Don Kohleone" which some are sticking on the former chancellor may turn out to be justified, but it is too early to be sure.

Already, though, two things stand out. In today's Europe parties with a religious or confessional identity at their core will have an increasingly hard time surviving. In its 50 years of existence the CDU has done too little to reform either its internal structures or the 1945-era ideology with which it began life. Like the Italian Christian Democrats, the CDU was cobbled together as a party of the centre right by the victorious western allies under Washington's leadership as an instrument to contain the threat of communism.

The German Social Democrats, by contrast, had a long pedigree from which to grow when democratic politics revived in 1945. So too did the Free Democrats, the heirs of the old pre-war liberal parties. But the CDU's line of descent from the Weimar Republic's largely Catholic Centre party was tenuous. When the allies plucked the elderly former mayor of Cologne, Konrad Adenauer, out of retirement to run the CDU and become West Germany's first chancellor, they were giving him a new machine with little institutional memory and few other cadres with a genuine anti-fascist past.

From the beginning the CDU was a party without a strong membership base, which relied on business donations for most of its finances. That remained the pattern to this day. The CDU's assigned task was to reintegrate Germany's Nazi-tainted corporate elite and tame the danger of nationalistic resentment in defeat, something which the right was thought more likely to be able to pull off. With the allies' help, Adenauer steered West Germany towards a revival of close ties with France as well as a totally new concept for Germany: subservient Atlanticism.

The underpinning was Adenauer's almost obsessive suspicion of Russia, his hatred of communism, and fear of "the east". In this, Helmut Kohl was always Adenauer's child. He was the last western politician to recognise Gorbachev's reforms were serious. When even Reagan was beginning to understand they were not just cosmetic, Kohl was calling Gorbachev, in a monumentally insensitive comparison, "a propagandist as good as Goebbels". In the last months before German unification, Kohl had to be pressed by the Americans to accept the post-1945 settlement of Poland's western frontier at the expense of ancient German territory in definitive treaty form. Otherwise Washington would not support his drive for unity.

The old instincts clung to Kohl. At a campaign rally in Rostock in the election of autumn 1994 I watched him in disbelief. While the rest of the world was preparing to celebrate a half century since the liberation from fascism, Kohl told his audience it would soon be 50 years since Russian forces broke through on to German territory in East Prussia "with all the terror and rapes that you know".

Just as the CDU began life and, as we now see, continued it on the basis of secret campaign donations Kohl the statesman, like Kohl the party manager, based his power on the use of money. If some of the undeclared funds went on building up CDU structures in East Germany, in a larger and more significant sense Kohl bought German unity. In the 80s he had already bought the East German leadership with a series of governmental loans, rightly suspecting that the flood of West German marks into the economy would create distortions and jealousies that would undermine what loyalty remained to the communist system.

In the spring of 1990 he bribed East German voters with the chance to change their Ostmarks for Westmarks at a rate of one to one, a policy of financial recklessness which shocked the then chairman of the Bundesbank and put a huge burden on West Germans. Later that year Kohl bought Gorbachev's assent to united Germany's membership in Nato by offering millions of marks to relocate Soviet troops back to Russia.

It was crude, and it worked. But Kohl failed to transcend this mechanical unification of Germany and create a mutually reconciled society in which East Germans would not feel they had been simply annexed. In the first pan-German poll of December 1990 the unity chancellor's CDU got a smaller share of the votes than at any election since 1949.

As time went on, his promise of "flourishing landscapes" in East Germany became increasingly hollow. Kohl was not the only West German to behave with arrogance towards the East, but he was the man in charge and deserves the blame. As CDU leader he failed to modernise his party's inner workings by finding new and transparent sources of finance just as, when chancellor, he failed to understand the social and psychological legacy of East Germany. On both issues he will be remembered as a prisoner of the past.

webTitle: Suicide of CDU official fuels Kohl scandal

fields.headline: Suicide of CDU official fuels Kohl scandal
fields.standfirst: German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: A member of Germany's crisis-torn Christian Democratic party committed sucide in his Berlin flat yesterday, injecting an element of tragedy into the deepening slush fund scandal surrounding the party's disgraced former chairman, ex-chancellor Helmut Kohl.
fields.body:
A member of Germany's crisis-torn Christian Democratic party committed sucide in his Berlin flat yesterday, injecting an element of tragedy into the deepening slush fund scandal surrounding the party's disgraced former chairman, ex-chancellor Helmut Kohl.

CDU officials named the dead man as Wolfgang Hüllen, 49, head of the parliamentary party's politically sensitive finance and budgetary office, and said his body was discovered yesterday morning. They said he had hanged himself.

"A letter was found next to him. It appears that the reasons for his decision to take his own life were personal," said the CDU spokesman, Joachim Hoerster. He declined to provide further details pending a police investigation.

But speculation was rife yesterday that as a CDU official in charge of the parliamentary party's budgetary and financial affairs, Hüllen was almost certainly privy to confidential information on party funding.

A party member for 28 years, Hüllen was thought to have known about an illicit DM1.15m (£370,000) transfer of funds from the CDU parliamentary party to the party proper in 1997, when Mr Kohl was chancellor.

The tragedy overshadowed efforts by the beleaguered Christian Democrats to apologise formally to parliament for the scandal surrounding Mr Kohl. The party leader, Wolfgang Schäuble, broke off a sitting of the Berlin parliament as soon as he received word of Hüllen's suicide.

Earlier, appearing bowed and guarded, Mr Schäuble conceded to the Bundestag that during the 16 years of Mr Kohl's tenure as chancellor the law was "quite obviously" broken through the party's system of illicit bank accounts.

"Trust in political parties and in the democratic institutions has been damaged," Mr Schäuble told the chamber, from which Mr Kohl was absent. "We will do everything possible to ensure that this cannot happen again."

The CDU leader's apologies failed to impress government MPs, who interrupted his speech with shouts and accusations.

"The Kohl system still has the CDU in its grip - because it is a system of the whole party. Many of you have still got to learn the difference between right and wrong," said the Greens' deputy party leader, Rezzo Schlauch.

The heated exchanges occurred as a parliamentary committee investigating the affair began its first session by circulating a list of prominent MPs and former government figures who will be called to give evidence. Although the list was not made public, committee members revealed that it included "virtually the whole of the government" during Mr Kohl's tenure.

Mr Kohl, who was forced to resign in disgrace from his post as honorary party chairman on Tuesday, is not expected to appear before the committee until later this year. Yesterday he reiterated his refusal to name the donors who illicitly funded the secret party accounts he set up during his 25 years as CDU chairman.

"I am the subject of a witch hunt," he told journalists who attempted to interview him outside his Berlin flat.

The "unification chancellor" has admitted taking up to DM2m in secret donations during the second half of the 1990s. Despite pressure from the CDU leadership to name the donors to his secret accounts, he has insisted that to do so would be a breach of confidence. "I will fight for my honour, and part of my honour is keeping my word," he said.

Speculation increased yesterday about the reasons for Mr Kohl's refusal. "Kohl has to explain why his word is more important to him than the oath he made on taking office. Otherwise he will continue to add credence to the suggestion that he is covering up criminal dealings," commented the influential newspaper Die Zeit.

Accountants investigating the party's finances will present their report to the CDU leadership at the weekend. Its initial findings have unearthed a further DM8m on the party's books whose origins cannot be accounted for.

This discrepancy was confirmed by the party's general secretary, Angela Merkel. "Until now, it has not been possible to establish where the money came from," she said.

In reports circulating yesterday, the accountants were said to have concluded that the CDU had functioned as a "money laundering" institution.

The discovery of the mystery DM8m followed the startling admission last week by the CDU in the west German state of Hesse that the party had for years run a secret Swiss bank account in which more than DM13m had been deposited in order to avoid tax.

On Monday the disclosure led to the resignation from politics of Mr Kohl's former interior minister, Manfred Kanther, the former party chairman in the state.

There was growing pressure yesterday on the Hesse state CDU government to resign and face fresh elections as a result of the revelations.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 If in the days ahead you see a letter on the opposite page from Valerie Shawcross, leader of Croydon council, attacking Ken Livingstone for questioning the quality and independence of Labour's GLA candidates, you may be sure no one put her up to it. You may - and then again you may not. An email to Valerie from her fellow GLA hopeful Trevor Phillips, Dobbo's deputy, finds its way to us. In it, Trevor asks her to attack Ken - something he does not want to do himself, "because it looks like pure self-interest" . . . so: "I suggest a letter to the Guardian or Observer." This should savage Ken for not showing respect to "people selected by ordinary party members" (ah yes, you can't beat OMOV, can you?), while Valerie might also suggest that Ken's mayoralty would be "a disaster for London". Trevor further points out that he wants this issue perceived as "mayor v assembly" rather than "Frank v Ken". Ooh, Trev, you amaze me! So let's hope Ken takes the message to heart and ceases questioning the fierce independence of these first-rate, Millbank-approved GLA candidates.

 The latest media triumph on Dobbo's website appears in a home page headline: "Financial Times endorses Frank Dobson for mayor." A glance at the leader in question suggests Dobbo is being a bit naughty, and that all the paper has said is that it prefers him to Ken as Labour candidate, and this its editor confirms. "It's not true at all that we've endorsed him for mayor," says Richard Lambert. "We haven't even thought about that yet." Poor show, Dobbo.

 Has there been a more diverting feud this century than Sun editor David Yelland's spat with the Mirror's Piers Morgan, now unquestionably New Labour's best boy in the media? On seeing Piers's letter here yesterday, we ring the pair to ask if they'd be interested in starring in a West End production of Neil Simon's the Sunshine Boys. David's manners desert him and he fails to call back (how often must I rebuke him for this?), but Piers says he'd like to try out for the George Burns role. Excellent. And your letter . . . we just want to check you had permission to send it from No 10? "Yes of course, I had it cleared by Alastair Campbell," says Piers. "When I get up in the morning I ring Alastair to find out if I should have tea or coffee." So we gather.

 The next time Alan Milburn visits his girlfriend Ruth's mother in Wakefield, he might do well to wear a false beard. The Yorkshire Post reports that Valerie Briel lives bang opposite Mavis Skeet, whose oesophageal cancer became inoperable while surgery to remove it was cancelled four times. Understandably, Mrs Briel declines to comment on this poignant geographical coincidence.

 In the Times, meanwhile, Anatole Kaletsky corrects Mr Tony's claim that raising NHS spending by 5% for six years would bring us into line with the EU average. In fact, it would take at least eight years to reach the average, 19 years to match France and 25 to equal German levels. It may be academic, Mr T having already downgraded the promise of an extra 5% to a hope, but if we're not careful with our figures people will think it's another of our whoppers.

 Poor at sums or not, there is no more supportive husband than Mr Tony. On Tuesday night, when Cherie was guest of honour at a dinner of the Chinese For Labour group at the New Hoo Wah restaurant in Chinatown, he found time to pop in with Alastair. It's true he only stayed for as long as it took the kitchens to prepare him a take-away, but it's the gesture that matters. As for any notion that he'd have stayed longer had Rupert Murdoch's missus Wendy Deng not failed to show up (despite having accepted an invite), I think we'll leave that to sneerers, whiners and whingers, shall we?

You may - and then again you may not. An email to Valerie from her fellow GLA hopeful Trevor Phillips, Dobbo's deputy, finds its way to us. In it, Trevor asks her to attack Ken - something he does not want to do himself, "because it looks like pure self-interest" . . . so: "I suggest a letter to the Guardian or Observer." fields.headline: Return of the natives
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: For the third time in three months, a local stalker has been called out to an injured roe deer. Population growth in roe is about 40-50% annually. Accidents are inevitably caused by vehicles, with traffic increasing on minor roads.
fields.body:
For the third time in three months, a local stalker has been called out to an injured roe deer. Population growth in roe is about 40-50% annually. Accidents are inevitably caused by vehicles, with traffic increasing on minor roads.

This week our postman reported a wounded yearling roe lying on a grass verge and when the local stalker went to dispatch it, he saw the doe hovering anxiously. The youngster had been following his mother who escaped over the dyke unscathed. Another call for help came when a local dog savaged a roe doe which was in a rape field, probably pregnant or sickly otherwise it would have outwitted the dog.

At this time of the year, roe deer are in mixed groups. During November and December, the bucks cast their horns and almost immediately new growth commences; this month they are carrying antlers encased in velvet. In spring the horn, inside its covering of hair and flesh, ceases to grow. The beast's head becomes irritated and to soothe the itch and remove the protective velvet, the animals thrash on young trees. Once the horn is clean, the antlers harden.

Roe are integral to this county. The alluvial beds of the river Tyne have provided, in the form of fossilised remains, evidence of their presence here in prehistoric times. Of course some landowners think roe are a pain in the neck. They damage young plantations, trample seeds and are partial to roses in country gardens. A family of roe deer can do a surprising amount of damage. In practice, it is difficult to eliminate the species from an area which they like.

Some years ago, plantations on this coast were severely disrupted by open cast coal mining. In collaboration with Northumberland Wildlife trust, with great sensitivity, devastated areas were restored. Five years later, the woods come back to life. In autumn, voles, stoats, weasels and even shrews rustled in fallen leaves. In late spring, the roe returned. At dusk a roe buck walked from the shelter of larches not 50 yards from me and began to clean the last shreds of velvet from his antlers against a sapling.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: • Donor : The founder of Netscape Communications , James Barksdale, and his wife, Sally, is giving $100m to help Mississippi children learn to read. Mr Barksdale now runs Barksdale Group, an investment firm.
fields.body:
 Donor : The founder of Netscape Communications , James Barksdale, and his wife, Sally, is giving $100m to help Mississippi children learn to read. Mr Barksdale now runs Barksdale Group, an investment firm.

 Buyer : Lexis-Nexis Europe, a subsidiary of Reed Elsevier , says it is to buy the business information product division of Financial Times Electronic Publishing from Pearson . The products, aimed at users of online business information, include FT Profile, FT Discovery and FT NewsWatch.

 Power bid : Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft , has announced that he holds a 5% interest in Avista, a provider of electricity and natural gas in the north-west United States. He did not disclose how much he had paid.

 Cell mates : GTE's wireless unit has selected InfoSpace.com , a provider of infrastructure services to websites, to provide wireless internet services for its cellphone users, InfoSpace.com said.

fields.headline: Flotation talk surrounds Arnault's Europ@web
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A senior executive of Bernard Arnault's 500m Euro internet investment vehicle, Europ@web, yesterday responded cautiously to reports that the company could be planning a stock market flotation, writes Mark Milner .
fields.body:
A senior executive of Bernard Arnault's 500m Euro internet investment vehicle, Europ@web, yesterday responded cautiously to reports that the company could be planning a stock market flotation, writes Mark Milner .

Chahram Becharat, Europ@web's managing director for European technology investments, said that as his firm was an investment company rather than a fund, "this is a question we can ask ourselves".

"Whether to become a public entity is something we have indicated as possible from the start but there is no specific news," he said.

Asked about whether an investment bank had been appointed to advise it on flotation, Mr Becharat said: "We have frequent conversations with many banks."

Europ@web was set up last year by Group Arnault, Mr Arnault's private holding company.

It has an extensive portfolio of investments in the US and Europe including 1-800-flowers, Boo.com, QXL.com and Icollector. It also has a joint venture, net service provider Libertysurf, with Britain's Kingfisher group, which is also reported to be coming to the market. Europ@web's 45% stake has been valued at £1bn in the business.

The growth in the internet investment industry was underlined yesterday when the French group, Alcatel, announced that it was setting up its own $150m (£91m) risk capital fund with a particular focus on the internet and advanced technology companies and start-ups.

webTitle: Guidelines may end infertility care bias

fields.headline: Guidelines may end infertility care bias
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Many more women could receive infertility treatment on the NHS if measures were taken to prevent triplet births, specialists said yesterday at the launch of new guidelines.
fields.body:
Many more women could receive infertility treatment on the NHS if measures were taken to prevent triplet births, specialists said yesterday at the launch of new guidelines.

At present, IVF (test tube baby) clinics replace up to three embryos in the woman's womb after fertilisation of her eggs with her partner's sperm takes place in the laboratory. The Royal College of Gynaecologists and Obstetricians said yesterday that this could be reduced to two without lessening most women's chances of a baby.

If the savings to the NHS were ploughed back into the IVF programme, some of the inequities in fertility treatment - which is available on the state in some areas but not others - could be removed.

Allan Templeton, secretary of the college, which has spent three years putting together the guidelines at the request of the department of health, said the changes would dramatically cut the unacceptably high multiple birth rate.

"Triplets cost the NHS nine times as much as a single or a twin birth. The financial, social and psychological impact on the parents is also very high and triplets have a considerably higher mortality and disability rate.

"The saving from reducing the triplet birth rate would pretty well pay for all the IVF treatment carried out in this country on the NHS at this time," he said.

One in seven couples in the UK have problems conceiving a child. Susan Rice, of the National Infertility Awareness Campaign , said it was "a national scandal" that some could get free treatment and others could not.

Not all fertility specialists agreed that it was right to restrict the number of embryos replaced to two. Ian Craft, who runs the private London Fertility Centre in Harley Street, believed women should be given a fertility score according to their age and other factors which made them likely to conceive triplets. This score would determine whether two embryos or even five should be replaced.

webTitle: Russian general falls into Chechen hands

fields.headline: Russian general falls into Chechen hands
fields.standfirst:
New pictures baring Grozny's devastation emerge as the battle for its centre rages on

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Chechen rebels claimed yesterday to have captured one of Russia's most powerful generals in charge of leading the assault on Grozny, inflicting an acute new humiliation on the struggling Russian army.
fields.body:
Chechen rebels claimed yesterday to have captured one of Russia's most powerful generals in charge of leading the assault on Grozny, inflicting an acute new humiliation on the struggling Russian army.

If confirmed, the capture of Major-General Mikhail Malofeyev will mark one of the gravest setbacks yet for the Russian campaign.

The general is said to have fallen into the hands of guerrillas as he led a reconnaissance trip into Grozny late on Tuesday.

Announcing the capture on a rebel television station, the Chechen warlord, Shamil Basayev, said Gen Malofeyev had been taken to a secret location outside the besieged capital where he was being questioned.

Military sources said last night that they did not know whether the general was alive or dead. Officials revealed that he had been wounded by sniper fire when his division was ambushed in the north-west of the capital, but said his subsequent fate was unknown; he has been classified missing in action and the army has already launched a search mission for him.

One of Russia's top 10 generals in Chechnya, Gen Malofeyev was the deputy commander of the northern front in Chechnya.

His disappearance came as Chechen rebels offered fierce resistance against the Russian onslaught on Grozny. New pictures emerging from the city show the true, graphic extent of the devastation caused by the battle for control of the city.

Bitter street fighting raged throughout the capital yesterday as Russian infantry advanced from several directions, struggling to drive out rebels from the city centre.

The fierce Russian ground attack was being backed by heavy artillery and Russian warplanes that bombarded the city centre.

A cloud of dust hung over the city as buildings crumbled into rubble beneath the onslaught, while Chechen and Russian fighters spent the day exchanging fire from neighbouring buildings in the north-west of Grozny.

Highly contradictory information has emerged about the success of the Russian advance; some Russian officers claimed that rebels were running out of ammunition and attempting to break out of the city, while other military sources said it was impossible even to inch forward under the heavy Chechen fire from rebel snipers, firing from positions high up in the buildings that were still standing.

Early reports that Russian forces had managed to seize the strategic and symbolically crucial landmark, Minutka Square, later proved unfounded, and guerrillas continued to be active in areas of the capital nominally under Russian control.

While Russia claimed to have taken several important tactical targets, the Chechen rebel spokesman, Movladi Udugov, indicated that Russian advances had been slight and losses huge.

Bislan Gantamirov, the commander of a pro-Moscow division of Chechen fighters, described yesterday's fighting as "extremely heavy" and reported that control of the city was in constant flux, with some areas frequently changing hands.

As many as 40,000 civilians, experiencing extremely restricted access to food or clean water, are believed to remain trapped inside the besieged capital. With aid agencies denied access and prevented from dispatching supplies through Russian lines into the capital, their plight remains severe.

After a day of intense fighting, both sides admitted unusually high casualty levels.

One Russian officer said that about 20 members of a single regiment had been killed overnight by rebels who had made their way through sewage tunnels to strike the conscripts from behind as they tried to advance through north-west Grozny.

Chechen rebel sources revealed that 45 guerrillas had been killed and 60 wounded in the latest assault on Grozny, far more than reported on one occasion since the fighting began in September.

The military is under increased pressure to seize the capital soon, in order to distract public attention from the mounting casualty levels, and also to ensure that some kind of victory can be announced to the electorate ahead of Russia's presidential elections on March 26.

Fighting also continued yesterday in the mountain re gions of Chechnya south of the capital.

With casualties among local residents reported to be high, elders from the village of Duba-Yurt yesterday pleaded with Russian officers for an end to the shelling.

Meanwhile, after a two-day fact-finding mission into human rights abuses in the region, a delegation from the Council of Europe urged Russia to call a ceasefire and to find a political solution to the conflict.

The resident of the council's parliamentary assembly, Lord Russell-Johnston, said Russia's suspension from the human rights body as a result of its offensive in Chechnya would be discussed in Strasbourg next week.

"We are not ready to recommend any such action as far as I know," Lord Russell-Johnston said. "But it is something which continues to be an option... while the fighting goes on."

webTitle: New generation of rebels steps up violence in Kashmir

fields.headline: New generation of rebels steps up violence in Kashmir
fields.standfirst:
Foreign Islamic militants prove to be tougher foes for the Indian army

The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: The falling snow mingled with hot, black ash. A choking, grey steam rose as shopkeepers dug through the rubble of 87 market stalls burned to the ground the night before.
fields.body:
The falling snow mingled with hot, black ash. A choking, grey steam rose as shopkeepers dug through the rubble of 87 market stalls burned to the ground the night before.

Residents and merchants in Pattan said Indian army troops had set fire to their market in anger after two soldiers were shot by guerrillas. The troops stopped fire engines from approaching for five hours, witnesses said. By the time the firefighters arrived, there was nothing left.

Thirteen people died recently in a bomb blast at a vegetable market in Srinagar, Kashmir's main city, 15 miles south-east of Pattan.

In Pattan, the rebels were targeting soldiers who came to buy food there. But once again, it was ordinary Kashmiris who bore the brunt of a ruthless war between Indian forces and separatist Islamic guerrillas.

Hardly a week goes by in the Kashmir valley without fresh violence. The body count rises almost daily.

Just six months ago, Indian authorities claimed they had vanquished the guerrilla movement. A decade of counter-insurgency campaigns had left most Kashmiri rebels dead or behind bars.

Today, a newly revived rebel movement has Indian forces on the defensive. It is better armed, better trained and more daring.

The operating methods of these new guerrillas are secretive and spectacular. In the past, armed squads would ambush military patrols or hurl grenades at police posts and run away. Now, they force their way into security facilities with guns blazing, seemingly prepared to die. Since November, they have attacked half a dozen security compounds in the region, leaving more than 50 people dead.

"For the first time in 10 years, the army is on the receiving end," said Tahir Mohideen, a newspaper editor.

Indian military officials say that now the rebels are mostly "foreigners" from Pakistan and other Muslim countries.

They belong to Islamic fundamentalist groups which aim not only to liberate Kashmir but to impose Islamic rule across the region.

The security forces have responded with a vengeance. Counter-insurgency troops raid villages and urban neighbourhoods daily. Military facilities are being fortified with extra barricades and weapons.

Popular anger against the Indian government is intensifying with incidents such as the burning of Pattan's market. And support for the guerrillas, however alien their origins and ideology, is spreading.

"This new militancy is very good for us," said Shabbir Dar, who owns a bakery in Srinagar. "We Kashmiris have been sitting in our houses for so long, feeling lost and afraid. But we all want our freedom. So we say, welcome Pakistanis, welcome Afghans, welcome Lebanese, welcome anyone who can help us."

Not everyone shares this enthusiasm. Political opposition leaders are uncomfortable about the "guest" rebels in their midst.

This is because of the guerrillas' radical Islamic agenda; because their aggressive tactics rob Kashmiris of their victim status; and because their Pakistani origins reinforce India's longstanding contention that Kashmir's independence movement is a tool of Pakistan.

"We are working on the same battle, and if someone says they want to help my cause, it's hard to object," said Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, a senior Muslim cleric in Srinagar and chairman of the main opposition party, the All Parties Hurriyet Conference.

But he added: "It has come as a shock. A Kashmiri would never have thought of attacking a security brigade. These people are willing to do anything. It's a fully-fledged war."

Indian military officials here insist that the new rebels cannot win against the 700,000 Indian troops in the region. They claim that most Kashmiris - who practice a moderate Islam - are repelled by the militants' violent tactics and radical agenda.

But while many Kashmiris are wary of the foreign guerrillas, their bitterness toward Indian forces appears to be far deeper.

 Washington Post

"We are working on the same battle, and if someone says they want to help my cause, it's hard to object," said Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, a senior Muslim cleric in Srinagar and chairman of the main opposition party, the All Parties Hurriyet Conference. But he added: "It has come as a shock. A Kashmiri would never have thought of attacking a security brigade. These people are willing to do anything. It's a fully-fledged war." Indian military officials here insist that the new rebels cannot win against the 700,000 Indian troops in the region. They claim that most Kashmiris - who practice a moderate Islam - are repelled by the militants' violent tactics and radical agenda. But while many Kashmiris are wary of the foreign guerrillas, their bitterness toward Indian forces appears to be far deeper.  Washington Post

webTitle: More symptoms of chronic illness in the NHS

fields.headline: More symptoms of chronic illness in the NHS
fields.trailText: Last month the mother of a friend was given an appointment with an NHS surgeon in 2001 for a hip replacement. The family had a whip round and sent her to a private surgeon who deduced that if she waited until 2001, the hip would have disintegrated irretrievably.
fields.body:
Last month the mother of a friend was given an appointment with an NHS surgeon in 2001 for a hip replacement. The family had a whip round and sent her to a private surgeon who deduced that if she waited until 2001, the hip would have disintegrated irretrievably. So they went private (Parties clash on role of private sector, January 19).

The operation was performed within 10 days. The surgeon was an NHS surgeon, the operation took place in an NHS hospital with NHS equipment, all paid for by the taxpayer, and she recovered in a public NHS ward. In effect, she had NHS treatment - but at an expensive premium.

Does this mean NHS waiting lists are largely caused by NHS personnel moonlighting with so-called private patients? Surely, a doctor either works within the NHS or becomes a free-enterpriser? Obviously, if one has the cash, even the NHS can be bribed.
Nick Milton
Lydbrook, Glos

 Larry Robison, a diagnosed paranoid schizophrenic who is due to be executed in the US today, was denied proper treatment because he was not covered by his family's health insurance. He went on to murder five people.

My brother is being treated in this country for much the same condition. Despite being in the palm of our "crisis-ridden" NHS, he is receiving excellent care. The Tories are happy to use the media coverage of the flu epidemic as a cover for their aspirations to privatise chunks of the NHS. Given the possibility that my brother and others like him may then slip through the care net by being uninsurable, as Robison did, I'd prefer our present "crisis" to theirs.
Michael Jenner
Sherborne, Dorset
m.jenner@virgin.net

 I am coming to the end of my three years of nursing training and I find that the two main hospitals in the area where I live have a job freeze on until April due to financial cuts. I am married with two children and am unable to move out of the area to look for work.

Where is the incentive for me to stay in nursing? I am told that my training has cost over £30,000 but if I cannot find a job in the NHS straight away I may well have to look to the private sector.
Name and address withheld

 My widowed father was discharged from a community hospital with terminal stomach cancer and with just 16 days of life left. He wanted to go home. I had, however, expected more support. Social services were brilliant. The NHS? Well the district nurses and the GP were kind and caring in themselves. But the system was not helpful. Neither the GP or nurse were easy to contact when my father was shouting in pain.

Why is there such a patchy structure within the NHS for terminal care at home? The focus has been on the pressure on hospital beds and cancelled elective surgery. Maybe a closer look should be taken at what patients in the community experience.
Prof Ann Bowling
London
a.bowling@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Round two
fields.trailText: Your correspondents can rage as much as they like (January 20) but truth is truth. During and after Mike Tyson's trial opinion polls conducted among African Americans and, to some extent, among members of the African race in this country, showed support for him running at over 50%.
fields.body:
Your correspondents can rage as much as they like (January 20) but truth is truth. During and after Mike Tyson's trial opinion polls conducted among African Americans and, to some extent, among members of the African race in this country, showed support for him running at over 50%. No wonder, therefore, that the prosecution insisted on an all-white jury.
GZ Opadia-Kadima
Nottingham

 The claim that no American black jury would have convicted Mike Tyson seems entirely plausible when compared with a case involving a predominantly black jury and a certain OJ Simpson.
William Bick
Newent, Glos

fields.headline: Blurred way ahead for Lords' 'cross-section'
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: The royal commission on Lords reform held a very modern launch. Their report has a CD-rom stuck into the back cover, so you can read on your computer all the evidence and papers submitted.
fields.body:
The royal commission on Lords reform held a very modern launch. Their report has a CD-rom stuck into the back cover, so you can read on your computer all the evidence and papers submitted.

Why do I doubt that Tony Blair will be elbowing young Euan away from the screen? I suspect he'll give the whole thing two minutes before going back to Tomb Raider III.

Before the press conference, leading members of the team - lords Wakeham, Hurd and Butler, Bill Morris, Lady Dean, Gerald Kaufman - posed for the photographers. A Tory foreign secretary, a former chief whip, a cabinet secretary, two trade union leaders and Harold Wilson's old spin doctor; it was not a team which inspired massive confidence - the grating and the good.

Still, it was a frightfully British occasion. In some countries constitutional change is marked by the storming of the Winter Palace; here we have a row of middle-aged folk sitting at a primrose and ochre set in oak-panelled room, chuntering amiably if ponderously at the press.

It's a good rule that when something is launched with almost as many people on the platform as there are listening, we won't get questions and answers so much as mini-orations.

And there was plenty to orate. The commissioners were very proud of their report. The new house would be a "cross-section of British society," said Lord Wakeham, and "an extremely strong addition to our constitution."

It is a fine piece of work. If all the recommendations were put into effect, we'd have a wise, forthright and independent second chamber.

Which is precisely why it won't happen.The clue came when Lord Wakeham announced that "the prime minister will no longer be able to control the size, balance or the political membership of the second chamber."

Lord Wakeham, please listen: in his ideal world, Tony Blair would like to control the size, balance and membership of the Ovalteenies. Do you think he's going to hand over the House of Lords?

There's a touching item on page 148. One problem is what to do with existing life peers in the new house. They decided that they shouldn't be forced to retire, but given the right to retire. "Life peers remaining in the second chamber should be reminded of this right towards the end of each session."

Reminded? Perhaps a chap with a rottweiller and too many earrings will call round to see them every July. But I doubt it. As one of the reporters ambiguously put it, "does this mean they'll be allowed to survive until they die?"

Lord Wakeham gave us another short lecture about the constitution. "The way the second chamber works by screwing legislation ... er, I mean construing legislation."

Over in the existing House of Lords, they were working hard at screwing legislation, this time on trial by jury.

The Tory spokesman, Lord Cope, if I understood him correctly, thought the bill should be thrown out because it was insufficiently Labour in spirit. "If anything, Labour was elected to oppose this bill," he said.

Lord Jenkins was greatly peeved because Jack Straw had claimed him as a supporter. "He has previously regarded me as the epitome of a woolly Hampstead thinker, even though I have never inhabited those salubrious heights, nor I am particularly fond of woolly clothing ..."

But a Jenkins speech is like a fine old Harris tweed jacket, familiar, well-worn, stitched to last a lifetime. And, truth be told, sometimes just a tiny bit woolly.

fields.headline: The great genes sale
fields.trailText: Your leader on gene patenting (January 18) almost reaches the heart of the matter. Yet corporate and legal mumbo-jumbo still obscure the issue.
fields.body:
Your leader on gene patenting (January 18) almost reaches the heart of the matter. Yet corporate and legal mumbo-jumbo still obscure the issue.

A horrifying wrong is being done and neither the public, nor most politicians, have yet understood it. Our very genes are being made the subject of private property, the subject of sale and purchase, merger and takeover.

A patent represents the right to treat an abstraction as an item of private property. And it is the abuse of private property by the world's major corporations that now constitutes the greatest threat to our civilisation. In permitting the patenting of genes, states are playing the corporate game, and playing into the hands of the abusers.
RW Evans
Swansea

 The struggle taking place over the patenting of life does not just concern patenting human genes (Money and the meaning of life, January 17). Nor is it only UK women suffering from breast cancer who are at risk.

Worldwide, a massive "gene rush" is under way as giant corporations claim patent rights to the genetic building blocks of plant and animal life. This privatisation of staple food crops by giant corporations poses huge risks to global food security and poor farmers' rights.

Publicly held resources of vital benefit to the most needy are being passed into corporate hands The patenting of life is all about putting private profit before public good, here and in the developing world.
Eve Mitchell
ActionAid

fields.headline: The empty chamber
fields.standfirst: The Wakeham proposals for reform of the House of Lords are absurd and have lost the plot
fields.trailText: The Wakeham report goes straight to the heart of the big question - do we want any constitutional reform or are we happy as we are? If there are problems with how we are governed, are the alternatives worse? All the great issues of the day - Europe and the euro, proportional representation and now the role of the second chamber - depend on the single question: is one-party dictatorship in an all-powerful Commons the best of all possible governments? If you ask the people in that crude way the answer is mainly yes. They like "strong" government. But then if you ask about a fairer voting system they also say yes - indignant that parties elected on around 40% of the vote rule with absolute authority. If you suggest checks and balances or fundamental rights beyond the reach of politicians, they say yes again.
fields.body:
The Wakeham report goes straight to the heart of the big question - do we want any constitutional reform or are we happy as we are? If there are problems with how we are governed, are the alternatives worse? All the great issues of the day - Europe and the euro, proportional representation and now the role of the second chamber - depend on the single question: is one-party dictatorship in an all-powerful Commons the best of all possible governments? If you ask the people in that crude way the answer is mainly yes. They like "strong" government. But then if you ask about a fairer voting system they also say yes - indignant that parties elected on around 40% of the vote rule with absolute authority. If you suggest checks and balances or fundamental rights beyond the reach of politicians, they say yes again.

This serious intellectual dilemma lies at the heart of all three constitutional issues. Many on the centre left have been wobbling since 1997. It looked so obvious in the days of the Thatcher dictatorship. Of course she should have been forced by PR into consensual politics by having to work with other parties in a rainbow-hued Commons of many parties and opinions. Of course a stronger second chamber should have saved us from the madness of the poll tax or the knee-jerk hysteria of Section 28 and dangerous dogs laws. Of course Europe offered the best protection against the worst outrages of Michael Howard. But now it's no longer quite so clear. Why share power when you can have it all?

Why let go when we have one of the best governments in modern times? Listen to the Tories unseductive offer of cross-party agreement on the future funding of the NHS (letting the private sector take over by degrees) and wonder why any government should voluntarily share with the enemy. The enemy might be Schröder and Jospin demanding we impose unfavourable new taxes on the City. The enemy might be Lib Dems demanding tax rises for the ideological sake of it. Or the enemy might be a powerful House of Lords insisting that the ancient right to trial by jury is not diluted. Who needs all that aggravation? Why share more power with Europe, with other British parties or with a second chamber when you can keep it all yourself?

In that recess of Tony Blair's brain where he keeps his "project", where he thinks about history and the new century, where he plans armageddon for the forces of conservatism, he believes that power should be better spread. But between the thought and the action falls the shadow. That shadow is the fierce opposition of many in his own party and his own cabinet. There is the even longer shadow of public opinion profoundly uninterested in constitutional reform - and when bounced, instinctively against change.

Unlike France, Germany or Italy, in Britain there is scant tradition of intellectual debate in politics. The public is never invited to engage in serious thought about the nature of power, who holds it or where it should reside. No amount of David Blunkett's citizenship studies in schools will compensate for the dearth of deep discussion by our politicians. Lack of any debate about where power is best exercised for which function has let the Eurosceptics run away with public opinion. It's easy to frighten people about losing sovereignty when they have never had any discussion about who has it anyway. In living memory the rest of Europe has drawn up constitutions and amended them. We have just bumbled along hanging on to Black Rod and mumbling about tradition.

And so Wakeham's report lands in a political wasteland. Who cares? A few anoraks and the Lib Dems. There was no great outcry when Labour caved in on its manifesto pledge: "The right of hereditary peers to sit and vote in the House of Lords will be ended by statute". Nothing there about the 92 remaining - or about the right of any old hereditary to come and go as they please in the place and even to sit at the foot of the woolsack whenever they want to make trouble. These concessions were forced from the government under threat of losing two years' legislation. Presumably it didn't cross Labour's mind that if they'd faced the old buffers down bravely the people would have risen up to support their government and chase the ermines away. No, the government has no great faith in the people. And that is why we shall not get a mainly elected second chamber.

Yesterday's report on the Lords is full of good Wakehamisms - I particularly liked "radical evolutionary change" - and it does make an elegant case for doing as little as possible. It lays out the awkward problem of creating a carbon copy Commons, replicating the same old party-political debates with a tired second team. Wakeham says the public voiced their distaste for yet another group of politicians "banging on at each other" - they have a point. Consider what damage "checks and balances" have done to the US presidency: Clinton's health policy and all his best endeavours were wrecked by a hostile congress. There is a lot to be said for strong one-party government with one party to blame if they get it wrong. The report found that in most democracies the second chamber is a constant subject of complaint and criticism. So the question looks finely balanced.

Oddly enough, it is not in the big idea but in the small print that Wakeham loses the argument. He takes his readers almost all the way on the undesirability of a wholly elected second chamber until we hit the old Churchill problem: "Democracy is the worst form of government except all those other forms that have been tried from time to time". Once it is revealed how the 500 great and good are to be selected, the game is up. The more elaborately explained, the more absurd it becomes. Eight Commissioners (three from the political parties) with the judgment of Solomon will miraculously conjure up a chamber of equal gender, representing every walk of life, reflecting exact regional and ethnic balance, plus all professions and occupations, plus a religious, moral and philosophical balance, not forgetting the lords of appeal in ordinary and all the bishops. All these must add up to an exact party political balance. (Get me a Lib Dem Catholic woman chartered accountant with one leg from Cardiff! Never mind what she's like!)

It's impossible. Step by sensible step, somewhere along the way the commission lost the plot. I refer anyone who doubts it to chapter 15 - the Representation of Religious Faiths - because it is extremely funny. (The Rosicrucians have a pillar in the Dome's faith zone, do they get in here too?) Democracy has a lot going for it but if Labour doesn't think so they'd do better abolishing a second chamber altogether than creating this brand new anachronism.

Lord Wakeham will be online on the Guardian network today at 4pm. Post your comments and queries at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/lords

He takes his readers almost all the way on the undesirability of a wholly elected second chamber until we hit the old Churchill problem: "Democracy is the worst form of government except all those other forms that have been tried from time to time". Once it is revealed how the 500 great and good are to be selected, the game is up. The more elaborately explained, the more absurd it becomes. Eight Commissioners (three from the political parties) with the judgment of Solomon will miraculously conjure up a chamber of equal gender, representing every walk of life, reflecting exact regional and ethnic balance, plus all professions and occupations, plus a religious, moral and philosophical balance, not forgetting the lords of appeal in ordinary and all the bishops. All these must add up to an exact party political balance. (Get me a Lib Dem Catholic woman chartered accountant with one leg from Cardiff! Never mind what she's like!) It's impossible. Step by sensible step, somewhere along the way the commission lost the plot. I refer anyone who doubts it to chapter 15 - the Representation of Religious Faiths - because it is extremely funny. (The Rosicrucians have a pillar in the Dome's faith zone, do they get in here too?) Democracy has a lot going for it but if Labour doesn't think so they'd do better abolishing a second chamber altogether than creating this brand new anachronism. Lord Wakeham will be online on the Guardian network today at 4pm. Post your comments and queries at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/lords

fields.headline: The jury's right to trial
fields.trailText: Critics of the home secretary's bill to remove the right of defendants to elect for trial by jury (An enemy of justice, January 20) have shown that the supposed £106m savings resulting from the faster processing of defendants is a false figure. They have also argued that the bill deprives individuals of the right to be judged by one's peers.
fields.body:
Critics of the home secretary's bill to remove the right of defendants to elect for trial by jury (An enemy of justice, January 20) have shown that the supposed £106m savings resulting from the faster processing of defendants is a false figure. They have also argued that the bill deprives individuals of the right to be judged by one's peers.

What has been absent from discussions is how these proposals are at odds with the government's professed intention to strengthen democratic institutions. The jury is an important political institution. It is an expression of the sovereignty of the people, and to undermine it is to deprive the electorate of an important right. The jury is also a salutary institution. It teaches equity in practice; it teaches individuals not to shirk responsibility for their acts; and it makes them feel that they have duties to society and take a share in its government. By withdrawing it from certain cases citizens are deprived of an important institution.
Dr Michael Drolet
Royal Holloway College, Surrey
M.drolet@rhbnc.ac.uk

 Helena Kennedy makes the important point that jury trials are democracy in action.

Once every four years we vote in a general election, about 12 times in the average lifetime. We vote in local elections about the same number of times.

Yet nearly all of us can be called to sit on a jury, a time when being a citizen matters. It is ironic that David Blunkett is calling for citizenship to be taught in schools when his government is restricting one of its few duties.

It's more than just about legal administration, it's about the erosion of freedom.
Dave Nicholson
Windsor

fields.headline: Terms of surrender
fields.standfirst:
BSkyB dreams of an astonishing deal

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: British Sky Broadcasting (BSkyB) would drop its opposition to the proposed digital licence fee if the BBC was ordered to close down its 24-hour news channel, according to a report in yesterday's Financial Times. Even if this is only partly true it represents a sublime piece of impertinence.
fields.body:
British Sky Broadcasting (BSkyB) would drop its opposition to the proposed digital licence fee if the BBC was ordered to close down its 24-hour news channel, according to a report in yesterday's Financial Times. Even if this is only partly true it represents a sublime piece of impertinence. Who do they think is going to fall for a tactic like that? True, this government listens too readily to Rupert Murdoch, but it surely knows naked self-interest when it rears up in front of its face.

No one pretends that News 24 has been a runaway success. But it is barely two years old. It took CNN and Sky the best part of a decade to establish themselves. BSkyB was so bad in its early years as to be laughable but it gradually built up into the slick, professional (though still loss-making) organisation it is today. Good: in the media world variety really is the spice of life (in the view of all except BSkyB, whose idea of competition seems to be to get rid of it). BSkyB says it opposes the use of licence payers' money "to prop up a 24-hour news channel in an area where there is no market failure", ignoring the fact that if the BBC withdrew there would be no market at all in this sector since CNN is globally orientated.

Critics of News 24 argue that its £54m a year cost is wasteful compared with BSkyB's £30m (though it is not clear they are comparing like with like). They may have a point. Certainly the national audit office ought to monitor News 24 closely to assure the taxpayers they are getting value for money. Yet is £54m so very much for a 24-hour news service? If one of the fashionable web start-up companies proposed a 24-hour rolling news service with input from a network of correspondents around the world for that amount, no one would believe them. One such startup has $100m allocated for marketing alone. Perhaps Greg Dyke, the new director-general of the BBC, should rename it News 24.com.

The subtext of all this is that BSkyB and other commercial broadcasters are lobbying strongly against the government allowing the BBC either to raise its present licence fee (hardly a rip-off at £101 a year) or to add a temporary digital levy. A decision is expected next month and the government is wobbling like jelly because of its desperate desire not to subject itself to a double whammy by alienating the Murdoch press in the run-up to the election and giving the Conservatives the chance to call the digital levy a stealth tax. Tony Blair should rise above this and accept that the BBC for all its faults has to be properly funded to prepare for the new age when digital TV sets will vie with computers to deliver TV and the products of the internet.

The argument is not whether the BBC needs the extra money - it does, it does - but whether it would be better to increase the licence fee (still cheap compared with subscriptions to Sky) rather than sanction the digital levy, which may slow down the take-up of digital TV. If Britain is to exploit the worldwide potential of the digital revolution then we should switch over as quickly as possible (with poorer people subsidised from the money gained from selling off the old spectrum). News 24 has huge potential as more people switch to digital channels. And though it is getting better, Greg Dyke would be well advised to make sure it is good and cost effective. Meanwhile, those with doubts about the BBC need only think of the Murdoch alternative to start to see things straight.

fields.headline: Don't sell out to Mugabe
fields.trailText: The proposal that spare parts should be sold for Zimbabwean British-made Hawk jets is indeed alarming (Keeping the Hawk jets in action, January 20). This would mean that British arms could contribute to exacerbating the tragic misery caused by the Congo conflict.
fields.body:
The proposal that spare parts should be sold for Zimbabwean British-made Hawk jets is indeed alarming (Keeping the Hawk jets in action, January 20). This would mean that British arms could contribute to exacerbating the tragic misery caused by the Congo conflict.

In a recent visit to Zimbabwe I saw for myself evidence of the severe economic problems facing the country. Inflation running at 57%, record unemployment, collapsing real wages, rampant corruption and real threats to democracy. Twenty per cent of the adults in Zimbabwe are HIV positive. They can't afford to import HIV testing kits or even blood bags. Education and health are in desperate need of investment. President Mugabe, nonetheless, continues to wage a war against the rebels in the Democratic Republic of Congo. This is untenable and incomprehensible, as is any idea that we should assist him in this project.

All too often the British taxpayer picks up the bill when countries default on payments for arms. This was the case with Indonesia and apparently Zimbabwe hasn't even paid up for the Hawks for which they now need spare parts. I wonder why Zimbabwe was not one of the countries excluded from entitlement to export credit support for arms sales in the chancellor's announcement last week, when a clear case can be made on the grounds of poverty, debt and development needs. It is time for this hidden subsidy for arms to be stopped.

The UK's compliance with the criteria laid down by the EU's code on arms exports would be called in to question if this deal were to go ahead. Many of us have asked for the loopholes in the existing code to be closed. We need reassurance that there would be unequivocal opposition by the EU to the export of European-manufactured arms to countries which raised major concerns in relation to the clear parameters set by the EU code. This code of conduct was after all the direct result of the hard work undertaken by Robin Cook during Britain's presidency of the EU.
Glenys Kinnock MEP

 It seems that the argument to justify this sale is based on the fact that Britain's arms industry is delicately sustained by the plight of countries in turmoil, and any move to rock the boat may lose Britain business. Britain's fears that such countries will seek their trade elsewhere cannot justify the recent decision to act in a way that directly supports a civil war, and lining the coffers is as abject as Mugabe's profit-driven incentives to remain in the Congo.

Britain's influence is unfortunately greater than its insight into the catastrophic effects that this war is having on ordinary civilians whose wellbeing does not depend on a £5bn industry.
C Stapelkamp
Harrow, Middx
brokenpunch@yahoo.com

 I hope your exposé of Zimbabwe's Congo involvement is the first part of a fuller examination of that situation. Uganda provided the example and the excuse for Zimbabwe's involvement. Museveni's brother Saleh is just the most prominent of Ugandan military leaders who have established business dealings on the back of Uganda's Congo wars since the pro-Kabila campaign. Without Uganda's later backing for the anti-Kabila rebels, Mugabe would have had no opportunity to get involved.

Mesmerised by Uganda's faithful adherence to the doctrine of "structural adjustment", Britain and the west remain four-square behind this government.
George Heron
Manchester
george@parksway.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Who doesn't dare, loses
fields.standfirst:
The Wakeham report oozes complacency

Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: John Wakeham gets at least one thing right. He states in the opening section of his report on reform of the House of Lords, published yesterday, that the task of any royal commission is to produce recommendations which are "not only persuasive and intellectually coherent but also workable, durable and politically realistic". He is right. But those words also stand as an indictment of his report.
fields.body:
John Wakeham gets at least one thing right. He states in the opening section of his report on reform of the House of Lords, published yesterday, that the task of any royal commission is to produce recommendations which are "not only persuasive and intellectually coherent but also workable, durable and politically realistic". He is right.

But those words also stand as an indictment of his report. For in its determination to find a proposal that is "politically realistic" - that is, acceptable to the prime minister - the Wakeham commission has produced a dog's dinner of a report, which ducks the issues or fudges them and leaves a contradiction on every page. It claims to be radical when in fact it is cowardly, preferring preservation of the status quo to imaginative reform, and constantly endorsing the clubby ways of the past as best left alone. Above all, it keeps power out of the hands of the men and women of Britain, recommending an elaborate rabbit warren of systems and mechanisms over the clear, democratic solution that was staring it in the face. The sheer lack of coherence of the Wakeham report means it can have little chance of implementation. By failing the chairman's first standard, it will fail his second, too. "We did not wish to spend months compiling a report that would gather dust in a pigeonhole," he writes in his introduction. Yet that is the fate his report invites.

Our own preference for the second phase of House of Lords reform - the first being last year's removal of all but 92 of the hereditary peers - was no secret. Along with hundreds of others we submitted our proposal to the 12 commissioners, advocating a directly elected second chamber. When Lord Wakeham states that his goal is a house that reflects the political balance of the country, we believe that there is a very simple way to achieve that: it is called an election. Indeed, in a democracy it is surely the only legitimate way.

The Wakeham 12 have decided otherwise, for reasons they state but chiefly for one they do not: political realism. It was perfectly clear to the commission chairman that the man who had appointed him, Tony Blair, was no enthusiast for a wholly or even largely elected house. So, keen to avoid the pigeonhole, the former Tory minister did what all those years in the whips' office had trained him to do: delivered the fix. He doomed direct election from the outset. The result is a series of tortured mechanisms designed to produce a legitimate, representative chamber without the sine qua non of legitimate representation, namely democracy.

To take one example from many, the report promises a new appointments commission, dispatching people to the chamber in order to reflect the regional, gender and ethnic make-up of the country and in accordance with the political complexion of the electorate expressed at the last general election - all the while keeping the total membership at the 550 mark. How does that add up? At present there are roughly that number of life peers around, and Wakeham elsewhere suggests these unelected folk should retain their seats in a reformed chamber until the day they die. In other words, there will be no vacancies for the appointers to fill until the grim reaper has created them. It could take decades for the selection methods outlined yesterday to kick in. Or, to name another flaw, the three selection models set out in the report (proof that the commissioners could not agree among themselves) have elected members chosen not all at once, but in thirds. That would mean, for instance, Tyneside electing people today, then waiting 15 years to have another go. The Scottish Highlands would be represented today by people chosen in 1985. It makes no sense.

Elsewhere decisions are funked: the name of the reformed body and of its members are "left to evolve". Opportunities are missed: Wakeham is quite happy for the second chamber to retain its judicial function, even though it is part of the legislature - a clear violation of the doctrine of the separation of powers which is honoured all over the world but ignored in this country. He is somehow able to contemplate the present role of the lord chancellor without recognising any case for reform. Nor is there any sympathy for the idea, proved effective overseas, that a second chamber should review the appointments of key people to the executive.

Instead, the report repeatedly seeks to maintain the Lords in its cosy old ways, albeit by a system superficially more modern. It still wants the grandeur, the chumminess and the ultimate weakness of a second chamber ensuring that it presents no real challenge to our over-centralised executive. The creation of a genuine check and balance was the prize within the grasp of the Wakeham 12. They have fumbled that chance. By presenting such a muddled report they have made it easy for Mr Blair to ignore their deliberations. Theirs is not a clarion call for change, but a mumbled agreement among the Westminster club to keep things as they are. If this is the best idea for a replacement, the "interim" house created last year may turn out to be as permanent as the last one. And that, remember, survived for nearly a century.

webTitle: Arkan buried: 'Tigers' militia salute Serb warlord

fields.headline: Arkan buried: 'Tigers' militia salute Serb warlord
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Paramilitaries fired into the air and a band played an ancient Serbian hymn as the indicted war criminal Zeljko Raznatovic, "Arkan" was buried in Belgrade's main cemetery yesterday, five days after he was assassinated in the lobby of a city hotel.
fields.body:
Paramilitaries fired into the air and a band played an ancient Serbian hymn as the indicted war criminal Zeljko Raznatovic, "Arkan" was buried in Belgrade's main cemetery yesterday, five days after he was assassinated in the lobby of a city hotel.

Mystery continued to swirl round the motives for his murder and whether President Slobodan Milosevic's government was the culprit. But pro-government newspapers said the arrest of two suspects disproved speculation of official involvement.

Thousands of mourners gathered for the funeral. Four members of Arkan's paramilitary Tigers unit, dressed in camouflage uniforms and red berets, stood as an honour guard.

The entire team of his premier league soccer club, Obililc, also attended, as well as business associates from the criminal underworld and friends from the wars in Bosnia and Croatia, where Arkan's militia conducted a reign of terror and brutal ethnic cleansing.

Family members, including his wife, the folk singer Ceca, his mother and his eldest son followed the coffin. Mihailo, the eldest of Arkan's nine children, held a cross and two other members of the Tigers carried a portrait of their leader.

Arkan's militia was disbanded after the Bosnian conflict ended in 1995 but some of its members continued to operate in Kosovo. He also had extensive business and political interests via his Serbian Unity party, and was part of Belgrade's social elite.

"There is no doubt that the [state security] service killed him," said a member of the Tigers at a memorial ceremony on Wednesday. "Those monsters who have been killing this country for 50 years have murdered my commander."

After the murder, speculation spread that the government was responsible because it feared that he was preparing to give United Nations war crimes investigators evidence that would implicate Mr Milosevic and other leaders.

"Arkan is not a political figure," a foreign ministry spokesman, Rade Drobac, said. "The west is blowing this story up, and we have nothing to do with it. We are not even interested in it. Let the authorities do their job."

In the Hague, Paul Risley, a spokesman for the war crimes tribunal, confirmed that "discussions" between the court and intermediaries purporting to represent Arkan had recently taken place, but he said the talks never included an offer of his surrender.

Two pro-government newspapers yesterday carried divergent accounts of the progress of the police investigation into the murder.

The biggest pro-government newspaper, Politika, said that police had identified Arkan's killer, who was in hiding somewhere in Serbia. Another pro-government newspaper in the northern town of Novi Sad said that police had arrested the alleged killer, whom it named as Goran Jevtovic, from Belgrade.

An accomplice of Arkan's killer was wounded in the lobby of the Intercontinental hotel in Belgrade during the assassination on Saturday. Police said he was operated on in a hospital in Loznica, western Serbia, but then moved to another clinic for his own safety.

Two other newspapers, Blic and Vecernje Novosti, said that the wounded man had at one time worked for the police.

Politika said the prosecutor's office had also launched an investigation into an opposition television station which carried allegations that the authorities had killed Arkan and have been jamming the media and threatening opposition politicians.

"The statements accuse the authorities of state terror, anarchy, physical, legal and media terror," Politika said, quoting a statement from the prosecutors.
