fields.headline: Study disproves fluoridation risk
fields.trailText: Adding fluoride to drinking water would not lead to more hip fractures as its opponents have argued, according to research published in this week's Lancet.
fields.body:
Adding fluoride to drinking water would not lead to more hip fractures as its opponents have argued, according to research published in this week's Lancet.

The study is a blow to those who have fought against universal fluoridation of the water supply to gain an improvement in dental health, particularly in children.

One of their objections has been that more people suffer hip fractures in areas with fluoride in the water, since the ingested fluoride is taken up by the bone structure. The study, by David Coggon and colleagues from the medical research council at Southampton university, dismissed this argument.

"Our findings suggest that concerns about a possible risk of hip fracture should not be a reason for withholding fluoridation of water supplies," said Professor Coggan. Some water authorities add fluoride, others do not.

His team studied 914 patients with hip fractures and 1,196 without in Cleveland. Those in Hartlepool had a lifetime exposure to natural fluoride in their water supply.

No evidence of an increase in hip fractures was found once known risks, such as poor food or lack of exercise, were taken into consideration.

In a commentary in the Lancet, Clifford Rosen, of the Maine centre for osteoporosis research and education in the United States, said that the study provided "compelling evidence", but did not think it would settle the argument. "The controversy is likely to continue, as water fluoridation becomes more widespread, osteoporosis in the general population increases, and more and larger studies are undertaken."

webTitle: Killer awarded £3,548 for paintings lost in prison

fields.headline: Killer awarded £3,548 for paintings lost in prison
fields.trailText: The prison service yesterday agreed to pay the killer and kidnapper Michael Sams £3,548 compensation for paintings lost during a move between jails.
fields.body:
The prison service yesterday agreed to pay the killer and kidnapper Michael Sams £3,548 compensation for paintings lost during a move between jails.

The six paintings by Sams were valued at £500 apiece by a judge at an earlier hearing. The rest of the cash is to cover other lost items, including cassette tapes and personal items, as well as earnings Sams missed while held in a prison segregation unit.

The prison service had contested the claim. A spokeswoman said: "The case has now been settled. The original hearing scheduled for February 18 will not now take place.

"The prisoner has accepted our offer but will not receive the money himself. It will go to nominated recipients."

It is understood the prison service decided it would be cheaper to settle the matter than allow a court case to drag on.

News of the settlement comes just a day after it emerged that plans had been drawn up for a special court hearing inside Whitemoor prison, Cambridgeshire.

The service said it was cheaper to bring a court to Sams than foot the bill for an elaborate security operation which would be needed if he were to appear in a normal court.

Sams, now held in Durham prison, was jailed for life in 1993 for the murder of Julie Dart and the abduction of the estate agent, Stephanie Slater, and is considered one of the country's most dangerous criminals.

Norman Brennan, director of the Victims of Crime Trust, condemned the pay-out and said new laws were needed to stop inmates pursuing claims against the prison service.

"I am aghast, and so are victims and the law-abiding public, at these bizarre pay-outs to criminals by the prison service."

webTitle: When Irish eyes sent the wrong signal to MI5

fields.headline: When Irish eyes sent the wrong signal to MI5
fields.trailText: Songs including We'll Meet Again, Windy Night and When Irish Eyes Are Smiling played on an Irish radio station during the second world war aroused the suspicion of security services and were scanned to see if they were hidden messages to hostile agents, according to intelligence reports released yesterday.
fields.body:
Songs including We'll Meet Again, Windy Night and When Irish Eyes Are Smiling played on an Irish radio station during the second world war aroused the suspicion of security services and were scanned to see if they were hidden messages to hostile agents, according to intelligence reports released yesterday.

Song requests played on a small station in Athlone, mid-Ireland, were scrutinised after the BBC monitoring service alerted the intelligence agencies MI5 and MI6.

In February 1941, the BBC reported the song When Irish Eyes Are Smiling, which was played for "grateful patients" in an Exeter hospital. The BBC left it to the security and intelligence agencies services to judge whether it was a coded message.

"Let us know if you wish to continue these," asked a puzzled BBC official who noted that the Athlone station had just played So I Pulled Myself Together, sung by Arthur Askey. More suspicious was the song, I Saw Three Ships A-Sailing.

MI5 was told there had been an SOS message for a Christy Hogan of Sparkbrook, Birmingham, who was asked to call at Richmond villas, Dublin, where his mother was ill. The implication was that it was a secret message.

"You may also be interested to hear that during a group of songs ... a tune, Moonshine, was broadcast 'for a listener in Whitehall'," added the BBC official. The suggestion was that it could be another coded message.

He carefully noted that another tune, Serenade in the Night, was described by the Athlone broadcaster as requested by "a pen pal in Roscommon to a pen pal in Nottingham, England".

The BBC monitor noted: "This is probably a perfectly innocent message but I thought you ought to know about it."

Edward Lustgarten, who became a well-known BBC announcer, told MI5 that his attention had been attracted by other songs - Stars all over the Sky, for instance - and even carols, including the First Noel.

The BBC described "an extraordinary episode" when on the same wavelength the song A Wild Irish Boy was interrupted by an announcer saying "Just a minute, here is a short number which is also topical, Floating Sea Mines". Suspicions were further aroused when the local orchestra asked to play it could not remember the tune.

There was alarm when the Irish station played what was described as a "German foxtrot" .

But by May 1941, the security services seemed to have finally lost interest. A memo notes: "There does not seem to be any significance in the titles heard so I would ask you so far as we are concerned not to continue to report song titles."

webTitle: After a fashion: Art meets couture in exhibition of the unwearable

fields.headline: After a fashion: Art meets couture in exhibition of the unwearable
fields.trailText: Many creations worn by catwalk models would be unlikely to find their way into most people's ward-robes. But even the most impractical examples of designer couture pale into mundanity compared with the garments about to go on show at a London exhibition.
fields.body:
Many creations worn by catwalk models would be unlikely to find their way into most people's ward-robes. But even the most impractical examples of designer couture pale into mundanity compared with the garments about to go on show at a London exhibition.

For those who despair at finding cocktail ensembles made from preserved roses, or who would kill to get their hands on a bikini knitted from human hair, the Sotheby's exhibition in New Bond Street, London's designer label heartland, will offer retail heaven.

Among other highlights will be Hussein Chalayan's plastic dress made from rubbish dug up in his garden, and Freddie Robins's gloves, designed for people with extra fingers or whose hands have been replaced with hooks. Then there is the unyielding and draughty dress made from twisted garden canes by a leading milliner, Dai Rees.

But none of the garments on show at Out of the Closet - Clothes of the Unwearable was designed to grace the human body.

"For some artists, society's preoccupation with clothes and fashion has evolved into a blossoming art form," said Janice Blackburn, the exhibition's curator. "The clothes have no place behind the doors of a wardrobe or on the body. They are to be seen and displayed on walls and floors both in museums and domestically."

Despite their lack of function, the clothes carry price tags that would not be out of place in the neighbouring designer boutiques.

Niquette Longmuir, who uses leftovers from her husband's dried flower business to make unwearable shoes, cardigans and handbags, is asking upwards of £500 for her creations. One - as opposed to a pair - of Robins's gloves will set you back £400, a bargain compared with the £3,970 asking price for an Emily Bates human hair dress.

Out of the Closet is part of Sotheby's contemporary decorative arts selling exhibition, which runs from February 10 to 17.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText:
'Filthy' prison infested with vermin
The chief inspector of prisons reported yesterday that nearly 70 young offenders aged 17 to 21 were living in a wing of Rochester prison in Kent that was "filthy, vandalised, infested with vermin and subjected to an impoverished regime in which the only constant was unpredictability".
fields.body:
'Filthy' prison infested with vermin
The chief inspector of prisons reported yesterday that nearly 70 young offenders aged 17 to 21 were living in a wing of Rochester prison in Kent that was "filthy, vandalised, infested with vermin and subjected to an impoverished regime in which the only constant was unpredictability".

Sir David Ramsbotham also expressed "deep concern" at the poor treatment and conditions of asylum seekers, immigration detainees and other foreigners making up nearly half the prison population. Sir David said he had made a "dreadful report", and conditions at the jail had worsened since it was inspected five years ago.

The prison became the first Borstal, named after a nearby village, early this century, but now houses a range of prisoners including young offenders, adult prisoners and detainees. Inmates reported mice and cockroaches throughout the wing, the staff rest room "reeked of dead vermin" and there was a "foul smell" in the TV room. Young prisoners had to wash their plates in two buckets of water just before mealtimes and had nothing to dry them with.

Sir David also criticised the lack of clear guidelines on how the immigration detainees should be treated. A hotline which staff could ring to secure access to a translator had never been used, said the report, and it cited an Albanian put in a cell with a Pole, who was told to pass on information about the regime "because both names ended in an 'i' ".

The report did praise work done in the prison with sex offenders and a resettlement strategy which provided work opportunities for inmates after their release. Sir David said he would be returning in a year to monitor progress.

In reply, the director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, categorically denied the jail was a "filthy establishment" and said he had recently made a lightning visit and found conditions "entirely satisfactory".

12 years for £50m fake cash plot
The owner of a printing plant was jailed yesterday for 12 years for leading a gang that printed fake banknotes and stamps worth £50m.

Two out of every three fake notes circulating between 1993 and 1998 were produced by the gang led by Kenneth Mainstone, 61, of Upminster in Essex, Winchester crown court had been told. Mainstone and his partner, Anthony Wilkie, 60, who was sentenced to three years and nine months, were convicted of counterfeiting and conspiracy charges following a three month trial in Winchester last year.

Three others had admitted their part in the plot: one, Bernard Farrier, 67, died in prison of cancer, while Stephen Jory, 50, was given eight years yesterday and Martin Watmough, 47, was jailed for three years. Edward Burns, 67, a paper supplier, accused of being involved with the gang, was acquitted by the jury last year.

Stephen Parish, prosecuting, told the court how Main stone was an "outwardly respectable" businessman who, together with Jory, ran the gang, which police nicknamed the Lavender Hill Mob. The fake notes were printed on a sophisticated four colour printing press at Mainstone's home. Wilkie supplied equipment for making perforations in fake stamps as a sideline to printing notes; he and Farrier had also intended to fake £1 coins.The counterfeiting ring began to crack when sheets of fake £20 and £50 notes were seized at Farrier's home in 1998.

Judge Michael Brodrick yesterday ordered that Mainstone and Jory's assets were to be seized to account for some of the £1.5m they gained between them from the conspiracy. He also ordered seizure of the press used to print the notes, and the destruction of the notes themselves.

Inspector Clive Merrett, of Hampshire police, said they were still looking for a man called Baron Menzel, 31, who was thought to be in the United States.

Jailed drugs workers begin appeal
Two charity workers jailed for nine years after refusing to name drug dealers operating at their homeless centre yesterday launched a fight to have their convictions overturned.

In a case which has sparked outrage among homelessness and drugs charities, Ruth Wyner and her colleague John Brock, both 49, of the government-backed Wintercomfort centre in Cambridge, were jailed in December for five years and four years respectively for allowing the supply of heroin.

About 50 supporters, carrying placards, gathered outside the court of appeal in London where their lawyers sought leave to appeal against the conviction and the sentences and tried to secure bail pending an appeal. Mr Justice Richards, hearing the application in chambers, reserved judgment to a later date.

Outside the court, Brock's wife, Louise, said she remained hopeful of at least getting the sentences reduced. Her husband had suffered such extreme depression in prison that he was under constant watch to prevent him harming himself. "It's been such a shock for him, a total disbelief at being put in prison," she said.

The campaign to release the pair has gathered support from thousands of people across the country.

The Wintercomfort charity's patron, the Cambridge university vice-chancellor Sir Alec Broers, said yesterday: "I am deeply shocked and I do not understand the rationale of the conviction, let alone the sentencing. There appears to be a lack of understanding about the realities of looking after the homeless and I only hope that this injustice can be corrected as soon as possible."

Stuart Turner, a former heroin addict who has been receiving treatment through the centre for two years, said: "Banging up two people who were just trying to help people is a disgrace. Wherever there are drug addicts you are going to get dealers; that is a fact of life and you can't stop that."

Lakeside elegy: Memory of Ruskin still burns bright
A ceremony to mark the centenary of the death of John Ruskin, the most influential art critic of the 19th century, brought together locals and literary pilgrims yesterday at his home in the Lake District. After the elegiac ceremony at Coniston Water, a lantern was left burning in the room where Ruskin went mad, seeing faces in the wallpaper, before dying of flu on January 20 1900.

The lantern was lit in the church in Coniston where Ruskin is buried and then brought to the lakeside by schoolchildren following his carriage. The lantern was carried across the water in the Jumping Jenny, the boat built for Ruskin, to Brantwood on the opposite bank, his last home.

Yesterday was the first in a series of centenary events, including recitals, plays, television programmes and an exhibition at the Tate Gallery. His admirers at yesterday's ceremony included David Barrie, director of the National Art Collections Fund, and the art historian Robert Hewison.

Monkeys kiss and make up
Feuding couples are not alone in kissing and making up after an argument, research at Chester zoo has found. Primates do it too.

Filippo Aureli, an animal behaviour specialist at Liverpool John Moores university, made the discovery in studying groups of chimpanzees and spider monkeys. He said the primates groomed and embraced to reduce anxiety and reconcile differences within the group. Conflict caused them anxiety, often manifested in self-scratching. In some cases, a third primate acted as an "emotional mediator" between the warring parties.

The chimpanzees and monkeys were particularly upset when they fell out with members of their own clique, "but then they reconcile more often with friends", Dr Aureli said. "I'm interested in how this behaviour regulates their social relationships; how they manage anxiety and resolve conflict."

He hopes his research will bring better understanding of animals' needs in captivity, enabling keepers to recognise their distress more easily.

At Chester zoo the males, while patrolling their communities because of the fierce competition for females, formed strong bonds with their fellow primates.

But Dr Aureli said conflicts over food, mates or space could escalate to aggression. "It's all about how much you need the others in your group. If they are important for your survival as an individual, the average relationship in a group will be very valuable. If you don't need them all, the average relationship will be less valuable.

"Emotional responses like self-scratching are related to the quality of the social relationship. In addition, social grooming has a relaxing effect and slows the heartbeat."

Dr Aureli is the joint editor of a forthcoming book, Natural Conflict Resolution, in which he argues that peacekeeping is as natural as aggression and competition. Written by specialists in fields as diverse as anthropology, political science and legal studies, it is aimed at devising strategies to resolve disputes between people.


Doctors seek wider use of IVF
Many more women could receive infertility treatment on the NHS if measures were taken to prevent triplet births, specialists said yesterday at the launch of new guidelines.

At present, IVF clinics place up to three embryos in the womb after fertilisation with the partner's sperm in the laboratory. The Royal College of Gynaecologists and Obstetricians said that that could be reduced to two without lessening most women's chances of a baby.

If the savings to the NHS were ploughed back into the IVF programme, some of the inequities in fertility treatment - which is available on the NHS in some areas - could be removed.

Allan Templeton, secretary of the college, which has spent three years putting together the guidelines at the request of the department of health, said the changes would dramatically cut the unacceptably high multiple birth rate.

"Triplets cost the NHS nine times as much as a single or a twin birth. The financial, social and psychological impact on the parents is also very high and triplets have a considerably higher mortality and disability rate.

"The saving from reducing the triplet birth rate would pretty well pay for all the IVF treatment carried out in this country on the NHS at this time."

One in seven couples in the UK have problems conceiving a child.

Not all fertility specialists agreed that it was right to restrict the number of embryos to two. Ian Craft, who runs the private London Fertility Centre in Harley Street, believed women should be given a fertility score according to their age and other factors which made them likely to conceive triplets. This score would determine whether two embryos or even five should be replaced. Sarah Boseley

He hopes his research will bring better understanding of animals' needs in captivity, enabling keepers to recognise their distress more easily. At Chester zoo the males, while patrolling their communities because of the fierce competition for females, formed strong bonds with their fellow primates. But Dr Aureli said conflicts over food, mates or space could escalate to aggression. "It's all about how much you need the others in your group. If they are important for your survival as an individual, the average relationship in a group will be very valuable. If you don't need them all, the average relationship will be less valuable. "Emotional responses like self-scratching are related to the quality of the social relationship. In addition, social grooming has a relaxing effect and slows the heartbeat." Dr Aureli is the joint editor of a forthcoming book, Natural Conflict Resolution, in which he argues that peacekeeping is as natural as aggression and competition. Written by specialists in fields as diverse as anthropology, political science and legal studies, it is aimed at devising strategies to resolve disputes between people. Doctors seek wider use of IVF Many more women could receive infertility treatment on the NHS if measures were taken to prevent triplet births, specialists said yesterday at the launch of new guidelines. At present, IVF clinics place up to three embryos in the womb after fertilisation with the partner's sperm in the laboratory. The Royal College of Gynaecologists and Obstetricians said that that could be reduced to two without lessening most women's chances of a baby. If the savings to the NHS were ploughed back into the IVF programme, some of the inequities in fertility treatment - which is available on the NHS in some areas - could be removed. Allan Templeton, secretary of the college, which has spent three years putting together the guidelines at the request of the department of health, said the changes would dramatically cut the unacceptably high multiple birth rate. "Triplets cost the NHS nine times as much as a single or a twin birth. The financial, social and psychological impact on the parents is also very high and triplets have a considerably higher mortality and disability rate. "The saving from reducing the triplet birth rate would pretty well pay for all the IVF treatment carried out in this country on the NHS at this time." One in seven couples in the UK have problems conceiving a child. Not all fertility specialists agreed that it was right to restrict the number of embryos to two. Ian Craft, who runs the private London Fertility Centre in Harley Street, believed women should be given a fertility score according to their age and other factors which made them likely to conceive triplets. This score would determine whether two embryos or even five should be replaced. Sarah Boseley

webTitle: Guide to the new power house

fields.headline: Guide to the new power house
fields.trailText: Composition
fields.body:
Composition

The commission resisted calls for a fully-elected chamber, arguing that would destabilise the power balance between Lords and Commons. Commissioners insisted the mainly-appointed option would not create a house of cronies, because of the independence of the appointments commission. Change would come incrementally. Commissioners argued that after 20 years there would be virtually no members appointed under the life peers system. The proposals represent a significant change from the present, but will not please idealists.

Roles and functions

Reformers seeking a significantly beefed up constitutional role for the House of Lords in order to strengthen its powers to check the executive will be disappointed. The commission stepped back from recommending any fundamental change of the powers of the upper house, though the report argued it would be more powerful than at present. In particular, members of the Lords would gain more scope to scrutinise secondary legislation - becoming increasingly important. However, while retaining the power to make MPs "think again", it would remain firmly secondary to the democratic authority of the Commons - "neither a clone nor a rival", according to the report.

Titles and pay

Reformers were keen to see a change of title for the second chamber and its members to reflect its new role and emphasise its distance from the old Lords of hereditary peers and patronage. However, the commission has ducked the question other than to underline that members of the reformed Lords should not take the title peer, which would become a purely honorary title awarded through the honours list.

Though the commission has been careful to ensure that members of the upper chamber would receive less pay than MPs, underlining the relative authority of the two houses, the proposals were still for a significant increase in both attendance payments and expenses, with extra office and secretarial resources. The recommendations underlined the pressure to ensure that members from around the British Isles could afford to attend regularly, and emphasised the desire to see membership of the Lords as an active role rather than a reward for political loyalty or good works.

webTitle: Golf pros in hole over dress code

fields.headline: Golf pros in hole over dress code
fields.standfirst: Tribunal's finding that PGA restrictions amounted to sex discrimination marks another triumph for women choosing trousers for work
fields.trailText: The Professional Golf Association was found guilty yesterday of sexual discrimination against a female employee ordered to change into a skirt or a dress after turning up for work dressed in a trouser suit.
fields.body:
The Professional Golf Association was found guilty yesterday of sexual discrimination against a female employee ordered to change into a skirt or a dress after turning up for work dressed in a trouser suit.

Judy Owen, 39, resigned three weeks into her job as a training manager at the PGA's Sutton Coldfield headquarters after being told by her manager that "women don't wear trousers at the PGA".

An industrial tribunal in Birmingham found that the association had discriminated against Mrs Owen by applying standards of dress to women that it did not equally apply to men.

The equal opportunities commission, which backed her case, described the ruling as a "memorable victory".

"This is fantastic news and now gives women the right to wear smart trousers to work," said Clare Hockney, the EOC solicitor who represented Mrs Owen. "This issue has not been tested since 1977, and standards of what is conventional dress for men and women have moved on."

Julie Mellor, the EOC's chairwoman, said: "We believe women should be judged on the quality of their work, not on what they wear.

"Women in all walks of life now wear smart trousers to work, and it is almost a year since David Beckham wore a sarong. It is right that the law should reflect these changes.

"It is no longer acceptable for employers to impose old-fashioned stereotypes about what they think is appropriate for women or men to wear to work."

The PGA, which disputed Mrs Owen's claim, said it would review the implications of the verdict and had no immediate plans to change its employment policy.

"We are not surprised by the tribunal's decision, in view of the environment in which we live, but as a fair employer it is disappointing to find ourselves in this situation," said Sandy Jones, its chief executive, in a statement.

"We have actively practised an equal opportunities policy since 1979 but have become a target because of who we are and fallen victim for not having a written policy."

Mrs Owen, who complained of a blatantly sexist atmosphere at the PGA, joined in May 1998 and wore a trouser suit to work in her second week.

She was told to go home and change by her manager, Gerry Paton, who said the association had a "smart, conservative dress code". Mrs Owen asked him if there was any written record of the dress code and asked to see it.

"I raised my concern at the appropriateness of this policy," she told the tribunal. "It was snowing that day, and I told him I had just bought three trouser suits. But he never got back to me."

She said that the next time she wore a trouser suit to work Mr Paton asked her if she "was playing games" and ordered her to go home and change.

After that incident her GP signed her off work for four weeks with a stress-related illness and on May 28 she resigned. "I have never felt so abused, and it has had a damaging effect on my self-esteem, confidence and career," said Mrs Owen.

Vivian Saunders, a PGA member and former chairwoman of the Women's PGA welcomed the verdict. "The PGA don't have a great record on women's issues," she said.

"The patron is the Queen, so the members seem perfectly happy to have a woman at the head of the organisation but less so about ordinary women.

"I hope this [case] will make them re-examine their approach to women in general."

The level of damages will be decided at a future hearing. Mrs Owen claimed £50,000.

Companies change with the times

Judy Owen's victory over the PGA is the second recent triumph for women wishing to wear trousers rather than skirts in the workplace.

In November Eurostar announced that female security guards could choose to wear skirts or trousers in screening passengers and other duties after Debbie Sheen, 37, and Lynn McKay, 35, were sent home the previous month from the Waterloo terminal in London for refusing to wear skirts.

The EOC has launched legal action against Whickham school, Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, claiming it has sexually discriminated against Jo Hale, 14, who has been fighting a school rule that she must wear a skirt.

Elsewhere dress codes are changing:

 Nationwide Building Society has had a trouser option for women since 1994, There are two styles of trousers (summer/winter) and three lengths of skirt. "From our figures it looks like 10-3 in favour of skirts," said a spokesperson.

 Life Futures and Options Exchange: Trouser suits have always been a uniform option for women. "All traders are asked to dress smartly in business attire, and smart trouser suits would be acceptable."

 Marks & Spencer: Trousers have always been available as part of the uniform. "Trouser wearing is increasingly popular among staff, especially in the food halls."

 Tesco has offered trousers to female staff since 1992. They come in two styles and the skirts in two lengths, with an above-the-knee option.

 Association of Female Barristers: The lord chief justice introduced the option for women to wear trousers in 1996. Before this a barrister's attire was at the discretion of individual judges.

 British Airways: Stewardesses do not have the option to wear trousers. "We've done extensive research into what cabin crew feel comfortable in, and market research in the past has suggested that female staff prefer to wear skirts," said a spokesperson. Any woman on the ramps or in loading areas can wear trousers for modesty, as can female pilots.

 Oxford university: Regulations require women to wear a black skirt at exams, matriculation and graduation. There is also a code for men.

webTitle: Royal commission forecasts end of patronage and cronyism in Lords

fields.headline: Royal commission forecasts end of patronage and cronyism in Lords
fields.standfirst:
Second chamber to be 'broadly representative of British society'

Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Stung by the very suggestion that the royal commission had produced a timid blueprint for a reformed House of Lords, Labour's Gerald Kaufman yesterday conjured up a wholesome new era as he denounced both prime ministerial patronage and the awarding of peerages.
fields.body:
Stung by the very suggestion that the royal commission had produced a timid blueprint for a reformed House of Lords, Labour's Gerald Kaufman yesterday conjured up a wholesome new era as he denounced both prime ministerial patronage and the awarding of peerages.

Both practices will disappear if the government agrees to set up the proposed appointments commission, statutory and independent. In future every new member of the second chamber would have to pass its scrutiny, he thundered.

"Prime ministerial patronage and political cronyism will be gone because the prime minister will no longer have any say in what the appointments commission does," the veteran ex-minister declared. If the report is accepted, he added, it would also mean "that no one ever again would get into the second chamber by a virtue of a peerage".

Insiders say this makes the commission one of the crucial elements in the Wakeham package. So how would it work? How would a public-spirited hospital consultant in Newcastle, a Sikh business leader in Leicester or a trade union stalwart in Southampton become part of the new set-up - "broadly representative of Brtish society", with its new ethnic and gender balances?

The idea is to create a new type of second chamber, less partisan, more inclined to the long view, with plenty of part-time members and no "politically ambitious" ones. Life membership would be all but impossible.

A standard 15 year term would even encourage party politican figures to be independent of their party whip, Lord Wakeham explained.

Assuming that Tony Blair accepts the idea, the Wakeham commission would consist of eight members, themselves appointed for 10 years and charged to dig out talent.

The three main political parties would nominate one member each, the crossbenches one and four, including the chairman, would be appointed on the meritocratic "Nolan principles" - preferably from each constituent nation of Britain. None would be an MP, though they would include members of the upper house itself.

They would receive nominations from the parties as usual, but there would be no working peers or new year's honours list appointments. Each nominee would have to be justified and could be rejected. No more peerages simply for being a party hack.

The royal commission rejected indirect election, for instance by local government leaders, or so-called "vocational groups" the idea that lawyers, artists or boilermakers might elect one of their own for a 15 year stint. They also said no to random selection - like the lottery - or to co-option of experts.

But the 12 commission members agreed at least 30% should be women, moving towards a 50-50 split, that ethnic and religious minorities should have better representation - though not ex officio.

There would also be up to 195 regionally elected members (more probably the compromise figure of 87), elected by voters on the same day and in the same regional constituencies as MEPs are now chosen.

For one thing the eight commissioners would have to re-balance the party appointees every election to reflect, not Commons seats, but a party's share of the votes. Thanks to retirement and death that would be easier than it sounds.

It need not be done immediately and, if needed, a few extras could be created, so that 550 is not a fixed number. For all the elaborate mechanism and effort in an average year just 20 to 30 new "peers" would emerge. It may be wholesome, but will also be a scrum.

fields.headline: 'New Britons' unite for common goal
fields.standfirst: Lord Wakeham will be live online at 4pm today on the Guardian network at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/lords
fields.trailText: The 12-strong royal commission which met throughout last year to produce yesterday's plea to Tony Blair reflects the kind of "New Briton" cross-section which the prime minister is keen to promote.
fields.body:
The 12-strong royal commission which met throughout last year to produce yesterday's plea to Tony Blair reflects the kind of "New Briton" cross-section which the prime minister is keen to promote.

A bishop, Oxford's Richard Harries , and a black trade union leader, Bill Morris , of the T&GWU, joined three women, one a Welsh BT manager, Ann Benyon , a Scots policy wonk, Sir Kenneth Munro , and a mixture of academics and establishment figures to produce a report they hope will neither please everyone nor offend Downing Street.

That is the style of Lord Wakeham , the 67-year-old accountant-turned Tory cabinet minister. He was boxed in by two political heavyweights as experienced as himself. Lord Hurd , aged 69, the former foreign secretary, represented William Hague's wish to move from supporting old privilege - hereditary peers - to full election of the upper house.

The MP for Manchester Gorton, Gerald Kaufman , Harold Wilson's Downing Street spokesman in the 60s represented Mr Blair's suspicion of a chamber that might threaten his command of the Commons.Both compromised, as did Dawn Oliver , of University College, London's constitution unit. She is a Liberal Democrat, said to have fought for wider election, though she backed the three options - all worth studying - yesterday.

Another political expert, Anthony King , of Essex University, is a veteran of many committees, as is Lord Butler of Brockwell, a newly retired Whitehall mandarin, soft-spoken cabinet secretary under John Major and Tony Blair.

Practical expertise on the workings of parliament was provided by Sir Michael Wheeler-Booth, a former senior official at Westminster. Last but never least was the formidable Baroness Brenda Dean , former print union head, now chairman of the housing corporation.

fields.headline: Boy questioned over baby killing
fields.standfirst: Police hold 12-year-old after stabbing attack
fields.trailText: Police yesterday began questioning a boy aged 12 about the horrific death of a six-month-old boy.
fields.body:
Police yesterday began questioning a boy aged 12 about the horrific death of a six-month-old boy.

Detectives, who said they were not looking for anyone else in connection with the killing, would not confirm that the boy is a brother or half brother of the murdered infant.

The baby suffered severe stab injuries, according to ambulance staff.

Police officers tried to revive the child after they were called to his home in the Hartcliffe area of Bristol on Wednesday afternoon but the boy was certified dead on arrival at Bristol children's hospital.

A postmortem was being carried out yesterday by a home office pathologist.

Forensic experts were carrying out a search of the bereaved family's three storey housing association home.

The house was sealed off with blue and white tape as detectives carried out their examination.

The family moved into the modern, brick-built property from another part of Bristol last summer.

They do not appear to have been particularly well known in the area.

The family's next door neighbours were too upset to talk about the tragedy.

But other local residents talked of their horror at what had happened.

"I have felt physically sick all day," one woman said. "It's just so tragic and appalling."

A woman living a few houses away said the first she knew that anything was wrong was when she left her house to see police cars and an ambulance outside the family's home.

"It made me feel sick when I heard about what had happened.

"It was was like I had lost one of my own children."

One young mother, who asked not to be named, said: "It must be every mother's nightmare.

"I just can't begin to imagine how I would cope if it happened to me."

Police are understood to have discovered the baby in an upstairs room of the four bedroom property.

A weapon was later recovered from the scene.

Hartcliffe, on the south western fringes of Bristol, is a mix of prewar and modern council and housing association properties.

The estate hit the headlines in July 1992 when the death of two joyriders who had stolen a police motorbike sparked several days of rioting.

The two men died after colliding head on with a police car following a high-speed chase.

Locals blamed the police for their deaths and took to the streets, looting shops and fighting running battles with riot police.

fields.headline: Reformed chamber presented as 'radical evolution'
fields.standfirst:
Wakeham report bans use of 'peer' but cannot decide on what to call members or the place where they sit
Lord Wakeham will be live online at 4pm today on the Guardian network at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/lords
fields.trailText: The Wakeham commission's blueprint for the reformed House of Lords sets out the case for what it argues is "radical evolutionary change which will contribute to better government for all".
fields.body:
The Wakeham commission's blueprint for the reformed House of Lords sets out the case for what it argues is "radical evolutionary change which will contribute to better government for all".

Its 216-page report, A House for the Future, contains 132 recommendations that the commission claimed to be "persuasive and intellectually coherent but also workable, durable and politically realistic".

If implemented, the document says, no new member of the second chamber would arrive there on the same basis as any existing member of the upper house.

The royal commission proposes a second chamber of around 550 members - the majority of whom would be chosen by an independent appointments commission, and the rest drawn from the regions by selection or direct election.

Members would no longer be known as peers, and those who have been made peers through the honours list would not be members.

The composition of the chamber as a whole would be regularly adjusted to reflect the balance of political opinion within the country.

Its elected element should "provide a voice" for the UK's nations and regions.

There should be a "totally independent" appointments commission, the report argued, with no association with the prime minister or government. It would appoint all members bar the regional members, lords of appeal, and representatives of the Church of England, and there would be no parliamentary approval of appointments.

This commission would be responsible for keeping the proportion of independents, or cross benchers, at around a fifth of the chamber's membership. It would be obliged to encourage appointments and nominations from under-represented groups, and report regularly to parliament on gender balance and minority ethnic groups. Commissioners would be charged with a "pro-active approach" to finding appointees, and the commission would be expected to consoutvocational, professional, cultural, sporting and other bodies, as well as publish criteria for appointment.

Model B (favoured by the majority of the commission) would see 87 members, directly elected at the time of each European parliament election according to PR similar to Euro elections.

Model C would provide for 195 regional members directly elected at the time of each European parliament election.

The 92 remaining hereditaries would be dispensed with, but could return as appointees or regional members.

Religious faiths
A large majority of the commission recommended that religious representation be "broader and deeper" than in the existing Lords. Though the Church of England should continue to be explicitly represented, so too should other Christian denominations and other faiths.

The commission proposed 16 places for Anglican representatives, five for other Christian denominations in England, and five for Christian denominations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. At least five more should be selected to be "broadly representative" of non-Christian faiths.

The commission concluded the current balance between the two houses is "about right and should not be radically disturbed".

It argued that the Commons should retain final say in respect of all public policy, while the second chamber should have sufficient power and authority to require the government and the Commons to reconsider proposed legislation and take account of cogent objections to it.

The chamber would retain the so-called "suspensory veto" set out in the parliament acts, giving it power to delay legislation but not permanently to block it. As now, the upper house would be unable to prevent the passage of a Commons bill backed by the Commons in two successive sessions of parliament.

While maintaining its right to delay flawed legislation, the second chamber would however continue to be obliged to consider government business within a reasonable time, and to observe the "Salisbury conventions" - the underlying principles obeyed by peers. As now, it would respect legislation in a governing party's manifesto, and would be expected to be sensible in using its powers to challenge the will of MPs.

The upper house would lose its absolute power to veto statutory instruments, on the grounds it was never used by peers. Instead, though the Commons would gain the final say, the chamber would gain more moderate but usable powers to delay, and demonstrate its concern about, specific statutory instruments.

It also suggests the second chamber should look at how to speed up consideration of law reform bills drawn up by the law commission.

In recognition of the growing volume of secondary legislation, the chamber should maintain and extend its power to scrutinise statutory instruments, the report said.

The chamber's role in protecting the constitution should be "maintained and enhanced", the commission recommended. One of the most important functions should be to act as a "constitutional long-stop", ensuring changes are made to the consitution only with full debate and a clear idea of the consequences.

However, the report stressed that the reformed chamber should not become a "federal legislature" supporting a "federal government", nor a forum for liasion be tween the government and the executives of the devolved Scottish parliament and Welsh and Northern Ireland assemblies. The house would not meet outside London, but some committees could meet in regional centres "from time to time".

Holding the government to account
The commission argued that ministers should continue to be drawn from, and be directly accountable to, the second chamber.

It recommended increasing ministerial accountability by requiring senior ministers based in the Commons to make statements to and take questions from second chamber committees when appropriate.

There should be more scrutiny of ministers' handling of European Union business, with additional resources for the European Union committee.

Though British MEPs would not be represented in the chamber, it should promote greater cooperation between MEPs and parliament.

More broadly, the commission recommended that the chamber continue to be "a relatively non-polemical forum for national debate", and that specialist committee work, drawing on the broad spread of expertise held by members, should continue.

It also proposes a committee to scrutinise treaties laid before parliament and to draw attention to any implications which might deserve consideration by parliament before the treaties are ratified.

The law lords
The commitee was asked to judge whether the chamber should continue to carry out judicial functions through committees of law lords.

It concluded that, as long as certain basic conventions were observed, there was no reason to change the present arrangements.

The report argued there were advantages in having senior judges in the legislature where they could be made aware of social developments and political balances that underlay most legislation.

However, in the light of controversy over the law lords' vote on the case of General Pinochet (which threw up concerns over the failure of one law lord involved in the judgment to declare his association with the human rights pressure group Amnesty International) the commission proposed requiring lords of appeal to set out in writing and publish a statement of the principles they intended to observe when participating in debates and votes and when considering their eligibility to sit on related cases.

Characteristics
The commission concluded that, taking account of its role and functions, the chamber should "above all, be authoritative, confident and broadly representative of the whole of British society".

Its members, according to the report, should have a breadth of experience and expertise outside the world of politics; particular skills and knowledge relevant to the careful assessment of constitutional and human rights issues; personal distinction; and the ability to bring a philosophical, moral or spiritual perspective and freedom from party domination.

Nevertheless, though authoritative, the reformed second chamber should not challenge the ultimate democratic authority of the Commons.

Titles and pay
The commission concludes that, since the link between the honours list and the Lords would be broken, members of the upper chamber would no longer be known as peers.

It floated the options of using the suffix LP (for Lord/Lady of Parliament) or the title senator, but made no recommendation. The report also stopped short of proposing a name for the second chamber, concluding that both titles "should be left to evolve".

The commission proposed increasing the remuneration received by members of the second chamber to ensure they were able to afford to attend from all over the country and not only from the south-east of England.

It argued that a clear link should be made between attendance and financial support, so that those who wished to devote significant time to parliamentary duties could afford to do so - without subsidising those who had a career and attended less frequently.

webTitle: Naked canteen lady puts diners off their food

fields.headline: Naked canteen lady puts diners off their food
fields.trailText: A naked statue of Buddha's mother is to be evicted from the British Library canteen because women staff objected to it as "sexist, pornographic - and by a man". They also said it put them off their food.
fields.body:
A naked statue of Buddha's mother is to be evicted from the British Library canteen because women staff objected to it as "sexist, pornographic - and by a man". They also said it put them off their food.

The decision delighted the sculptor's agent as well as the women. The work is meant to depict one of the most sacred events in Buddhist religion, the annunciation in which the founder was conceived.

But one woman at the library said yesterday: "Looking at it, you wouldn't say, ah yes, the mystic east.

"You'd say, there's a great big, naked woman up there - and what's that elephant doing?"

The six-foot sculpture, The Involuntary Creation, is by the Indian-born Royal Academician Dhruva Mistry. Estimated as worth £30,000, it was runner-up in a competition last year to mark the opening of the library.

Yesterday Mistry's UK agent, the London art dealer Anthony Wilkinson, said: "I think he will find it quite amusing".

Mistry, aged 43, who returned to India from Britain two years ago, was unavailable for comment. His biggest project so far is his redesign of Victoria Square, Birmingham, where one of his female statues in a fountain is locally nicknamed "the floozy in the Jacuzzi".

The British Library sculpture shows the childless queen Maha Maya lying asleep naked beside a temple, with an elephant hovering above her. This reflects Buddhist legend, in which angels carry her away on a night of the full moon to a Himalayan lake.

There a white elephant appears and circles her three times, striking her right side. When she awakes, wise men tell her husband: "Your Majesty, you are very lucky, the devas [angels] have chosen our queen as the mother of the Purest One and the child will become a very great being."

Sixty British Library staff members, all women, signed a petition against the work. A library spokesman said: "The workers objected because they had to sit and eat with this rather revealing sculpture of Buddha's mother, with her large breasts, above them."

"The elephant looks as if it is jumping, flying or crouching. Whether our staff thought that the woman's expression of ecstasy and abandon constituted entry by the elephant I don't know."

The library architect, Colin St John Wilson, a friend of Mistry, said: "The resistance to it appears to have less to do with shy, retiring librarians and more to do with feminism."

The woman staff objector, who asked not to be named, said: "If it was by a woman and showed equally inflated parts of a male body, every male would petition for its removal".

The Involuntary Creation may now be moved to a part of the library where the public can see it, close to an area with Buddhist texts which throw light on its symbolism.

webTitle: Trainee teachers must pass maths exam to qualify

fields.headline: Trainee teachers must pass maths exam to qualify
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sample maths questions that trainee teachers must be able to answer are published today, in preparation for the compulsory numeracy test to be taken by the first students in June.
fields.body:
Sample maths questions that trainee teachers must be able to answer are published today, in preparation for the compulsory numeracy test to be taken by the first students in June.

The test, comprising mental arithmetic and written questions, is the first of three national skills tests being introduced by the government's teacher training agency to ensure that teachers are numerate, literate and competent in information and communications technology.

The biggest teaching union, the National Union of Teachers, said trainees were already required to hold good grades in English language and maths to get on the course, and the requirement might deter entrants.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "We warmly welcome these tests. We are not talking rocket science here."

Students who fail at the first sitting can retake the tests, but if they fail again they will not be allowed to qualify and will be unable to work in the state sector. Around 25,000 trainees will take the first tests in June using paper and pen. From February next year candidates will be able to take all three tests at any stage of their teaching course, using a computer. The standard of the numeracy test is midway between GCSE and A-level maths. The agency said that it had not yet decided on the pass mark, but hinted that, as the test was designed to measure "competence", it would be on the high side.

Introduction of the tests was ordered by the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, and was included in his green paper designed to modernise and raise standards within the profession. The questions in all three tests will relate directly to day to day work in the classroom.

The agency's head of teacher training, Frankie Sulke, said yesterday: "There is an increasing need for all teachers to be proficient in their application of numeracy, literacy and information and communications technology in their everyday work."

The NUT general secretary, Doug McAvoy, said: "What will happen to the potentially brilliant music and arts teachers who may not be brilliant at adding up?"

Mr Hart said: "It is difficult to understand how anyone could remotely object to trainee teachers who will be handling numeracy in various forms every day in the classroom being required to show a basic understanding of maths."

Out for the count or back to school

Mental arithmetic

1.In a year group of 125 pupils, 80% achieved full attendance. How many pupils were absent on at least one occasion?

2. A teacher wants to show a 20 minute video, which must finish exactly five minutes before the end of the lesson. The lesson will end at 10 minutes past 11 o'clock. At what time must the video start?

3. A pupil scores 36 out of a possible 60. What percentage score is this?

4. A computer has an 800 megabyte hard drive. Some 435 megabytes are already used. A program is installed and occupes a further 120 megabytes. How many megabytes are available?

5. The entrance fee to a French museum is 12 francs. If the exchange rate is eight francs to the pound, how much is the entrance fee in pounds?

Written questions

6. A teacher arranged for five groups of pupils to give short presentations in a session lasting 1 hours. The pupils were given 15 minutes to prepare at the start of the session. Each presentation lasted 10 minutes. There was a changeover time of two minutes between presentations. How much of the session remained after the last presentation?

7. For a GCSE subject, 20% of the marks were for coursework and 80% for the exam. Coursework was marked out of 95 and the exam out of 75. A pupil scored 68 for coursework and 65 for the exam. What was final percentage mark to the nearest whole number?

a 74%; b 75%; c 83%; d 84%

Answers

1. 25; 2. 10.45 am or 1045 hrs; 3. 60%; 4. 245; 5. £1.50 or 150p; 6. 17 mins; 7. d.

A teacher wants to show a 20 minute video, which must finish exactly five minutes before the end of the lesson. The lesson will end at 10 minutes past 11 o'clock. At what time must the video start? 3. A pupil scores 36 out of a possible 60. What percentage score is this? 4. A computer has an 800 megabyte hard drive. Some 435 megabytes are already used. A program is installed and occupes a further 120 megabytes. How many megabytes are available? 5. The entrance fee to a French museum is 12 francs. If the exchange rate is eight francs to the pound, how much is the entrance fee in pounds? Written questions 6. A teacher arranged for five groups of pupils to give short presentations in a session lasting 1 hours. The pupils were given 15 minutes to prepare at the start of the session. fields.headline: Teacher poisoned by fumes awarded £500,000
fields.standfirst:
Head of science's career ended by slow leak of carbon monoxide

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A science teacher yesterday received more than £500,000 in a record school compensation deal after he was disabled by years of slow exposure to carbon monoxide seeping from a defective boiler room underneath his classroom laboratory.
fields.body:
A science teacher yesterday received more than £500,000 in a record school compensation deal after he was disabled by years of slow exposure to carbon monoxide seeping from a defective boiler room underneath his classroom laboratory.

John Gill, 52, was forced to retire early after 16 years as head of science at the Royal Manor School in Portland, Dorset. While his health was deteriorating in his final years at the school, the local education authority misinterpreted his poison-induced lethargy and began proceedings to challenge his competence.

According to details released yesterday by his union, the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, Mr Gill will receive £562,538 in an out-of-court settlement with insurers for Dorset county council. The authority has not accepted liability and a spokesman said the fault in venting of the school boiler was a "one in a million chance" that could not have been detected during regular maintenance.

Mr Gill, who is married with four children, has been unable to work for six years and took early retirement on grounds of ill health four years ago.

The Nasuwt said he required constant supervision because of severe mental impairment. One of the features of his disability that he found hardest to bear after a long career in teaching, was that he was too damaged to help his own children with their homework.

Mr Gill became head of science at the Royal Manor School in 1978 and taught for most of the next 16 years in a laboratory directly above the boiler room.

Subsequent investigation showed that a faulty flue was pumping carbon monoxide from the boiler through a vent under the teacher's workbench. But the county council said there was no evidence to show when the fault developed.

Unaware of the odourless, colourless gas, Mr Gill suffered for years from headaches and lethargy during term time, particularly in the winter. He recovered at weekends, holidays and in the summer term. A lab technician in a nearby room reported a similar pattern of symptoms, but neither associated them with poisoning and the pupils were not affected.

Mr Gill's condition became so severe that he was off work throughout the spring term in 1992.

After returning, his condition deteriorated further and his employers began proceedings to question his competence. At that stage the union satisfied the school that he had not lost his capability as a teacher.

In January 1994, he returned to school after the Christmas holiday when the lab had been closed and unventilated. Smelling fumes from the boiler but still unaware of the undetectable carbon monoxide, he evacuated pupils and staff and alerted the school's management.

He continued his lessons elsewhere, but by the end of the day his condition was so bad he had to be driven home. He never returned to work. The lab technician and another science teacher suffered less severe effects of carbon monoxide poisoning, the cause of which was later identified by engineers inspecting the boiler.

Mr Gill said: "My life was destroyed through the negligence of my employer and then they abandoned me completely ... I can only assume the amount of compensation, a record sum as I understand it, is evidence of the scale of their neglect."

Richard Ely, Dorset's director of education, said the council sympathised with Mr Gill and his family and was sorry that insurance proceedings had taken so long to resolve.

The authority is installing carbon monoxide sensors on school boilers and is advising schools on improving safety.

Under the government's scheme for devolving school budget, some heads and governors are taking responsibility for boiler maintenance that used to be handled by education authorities.

Invisible foe that kills by stealth

Carbon monoxide is deadly. It kills by stealth because nobody realises it is there. It is colourless, odourless and poisonous.

Carbon monoxide is emitted from the exhausts of cars with a petrol engine and has long been used as a way of committing suicide. It can also leak from domestic heating appliances burning coal, gas, oil or bottled gas.

The gas is poisonous because it binds with haemoglobin in the red blood cells and stops the molecule from carrying oxygen. The result is asphyxiation - insufficient oxygen reaching the brain - which can kill.

Inhaling small amounts of carbon monoxide over a long period may lead to brain damage.

The early symptoms can be mistaken for food poisoning. The victim feels dizzy, sick and faint and their head aches. If they continue to inhale enough of the gas, they will lose consciousness.

They urgently need fresh air, and artificial respiration if they have stopped breathing. They should always be checked by a doctor.

 Sarah Boseley

fields.headline: Police recover Constable oil sketches
fields.standfirst: Officers catch trio with works stolen from V&A museum
fields.trailText: Two oil sketches by John Constable stolen from the Victoria and Albert museum in London have been recovered in a classic "sting" operation by undercover officers from the national crime squad, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Two oil sketches by John Constable stolen from the Victoria and Albert museum in London have been recovered in a classic "sting" operation by undercover officers from the national crime squad, it emerged yesterday.

Three men were seized shortly after 3pm on Wednesday as they tried to sell the paintings to a detective posing as an art dealer in a west London hotel room.

Officers who were waiting in an adjoining suite burst in after a deal had been discussed. One of the men had a loaded handgun in the belt of his trousers but was overpowered before he had a chance to reach for it.

"It was over very quickly," said Detective Chief Inspector Mick Deats, who was in charge of the operation. "Thankfully there was no violence and the gun was not used. We caught them by surprise and my officers were not injured."

Three men, aged between 34 and 37, were being questioned at a west London police station last night.

The sketches - Dedham Lock and Mill (c1810-1815) and Sketch for Valley Farm (c1835) - have a combined value of £800,000. They were returned to the V&A yesterday apparently in good condition, though they were being inspected at its conservation studio. The museum realised the sketches were missing from the prints and drawings study room in November 1998, when another gallery asked if it could include them in an exhibition.

Only staff and accredited visitors are given access to the department, which contains 1m works. The museum admitted that nobody had seen the paintings since an audit in August 1998.

The first clues to the paintings' whereabouts came last week when an informer tipped off the squad that they were being touted around by figures in the underworld.

A six-strong team was set up in an operation codenamed "Goldfinch", and a meeting was arranged with the three men at the hotel.

"They were arrested as they went through the process of trying to sell the paintings," said Mr Deats. Within hours, officers raided a house in Beckton, east London.

Alan Borg, director of the V&A, said the museum was delighted to have the sketches back, describing them as "important pieces of our artistic heritage".

They were painted near Constable's home on the Suffolk-Essex borders and were studies for larger works.

Alexandra Smith, operations manager of the art loss register, an international database of stolen art and antiques, said: "They are typical Constable scenes and have artistic value in their own right. They are quite wild and show a more relaxed, looser style."

The V&A has the largest collection of works by Constable with 415, mostly on paper, including 80 oils and oil sketches. The missing paintings were bequeathed to the museum by Constable's daughter, Isobel, in 1888. Dedham Lock and Mill is particularly important to the museum because it also holds the finished painting in its collection.

Art theft has become an international industry worth £3bn a year, the biggest illegal trade after drugs and arms.

Although some paintings are stolen to order, the register believes many are taken by criminals who have little idea of their intrinsic value.

James Emson, managing director of the register, said: "They think they are going to make a fortune, but then realise it is quite difficult to get rid of them."

webTitle: SS man's unit shot British PoWs

fields.headline: SS man's unit shot British PoWs
fields.trailText: The SS unit to which a former German alleged war criminal now living in Britain belonged, murdered seven British prisoners of war in cold blood, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The SS unit to which a former German alleged war criminal now living in Britain belonged, murdered seven British prisoners of war in cold blood, the Guardian has learned.

The former concentration camp guard, Alexander Schweidler, 78, is living in a council house in Milton Keynes and receiving a state pension. A naturalised British citizen since 1964, he resettled here after being deported from the US in 1994 for crimes against humanity.

MPs and Jewish groups yesterday called for an urgent meeting with the Home Secretary. They also demanded Mr Schweidler's citizenship be revoked and that British police reinvestigate his alleged role in atrocities while serving at the Mauthausen concentration camp where more than 80,000 inmates died.

Documents seen by the Guardian reveal that seven British soldiers were among a group of 48 prisoners executed at Mauthausen. Mr Schweidler was a member of the SS unit which carried out the shootings on September 6 and 7, 1944. There is no evidence pointing to or ruling out his involvement.

It is believed that the Britons were members of the Special Operations Executive, which waged a covert war against Germany behind enemy lines.

The SS kept a record of those they executed in a book called "the registry of unnatural deaths". One record recovered from the camp lists four "English soldiers" who were shot on September 6. They were Lt Marcus Bloome, Lt John Young, Major Gilbert Norman, of the Durham Light Infantry, and Captain Sydney Jones, of the Royal Engineers.

The other British soldiers who were shot were Captain Edward Wilkinson, Captain Isidore Newman, and Lt George Clement, of the Royal Armoured Corps.

A Czechoslovakian inmate at Mauthausen, Victor Pistora, described the massacre in a document prepared by a British officer, Vera Atkins, who investigated the deaths of SOE members at the camp.

Mr Pistora wrote: "At 1 o'clock these 48 men left for the quarry and in the afternoon 21 were shot. Towards 5 o'clock I saw personally the entry of the remainder surrounded by armed SS men, being led off to the camp prison and dragging carts in which were piled the bodies of their murdered comrades. These 27 officers spent the night in the prison.

"The next day [September 7] they were brought out after the work parties, that is to say 7.30 [am] and led off immediately down the path which led to the quarry where they were shot down by tommy guns and light machine guns. By 8 o'clock all was over."

Lord Janner, secretary of the all party war crimes group which reconvened yesterday after two years, said: "If he was a guard in the camp at the time, he should be asked if he has any knowledge of who murdered these British troops."

Peter Black, of the US Holocaust museum, who has studied how Mauthausen worked, said: "Mr Schweidler, like the others, is responsible for keeping the prisoners in the camp. He, like others, may have been aware that captured soldiers were shot." Perimeter guards, which Mr Schweidler claims to have been, were known to have escorted prisoners to their place of execution.

Mr Schweidler admitted to the Guardian that he had been an SS guard at Mauthausen. He said a report filed to the SS, bearing his signature, in which he details gunning down two escaping Russian prisoners, was "falsified". In another document seen by the Guardian an SS guard says prisoners were chased towards the camp fence so that they could be used as live target practice.

webTitle: DTI appoints inspectors to investigate Robinson firm

fields.headline: DTI appoints inspectors to investigate Robinson firm
fields.trailText: Government inspectors were appointed last night to investigate TransTec, the collapsed engineering group founded by the former Labour treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson.
fields.body:
Government inspectors were appointed last night to investigate TransTec, the collapsed engineering group founded by the former Labour treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson.

Chartered accountant Hugh Alous and barrister Roger Kaye QC have been armed with sweeping powers to investigate the troubled company's past - stretching back, if they so choose, to its birth in the 1980s. The pair are known as veteran investigators capable of dealing with sensitive and complex cases - conducting the probes into Mohamed Al Fayed's purchase of Harrods and the Anglia share dealing affair involving Lord Archer.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, has ordered them to complete their inquiry as quickly as possible and has, uniquely, given a commitment to publish their report.

The dramatic move was being seen in Westminster as a bid by supporters of the prime minister - of whom Mr Byers is one - to get a grip on an embarrassing episode blamed on Mr Robinson, a close ally of the chancellor, Gordon Brown. Mr Robinson may face not only compulsory questioning by the inspectors but possible disqualification as a company director should his conduct at TransTec be called into question.

TransTec collapsed just before Christmas with debts of about £200m. Bankers pulled the plug after it emerged TransTec had concealed from investors both a £12m claim from motor giant Ford and the fact that £8m of this claim had been secretly paid to the car company. Mr Robinson, who owns 16% of TransTec, has seen the value of his investment fall from £36m three years ago to less than £2m when the shares were suspended on Christmas Eve.

The Labour MP for Coventry north-west resigned from the company in May 1997 when he entered office as a government minister, and the concealment of the £12m claim took place after that date. But the first indications of Ford's unhappiness with TransTec would have emerged during 1996, when Mr Robinson was still chairman.

Mr Byers has asked the inspectors to concentrate their inquiry in two areas: the concealment in the accounts of a £12m claim from Ford for alleged late delivery of motor parts TransTec produced for the group; and the reasons for TransTec's collapse.

Mr Byers said last night: "There are clearly a number of serious issues regarding the collapse of TransTec which the public interest requires to be investigated by independent inspectors.

"I have emphasised to the inspectors that their prime objective must be to provide me with a full report as quickly as possible, consistent with the need to undertake a fair, thorough and professional investigation."

The results of the inquiry can be passed to professional bodies and to the crown prosecution service.

The investigators are empowered under section 432 of the companies act, which covers circumstances that suggest to the DTI that a company's affairs have been conducted so as to defraud creditors or for another fraudulent or unlawful purpose, or that shareholders have been deprived of information, or that officers of the company have been guilty of fraud, misfeasance or other misconduct.

Inspectors can examine the entire history of TransTec, founded by Mr Robinson in the 1980s as a vehicle for turning academic ideas into money-making propositions. It was transformed in 1990 under a deal with a Maxwell-controlled engineering group, Central & Sherwood. TransTec in its present form was created after a £5.5m deal between Mr Robinson and Mr Maxwell.

Mr Robinson has been a generous donor to the Labour party, and his generosity cost him his job as paymaster general 13 months ago, when it emerged he had made a £373,000 home loan to the then trade and industry secretary, Peter Mandelson, who also resigned.

fields.headline: Ministers' £750m disability saving
fields.trailText: The government has underspent on disability benefits by precisely the amount it set out to save through the controversial cuts that triggered the biggest backbench revolt since Labour took office, it is today revealed.
fields.body:
The government has underspent on disability benefits by precisely the amount it set out to save through the controversial cuts that triggered the biggest backbench revolt since Labour took office, it is today revealed.

The underspending last year of just over £750m was half as much again as ministers eventually achieved by the cuts after they were forced to make concessions to minimise a second revolt.

Disability campaigners are angrily questioning why Labour went ahead with the cuts, which were deeply unpopular and soured relations with leading charities, when it was heading for savings of such a scale.

Lorna Reith, chief executive of the Disability Alliance umbrella group, said: "They must have known this when they were cutting benefits and not increasing benefits for disabled children by as much as they ought."

The underspending is disclosed in the national audit office's annual report on the social security accounts. The report, for 1998-99, shows that the government saved almost £1.7bn of what it planned to spend that year on benefits adminstered centrally.

By far the largest area of saving was disability benefits, where the £754m unspent was equivalent to 7.7% of the cash that was paid out.

Soon after Labour took office, it identified disability benefits as a key target for reform. It said that it was "one of the fastest growing areas of social security" and that "current trends indicate a continuation of this growth".

In October, 1998, Alistair Darling, social security secretary, published the plans for disability benefit changes designed to achieve an ultimate net cut in spending of £750m a year.

Today's NAO report says Mr Darling's department had identified "a large underspending" two months before his announcement because "customer levels rose less than was anticipated". It had then been too late to revise the budget allocation.

Ms Reith said it would not have been too late to abandon the cuts, as they had not even been tabled, or to do something to promote disability benefits where take up was low.

According to latest official figures, take up of the care component of disability living allowance is only 30-50%. Take up of the mobility component is 50-70% and of attendance allowance 40-60%.

The cuts will affect mainly future claimants of incapacity benefit, tightening eligibility criteria and clawing back benefit from people with private pensions or insurance payments.

Following the concessions, the eventual net saving will be £530m-£550m a year.

More than 80 Labour MPs rebelled when the cuts went before the commons last May and more than 50 joined the second revolt last November.

A department of social security spokeswoman said the changes were not about saving money, but ensuring that benefit went to the right people and did what was intended. The spending forecast for disability benefits had been "prudent", but had overestimated the numbers of claimants.

The total underspending of £1.7bn identified by the NAO in 1998-99 means that the government saved £3.5bn on benefits in the first two years after the general election as unemployment fell steeply.

Disability campaigners are angrily questioning why Labour went ahead with the cuts, which were deeply unpopular and soured relations with leading charities, when it was heading for savings of such a scale. Lorna Reith, chief executive of the Disability Alliance umbrella group, said: "They must have known this when they were cutting benefits and not increasing benefits for disabled children by as much as they ought."
