webTitle: Girl left outside club was lured to her death

fields.headline: Girl left outside club was lured to her death
fields.standfirst: Life for labourer who enticed 17-year-old to his flat and murdered her after she was abandoned on street
fields.trailText: A schoolgirl was sexually assaulted and murdered by an unemployed labourer after she had been ejected from a friend's birthday party at a nightclub.
fields.body:
A schoolgirl was sexually assaulted and murdered by an unemployed labourer after she had been ejected from a friend's birthday party at a nightclub.

Ashleigh Robinson, 17, was asked to leave Cinderella's nightclub in Guildford, Surrey, by a bouncer after appearing unsteady on her feet. Despite repeated requests to be let back in she was still on the street when, by "a cruel twist of fate", Matthew Howick, 30, passed by.

After enticing her to his flat Howick subjected her to a prolonged assault before strangling her with a shower hose and dumping her naked body in a street 50 yards away. Howick, 30, of Guildford, admitted murdering Ashleigh on April 13 last year and was jailed for life at the Old Bailey yesterday.

Ashleigh had travelled to Guildford from Somerset, where she lived, to attend a birthday party. A coach had been organised to take a group of 46 teenagers to the party and bring them home again. Ashleigh had been due to stay with the parents of a friend.

"Although she [Ashleigh] was not misbehaving in any way, a doorman approached her," said Mark Dennis, prosecuting.

"She had been sitting on a ledge talking to a 19-year-old boy, and it seemed the doorman had not liked her sitting on the ledge and asked her to get off."

The doorman then decided she was unstable and sent her outside the club to be allowed back in later.

"Why this was done without anyone bothering to contact her friends so someone could stand with her, or to ask her to sit in the foyer or a room is not known and something only the nightclub can answer for," said Mr Dennis.

The court heard that closed cicuit television cameras recorded Ashleigh standing outside the club without her jacket and handbag at 11.15pm, and that she appeared to have made repeated requests to be allowed back in.

A doorman went out and stayed with her for a while but her exclusion coincided with the arrival of Howick, said Mr Dennis.

"What followed demonstrates some degree of confidence on his part, quick thinking and determination," Mr Dennis told the court.

The teenager and Howick engaged in conversation, with the doorman excluded, and Howick received confirmation she was not allowed back in because of her state. A CCTV camera recorded her being led up the street with Howick holding her hand.

One passer-by described having seen someone "marching" Ashleigh away. A motorist who had the impression they were arguing drove around the block to see what was happening, but the pair had disappeared.

Mr Dennis said that Ashleigh had been missed by her friends, but it was not until later that they realised she had not been in another part of the club. They reported her missing to police, and viewed CCTV footage taken around the time the club closed. Crucially, they did not see film of the earlier incident.

The following day Howick, who spent the morning attempting to clean his flat, saw police activity outside and went to visit his mother. When he returned officers were waiting for him.

In a black bin bag in the loft officers found the shower cord, which matched marks on the dead girl's neck. Five pieces of tape used to bind and gag Ashleigh were also recovered, with traces of her hair and saliva stuck to them.

Howick initially told detectives Ashleigh had left him in the street, but then admitted taking her to his flat "for coffee" and said a violent argument took place. She had said all men were after the same thing. He claimed she stated: "I am not that kind of person - what kind of girl do you think I am?"

Sentencing Howick, Judge Geoffrey Grigson said: "You snuffed out a bright young life in a terrible way."

He added: "Plainly Ashleigh Robinson was drunk, but however drunk she may have been, nothing she did or could have done justified your response."

Nigel Sweeney, defending, said Howick, who is 6ft 4ins, 18 stones and dyslexic, was of lower-than-average intelligence and could remember little of what happened on the evening of the murder.

webTitle: Real IRA ends silence with call to arms

fields.headline: Real IRA ends silence with call to arms
fields.standfirst:
Real IRA ends silence with call to arms

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Real IRA last night issued a dramatic call to arms to republican terrorists who have doubts about Sinn Fein's approach to come under its banner and push for a united Ireland.
fields.body:
The Real IRA last night issued a dramatic call to arms to republican terrorists who have doubts about Sinn Fein's approach to come under its banner and push for a united Ireland.

The statement fell short of announcing an imminent return to violence, but it did indicate that the hardline group was considering ending its ceasefire.

The Real IRA announced its cessation three weeks after killing 29 people and injuring 200 in a car bomb attack in Omagh, Co Tyrone, in August 1998. It was worst atrocity in 30 years of the Troubles.

The terror group, led by a former quartermaster of the IRA, called its ceasefire only after waiting to see whether the revulsion within republicanism which the Omagh massacre sparked would dissipate. Its statement 16 months ago was its last until now.

Security sources suggested last night's long recruitment statement - the first from a terror group ever to be delivered to the media via email - meant the Real IRA might soon call off its cessation. It instructed all volunteers to ensure the safety of civilians at all times, a grudging apology for the deaths at Omagh.

One view within republicanism was that the Real IRA's move would make it more difficult for the IRA to begin arms decommissioning. That would pile pressure on the fledging government in Northern Ireland, apparently one of the key aims behind last night's statement.

The group encourages all those doubting Sinn Fein's strategy to rally behind it, evoking the all-Ireland parliament of 1918. There are several swipes at mainstream republicans, labelling them "an elite clique, or corrupt treacherous administration."

But some republicans believe the Real IRA is so discredited that its move could entice the IRA to make a start to decommissioning. There is bad blood between the outfits, and there have been clashes.

While there have been defections to the Real IRA, the Irish police believe their recent operations, culminating in several arrests, have left the dissident group weakened and with dented credibility. They believe few IRA members are likely to defect. One Garda source discounted recent suggestions the Real IRA had doubled in strength to almost 200 members. He believed the figure remained between 80 and 100 members.

The Real IRA was formed when several leading IRA figures quit in September 1997 in opposition to Sinn Fein signing up to the Mitchell principles of peace and democracy to enter the multi-party talks at Stormont. It is opposed to the Good Friday agreement.

It has since attracted support from the small dissident group, Continuity IRA, linked to Republican Sinn Fein, and the Irish National Liberation Army.

It has also won the support of several well-respected IRA figures, particularly in border areas.

The statement says: "It would be remiss of Oglaigh na hEireann to abdicate our responsibility for the many innocent lives that have been lost and injuries occurred as a consequence of the ongoing struggle for freedom in the past century. It is incumbent on all volunteers to ensure the safety of non-combatants at all times."

fields.headline: BMA berates Straw over Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The British Medical Association has criticised Jack Straw for deciding to keep the former dictator Augusto Pinochet's medical report secret, while Spain yesterday cleared the way for the general to be sent home.
fields.body:
The British Medical Association has criticised Jack Straw for deciding to keep the former dictator Augusto Pinochet's medical report secret, while Spain yesterday cleared the way for the general to be sent home.

In a letter to the Times, Michael Wilks, chairman of the BMA's medical ethics committee, said the details of the examination should have been released in court following medical and legal precedents.

He said Mr Straw should not give in to pressure from the general over patient confidentiality because the doctors who carried out the report were acting in a forensic capacity and had a responsibility to the organisation asking them to carry out the examination.

In his letter he said: "In being asked to provide an opinion on the general's fitness to stand trial, the reports compiled should be disclosable in any judicial procedures, and the opinion therein tested in court."

The criticism will increase pressure on Mr Straw to release the report, which led to the home secretary saying that he was "minded" to release General Pinochet because he was mentally unfit to stand trial.

Human rights groups, Labour MPs and Spanish judge Baltasar Garzon have all requested access to the report.

However, in what amounts to Spain avoiding further embarrassment over the Pinochet case, the Spanish government yesterday blocked Judge Garzon's bid to file an immediate appeal if Britain frees the former dictator.

The foreign minister, Abel Matutes, said he had turned down Judge Garzon's request to ask British prosecutors to challenge any move by Mr Straw to send the 84-year-old general home. "There will be no further appeals," Mr Matutes told reporters.

webTitle: EU scientists' new doubts over beef on the bone

fields.headline: EU scientists' new doubts over beef on the bone
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Britain may be forced by the EU to reintroduce the beef on the bone ban and bring in further controls on sheep offal as top European scientists are said to be assailed by new doubts.
fields.body:
Britain may be forced by the EU to reintroduce the beef on the bone ban and bring in further controls on sheep offal as top European scientists are said to be assailed by new doubts.

An internal Welsh assembly briefing last night showed the extent of concern among some civil servants about the consequences of an EU report which raises new worries about dangers from nerve endings near the bones of cattle.

The ministry of agriculture in London quickly tried to quash the fears, saying the document had been written by a junior official who had misinterpreted the information. A spokesman said: "There is not going to be a ban. The official's assessment of what the European commission is looking at is incorrect."

The memo will raise the political temperature over the safety of British beef yet again, just as the European commission's legal battle with France over its refusal to allow it into the country gets under way. The document was emailed by mistake to journalists yesterday. But the ministry spokesman insisted it was not intended for dissemination even within the civil service "and would certainly not have got any credibility among officials".

A Welsh assembly spokesman last night refused to comment on the leak but Tim Yeo, the shadow agriculture spokesman, said: "The government must stamp on this outrageous suggestion immediately. There is no scientific or health justification for such a ban. A failure to block this ridiculous proposal will be the final nail in [agriculture minister] Nick Brown's coffin."

The beef on the bone ban was only lifted last month after two years in which few cases were brought , and no one successfully prosecuted, for breaking it despite some high profile flouting of the rules. It was unclear last night whether Britain had, or needed, formal permission from Brussels to lift the ban but it seems unlikely that ministers went ahead without getting the green light to do so.

But the government will be worried that it has been caught by a paper by EU scientists whose main aim was to ensure member states that have no controls about what parts of cattle are allowed into food introduce them.

Britain already has a lot.

Seven countries, including Germany, have none. The scientists warn that EU consumers are at risk, even in countries which claim to have no BSE, because of cross-border trade in live animals, organs and offals.

The internal memo causing all the trouble last night raised the prospect of new EU regulations being introduced in July.

This would require the removal of additional material from cattle and sheep carcasses thought most at risk of spreading BSE to humans.

fields.headline: Kaufman storms from TV studio
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Members of the House of Lords may not voluntarily give up their seats under yesterday's reform plans, but the Labour MP, Gerald Kaufman, was more than willing to give up his last night as a TV news item over Lords reform turned nasty.
fields.body:
Members of the House of Lords may not voluntarily give up their seats under yesterday's reform plans, but the Labour MP, Gerald Kaufman, was more than willing to give up his last night as a TV news item over Lords reform turned nasty.

Mr Kaufman ripped out his earpiece and stormed out of the Channel 4 News studio during a live interview with Jon Snow.

He had been angered at the beginning of the four-minute interview when Mr Snow suggested that members of the Lords would not voluntarily resign under the reform plans. Voices were raised and insults traded.

Mr Kaufman, a member of the Wakeham Commission which is behind the proposals, complained that the programme had probably not "even opened" the report.

Mr Snow asked why anyone in the Lords would give up their seats given the perks, in cluding free parking and cheap dining.

Mr Kaufman, MP for Manchester Gorton, said: "This is really very cheap stuff. No, it's not true and you've got it wrong and you've misinformed your viewers on issue after issue."

As Mr Snow tried to reply, the MP barked: "Look, stop interrupting me. You've had your say. Let me now answer your questions and let me do it in complete sentences."

Mr Snow accused Mr Kaufman of wanting a seat in the Lords to which the increasingly angry MP replied: "No, I will never go to the House of Lords. I have never heard so much ludicrous claptrap. You're sinking so far below your normal standards that I am amazed at this."

The Liberal Democrat MP, Robert Maclennan, said on the programme that he thought Mr Kaufman's reaction had been "abusive, inaccurate and evasive".

Millions of viewers then watched as Mr Kaufman removed his earplug and left.

webTitle: Climate shakeup:  US faces weather extremes for next 30 years, say Pacific ocean watchers

fields.headline: Climate shakeup:  US faces weather extremes for next 30 years, say Pacific ocean watchers
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Californians could be forced to revive the tradition of spraying scorched grass green if scientists' interpretations of new data are correct, and the unusual weather patterns of the past 18 months become the norm for the next 30 years.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison  in New York and  Tim Radford
fields.body:
Californians could be forced to revive the tradition of spraying scorched grass green if scientists' interpretations of new data are correct, and the unusual weather patterns of the past 18 months become the norm for the next 30 years.

"For the last 20 years, California has had above normal rainfall and Seattle has had milder weather and less rainfall," said William Patzert, an oceanographer at Nasa's jet propulsion laboratory in Pasadena. "Now we're going back to the good old days, when it was really dry in California and really stormy in Seattle."

The climate change - observed through a concept called the pacific decadal oscillation (PDO) - might have started to take effect already, with parts of southern California experiencing its third-driest rainy season since records began, and Texas enduring its third drought in four years.

Researchers believe that the Pacific, which covers a third of the earth's surface, may be undergoing a dramatic temperature change.

Winters that are dry and hot in the south-western United States, cold in the north-east and wet in the north-west are normally associated with La Niña, a cooling in the Pacific near the equator. This is the opposite of El Niño, which makes it rain in California.

New images from the US-French Topex/Poseidon satellite show that sea surfaces are up to 9in higher than normal around the Pacific rim and about the same amount lower near Central and South America.

This is believed to be caused by water expanding and contracting with higher and lower temperatures.

PDO, a theory of climate cycles, is a system in which ocean temperature changes indicate a shift that happens every 20 or 30 years and, for unknown reasons, change the weather.

"The persistence of warmer and colder than average ocean temperatures shows us there is much more than an isolated La Niña ocurring in the Pacific ocean," said Mr Patzert.

"We're coming out of a warm PDO pattern, and if it continues into a cold PDO, certain tendencies that we've seen for the past 20 years could potentially reverse themselves, changing temperature and rainfall patterns around the planet."

"We're coming out of a warm PDO pattern, and if it continues into a cold PDO, certain tendencies that we've seen for the past 20 years could potentially reverse themselves, changing temperature and rainfall patterns around the planet."

webTitle: Like it or lump it, Hague tells critics

fields.headline: Like it or lump it, Hague tells critics
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday issued a direct challenge to the Tory grandees Kenneth Clarke and Michael Heseltine to leave the Conservative party if they refuse to accept his leadership.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday issued a direct challenge to the Tory grandees Kenneth Clarke and Michael Heseltine to leave the Conservative party if they refuse to accept his leadership.

In his strongest attack on the two "big beasts", who have recently stepped up their attacks on the Tory leadership, Mr Hague dismissed Mr Clarke and Mr Heseltine as spent forces who would never hold office under his leadership.

Underlining his determination to stamp out dissent, Mr Hague said: "They will have to like it or lump it." Mr Hague's outburst, which came during an appearance on BBC Radio 2's Jimmy Young Show, was provoked by a series of stinging attacks on his leadership from party grandees who include John Major and the former chancellors Ken Clarke and Geoffrey Howe.

Mr Clarke, who infuriated Mr Hague last year when he made a joint appearance with Tony Blair to promote Europe, warned over the new year that the Tory party was in danger of making itself unelectable after its recent "lurch to the right".

His criticisms were echoed by Lord Howe who said that the Tory party was not seen as a "credible alternative" government.

Mr Hague struck back yesterday, saying that he would not bow to pressure to abandon his hardline stance on Europe or his rightwing Common Sense revolution. "Nobody is going to put me off - I don't care who criticises me on things like that," he said. "That is what we are going to do, and they will have to like it or lump it."

Mr Hague sent a clear signal that he will do his best to freeze out the grandees. "The remaining people who still cause some difficulties within the party no longer hold positions of influence or power in the Conservative party, and clearly nor are they going to do so," he said.

"When you've made a generational change within a party, some of the people who are no longer in the leadership of the party of course harbour some resentments and grudges. Well so be it, that's life, and we go on without them."

Mr Hague issued a milder rebuke to Mr Major who warned his successor over the new year to distance himself from Margaret Thatcher, which he described as "the ghost of government past". The Tory leader said that Mr Major's remarks had been taken out of context, but added pointedly: "John Major was warning us to do things that we are not going to do."

The Tory leader denied that he had adopted an extremist position on Europe and he insisted that his new set of policies did not mark a shift to the right. "This is the middle," he said. "The middle in British politics is to be committed to keep the pound. I don't think it's a right-left thing at all."

Mr Hague's bitter attack on the likes of Mr Clarke and Mr Heseltine, on a high-profile radio show, was designed to show that he is a strong leader in the mould of Tony Blair. The Tory leadership is obsessed by the prime minister's apparent toughness and believes that high-profile rebukes and sacking will show that Mr Hague is decisive.

However, moderate Tory MPs believe that hitting out at such popular figures will backfire on Mr Hague by casting him as the extremist.

Labour will be delighted by Mr Hague's outburst. The prime minister hit back at Mr Hague this week in the Commons, by pointing out that his pledge to cut tax would lead to a drop in NHS funding.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.body:
Yet another American has won $1m on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire overseas, while the Brits still can't seem to make it past the half-million mark. Dan Blonsky, a lawyer from Miami, this week became the second contestant to hit the US jackpot by correctly answering how many miles separate the earth and the sun. (It's 93 million, apparently).

Unconcerned about over-extending the appeal of the show, US network ABC has dumped the "stunt scheduling" tactics adopted here, of broadcasting the show every night for a fortnight, and is running Millionaire as a full series three nights a week. So far, the ratings have only risen, and ABC is celebrating an amazing turnaround from lowest rated network to king of the heap. Whereas on ITV, Millionaire is starting to suffer. It was beaten by EastEnders on Monday and Tuesday this week - albeit narrowly - and Wednesday's £500,000 winner scored just 9.8m viewers, despite leaks to the press that a new record had been set.

The only cloud on ABC's horizon is that Millionaire has been ruled ineligible for the Emmys. Despite being the major prime-time ratings hit of the year, it cannot be entered for the primetime Emmys, which will be presented in September, due to a bizarre rule stating that gameshows can only be entered for daytime Emmys.

Meanwhile, chat-show plans for Newsnight savager Jeremy Paxman continue apace. Paxman meets Bill Gates was the prototype; the clash of the titans received a perfectly respectable 2.5m viewers for BBC2, so is set to be followed by Paxman meeting Hillary Clinton, Rupert Murdoch and Steven Spielberg. Or so the producers wish. Imagine, if you will, even now teams of BBC researchers are wooing Hillary, Rupert and Steven with faxes, flowers and flattery. Sadly, in six months time, they'll almost certainly end up with Edwina Currie, Piers Morgan and Michael Winner.

fields.headline: The home front
fields.standfirst: The Sopranos and Larry Sanders both owe their existence to the US subscription channel, HBO, which offers viewers uncut, uninterrupted quality TV.  Janine Gibson  thinks we might be seeing the future of British television
fields.trailText: The Sopranos and Larry Sanders both owe their existence to the US subscription channel, HBO, which offers viewers uncut, uninterrupted quality TV. Janine Gibson thinks we might be seeing the future of British television
fields.body:
What motivates a television viewer, however fanatical, to take a very deep breath, make a check on their finances and shell out anywhere between £10 and £30 a month to sign up for the multi-channel experience?

Certainly not the attractive dish and rarely the cheap telephony. The twin gods of pay-TV have been sports and movies since a bright spark first overpaid for a boxing bout and invented the concept of inviting the neighbours round with a six pack for a fight party.

To that short list, add an overweight Mafia anti-hero. The Sopranos, which launched its second series last week in the US, has finally proved what many have suspected for some time. That even a drama series can drive pay-TV subscriptions - if it's good enough.

Sitting smugly on this revelation and counting the new sign-ups is Home Box Office, owned by Time Warner. Founded nearly 20 years ago as a cable movie channel offering the paying public uncut, advert-free films, over the last 10 years it has evolved into one of America's classiest programmers.

In the early 90s, HBO realised that simply providing another window for feature-film viewing between cinema release, video release and network screening was not sufficient to maintain its growth, and began to commission and produce its own programmes. Early cult series such as Dream On made their way over the Atlantic to late-night slots on BBC2 or Channel 4, where suitably dedicated viewers have ever since complained vociferously about their erratic scheduling.

Liberated by only having to satisfy its subscriber base, HBO developed a reputation for high-end comedy and drama on subjects considered too controversial for the US networks, known for their lack of tenacity. So, when Channel 4 was looking for a US home for its Queer As Folk gay drama series, the first to be approached were the subscription cable networks HBO and Showtime.

In return for its high investment in quality shows, HBO has generated enormous loyalty from its subscriber base and seems to have solved the question of how to make the public pay for something they are accustomed to receiving for free - give them something they can't get for free. Searching for ways to improve value for its subscribers, HBO moved into comedy, drama and sports.

Its early successes included transforming Tracey Ullman's career from "the girl in Three Of A Kind" to Emmy award-winning darling of the smart set in LA. Tracey Takes On - her character-driven sketch show, is a staple of the network's comedy strand; it was the original home of The Simpsons, and it provided the kind of critical success which enabled the channel to begin to brand itself as premium product.

Then in the early 90s there was The Larry Sanders Show, the cameo-heavy, sitcom-makers' sitcom, still cited by television producers as the best ever. A subtly crafted mockery of the US late-night talk-show phenomenon, Larry Sanders will never grab the ratings volume of Friends, but it proved a long-running hit for HBO. Sex And The City, the lurid depiction of bedroom goings-on in Manhattan, carried the momentum and enhanced HBO's reputation for bringing the shows other networks dare not touch.

It's The Sopranos, though, which has been described as HBO's "first phenomenon". It is its first true breakthrough series: that is, a show with so much buzz around it that it generates subscriptions to the channel. It is estimated to have lured more new subscribers than any other show in the history of the network.

Now that every football fan whose lust for the premier league outweighed their reluctance to pay for television is already signed up, and every movie obsessive is watching TNT and Sky Premier, the pay-networks are having to turn their attention to this altogether harder-to-reach section of the paying public.

The genius is pitching HBO as not just another movie channel. It's the comedy, entertainment and drama channel for the kind of subscriber who doesn't really like to admit to watching television. HBO also presents documentaries about subjects unheard of on American television. Children In War, beginning later this month on HBO, was filmed in Bosnia, Israel, Rwanda and Northern Ireland. More BBC2 than Sky One.

No one is monitoring HBO's success more closely than Sky. Two years ago, Sky revamped its movie channel offering and began to investigate pitching Sky Premier as the HBO of the UK. It began to pour money into original productions - exclusive TV movies which would premiere on the network - and more recently has begun to invest in sitcoms - a deal with Al Murray, the pub landlord, and the £5m, 22-part offering from David Baddiel aimed for Sky One. Clearly the hope is to generate the same type of premium programmes for the non-sport-obsessed subscriber. It should, at least, be cheaper than trying to hold on to the premier league.

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText:
High Art (Lisa Cholodenko, 1998)
10pm, FilmFour
fields.body:
High Art (Lisa Cholodenko, 1998)
10pm, FilmFour

Perceptive lesbian drama elevated by a desire to explore character and motivation rather than salivate over its subject matter. Radha Mitchell is the naive art magazine editor who discovers that her neighbour, Ally Sheedy (unrecognisable from her Brat Pack days), is a once-celebrated, but now drug-addled photographer. Ambition and curiosity gradually draw her into Sheedy's upstairs demi-monde of druggy companions, including an outstanding Patricia Clarkson as a washed-up German actress.

A Man For All Seasons (Fred Zinnemann, 1966)

6pm, Sky Cinema

Paul Scofield, stars as Thomas More. He is the film's centre, no dull cleric but a flesh-and-blood, good-humoured man of principle who pays with his head for crossing Henry VIII. A moving chunk of history. Robert Shaw is Henry; Wendy Hiller is Alice More; Vanessa Redgrave Anne Boleyn; Orson Welles and Leo McKern the heavyweight troublemakers.

Ball Of Fire (Howard Hawks, 1942)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

Hard to imagine Barbara Stanwyck as Snow White, but Hawks' super screwball-comedy version of the fairy tale has been filtered through the sly imagination of scriptwriter Billy Wilder. So Stanwyck is nightclub floozy Sugarpuss O'Shea, gatecrashing the dusty academic world of seven aged professors, pursued by hoodlum Joe Lilac (Dana Andrews).

The General (John Boorman, 1998)

11.30pm, Sky Premier

This may be Boorman's anthem to Ireland, his adopted home, but in tone it's a throwback to his brutal Lee Marvin thriller, Point Blank. Shot in stark black-and-white, it opens with the slaying of Dublin crime boss Martin Cahill in 1994, then backtracks to follow his life, rising from petty theft to Godfather. Brendan Gleeson is superb as the volatile Cahill, and among other excellent acts are Adrian Dunbar as his lieutenant, Maria Doyle Kennedy his wife, and Jon Voight as Irish cop, Ned Kenny.

fields.headline: Sinners and saints
fields.trailText: Other people might have trouble thinking up ideas for new comedy shows but not Simon Nye, creator of Men Behaving Badly. What is Beast (BBC1) but Vets Behaving Badly? If anything, Beast, set in a veterinary practice, is even more desperate for a chortle.
fields.body:
Other people might have trouble thinking up ideas for new comedy shows but not Simon Nye, creator of Men Behaving Badly. What is Beast (BBC1) but Vets Behaving Badly? If anything, Beast, set in a veterinary practice, is even more desperate for a chortle. Enter vet Andrew (Stephen Alvey), for example, with a painting which he thinks is a painting of New York but which to everyone else is, as schoolboys say, a fanny. Who will tell him what he is hanging on the wall? And when he exchanges the painting for another, what will that depict? A penile lighthouse. It's so funny, isn't it? Doesn't Simon Nye deserve to be paid lots of money for that - or should he be put down at the vets?

Vet Nick (Alexander Armstrong), meanwhile, is lusting after his next-door neighbour. She invites him round to sedate her dog. He goes out into the garden and finds - a huge Alsatian. Chortle. How's that for a situation? Nick gets bitten by the dog. Double chortle. What a pity the dog didn't chew him up and then eat the rest of Simon Nye's characters. That would be a very satisfying conclusion to Beast.

At Home With The Braithwaites (ITV) is in the long tradition of stories about ordinary folk who suddenly come into loads of money, and is scheduled just after Chris Tarrant's Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? A sum of £1 million was once sufficient for dramatic purposes, but nowadays that would hardly buy the new house, the round-the-world cruise and the Mercedes Kompressor. Sally Wainright, who wrote AHWTB, found that even a win on the National Lottery did not give her enough dramatic scope and invents a Euro lottery that bumps up the prize money to £38 million. The money goes to Alison Braithwaite (Amanda Redman), hereafter known as the Blessed Braithwaite, since a good deal of time is spent establishing that she is one of the nicest women in the world, her eyes beaming love, understanding and sympathy at her rude kids, boring husband and local pensioners.

The Blessed Braithwaite could not, of course, have bought the lottery ticket herself - that would be a tad avaricious, wouldn't it? It is given to her as a present from her youngest daughter, who, like the rest of the family, has no idea that mum has won £38 million. The Blessed Braithwaite cannot, of course, spend the money on herself but sets up a company that will, in ways yet to be revealed, attempt to do good in the world.

What will the moral of the story be? We may anticipate that we will be shown how interfering in people's lives is much more complicated than we had imagined, but what really matters is the fun, heavy-handed though it may be, Sally Wainright has along the way with suburban sadnesses. The Blessed Braithwaite's husband having miserable sex with his secretary in a supermarket car park, her eldest daughter struggling with student life, a barbecue where class warfare breaks out, and so on. To me it is like much-diluted, low-calorie, supermarket-friendly Alan Ayckbourn, but compared to Beast it is a delight. It may even turn out to be educative for all those who desperately want to take £1 million from Chris Tarrant.

I've only seen the second part of Darcus Howe's White Tribe (Channel 4), in which he wanders around England looking for symptoms of an alleged crisis of identity amongst the English, but the crisis seems to be amongst the eccentric and the poor. The eccentric, for example, were represented by a priest of the English Orthodox Church in Felixstowe, Sussex, who wants to save English Christians for the faith of their ancestors. Does this priest tell us anything about England? I don't think so.

The poor were on a council estate in Oldham. It didn't take much to get them mouthing off. "Us whites are second-class citizens." "It's a white estate and it'll stay a white estate." "Even the French speak a bit of English." In Eltham, joy of joys for a TV producer, they found a man with his shirt off and loads of tattoos. In Dover, Darcus struggled to find even a few refugees in a town that is supposed to be threatened by them. He rightly concluded that the threatened don't really have much place in the more tolerant England of today and tomorrow. But they will, I guess, still be there, so long as there is so much poverty - of income and education - in the country.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Open The Box | The Routes Of English
fields.body:
Now that Britain's mobile phones apparently outnumber the nation's households we must assume the end is nigh for our network of telephone boxes. Sara Parker offers a nostalgic account of them that will doubtless be replayed to utter disbelief in a couple of generations' time. She has spent much of the past six months researching the use and abuse of payphones. In Open The Box (11.0am, Radio 4) she finds that they are not always just passive victims: one nearly committed murder.

Melvyn Bragg's second series of The Routes Of English (4.0pm, Radio 4) looks at our national obsession with almost every form of word play. Puns, alliterations, malapropisms, and spoonerisms have poured out of us for centuries. According to research by Carol Fox, the habit often starts in early childhood, as we discovered when our three-year-old suddenly decided that our car indicators were far better described as "corner-warners".

fields.headline: Sceptic party torn by feuds
fields.trailText: Powerful financial backers are threatening to withdraw support from the anti-European United Kingdom Independence party in protest at an internal row which is threatening to destroy the party.
fields.body:
Powerful financial backers are threatening to withdraw support from the anti-European United Kingdom Independence party in protest at an internal row which is threatening to destroy the party.

One businessman, who has donated thousands of pounds to the party, has warned that he will withdraw support by the weekend unless a "gang" opposed to the party leader Michael Holmes "disappears completely".

John Langham, a Dorset businessman, warned that UKIP was in danger of "disintegration" after the party's ruling body passed a motion of no confidence in Mr Holmes last year. Mr Holmes, one of three UKIP Euro MPs elected last June, refused to accept the vote which has led to the convening of an extraordinary general meeting in London tomorrow.

Up to 1,000 party members are expected to pack into Methodist central hall in Westminster to decide whether to back Mr Holmes or UKIP's ruling executive.

The anti-Holmes faction is being led by Anthony Scholefield, UKIP's party secretary, who accuses the party leader of being too soft on Europe.

In a letter to Mr Scholefield, which has been passed to the Guardian, John Langham underlines the bitterness of the row engulfing the party.

"What you are doing is destabilising the party just at a time when it should be exploiting its success and when the British people are more and more Eurosceptic," the businessman wrote earlier this month.

In a circular to party members, Mr Scholefield accused the party leader of "unacceptable behaviour" which culminated in his "damaging speech" in the European parliament which recommended an extension of its powers.

Pro-Europeans last night seized on the party's internal feuding. Danny Alexander, a spokesman for the Britain in Europe pressure group, said: "We have always known that the anti-Europeans are factionalised, but the language in these documents is ridiculous."

webTitle: Davies in new trouble after Labour attacks

fields.headline: Davies in new trouble after Labour attacks
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: The former Welsh secretary, Ron Davies, could face disciplinary action by the Labour party in Wales after heaping further public criticism on the embattled Labour leadership in the national assembly.
fields.body:
The former Welsh secretary, Ron Davies, could face disciplinary action by the Labour party in Wales after heaping further public criticism on the embattled Labour leadership in the national assembly.

Mr Davies, whose own hopes of assuming the mantle of devolved power were dashed as a result of his "moment of madness" on Clapham common, has incensed members of the minority Labour administration with an outspoken attack on the way it is running the assembly.

His comments, in a speech to an invited audience in Cardiff on Wednesday night, came only days after he criticised Labour's "inept" handling of European funding for west Wales and the valleys and have led to accusations that he is acting like a member of the opposition.

His strictures come at a particularly testing time for the first secretary, Alun Michael, whose performance could soon become the subject of a motion of no confidence by the opposition parties. Speaking of the assembly "limping on, day to day, issue to issue" Mr Davies claimed in a speech at the Institute of Welsh Affairs that many of the problems it faced were due to a political culture that was not inclusive. "As a result," he said, "we have unstable government which can't build a long-term strategy and is unable, therefore, to provide effective leadership."

His comments provoked fierce criticism from the secretary of the Caerphilly Labour party, Martin Mansfield, who announced he was bringing forward his planned resignation from the post. He claimed Mr Davies expected total loyalty and discipline from local party officers but had shown neither of those qualities himself. "The Labour party gave Ron Davies a second and even a third chance to rebuild his political career and he has repaid us with a stream of attacks designed to help the nationalists. In seeking to build alliances with the nationalists against our own Labour administrations in Cardiff and Westminster he has shown the worst sort of disloyalty."

A Labour spokesman said last night said the party in Wales was not ruling out disciplinary action against Mr Davies. "Many party members have phoned to say that someone who stands for election on the Labour party ticket should spend their time promoting policies on which they were elected and not constantly echo the criticisms of our electoral opponents."

Meanwhile Plaid Cymru set out the demands Mr Michael will have to satisfy if he is to avoid the long-threatened motion of no confidence in his running of the assembly. The party is pressing for an extra £85m for the assembly's budget this year and a guarantee from the treasury that the full £1.2bn of structural funds from Europe will be handed over to the assembly.

webTitle: Straw retreats on plan to gag commissioner

fields.headline: Straw retreats on plan to gag commissioner
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw was forced into a fresh climbdown over his controversial freedom of information bill yesterday over plans to gag the new information commissioner.
fields.body:
Jack Straw was forced into a fresh climbdown over his controversial freedom of information bill yesterday over plans to gag the new information commissioner.

The home secretary provoked an all-party revolt by proposing to make it a criminal offence under the bill for Elizabeth France, the information commissioner, to release detailed information on the handling of complaints against governmment depart ments. Yesterday David Lock, the junior home office minister, promised to look again at the provision after protests from John Green, Tory junior spokesman on home affairs; Robert Maclennan, Liberal Democrat constitutional affairs spokesman; and former Labour minister Mark Fisher.

Maurice Frankel, director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, said: "To restrain the information commissioner should be unthinkable. It could undermine her ability to explain the basis of her approach.

"Any suggestion of secrecy on the part of the information commissioner could damage the credibility of the legislation itself. "

fields.headline: Anthony Hyman
fields.trailText: From his student days at the London School of Oriental and African Studies, the Muslim world was the driving intellectual interest of Anthony Hyman, who has died aged 53. An expert on Afghanistan, Iran, Pakistan and central Asia, and a commentator for the BBC World Service for more than 20 years, he was a linguist, historian, bibliophile, art lover and traveller.
fields.body:
From his student days at the London School of Oriental and African Studies, the Muslim world was the driving intellectual interest of Anthony Hyman, who has died aged 53. An expert on Afghanistan, Iran, Pakistan and central Asia, and a commentator for the BBC World Service for more than 20 years, he was a linguist, historian, bibliophile, art lover and traveller.

His early work was on the development of pan-Islamism in early 20th-century India, out of which grew a life-long interest in Pakistan and the wider Islamic world. A student of Persian, he followed Iranian politics closely and, in 1982, soon after Afghanistan took centre stage in global politics, his standard work, Afghanistan Under Soviet Domination, was first published.

His understanding that the Afghan resistance struggle would throw up challenges to traditional society and produce its own process of radicalisation was ahead of its time, as were his fears for the disintegration of Afghan unity under pressure from tribalism and sectarianism. More recently, he had been particularly critical of the Taliban, and of what he saw as their narrow vision of Afghanistan's future.

Anthony's many friendships with Iranians, Afghans and Pakistanis gave his work a human dimension. For a time, he was secretary of the British-Afghan support committee and worked with the Afghan Refugee Information Network and Amnesty International. But he never let friendships cloud his intellectual judgment; he spoke his mind clearly and, through writing for radio, the newspapers and journals, and lectures and exchanges with policymakers, he came to wield some influence where policy was being made.

After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Anthony became absorbed with central Asia, travelling there, learning Russian, acquainting himself with the new states' politics and cultures and introducing these countries to a wider audience through his writings. As with Afghanistan, he advocated a higher-profile European interest in these countries and their needs. He was a founding director of the charity Links, which works to resolve conflict and promote democracy in the region.

In 1991, he became a senior fellow of the MacArthur Foundation in New York and visiting fellow of Queen Elizabeth House, Oxford. He was also an associate editor of the journal Central Asian Survey. In addition to his many articles and studies, he co-authored Pakistan: Zia And After (1989) and wrote a yet to be published book on the Sherley Brothers, early travellers in Iran.

A generous and hospitable man, Anthony faced his long illness with remarkable courage and fortitude. He is survived by his wife Hilary. Anthony Hyman, writer and broadcaster, born April 17 1946; died December 19 1999

fields.headline: Pierre Clémenti
fields.standfirst: French actor and director of the avant-garde left 'a broken dandy' as his looks faded
fields.trailText: The films of the French actor-director Pierre Clémenti, who has died of cancer aged 57, included Luchino Visconti's The Leopard (1962), Luis Buñuel's Belle de Jour (1967), and The Milky Way (1969), Pier Paolo Pasolini's Pigsty (1969), and Liliana Cavani's reworking of Antigone, The Cannibals (1970).
fields.body:
The films of the French actor-director Pierre Clémenti, who has died of cancer aged 57, included Luchino Visconti's The Leopard (1962), Luis Buñuel's Belle de Jour (1967), and The Milky Way (1969), Pier Paolo Pasolini's Pigsty (1969), and Liliana Cavani's reworking of Antigone, The Cannibals (1970).

In 1971 he worked with Walerian Borowczyk in Blanche, and, for the decidedly less flakey Hungarian director Miklos Jancso, in The Pacifist, opposite Monica Vitti. His politics were in evidence with these directors, and, more markedly, with the Brazilian Glauber Rocha, who directed him in Cabezas Cortadas (1970). He made two movies for Bernardo Bertolucci. After Partner (1968), he was rewarded with a key role in the director's masterpiece The Conformist.

Yet the charitable view of Clémenti and his 40-year career would be that he did not realise his potential. The reasons involve his back ground and lack of training, rightwing pressures and post-1970s changes in world cinema which marginalised him and other radicals. An alternative version is that he was not a versatile actor, and, as a director - of four features and some shorts - his interests ended with the experimental and avant-garde. He was an art-house figure, a sexy, disturbing, androgynous presence in some memorable European films made between the early 1960s and the late 1970s. Many of his roles were minor, especially as his looks faded, and he only occasionally acted in mainstream cinema - for example, in the period romp Benjamin (1968).

Clémenti was born in Paris, to an unknown father, and while young, spent time in reform school. His film career began in 1960 with Yves Allegret's Chien de Pique. Two years later Visconti cast him as Burt Lancaster's son in The Leopard, and his sultry, full-lipped face won him parts in French and Italian movies. He also featured in a French television series.

His big break came with his role in Belle de Jour, starring Catherine Deneuve, and in 1968 he was reunited with her when, at 26, he starred in Benjamin, as a 17-year-old trying to lose his virginity. "Clémenti indicates adolescent innocence by being loose-limbed and girlish," wrote Pauline Kael. "It is essential for the boy to suggest the kind of man he will become once he has learned what everyone is so eager to teach him, but Clémenti looks as though he would become a lesbian."

The period from the making of Belle de Jour was wonderfully productive, but in 1971 Clémenti was imprisoned in Italy on drugs charges. He never seemed to fully recover from the ordeal, but the experience led to a book and a film, New-Old (1978), which he described as "my diary of my life before and after 1973". He was bitter about the lack of help from the French authorities over the charges, feeling this was a delayed punishment for his support of the 1968 uprising.

In the late 1960s he began work as a director, initially making 16mm experimental shorts, and the psychedelic Visa de Censure (1968). It was 10 years before he made another feature, New-Old, and a further decade before Soleil (1988), described as a song of love and death and stemming from his theatre work. In the same year, he directed A l'Ombre de la Canaille Bleue, which, like the others, only surfaced in a Cinemateque Francaise retrospective of experimental movies.

After his release from prison in 1973, Clémenti worked for Dusan Makavejev, playing a sailor in the outrageous Sweet Movie. A sturdy version of Herman Hesse's Steppenwolf (1974) followed, and his leftist credentials earned him a role in the Marxist The Red Poster (1976). Several weak films followed, then he took the lead in Jean-Jacques Andrien's debut feature, Le Fils d'Amr est Mort (1978), a magical work which nonetheless failed to revive the actor's career. During the next 20 years, Clémenti worked mainly in Portugal, France and Germany, and had a small part, as Vic, in the independent American director James Toback's thriller Exposed (1983), with a cast that included Rudolf Nureyev, Bibi Andersson and Harvey Keitel.

Although he worked in the theatre and occasional films, including L'Autrichienne (1989) opposite Ute Lemper and Massacre (1995), by the 1990s his looks had gone and he was memorably described as "a broken dandy" - a description which encompassed his Wildean sense of the extravagant. Oddly, his last film was British, Hideous Kinky (1998), but his role was minor. Ill-health had cut his workload to a minimum.

Clémenti was not a great actor, but he was an incarnation of a period long gone from both cinema and life. It is now replaced with the conformity he could not abide.

Pierre Clémenti, actor, director, born September 28 1942; died December 28 1999

fields.headline: Francis Haskell
fields.standfirst: Gifted art historian generous with his talents
fields.trailText: Francis Haskell, who has died of cancer aged 71, was one of the most distinguished and internationally admired art historians of his generation, and for many years professor of the history of art at Oxford.
fields.body:
Francis Haskell, who has died of cancer aged 71, was one of the most distinguished and internationally admired art historians of his generation, and for many years professor of the history of art at Oxford.

The son of Arnold Haskell, the well-known writer on ballet, and his Russian wife, Vera Saitzoff, he was educated at Eton and King's College, Cambridge. His first job was as a junior library clerk in the House of Commons, but he was already engaged on art historical research.

After meeting him for the first time at dinner in the Palazzo Massimo alle Colonne in Rome, I ran into an elderly fellow-guest, deep in the catacombs of San Clemente. Impressed by Haskell's erudition and seriousness, he prophesied that "that young man will go far." A year later, in 1954, Haskell was elected a fellow of King's, Cambridge, where he remained for over a decade, also serving as librarian of the fine arts faculty.

In 1967, he was elected as professor of the history of art at Oxford, only the second person to occupy the chair, and a fellow of Trinity College. As far as teaching and furthering the cause of art history were concerned, his experience was frustrating. Oxford, probably the last major university in the world to recognise art history as a serious academic discipline, was not prepared to go as far as introducing an undergraduate degree.

But Haskell did succeed in transforming and developing the one-year diploma course, which proved very popular with graduates. He also made a major contribution by the quality and originality of his research and publications.

His first book, Patrons and Painters: a Study of the Relations between Art and Society in the Age of the Baroque (1963), established the direction of his interests. It was a brilliant choice of theme, which became personally associated with him; although others had written on patronages, collecting and taste, none had done so with such intensity and depth of research as Haskell was to do over the next 37 years. What might have been a dry academic exercise was invariably brought vividly to life by his deft evocation of the personality and idiosyncrasies of his varied cast of characters. Such was the wide-ranging nature of his field that he was able to match "consumer" and "art" in any chronological configuration which was pertinent.

He could equally well write on 19th-century collectors of Florentine quattrocento painting as Baroque patrons of the art of their time, or, in one of his most delightful essays, on a Turk and his collection of French pictures. Haskell was an international star, invariably the centre of attention at conferences, symposia and art-historical gatherings around the world. It was seldom that he was not able to contribute something relevant. An archaeological conference on the island of Chios, for example, characteristically included his paper on Delacroix's painting of the Massacre at Chios.

Haskell was a much sought-after lecturer: a small man, he projected his ideas compellingly in a deep, resonant voice, as fluently in French or Italian as in his native English. He was a dedicated committee member, serving devotedly for many years the National Art Collections Fund, the Burlington magazine, the Wallace Collection and the Ashmolean Museum.

His contribution to discussions was distinctive; carefully choosing his subject and his moment, he would develop his argument with a passionate eloquence which generally swept all before him. He cared deeply about the quality of acquisitions made by museums and, very particularly, believed in the principle of free entry to them. But he was not doctrinaire. When the Ashmolean was faced with the possible introduction of entrance charges (happily avoided at the last moment), he was sensitive to the problem, and, albeit reluctantly, voted in favour.

In 1965, Haskell married Larissa Salmina, then a curator at the Hermitage Museum. It was a union of great happiness and closeness, which offered a haven of conviviality in their house in Walton Street, Oxford. Surrounded by friends, as often from abroad as from home, Haskell was a lively conversationalist, happily ranging from personal gossip to a discussion of serious ideas Around 1960, I met by chance the then-editor of the Burlington magazine, Benedict Nicolson, much excited about his forthcoming first visit to Leningrad, as it then was. But it soon became clear that his bubbling enthusiasm was directed not so much towards the great art and architecture he was about to see, as to the fact he was going to share a wagon-lit with Haskell for a whole 48 hours, and "what wonderful conversations we are going to have."

The son of Arnold Haskell, the well-known writer on ballet, and his Russian wife, Vera Saitzoff, he was educated at Eton and King's College, Cambridge. His first job was as a junior library clerk in the House of Commons, but he was already engaged on art historical research. After meeting him for the first time at dinner in the Palazzo Massimo alle Colonne in Rome, I ran into an elderly fellow-guest, deep in the catacombs of San Clemente. Impressed by Haskell's erudition and seriousness, he prophesied that "that young man will go far." fields.headline: Robert Hopper
fields.standfirst: Visionary who forged Yorkshire's worldwide reputation for sculpture
fields.trailText: In 1988, the trustees of the Henry Moore Foundation established the Henry Moore Sculpture Trust in Leeds. They had recognised that, if the foundation were to contribute to contemporary art, it had to do more than sustain Moore's colossal reputation. And they appointed a visionary, Robert Hopper, who has died of a heart attack aged 53, as the Trust's founding director, with a brief to promote the making and understanding of contemporary sculpture.
fields.body:
In 1988, the trustees of the Henry Moore Foundation established the Henry Moore Sculpture Trust in Leeds. They had recognised that, if the foundation were to contribute to contemporary art, it had to do more than sustain Moore's colossal reputation. And they appointed a visionary, Robert Hopper, who has died of a heart attack aged 53, as the Trust's founding director, with a brief to promote the making and understanding of contemporary sculpture.

Robert did much more. And in the process he helped define a role for the foundation itself in its support for contemporary art. He also established Yorkshire's international reputation for sculpture - about which Robert was passionate.

Part of his success was in understanding the curatorial aspirations of artists. In 1989, supported by Ernest Hall, he had established a studio at a former carpet factory, Dean Clough in Halifax. Opened by the Prince of Wales, the studio attracted a score of international artists, displaying the confidence they had in Robert. There was no fee; artists were drawn by the immense space, the chance to take risks, and curatorial control over the nature and display of their work. The artists included Anthony Caro, Jannis Kounellis, Magdelena Jetelova, James Turrell and Michaelangelo Pistaletto.

Robert was particularly excited when artists responded to the history of Dean Clough, as when Christian Boltanski created an enormous impact with his installation The Lost Workers, based on Dean Clough's closure as a carpet factory. Artists were encouraged to utilise the region's industrial context. Ulrick Rucknem used local stone, Lawrence Weiner ironworks cast from a local foundry.

Working with Leeds city council, and architect Jeremy Dixon, Robert established the Henry Moore Institute in 1993. This new building, physically linked to Leeds City art gallery, provided a small gallery space to display sculpture of all periods and nationalities, connected, as Robert had planned, to the "ideas held within the library and research facilities". Robert curated several small but notable shows there.

Robert's biggest project was ArtTranspennine, co-curated with Lewis Biggs in 1998. It was the largest exhibition of contemporary art held in this country. Stretching from Liverpool to Hull, it involved 55 artists from different countries, curators, local government officers, people from industry and commerce, working on 40 projects in gardens, parks, galleries, docks, pits, bridges, schools, hotels, water and within the landscape itself.

Robert was born in Grantham, and studied art history at Manchester university. From 1972 until 1981, he worked as assistant keeper and deputy principal keeper in fine art at Manchester's Whitworth art gallery. He helped organise the Northern Young Contemporaries exhibitions, an important Frank Dobson exhibition, and promoted the open-air siting of contemporary sculpture. In 1979, he was elected to the Yorkshire Sculpture Park's management committee and, in 1981, became director of Bradford art galleries and museums. Then came the trust.

The Hopper family live in a historic farmhouse outside Hebden Bridge. From there Robert travelled the world, promoting the Henry Moore Foundation and Yorkshire as a centre for sculpture. He took on local and international responsibilities, including membership of the Arts Council visual arts board, and trusteeship at Rome's British School.

I first met him in 1978. For more than 20 years, we worked together to support the development of sculpture. His enthusiasm was boundless, his love and knowledge staggering. I have vivid memories of him driving across New Mexico as we searched for Walter De Maria's Lighting Fields. Above all, I remember his hard work, the setbacks and the bruises, which he always overcame with dignity. He was an unforgettable, warm and dynamic friend. The art world owes him a great debt.

Robert leaves his wife, Christine, and their three children, Henry, Sophie and Rebecca.

Robert Hopper, arts administrator, born June 26 1946; died December 17 1999

fields.headline: Thelma Rogers
fields.trailText: It was in the early 1950s that Thelma Rogers, who has died aged 75, was spotted by Tony Shryane, the first producer of what has become one of the longest running radio series in the world, the Archers.
fields.body:
It was in the early 1950s that Thelma Rogers, who has died aged 75, was spotted by Tony Shryane, the first producer of what has become one of the longest running radio series in the world, the Archers.

Thus was Thelma recruited to play the part of Ambridge's schoolteacher, Elsie Catcher. It was not a key role, but it was one in which she made an impression. So in 1953, when June Spencer, the actress who had created the role of Peggy Archer, left the cast to raise her family, it was to Thelma that Shryane looked for a replacement.

The cast of the Archers was smaller in those days. For some actors entering an atmosphere that could be rather like a club, it might be a daunting experience, even one triggering flamboyant reactions. But this was not Thelma's style - there was nothing frenetic about her, and no waving of arms. She was deeply professional, and, when confronted with an important part like that of Peggy, she knew how to consolidate it, building on June's work of the previous two years.

It was a way of working that fitted the rhythm of the Archers, which is about ensemble playing and very much a show without stars, where we all have something to contribute. This is part of a recipe which accounts for the show's success during the last half century. Thelma was very much a team player.

Born and raised in Coventry - her father was lord mayor there in the 1960s - she studied for two years in Cambridge to become a teacher, but focused on a stage career and joined the Leicester Repertory Company, where she worked for four years. It was from there that she joined the Archers.

In 1962, Thelma left the radio series to return to her stage career, mainly in Scotland. It was an amicable departure, with June Spencer returning to the part she has retained to this day. Thelma went on to join the Perth Repertory Company. She appeared in major parts in Dundee and Glasgow, and featured in the Lionel Bart musical, Oliver, both in London and on tour. On television, she had a part in another Birmingham-based series, the soap opera Crossroads, and in Coronation Street. In Scotland, she took a prominent role - playing an author - in the Scottish TV series Take the High Road.

Thelma was a quiet person, but a wonderful conversationalist and a serious reader, whether it be Shakespeare or Shaw, Virginia Woolf or Jane Austen; she was a great Janeite. Not all actors wish to talk literature, but Thelma did. She hated the name Thelma - until someone pointed out it was an anagram of Hamlet. She had a quiet enthusiasm for things.

Thelma Rogers, actress, born June 24 1924; died January 13 2000

webTitle: Japan begins review of its pacifist constitution

fields.headline: Japan begins review of its pacifist constitution
fields.trailText: Japan's parliament broke its strictest postwar taboo yesterday by launching the first review of the country's pacifist constitution since it was imposed by the United States in 1947.
fields.body:
Japan's parliament broke its strictest postwar taboo yesterday by launching the first review of the country's pacifist constitution since it was imposed by the United States in 1947.

The outcome of the process, which is expected to take at least five years, is far from certain. But the very fact that it has begun is a victory for nationalists.

Two parliamentary committees, one in each chamber, have been set up to study the existing constitution and propose revisions. Changes would require a two-thirds majority in both houses and the approval of the electorate in a national referendum.

The committees will scrutinise a document that was drafted in just one week by General Douglas MacArthur's occupation authorities in the wake of the second world war.

Based on recommendations from Washington, the constitution was designed to prevent a recurrence of Japanese aggression by promoting democracy and emasculating the country's military.

Article nine - certain to be the most contentious area of the panel's deliberations - renounces war and "the threat or use of force as a means to settle international disputes".

For decades, nationalists in the ruling Liberal Democratic party, including Yasuhiro Nakasone, Japan's prime minister from 1982 to 1987, have called for a reform or annulment of what they describe as an alien, badly written and contradictory constitution.

Even the constitution's supporters admit that several of its goals have failed. Article nine declares that the potential for war will never be maintained - but Japan has one of the most powerful military forces in the world. The constitution is also supposed to guarantee sexual equality, much to the incredulity of many Japanese women.

In the past, any talk of reform was blocked by leftwing parties, who saw it as a step back towards Japan's militaristic past. But their influence has waned.

"The ideological era has passed, along with the cold war," said Norihiko Akagi, a Liberal Democrat MP. "Now everything is open for debate, including article nine."

Proponents of the review, which has broad cross-party support, have sought to reassure the public and neighbouring nations that change will not mean a more aggressive Japan.

They say that reform will fill gaps in the constitution on the environment and other contemporary concerns, and enable the country to play a more active role in international peacekeeping operations.

But many Japanese are proud of the country's pacifist constitution, and surveys show opinion is split down the middle on the need for reform.

Opponents say the review is a sign of resurgent nationalism in Japan, following the passage last year of new defence guidelines and legislation to recognise the national flag and anthem.

"This debate plays into the hands of revisionists whose only interest is to discard article nine," said Takako Doi, the leader of the Social Democratic party. "But now that it has started, we must take part to protect the constitution."

Japan's neighbours are also paying close attention to the review. "We would like Japan to continue very clearly on the course of peace," said Li Wen Liang, a spokesman for the Chinese embassy in Tokyo.

Anxieties about the growing strength of revisionism in Japan were fuelled yesterday when approval was given in Osaka for a conference describing the Nanking massacre as "the biggest lie in the 20th century". Up to 300,000 people, including prisoners of war and civilians, were slaughtered by Japanese troops in the 1937-38 occupation of the Chinese city.

fields.headline: Muslim leaders back Lombok crackdown
fields.standfirst:
President Wahid blames Indonesia's ousted power elite for sectarian violence on tourist island

Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Indonesian police said yesterday they had been forced to shoot more than a dozen people to end the violence that has ravaged the tourist island of Lombok for four days.
fields.byline: John Aglionby in Mataram, Lombok Island, Indonesia
fields.body:
Indonesian police said yesterday they had been forced to shoot more than a dozen people to end the violence that has ravaged the tourist island of Lombok for four days.

But as the security forces deployed in strength at strategic locations in Indonesia's capital Jakarta, to calm fears that thousands of provocateurs are about to descend on the city, few people believe the authorities have control of the growing crisis.

The police spokesman Brigadier General Erald Dotulong said the security forces in Lombok acted swiftly after receiving orders on Wednesday to shoot on sight anyone seen causing trouble. "Overnight we shot a number of people who were doing violent actions. Three were killed."

Since Muslim mobs began rampaging on Monday, the police have shot at least 16 people in Lombok, five of whom have died. The only other fatality was a Christian teacher who died of a heart attack after he heard a Muslim mob was heading for his house.

"We are not sorry for doing this because these people were about to attack and burn a church," Gen Dotulong said. "We cannot allow this to happen. We have to protect the people and their property."

Muslim leaders in Lombok are backing the crackdown. "I completely agree with what the police are doing," said Haji Ahmad Usman, one of the island's senior Muslim figures. "The police started shooting yesterday afternoon and it had an immediate effect. The island is now much calmer."

He said religious leaders had issued a joint appeal for peace and cooperation. "There is no enmity between us. We have worked together for years. Hopefully we will be able to calm the people."

The rioting on Lombok started after extremist Muslims incited thousands of people to attack Christians in retaliation for the deaths of hundreds of Muslims in the year-long sectarian conflict in the eastern Molucca islands. In three days 18 of the 24 churches in the island's three main towns were burned or destroyed.

Simon Simonjunta, the priest at the Pentecostal church in Ampenan, lost everything.He said the mob who attacked his church included his neighbour who had regularly borrowed his chairs but took great pleasure in burning them along with the rest of the church. . "There were hundreds of people. They chased me away, waving swords at me."

Most of the burned churches are daubed with threatening graffiti, such as: "Jesus was the son of a whore" and "Don't try to rebuild, it's only going to get worse" and "My god and your god are different".

More than 100 other buildings were destroyed as mobs rampaged on foot and in trucks to houses and shops owned by Christians. Thousands of people, including almost all tourists and expatriates, have fled. Thousands more are sheltering in police stations and army barracks.

In the village of Jerneng yesterday local gangs armed with traditional weapons blocked the road to the main ferry port at Lembarand.

"Yesterday the police shot at us as they came through, taking Chinese refugees to the port," said Johnny, leaning on a bamboo spear. "Two people were injured so we are now making sure it does not happen again. If the police try to come here we will resist."

Elsewhere people were still hiding behind barricades, not daring to come out of their houses in the wake of Wednesday night's violence.

"A mob suddenly arrived last night. They attacked all the Christian houses here and burned several," one man said in Prosperity Garden, a neighbourhood of Ampenan town, as he meandered between a badly slashed sofa and pages of a defaced photograph album strewn in the road.

Most buildings now display signs saying "Owned by Muslims" in Indonesian and Arabic on their front gates. Rows of hire cars stand idle, likely to remain so for weeks.

Despite the ebbing tension, dozens of people mounted neighbourhood watches on the streets last night, many armed with spears, machetes and iron bars.

"We can't take any chances," said Ketut Sugiartha, guarding a Hindu area with 15 friends.

People are puzzled as to the source of the unrest. Despite the link to the conflict in the Moluccas, the two areas are very different. In the Moluccas the Muslim and Christian populations are almost the same size, whereas in Lombok Muslims make up almost 98% of the 3m people, Hindus 2% and Christians 0.06%.

"I've lived here for 50 years and the different religions have always lived in harmony," said John Kaluluge, one of 3,600 people sheltering at an army barracks in south Mataram. "The riots were definitely provoked."

In an interview with the Guardian on Wednesday, the Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, said the Lombok unrest was orchestrated by a handful of people who had lost power in last year's transition to democracy.

He believes it is part of a wider campaign to destabilise the country, driven by revenge and bitterness.

Unrest is already burgeoning in Sulawesi, and rumours of imminent riots in Java's main cities were rife yesterday.

Jakarta's police ordered personnel deployed at bus terminals and train stations to prevent hordes of "mysterious and suspicious strangers" flooding the capital.
