"Overnight we shot a number of people who were doing violent actions. Three were killed." Since Muslim mobs began rampaging on Monday, the police have shot at least 16 people in Lombok, five of whom have died. The only other fatality was a Christian teacher who died of a heart attack after he heard a Muslim mob was heading for his house. "We are not sorry for doing this because these people were about to attack and burn a church," Gen Dotulong said. "We cannot allow this to happen. We have to protect the people and their property." Muslim leaders in Lombok are backing the crackdown. "I completely agree with what the police are doing," said Haji Ahmad Usman, one of the island's senior Muslim figures. "The police started shooting yesterday afternoon and it had an immediate effect. The island is now much calmer." He said religious leaders had issued a joint appeal for peace and cooperation. "There is no enmity between us. We have worked together for years. Hopefully we will be able to calm the people." The rioting on Lombok started after extremist Muslims incited thousands of people to attack Christians in retaliation for the deaths of hundreds of Muslims in the year-long sectarian conflict in the eastern Molucca islands. In three days 18 of the 24 churches in the island's three main towns were burned or destroyed. Simon Simonjunta, the priest at the Pentecostal church in Ampenan, lost everything.He said the mob who attacked his church included his neighbour who had regularly borrowed his chairs but took great pleasure in burning them along with the rest of the church. . "There were hundreds of people. They chased me away, waving swords at me." Most of the burned churches are daubed with threatening graffiti, such as: "Jesus was the son of a whore" and "Don't try to rebuild, it's only going to get worse" and "My god and your god are different". More than 100 other buildings were destroyed as mobs rampaged on foot and in trucks to houses and shops owned by Christians. Thousands of people, including almost all tourists and expatriates, have fled. Thousands more are sheltering in police stations and army barracks. In the village of Jerneng yesterday local gangs armed with traditional weapons blocked the road to the main ferry port at Lembarand. "Yesterday the police shot at us as they came through, taking Chinese refugees to the port," said Johnny, leaning on a bamboo spear. "Two people were injured so we are now making sure it does not happen again. If the police try to come here we will resist." Elsewhere people were still hiding behind barricades, not daring to come out of their houses in the wake of Wednesday night's violence. "A mob suddenly arrived last night. They attacked all the Christian houses here and burned several," one man said in Prosperity Garden, a neighbourhood of Ampenan town, as he meandered between a badly slashed sofa and pages of a defaced photograph album strewn in the road. Most buildings now display signs saying "Owned by Muslims" in Indonesian and Arabic on their front gates. Rows of hire cars stand idle, likely to remain so for weeks. Despite the ebbing tension, dozens of people mounted neighbourhood watches on the streets last night, many armed with spears, machetes and iron bars. "We can't take any chances," said Ketut Sugiartha, guarding a Hindu area with 15 friends. People are puzzled as to the source of the unrest. Despite the link to the conflict in the Moluccas, the two areas are very different. In the Moluccas the Muslim and Christian populations are almost the same size, whereas in Lombok Muslims make up almost 98% of the 3m people, Hindus 2% and Christians 0.06%. "I've lived here for 50 years and the different religions have always lived in harmony," said John Kaluluge, one of 3,600 people sheltering at an army barracks in south Mataram. "The riots were definitely provoked." In an interview with the Guardian on Wednesday, the Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, said the Lombok unrest was orchestrated by a handful of people who had lost power in last year's transition to democracy. He believes it is part of a wider campaign to destabilise the country, driven by revenge and bitterness. Unrest is already burgeoning in Sulawesi, and rumours of imminent riots in Java's main cities were rife yesterday. Jakarta's police ordered personnel deployed at bus terminals and train stations to prevent hordes of "mysterious and suspicious strangers" flooding the capital.
fields.bylineHtml: John Aglionby in Mataram, Lombok Island, Indonesia

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Police inquiry into Weizman
Israel's attorney general has ordered a criminal investigation of President Ezer Weizman over alleged financial improprieties.
fields.body:
Police inquiry into Weizman
Israel's attorney general has ordered a criminal investigation of President Ezer Weizman over alleged financial improprieties.

The justice ministry said it had evidence possibly linking him to a French millionaire's businesses in Israel between 1983 and 1984. Mr Weizman has admitted receiving at least $200,000 from Edouard Sarousi between 1988 and 1993.
AP, Jerusalem

Iran releases businessman
A German businessman, Helmut Hofer, who was once held on death row in Iran for illicit sex with an unmarried Muslim woman, was yesterday fined on a minor assault charge by a court, paving the way for his return to Germany.

"I am very happy. I will be leaving in the next few days," Mr Hofer, 58, said before leaving in an embassy car.
Reuters, Tehran

Cape fires die down
Cape Town stood down most of its firefighters yesterday as flames faded after four days of fires that destroyed thousands of hectares of scrubland and several houses. Fires broke out in 120 locations.

But council spokesman Johan Minnie warned that with 40°C temperatures forecast and no rain, it was too early to relax.
Reuters, Cape Town

Serbs injured by grenade
Two Kosovan Serb teenagers were wounded yesterday when Albanians in a car they were chasing threw a hand grenade at them, witnesses said. The incident occurred in the Serb part of the ethnically divided city of Mitrovice, where the youths, 18, had been playing basketball in the street when the car drove through.

Nato peacekeepers and UN police sealed off the street and Serbia's state run news agency Tanjug cited unofficial reports that two suspects were apprehended.
AP, Mitrovice

'Flying ice ball' hits woman
A Spanish woman, 70, has claimed she was hit by a falling ice ball, the first victim of a phenomenon that is puzzling scientists,state radio said yesterday.

Juana Sanchez Sanchez, said she was knocked out by a large frozen object as she walked near her home in Almeria. Scientists are examining 12 of the objects, but at least three have proven to be fakes.
Reuters, Madrid

webTitle: New era dawns for old enemies

fields.headline: New era dawns for old enemies
fields.trailText: Turkey and Greece began to put decades of mistrust behind them yesterday by signing a series of agreements and promising to work hard for better relations in the future.
fields.body:
Turkey and Greece began to put decades of mistrust behind them yesterday by signing a series of agreements and promising to work hard for better relations in the future.

"It is a new page, even a new era, in relations between our two countries", the Turkish foreign minister, Ismael Cem, said as he held talks in Ankara with his Greek counterpart, George Papandreou.

It is the first official bilateral visit of a Greek foreign minister to the Turkish capital for 38 years. Turkey and Greece are neighbours and Nato members - but they have been bitter rivals since the fall of the Ottoman empire.

Mr Papandreou met political leaders and laid a wreath at the mausoleum of Turkey's founding father, Kemal Ataturk, who drove Greek armies from Anatolia in the 1920s.

The two sides signed agreements on joint tourism projects, environmental protection, investments and measures to combat the fight against crime and terrorism.

Just four years ago Turkey and Greece came close to war because of a territorial dispute over a tiny piece of rock in the Aegean sea. Last February relations plummeted again, over Greek support for the Kurdish rebel leader, Abdullah Ocalan.

But the response to the earthquakes which struck both countries last year proved that ordinary people wanted to bridge the divide.

webTitle: VIP prisoners speak out against French jail conditions

fields.headline: VIP prisoners speak out against French jail conditions
fields.trailText: France's best known prisoners, including former ministers, top businessmen and senior civil servants, have condemned inhuman conditions in French jails, where 124 detainees committed suicide last year.
fields.body:
France's best known prisoners, including former ministers, top businessmen and senior civil servants, have condemned inhuman conditions in French jails, where 124 detainees committed suicide last year.

A petition to the justice ministry printed in Le Nouvel Observateur yesterday, led by Loik le Floch-Prigent, former head of the state petrol company, Elf, described horrifying conditions to support a campaign by Véronique Vasseur, chief doctor at La Santé prison in Paris.

Foul cells, systematic rape, humiliation of visiting families, crude health care, drug dealing by warders and detention of young offenders with seasoned criminals had turned jails into factories of crime and misery, the petition said.

José Bové, the environmentalist leader held for allegedly wrecking a McDonald's outlet, signed alongside Christine De viers-Joncours, one-time companion of the former foreign minister Roland Dumas, being questioned about fraud.

They are joined by such Santé residents as the mercenary colonel Bob Denard and the former prefect in Corsica accused of illegal police operations, Bernard Bonnet.

Many signatories have yet to be tried. There are 27,000 detainees in France awaiting trial, nearly half its 55,000 prisoners.

After Dr Vasseur spoke out against nine-square-metre (100 sq ft) cells housing six prisoners, poisonous food and corridors running with rats and cockroaches, Jean-Michel Bouch-eron, a former Socialist mayor jailed for corruption who said his cell was above La Santé's punishment block, added: "My eyes have been stung regularly by tear gas thrown into isolation cells by warders. In another prison, I paddled through blood left by a prisoner who committed suicide after banging on his cell door all night without getting help."

Pierre Botton, a businessman convicted of fraud, said he was saved from suicide by Dr Vasseur.

At La Santé, no one was allowed to talk to the best known detainee, the terrorist, Carlos "the Jackal". Every night, Mr Botton heard him wailing in solitary confinement: "I'm Carlos - doesn't anyone want to talk to me?"

While some of the press mocked "the revolt of middle- class prisoners", the International Prison Observatory which organised the petition said VIP support had probably advanced the campaign by 10 years.

Bernard Tapie, a Socialist former minister jailed for fraud and now released, refused to sign the petition. He said that despite finding 200 cockroaches in his bed, "life in clink is better than life in the rundown suburbs for 90% of detainees It's that life outside which is truly unbearable."

fields.headline: A question of star quality
fields.standfirst: The Michelin guide is an industry standard, but does it have any bearing on where we eat out?  Matthew Fort  flicks through the 2000 edition
fields.trailText: The Michelin guide is an industry standard, but does it have any bearing on where we eat out?  Matthew Fort  flicks through the 2000 edition
fields.body:
The millennium Michelin Guide to top grub in Great Britain and Ireland has hit the newsstands with something between a wheeze and thump. For most Britons, the guide is slightly less interesting than the Millennium Dome, but for chefs and proprietors, the Michelin is the word of God when it comes to deciding culinary pecking orders, as well as a useful stimulus to tourist business.

Among the disappointed may be Gordon Ramsay, Raymond Blanc and Michael Caines of Gidleigh Park, who might reasonably have expected to be booted up to three stars; and Marcus Waring of Petrus, Samuel Gicqueau at Le Terrace, Folkestone, and Aaron Paterson of Hambleton Hall, who might reasonably have thought they would get a leg up to two stars. And there are those too numerous to mention who will have been grateful to have hung on to anything they've got.

Of course, the big news as far as the media is concerned has been the removal of Marco Pierre White's Oak Room and Nico Ladenis's Chez Nico at 90. The removal of the restaurants had been requested in advance by the two chefs - White is retiring from cooking to concentrate on managing his business and Ladenis is changing the direction of his establishment. Still, you might think all the publicity was a deliberate ploy to keep well-known names in the public eye.

Incidentally, it is not for chefs to give back their stars, as some have claimed: the awarding and the taking away of stars is entirely a matter for the Michelin inspectorate and no one else. Still, magnanimity makes better copy than demotion.

So now we have only one Michelin three-star restaurant in the country (France has 21). Does it matter? In the wider scheme of things, perhaps not. Certainly, the great majority of the British eating public couldn't give a monkey's, partly, one suspects, out of chauvinism, partly out of a lack of sophistication and partly because our newspaper critics have higher profiles and generally carry greater weight than their equivalents in France.

However, I do think that Michelin is on to something. While it pains me to say so, over the last few years it has proved a more accurate weather vane of our gastronomic scene than home-grown guides. And I think we should be concerned by the fact that there are so few beacon restaurants and, indeed, that there has been so little change in the quality of public eating in the last couple of years. There has been precious little movement among the lower divisions in the Michelin either.

Having celebrated the dynamism, open-mindedness and vitality of British restaurants for, well, almost a decade, suddenly these qualities seem in short supply. Restaurateurs seem to have worked out what it is that people want, and can now deliver a simulacrum of an exciting eating experience without trying. Menus, design, service have become imitative, a process exacerbated in London by the consolidation of the middle market by a small number of companies.

More, there seems to be a exploitative cynicism when it comes to charging for all this. It can come as no surprise to anyone who eats out in the capital that London is now the most expensive city in the EU.

As a general rule, it is almost impossible to eat and drink at any of London's more fashionable (which is not the same thing as best) watering holes for less than £35 a head for quite a modest meal. Compare this to Paris, where a recent five-course extravaganza with two bottles of top-grade burgundy and other sundries came to £30 a head.

Soon it may be better value for money to go to France for lunch than to eat in Britain, a situation which would suit Michelin down to the ground. They do an excellent guide to the country.

 The Michelin Red Hotel and Restaurant Guide: Great Britain and Ireland 2000 (Michelin, £13.50).

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15 |  Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.body:
Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15

The Royal Oak, Church Road, North Woodchester, Gloucestershire. Tel: 01453 872735.

Rich and squidgy corned-beef hash with two perfectly poached eggs, £5.80; two fat brown sausages made from Gloucester Old Spot pigs with a dash of Uley bitter on a cloud of mash set in a wine-dark sea of onion gravy, £6.50; three-cheese ploughman's lunch, £5.75; rib-eye steak and chips, £8. And such chips, too, mighty hand-crafted hunks. Smiles beer. Cheerful service. A massive open fire. Plain tables, plain floors, plain walls, all housed in a building of mellow Cotswold stone, set in a small road off the main drag. Peace, harmony, and pleasure. Or did I dream it all?

Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Tajima-Tei Japanese Restaurant, Dorrington House, 9-15 Leather Lane, London EC1. Tel: 0171-404 9665

Once you've scoured the market for knickers, socks, CDs, bananas and a potted palm, and you fancy a quick but sustaining snack, step into the purposeful quiet of the Japanese restaurant at the Holborn end of the market. It's purposeful because they don't hang about. High-quality sashimi and sushi, very acceptable tempura, oodles of noodles, katsudon and other Japanese staples are rolled out at a cracking rate. Some persuasive combinations, for example a sushi and tempura lunch for £12. Service of great charm.

fields.headline: On the menu: jaggery
fields.trailText: What is it? Sugar, sweetness, pure and simple, and a staple of Indian cookery.
fields.body:
What is it? Sugar, sweetness, pure and simple, and a staple of Indian cookery.

What, like the white caster or granulated we're always being told is not good for us? No, no, no. Your jaggery is raw palm sugar, quite another kettle of fish.

What does it look like, then? It comes in slightly brown, slightly crumbly, slightly sticky lumps.

Does it taste different from white sugar? Yes, it's ever so slightly fruity.

And where can I find it? It comes from India, in particular the town of Kolhapur in Maharashtra, and you'll find it in Indian shops here, if you're lucky.

Not to be mistaken for: Mick Jaggery, sweetness.

fields.headline: Beach boy
fields.standfirst: In seven short years and with just a handful of films, Leonardo DiCaprio has evolved into one of the biggest stars on the planet. In an interview with Talk magazine, the 25-year-old tells  Aaron Latham  about his sensational rise - and about working with the Trainspotting team
fields.trailText: Leonardo DiCaprio was just 17 when he got his first big part, in This Boy's Life. "I had the big meeting with Robert De Niro," DiCaprio said. "I read a scene with him. To make an impression, I yelled some of the lines in his face. I was a smart ass in a lot of ways. Very over-confident."
fields.body:
Leonardo DiCaprio was just 17 when he got his first big part, in This Boy's Life. "I had the big meeting with Robert De Niro," DiCaprio said. "I read a scene with him. To make an impression, I yelled some of the lines in his face. I was a smart ass in a lot of ways. Very over-confident."

One day, Robert De Niro and Ellen Barkin were doing a scene, while DiCaprio cavorted about, distracting them. Ellen started lecturing him: you've got to learn to behave to be more like the two of us.

"Like the two of you," DiCaprio shot right back. "Let's see, on the one hand, he did Raging Bull. On the other hand, you did Switch. And you're the one who's telling me what to do?"

DiCaprio and I are sipping lemonade at the Chateau Marmont, a few blocks from where he grew up in Los Angeles, discussing his latest film, The Beach. For DiCaprio, it is a change of direction. The film was, he says, "the first film where I really wanted to take more responsibility for what I was doing as far as steering the story in the right direction. And Danny [Boyle, the director] was unbelievably open to my doing that."

What was the hardest thing about The Beach? Well, DiCaprio was badly stung by jellyfish during the water scenes. He tried wearing tights to protect himself but they didn't help much. And he worked 70 days with only four days off.

And what about Titanic? What was the hardest thing about that?

"Everything. Every day. The hardest thing I've ever had to do was make that movie."

Physically? Emotionally?

"Everything."

"He gets in quite a lot of fistfights," says Cheryl Rixon Davis, co-owner of the Playroom nightclub in LA. "But he's very friendly. Very sweet. People only mention it because it's him. He's a perky chap, a feisty young man. The fights are broken up quickly. No one wants to see Leo beaten up in their club. For him it's part of the entertainment."

What about girls?

"A different girl every half hour. He comes in with Carmen Electra. They make out big-time to entertain the crowd. He's an exhibitionist like she is."

DiCaprio's fame has left him wanting something real. Something pre-Titanic. "It was so unreal to me when it all happened," he says. "It was almost like a joke." A part of him longs for a world untouched by movies. Especially his movies. In his new movie, Leo's character Richard doesn't want to see the beach overrun by tourists. In his new life as a megastar, Leo himself doesn't want to be overrun by fans.

"People slag him off for Titanic," Danny Boyle tells me. "But you have to try to separate him from the publicity, that crazy balloon."

"What's the nature of his appeal?"

"He has a feminine side that all great actors have access to. It's what makes women fancy him."

"There was a moment when I was at an airport somewhere," says DiCaprio. "This girl grabbed my leg. It was like one of those things I had seen in a Beatles documentary. She was this fanatical fan. I wanted to say to her, 'Look, it's just me. I'm really, truly a regular guy. You don't need to do this.' But there was nothing I could say.

"My attitude to fame was some thing different. I was going to be who I was, and I was going to lead my normal life and do what I was going to do no matter what people say."

How has that worked out?

"The more you try to do something like that - well, the more you have to compromise."

Does he think he's grown up a bit since Titanic?

"Certainly. There is obviously a whole adjustment process. I have learned to trust myself more. I think I take more responsibility for what I need to do. I really try to control a little more where I want things to go. But I would not want to become an adult in every sense of the word. Who the hell does?"

DiCaprio has just bought a house in Hollywood, which suggests growing up. I tell him about a scene a friend of mine once witnessed: Greta Garbo and Montgomery Clift having a loneliness contest. Garbo said: "I am so lonely that I only ever have one dish in my dishwasher." Clift said: "I'm so lonely that I only ever have paper plates."

DiCaprio interjects immediately, "I'm so lonely that I don't have any dishes at all."

Lonely? Does that mean he doesn't have a girlfriend?

That's right, no girlfriend - "Nope" - at the moment.

Later we watch The Beach together in a preview theatre. Afterwards I tell DiCaprio I liked it very much.

"Really?" he asks.

He seems to lack confidence. He knows this movie, this career move, is risky. His character begins light and grows steadily darker. Will his Titanic fans like this very different DiCaprio? Surely not all of them. But the movie works. It is about something. It says something. It is part of a straight line that goes from This Boy's Life to What's Eating Gilbert Grape to the Basketball Diaries to Total Eclipse to Romeo and Juliet to The Beach. Titanic is the aberration.

webTitle: I want to leave my wife but don't want to lose my children or my house

fields.headline: I want to leave my wife but don't want to lose my children or my house
fields.trailText: I am 37, have been married 11 years and have two daughters. Last year I was sacked, but instead of giving me support during my unemployment, my wife had an affair and left me.
fields.body:
I am 37, have been married 11 years and have two daughters. Last year I was sacked, but instead of giving me support during my unemployment, my wife had an affair and left me.

I asked for a divorce, but she came back to me. Then she told me she didn't want to be married any more. I turned to other women for companionship but without much success, mainly because they didn't want to be involved with a married man.

I have recently filed for divorce but now my wife says she is being stalked by her ex-lover and, though in favour of separation, she does not want a divorce. My wife won't move out and, if she did, she would take our children with her.

If I move out, I would really be alone and I believe that the first one to leave loses rights to the house. How can I meet someone new without compromising my children and losing everything I put into our house?

Stand up for yourself

You still love your wife, despite the ways in which she has hurt you: you took her back, you still share a home with her - and you are chasing other women just to make her jealous. Even your threat of divorce sounds like a bit of a canard. Face it, she doesn't love you. And do you really believe her story about being stalked?

You ask how you can move out without compromising your children or losing all that you have put into the house. The answer is you cannot. What value do you place on your future happiness? I would hope the answer is that it is priceless - you should be prepared to lose everything you have now to secure it. Stop worrying about your bank balance. And children can cope with change; it is instability they find difficult.

Get legal advice. Stand up for yourself and your access rights. Make a new life. Only when you are free, and happy with yourself, will you be able to build a future with someone new.
David Anderson
North London

Consult a lawyer
You say you believe that the first one to leave would lose rights to the house. Consult a lawyer and you could find that this is not the case. You cannot make decisions on the basis of what you

Why don't you move out and find out how you fare on your own before you go plunging into another relationship? Maybe then, when you are more relaxed with your own company, you will be more attractive to others.

You say you believe that the first one to leave would lose rights to the house. Consult a lawyer and you could find that this is not the case. You cannot make decisions on the basis of what you 'believe'. Also, ask your lawyer about access to your children. Frequent regular access, if you are consistent and reliable, can often make for a better relationship with them than having them relate to you in the middle of a battlefield, or as the 'hard done to', unhappy member of the family.

I do feel that men sometimes get a raw deal when it comes to custody of children but, in my own experience, if you learn to cooperate with your partner and focus on the needs of the children rather than perceived grievances, you can still have a happy family life, even if you are not all living together. Perhaps then, when you feel happier and more in control of your life, a new relationship would be more likely to happen and succeed.
Jess Fitzgerald
Glasgow

Next week

I have recently divorced my husband and have custody of our two teenage daughters. They are now of an age where they make their own contact with their father but I still have regular conversations with him about their progress and wellbeing.

One daughter has a successful career and is doing well. My other daughter has recently had to leave university and is afraid to tell her father. He is a very successful academic and has always had high expectations of his children. He is under the impression that she is also doing well.

I would feel disloyal to my daughter if I had to tell him otherwise, but I feel dishonest not telling him the truth. She is adamant that she couldn't cope with his anger and disappointment on top of all the other problems she has at the moment. I am caught in the middle of a "no win" situation and don't know what to do.

Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.headline: Food on the net
fields.trailText: www.food.epicurious.com
fields.body:
www.food.epicurious.com

A US site "for people who eat", apparently, which should suit pretty much everyone. Covers just about everything from cookbook reviews to difficult questions of etiquette (picking fish bones from your teeth, eating corn on the cob in public).

Pros: Over 10,000 recipes on file to search through; plus a mammoth dictionary for any baffling ingredients. Will track down out-of-print cookbooks free.

Cons: Backed by Condé Nast, linked to a couple of foodie mags and to a show of the same name on the Discovery Channel. The site might be a bit too corporate for some, or a bit too American - avoid recipes for "girl scout cookies".

fields.headline: Muse and mistress
fields.standfirst: She was a lover and a source of inspiration to both Laurie Lee and Lucian Freud. John Cunningham on the legacy of the late Lorna Wishart
fields.trailText: She was a lover and a source of inspiration to both Laurie Lee and Lucian Freud. John Cunningham on the legacy of the late Lorna Wishart
fields.body:
Pity any woman who becomes the mistress of an artist or writer. The deeper the relationship, the more roles she'll have to play: muse, manager (artistic, domestic and financial), mother of his kids - but with no chance of marriage. And, after years of subterfuge, the split inevitably comes. Shining fame for him; ongoing obscurity for her.

Ironically, the only public acknowledgement of a mistress's influence on the life and work of a novelist, poet or painter tends to come decades after she's been discarded: on the obituary pages, as in the case of Lorna Wishart, who died on January 12 this year aged 89. Her obituaries recalled that as a middle-class married woman she was, more than 60 years ago, the lover of both Laurie Lee and Lucian Freud.

Mrs Wishart inspired both the poet and the painter at the start of their careers, carrying on the tradition of the creative clan to get the maximum out their lovers. It still happens. This week, Hugo Williams, a middle-aged married poet, picked up the £5,000 TS Eliot Award for a book about a five-year relationship with a much younger woman.

The imminent release of a movie version of The End of the Affair has produced a crop of media reports revealing the debt Graham Greene, a generation ago, owed to a wealthy American woman, Catherine Walston. She was his mistress for at least 10 years, while married to the Labour peer Lord Walston; and Greene plundered the liaison, and the personalities, for the plot of his novel.

Two generations ago, Lorna Wishart discovered that being the lover of a poet was even more draining than mothering a family and running the house for her well-connected husband. On a family holiday in Cornwall in 1937, she saw a young lad with a violin strolling by. 'Boy, come and play for me,' she called out. The fiddler was Laurie Lee and, once they became entangled, he apparently called the tune at least as often as she, in spite of the difference in their social status. The lad from Slad Valley in Gloucestershire had a penny-pinched childhood and an absent father; she was one of seven daughters of a well-off doctor, Walter Garman, who married Ernest Wishart when she was only 16.

Alongside tales of his bucolic boyhood in Gloucestershire and his exploits in the Spanish civil war, Lee's relationships with women fuelled his volumes of autobiography and poetry until his death in 1998. But, beautiful and vivacious though she was, Lorna had far more than sex to offer Lee.

As well as being the inspiration for many of his compositions, she ensured that his early poems saw the light of day by commending them to Stephen Spender and Cyril Connolly at Horizon, which was the literary magazine to appear in. When he decided to join the struggle in Spain, she is said to have sent him pound notes dabbed with Chanel No 5; it's also said that she got friends to bring him out of the country when he was in danger.

All of this demanded flexibility and deceit, since she remained married to Wishart, and brought up their children. Also, her affair with Lee was conducted during the 1939-45 war.

When Lorna became pregnant by Lee, she handled it with stunning competence. Their daughter, Yasmin, was born in February, 1939. Lorna was on one of her temporary absences from her family, and the couple were living in a flat in Bloomsbury. A good mistress can do even more for a literary man than a top agent: the baby was brought up along with the Wishart children.

Ernest Wishart was extremely forgiving. He seems to have accepted Lorna's bohemian streak, which ranged from her erotic encounters in an old farm-bound caravan that Lee rented in Sussex, to getting drunk with the literary set in London during the blackout. It might have been no more than damage limitation to keep the children of two fathers together, but, in agreeing to it, Wishart seems nobler than Lee, who didn't acknowledge his daughter until, as an adult, she sought him out.

The literary recognition Lorna received from the poet was limited to having The Sun My Monument - a book she inspired - dedicated to her. In the official biography, Laurie Lee: The Well-Loved Stranger, author Valerie Grove remarks that while the poet often said he loved women, 'he never paid tribute to them as mentors; only as cosseting, embracing, accommodating creatures. He liked women, but in their place.''

Lorna's genius as a mistress was that she recognised this, and knew when to move on - as she did, to Lee's torment, when she encountered Lucian Freud as a 21-year-old painter. And on from him - after she had become Girl with Daffodil in one of his portraits.

The effect she had on her two lovers seems to have been that of a catalyst. Yasmin is quoted in Grove's book as saying of her mother: 'Lorna was a dream to any creative artist because she got them going. She was a natural muse, an inspiration. She was a symbol of their imagination, of their unconscious, she was nature herself: savage, wild, romantic and without guilt.''

Others in Lorna's family were less than conventional. Two of the seven Garman sisters ran away to London in 1920: Mary fell for and married the South African poet Roy Campbell, while Kathleen shacked up with the sculptor Jacob Epstein, having three children before he was free to wed.

When Lorna came to marry at 16 it was fortuitous that her husband was wealthy - and unconventional. He was a communist, who set up the publishing firm Lawrence and Wishart. And, after her career as a literary mistress, it was to life with Wishart that Lorna returned. She became a Roman Catholic, lived in the South Downs - and contrived to keep her secrets. She burned letters from her two famous lovers, saying it was nobody's business but hers. Every inch a mistress to the last.

fields.headline: Five books about healthy eating
fields.standfirst: ... to save you burden of reading them
fields.trailText: ... to save you burden of reading them
fields.body:
Improve Your Digestion by Patrick Holford (Piatkus Ltd, £5.99)

Buy it at BOL

Remember that your digestive system is the path towards the "inner kingdom of your body", so guard it. Once you have memorised the millions of complicated biochemical processes that break down food (and the scientific terms for them), you will know how to improve absorption and conquer every ill, from wind to leaky gut syndrome. Keep eating that sauerkraut. Words of wisdom: one day the molecules of food will literally become you.

Cleanse Your System by Amanda Ursell (Thorsons £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Relax, this is not a book about mad detox diets or sessions "to manually wash out your insides". It is a guide to understanding your digestive system "on a daily basis", designed to leave you feeling "full of life". The cleansing process is both psychological and physiological, so try baked banana with fromage frais and toasted muffin for heartburn and stomach cramps. Words of wisdom: the digestive system has as many nerve endings as the brain.

Good Housekeeping - Eat Well, Stay Well (Ebury Press, £25)
Buy it at BOL

This myth-shattering book explores controversial issues from "What is fat?" to "What exactly is an essential nutrient?" But enough questions. Just dive straight into the 300 recipes, each of which comes complete with nutritional analysis and "suitable for" hints. The Royal College of General Practitioners even provides a revolutionary cure for tooth decay, warning us to "avoid sweets and fizzy drinks". Words of wisdom: try not to overdose on vitamin E.

Bodyfoods for Life, by Jane Clarke (Seven Dials, £14.99)
Buy it at BOL

In the third century BC, the Indian Upanishads said: "Food is better than power." How right they were. Today, we are cursed with the "diseases of modern living", such as cancer, heart problems and digestive disorders, but we can alleviate them through thoughtful "nutritional management". If you suffer from constipation, replace sugary cola drinks with juices, and you won't need laxatives. Words of wisdom: a good cook is half a physician.

Liver Detox Plan, by Xandria Williams (Vermillion, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

The liver is the body's "receiving and processing plant". There is no part of the body that is not dependent on the liver, or that may not suffer if the liver is under-performing or unhealthy. The liver is part of the immune system. Basically, the liver is pretty damn important. Look after it by detoxing - and say goodbye to cakes, biscuits, desserts, crisps and roasted nuts. Words of wisdom: use dandelion to stimulate the normal flow of bile.

fields.headline: Brave heart but no cigar
fields.standfirst:
George rebuffs SNP interest plan

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: There are times when Eddie George must wonder why he bothers. He decamps virtually the whole Bank of England to Scotland, including two-thirds of the monetary policy committee, for a two-day bonding session and what happens? He gets into a slanging match with Alex Salmond of the Scottish Nationalist Party over whether Scotland would be better off if it could set its own interest rates at the same level as those inside the eurozone.
fields.body:
There are times when Eddie George must wonder why he bothers. He decamps virtually the whole Bank of England to Scotland, including two-thirds of the monetary policy committee, for a two-day bonding session and what happens? He gets into a slanging match with Alex Salmond of the Scottish Nationalist Party over whether Scotland would be better off if it could set its own interest rates at the same level as those inside the eurozone.

On the face of it, cutting interest rates north of the border from 5.5% to 3% sounds like a wonderful idea. Mr George thinks not. He said Mr Salmond's policy ideas were "naive and shallow", pointing out that euroland may have interest rates at half the level of Scotland but has double the level of unemployment.

The governor is right. Mr Salmond appears to think that his party's policy of independence in Europe would mean a monetary policy better tailored to Scotland's needs, but this is sloppy thinking of the worst kind. First, there is little evidence that Scotland's economic performance over the past few years has been out of line with the rest of the UK. Growth has been 2.6% a year on average during the eight-year recovery for Britain, 2.4% for Scotland.

Second, the SNP believes that London is remote from Scotland, with the monetary policy committee knowing little about what economic conditions are like in the industrial belt of the lowlands or in the crofts of the highlands. This may be true, but it is hard to see how the situation would be improved by having monetary policy set in Frankfurt by the European Central Bank. To be sure, an independent Scotland might have a seat on the board, but it would command around 4% of the vote. Frankly, it is probably better off with Mr George in charge.

Finally, there is the example of Ireland. The SNP appears to think that Scotland, removed from the dead hand of English control, can be the next Celtic tiger. This is moonshine. Figures yesterday showed that inflation in Ireland is climbing alarmingly fast, primarily because interest rates that are good for a weak German economy are bad for a booming Ireland. Lower does not necessarily mean better.

An old wheeze

It is impossible to avoid a cackle at the situation-comedy of Stephen Byers' calling in a full-dress department of trade and industry inquiry into Geoffrey Robinson's collapsed engineering concern, TransTec. Faced with a political problem that just would not go away, some bright spark has remembered the inspector-thingies of the 1980s. Great wheeze: pull in a couple of worthies, give them a year or five to do their interviews, allow their findings to get lost at the printers for another three years and then publish the tome on a Friday afternoon before Christmas in the certain knowledge that no one will read it even if they can remember why it was ordered in the first place.

In fact, the last time inspectors were sent in under such circumstances was after the Mirror Group flotation eight years ago - and that report still hasn't seen the light of day.

Still, the fact that we are now getting an independent investigation of the TransTec affair is a welcome move. Given the association of the former paymaster general with the company - he was its non-executive chairman until his appointment to the government in May 1997 - anything less would have attracted criticism.

But while the decision to appoint outside inspectors clearly meets the independence test, it is not sufficient. As Mr Byers's statement indicates, it is important that the probe into TransTec is done quickly and its results made public.

For the DTI inspectors, being thorough and impartial in their deliberations does not mean they have to work at the traditional speed of law.

And this, of course, brings us to the question of what exactly will be done with evidence gathered.

The inspectors have wide powers to demand information but that information can no longer be used in any subsequent criminal proceedings, thanks to the European court of human rights ruling in the case of Ernest Saunders v United Kingdom.

This is not to say the inspections themselves are now worthless exercises. Not only can material gathered be used to press for disqualification of directors, and may be cited in civil suits by creditors seeking to lift the protection of limited liability, but inspectors produce reports that, as Messrs Maxwell, Fayed and others have discovered, stay on the record and can be quoted thereafter.

That said, this may be an opportunity for Mr Byers - who would doubtless wish to be remembered as a reforming DTI chief - to turn his mind to whether the system under which they operate is the best that can be devised, or whether "modernisation" is called for.

fields.headline: New parliament, same old prejudice
fields.standfirst: Hopes that Section 28 would be calmly repealed are fading as homophobia is stirred up in Scotland
fields.trailText: It was an ugly death. Michael Doran, a 35-year-old homosexual, was cruising the lawns and pathways of Glasgow's Queens Park, a well-known gay haunt, when he was set upon by a gang of youths. He was found next morning in a flower-bed, every bone in his face and head broken.
fields.body:
It was an ugly death. Michael Doran, a 35-year-old homosexual, was cruising the lawns and pathways of Glasgow's Queens Park, a well-known gay haunt, when he was set upon by a gang of youths. He was found next morning in a flower-bed, every bone in his face and head broken.

But that was five years ago, a time when the police force that investigated his murder didn't have a gay liaison officer, even though it was common knowledge that homosexuals were being targeted by gay-bashing gangs. A time when the public was more exercised by the fact that one of his killers was a 14-year-old girl. A time when gay campaigners considered setting up their own vigilante force because they had no confidence in the authorities to protect them, or the broader public to be much interested in their plight.

And this is now. Post-devolution. Brave new Scotland. At least that's what Scotland's communities minister, Wendy Alexander, must have thought when she formally announced last October the executive's intention to repeal Section 28 of the local government act 1988. Her platform was an international gay conference at Glasgow university, where she spoke powerfully about a gay friend who had been taunted.

Alexander and other ministers expected little backlash. The clause, which bans the promotion in schools of the acceptability of homosexuality, was unjust and reactionary, they believed: its repeal would be welcomed as the new parliament showed how bright, shiny and inclusive it could really be.

They could not have been more naive. Not since the poll tax has a piece of legislation caused more fist shaking and hand-wringing north of the border. The intervention of the Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter and a renewed attack by Cardinal Winning, branding homosexuality a perversion, has galvanised and polarised the debate.

Souter, a father of four, has painted himself as a concerned parent, anxious that Scotland's silent majority is not being heard. But he has also brought money into the equation. Lots of it. Some £500,000 to bankroll a campaign by the Scottish School Board Association to retain the clause.

The SSBA, a sober body given more to polite outrage than blustering polemic, has been repackaged, both by Souter's millions and by Jack Irvine, an arch media manipulator and the man behind the Media House PR firm.

Irvine, who once wrote of homosexuals as "slobbering old queers", was the architect of a farcical news conference this week to launch the Keep the Clause campaign. Claims of support from various celebrities had to be withdrawn. Explicit gay literature was handed out with the implication that it would end up next to Topsy and Tim on the school library shelf.

For all their clumsiness, there are disturbing signs that the campaigners have already struck a chord with sections of the Scottish public. One Daily Record survey found 66% of Scots wanted the clause retained. And politicians' mailbags are said to be bursting with letters of complaint.

What they don't show, however, is that Scots truly understand what Section 28 is and what the effect of repeal might be. Children will not be encouraged to role-play cottaging or peruse graphic homosexual material as the Keep the Clause campaigners have claimed they might be. There is already a protective layer of guidelines on the teaching of sex and health education in Scottish schools. The executive promised to review and tighten them some time ago.

The aim of repeal is simply to allow teachers to deal with all aspects of sexuality without the threat of censure hanging over them from a deeply offensive, outdated piece of Conservative legislation.

The executive has closed ranks but Wendy Alexander has none the less been removed from the spotlight. That is unfortunate. While she may have misread the early signs, she has proved herself to be a principled and able politician and she should have been allowed to guide the matter through to the end.

She must have been casting envious glances towards Westminster, where a similar repeal has been gliding through the legislative process without the same consultation exercise or public outcry.

North of the border, meanwhile, the talk is rarely rational. Gay rights campaigners worry that the debate has taken a decidedly homophobic turn and say a well-funded media campaign against repeal can only stir up prejudice. Last year alone, 37% of gay people in Edinburgh were physically assaulted, a rate 14 times higher than that for the general public. The matter is reflecting badly on Scotland as a new nation. This may be one of these great tests for the country, a chance to see if we can be as inclusive as we promised in the heady days of last spring.

The signs are not good. Even if the repeal of Section 28 goes through, as it is expected to do, the rancour of the past few weeks suggests we could rightly be seen as one of the less tolerant countries in Europe.

It is deeply unfortunate, not least for the memory of Michael Doran, that Scotland has set itself up for that.

The aim of repeal is simply to allow teachers to deal with all aspects of sexuality without the threat of censure hanging over them from a deeply offensive, outdated piece of Conservative legislation. The executive has closed ranks but Wendy Alexander has none the less been removed from the spotlight. That is unfortunate. While she may have misread the early signs, she has proved herself to be a principled and able politician and she should have been allowed to guide the matter through to the end. She must have been casting envious glances towards Westminster, where a similar repeal has been gliding through the legislative process without the same consultation exercise or public outcry. North of the border, meanwhile, the talk is rarely rational. Gay rights campaigners worry that the debate has taken a decidedly homophobic turn and say a well-funded media campaign against repeal can only stir up prejudice. Last year alone, 37% of gay people in Edinburgh were physically assaulted, a rate 14 times higher than that for the general public. The matter is reflecting badly on Scotland as a new nation. This may be one of these great tests for the country, a chance to see if we can be as inclusive as we promised in the heady days of last spring. The signs are not good. Even if the repeal of Section 28 goes through, as it is expected to do, the rancour of the past few weeks suggests we could rightly be seen as one of the less tolerant countries in Europe. It is deeply unfortunate, not least for the memory of Michael Doran, that Scotland has set itself up for that.

webTitle: On a new track: SNCF bid for Underground role

fields.headline: On a new track: SNCF bid for Underground role
fields.trailText: The French state-run rail operator, SNCF, was last night said to be bidding for the £3.2bn contract to run part of the London Underground now Railtrack has withdrawn from the chase.
fields.body:
The French state-run rail operator, SNCF, was last night said to be bidding for the £3.2bn contract to run part of the London Underground now Railtrack has withdrawn from the chase.

The company, which relies on a considerable subsidy from the French government and which last year made a loss of £720m, would make no comment. But its engineering arm, Cintra, is said to have registered an interest by yesterday's deadline.

LU refused to identify firms expressing an interest in the proposal to repair and maintain the tube's surface lines. Cintra staff have attended a briefing on the government's private-public partnership scheme given by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

Railtrack's involvement with the project was undermined by the Paddington rail crash. It had been about to sign a deal when the crash occurred.

Within hours of Railtrack's announcement TubeRail, a consortium of banks and contractors, said it had formally lodged a bid to run the sub-surface stations. It has already been shortlisted to bid for the two deep tube infrastructure companies including the Jubilee line (seen left at North Greenwich).

 Railtrack admitted yesterday it was unlikely to meet the target to cut passenger train delays fixed by the rail regulator, Tom Winsor. It faces a fine of at least £12m, but is seeking a judicial review.

And Connex said it could lose up to £2m a day from six one-day strikes starting next Tuesday, when 90% of its services were likely to be cancelled. The company published a list of earnings for its 1,500 drivers who are pressing for a 35-hour week and an end to compulsory rest day working. They show projected earnings for some drivers at Victoria up to £46,000 and an average of about £38,000.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: LVMH posts record profits
fields.body:
LVMH posts record profits

The world's biggest luxury goods group, LVMH, posted record 1999 sales figures yesterday, cheering analysts who said the result reflected more than just economic recovery in Asia. Paris-based Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy said 1999 turnover rose 23% from 1998 levels to a record €8.5bn (£5.2bn), with operating profit up more than 20%.

"The whole range of activities and different geographic zones have seen very well-supported growth, which accelerated even further in the fourth quarter," LVMH said.

Scottish Radio to raise £75m
Scottish Radio yesterday primed itself to play a part in the consolidation of the sector by announcing plans to raise £75m through the placing and open offer of 5.5m new shares. The group, which has interests in radio, regional newspapers and outdoor advertising, said it had made six acquisitions last year and expected the rate of new opportunities to continue apace.

German firm denies sale talk
Germany's Metro denied yesterday it had held talks with US retailer Wal-Mart, but analysts said Metro's major shareholders could independently be seeking a sale of the world's number three retailer to its American rival.

Arkansas-based Wal-Mart Stores, which towers over competitors with annual sales of $139.2bn (£84.3bn), is intent on European expansion and has recently acquired two hypermarket groups in Germany and Britain's Asda supermarket chain. Analysts said Metro's low share price and extensive hypermarket and cash and carry network would be attractive to Wal-Mart, which wants a foothold in central Europe.

Unifi enters NatWest fight
MPs are being warned that the bidding war for NatWest will result in a "Valentine's day massacre", which will hit jobs and consumers.

Unifi, the finance union, has written to MPs seeking support for their call that takeover bidders should be required to show their bids are in the "wider public interest".

NatWest, which is trying to fend off bids by Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland, is cutting 15,000 jobs as part of its defence, while Royal Bank admits to a 18,000 job toll.

"Unfortunately each bidder, and indeed NatWest itself, increasingly appear as if they are playing a poker game in which the chips are branch closures in their hundreds and jobs in their thousands," the union's joint secretaries said in their letter.

Ofgem extends licence rules
Energy market regulator Ofgem said it is to extend for two year the rules in suppliers' licences covering the sales and marketing of gas and electricity.

The rules were to expire at the end of February. The marketing condition, which was added to suppliers' licences in January 1998 in response to complaints about doorstep sales practices, lays down rules for the sale and follow-up of contracts signed on the doorstep. It also covers telephone selling.

webTitle: Deutsche analyst goes to the wall

fields.headline: Deutsche analyst goes to the wall
fields.trailText: After ten years at the top, Fergus MacLeod has had enough of being an analyst and has finally left Deutsche Bank's Edinburgh-based oil equity research team.
fields.body:
After ten years at the top, Fergus MacLeod has had enough of being an analyst and has finally left Deutsche Bank's Edinburgh-based oil equity research team.

Mr MacLeod, who has been voted outstanding individual analyst in the UK and Europe every year since 1994 in the Extel survey of fund managers and finance directors, says simply that he is leaving to pursue "new opportunities".

His immediate plans include a sponsored walk along the Great Wall of China in June to raise money for the Stirling-based Aberlour Childcare Trust.

But he is expected to re-emerge within a few months working "with oil companies and the investment community" but in a different role from the one he has pursued in recent years.

"It has always been the case that the thing which gets me out of bed in the morning is intellectual stimulation," he said. "The money has always been nice but the intellectual stimulation has become more important as I get older."

He said he had a number of irons in the fire but hoped that the announcement that he was leaving Deutsche Bank would result in people coming forward with other proposals. "I am open to other ideas," he said.

For Deutsche, this can only be considered a devastating blow. Mr MacLeod was part of the the County NatWest /Wood Mackenzie research team and stayed with the business through its various guises - NatWest Markets, BT Alex Brown and Deutsche. Aside from the work for investment clients, this man also amounted to a serious corporate finance fee-puller.

His next venture should be watched very closely.

webTitle: BA makes strike union a partner

fields.headline: BA makes strike union a partner
fields.trailText: British Airways and the Transport and General Workers Union - who were bitter enemies during the costly cabin crew dispute in the summer of 1997 - are set to announce a deal on co-operation.
fields.body:
British Airways and the Transport and General Workers Union - who were bitter enemies during the costly cabin crew dispute in the summer of 1997 - are set to announce a deal on co-operation.

David Lebrecht, head of industrial relations at BA, and George Ryde, the TGWU national transport secretary, are due to share a platform on Tuesday at a government-backed conference on partnership and rebuilding relationships - the first time they have appeared in public since the dispute.

The three one-day strikes by TGWU cabin crew cost the airline some £125m and a reduction of shareholder confidence and continue to haunt BA, which is expected to announce losses of up to £200m - its first since privatisation - in the year to the end of March.

The union has increased its membership since the strikes by 50% to more than 10,000, but is stopping short of seeking the sort of full-scale partnership agreement with BA that the rival AEEU engineering union has - and the pilots' union, Balpa, is seeking.

The new spirit of co-operation is being fostered depite the fact that the airline is to axe up to 6,000 jobs - mainly back-office staff - under a rolling cuts programme that should save £1.225bn in this financial year and a further £500m in the next.

Mr Lebrecht said: "We have been working very hard to improve relations over the last couple of years. We recognise we have difficult challenges ahead but we believe this is the best way of making our way through them."

BA sources say involving unions in the commercial side of the business, with access to confidential data, is more important than traditional industrial relations.

"This is about keeping the unions, and through them employees, in tune with where the business is going," a BA official said.

"We operate in a very difficult business environment with the company in financial difficulties, and we and the unions are recognising reality and going along with change while protecting our own interests."

TGWU union officials said: "Clearly it's in our interests to make sure that BA recovers from the financial troubles it is having.

"We want to make sure that the company succeeds and, if there are any job losses, they should be managed properly."

Willy Coupar, director of the Involvement and Participation Association, told People Management magazine: "The BA case shows that partnership is not about lovey-dovey relationships. Those involved there are trying to put in place something that has legitimacy, that will not be cosmetic."

Balpa, according to Mike Sparham, its assistant general secretary, wants to transform its "guiding principles" arrangement with BA - "the source of three years of industrial peace, albeit a close-run thing on occasions" - into a full partnership deal with the aid of government funding.

"Effectively this gives access to information on and involvement in key business decisions before they are unveiled and activated," he said.

Balpa is in the middle of talks with Mr Lebrecht - a former Balpa official - and his team on proposals to transfer a third of routes from Euro Gatwick, the former Dan Air, to Cityexpress Flyer, a low-cost subsidiary using short-haul routes to Europe.

The union is concerned that this could involve a substantial cut in pilots' salaries as part of BA's cutbacks, but hopes to avoid a dispute over the coming weeks.

webTitle: On a scale of 0 to 10, farmers are least corrupt

fields.headline: On a scale of 0 to 10, farmers are least corrupt
fields.trailText: Construction groups, defence manufacturers and power and energy companies are the most likely to offer bribes to gain business in developing countries, according to a survey published yesterday.
fields.body:
Construction groups, defence manufacturers and power and energy companies are the most likely to offer bribes to gain business in developing countries, according to a survey published yesterday.

On a scale of 0 to 10 - where 0 represents the most corrupt and 10 the least - the public works and building industry scored 1.5 and the arms industry two.

Even the cleanest sector, agriculture, failed to achieve a perfect 10 rating, scoring six.

This "indicates... a great problem", according to Carel Mohn of Berlin-based Transparency International, the anti-corruption watchdog that commissioned the survey. This is the first time Transparency has looked at individual sectors to gauge corruption.

Business leaders in countries accounting for 60% of imports from the developing world - including India, Indonesia, Brazil, the Philippines, Poland, Russia, Nigeria and South Africa - were surveyed.

In parallel, Transparency asked which governments in the industrialised world were most likely to try to gain an unfair edge for their companies in developing markets. The US was named most often in this category (by 61% of respondents) followed by France and Japan (34% each), China (including Hong Kong) (32%), Germany (27%) and Italy (24%).

Britain scored 23%, ahead of Spain (17%) and Malaysia and Taiwan (16% each).

The most blameless governments in this regard were Canada, Sweden and the Netherlands (8% each), Austria (7%) and Switzerland (6%).

Diplomatic or political pressure was the instrument cited most often as being used to gain unfair advantage (53%), followed by commercial pressure (49%) and financial pressure, including subsidies, discriminatory taxes and customs barriers.

Tied aid was next along with "favours and gifts" (both 36%).

After construction and defence, power companies (including oil and energy groups) scored 3.5 as likely bribe-payers, followed by industry, including mining, at 4.2, healthcare and social work, and post and telecoms (both 4.6), civilian aerospace (5.0) and banking and finance (5.3).

In a survey last year, Transparency found the countries whose businesses were most likely to pay bribes were China, South Korea, Taiwan, Italy and Malaysia. The cleanest were Sweden, Australia, Canada, Austria, Switzerland and the Netherlands.

Britain ranked next, just above Belgium.

Mr Mohn said putting these results together with those found in the current survey gave the lie to common justification that "clean" countries could afford to be so because their governments exerted pressure on their behalf.

The Netherlands, Austria, Sweden and Switzerland ranked highly both in terms of non-corrupt commercial behaviour and in terms of ethical behaviour by their respective governments.

fields.headline: Setting sale
fields.standfirst: P&O on course
fields.trailText: Shipping group P&O yesterday sold the bulk of its remaining UK property portfolio for £400m in a move which substantially completes the disposals the group promised last March.
fields.body:
Shipping group P&O yesterday sold the bulk of its remaining UK property portfolio for £400m in a move which substantially completes the disposals the group promised last March.

The deal means P&O will have raised around £1.6bn in about half the time the group's chairman, Lord Sterling, initially indicated, and it leaves P&O focused on its Princess cruise operation and its lucrative port and logistics businesses.

Although the reshaping of the group stops short of what some in the City had called for, that P&O should become a cruise-only business, shares rose 21p to 941p.

The speed at which the sales were achieved underpinned Lord Sterling's revived reputation for deal-making.

The latest disposal, including the landmark St James' Buildings in Oxford Street, Manchester, follows the sale of P&O's Australia and New Zealand services operations for £120m and the disposal of construction subsidiary Bovis. That had been destined for flotation, but ended up in a trade sale for £285m. In addition the Earls Court and Olympia concert and exhibition centres in London have been jettisoned, as has Canadian property subsidiary Laing.

Although there are a few remnants in the P&O portfolio still to be sold, the company may fall short of the headline £2bn sales target which Lord Sterling flagged, but a spokesman said the figure had always been indicative rather than a promise.

fields.headline: Net Investor
fields.trailText: The risk of choosing individual internet stocks in which to park your cash should, in theory, be spread by taking a stake in an investment fund. The rewards have, in some cases, been spectacular.
fields.body:
The risk of choosing individual internet stocks in which to park your cash should, in theory, be spread by taking a stake in an investment fund. The rewards have, in some cases, been spectacular.

The latest arrival is Net Investor which plans to raise £50m through the placing of 25m shares at £2 each. Dealing in the shares is scheduled to commence on February 3.

Net Investor aims to spread the risk even further. It will channel the funds into chiefly unquoted US venture capital funds which focus on companies in the internet, e-commerce and information technology sectors at the early stage of their development.

The company's board is chaired by Barbara Thomas, the former SEC commissioner and US lawyer. "Our investors will know that every deal is scrutinised by a pool of highly successful venture capitalists and analysts," she said.

The company will be concentrating its investment in internet infrastructure companies. "We think the dot.com sector may be over-hyped and the smart money is investing in infrastructure build-out, which is what the major US venture capital firms are focusing on," she said.

The company has already pledged cash in two US investment funds which have positions in some 18 businesses.

fields.headline: Licensed to brawl
fields.standfirst: Public funding of the BBC's digital news channel is a sore point with rival broadcasters
fields.trailText: BSkyB dropped a carefully timed bombshell yesterday when it threatened to take action in Brussels against the government if it pushes ahead with the introduction of a digital licence fee to augment BBC funding.
fields.body:
BSkyB dropped a carefully timed bombshell yesterday when it threatened to take action in Brussels against the government if it pushes ahead with the introduction of a digital licence fee to augment BBC funding.

The pay-television group's resolve to fight the levy seemed designed to damp down comments that a rift might be developing between BSkyB and its coalition partners in the commercial sector.

It has formed an unprecedented alliance with rivals including ONdigital and Cable & Wireless Communications to fight the introduction of the additional licence fee. A spokesman for the department of culture, media and sport said legal advice had already been sought on the imposition of of a new levy.

BSkyB last year faced the European commission, arguing that the licence fee-funded BBC News 24 contravened EU competition laws. The commission ruled against BSkyB, although the company believes it may have a case if new public money is raised specifically for digital services.

Any new cash that constitutes state aid would come under more intense scrutiny, it argues. "If the digital licence comes in it is highly likely that we would take action through the Association of Commercial TV in Brussels," a BSkyB official said.

"Once a public broadcaster says we want new state aid to replicate something already out there in the marketplace, does that constitute unfair competition and distort the market?"

BSkyB's stance is in contrast with reports earlier in the week that it might be prepared to break ranks and use the licence fee as a bargaining counter to force the closure of the BBC's News 24.

"At the end of the day it is clear they would like to see News 24 off the air, not because of any threat in the ratings but because Sky News gets kicked out when there is the offer of a free alternative," noted one media analyst. Yesterday BSkyB denied any intent to seek a separate deal with the government, saying: "We remain united against this unfair tax."

An ONdigital official shrugged off the idea that BSkyB was looking out for itself. The British Internet Publishers Alliance has also approached the commission.

The gathering pace of spin foreshadows the date of culture secretary Chris Smith's pronouncement on the future of the licence fee, now expected at the beginning of February.

Two weeks ago BSkyB's chief executive, Tony Ball, wrote to Tony Blair with Greg Clarke of CWC and Stuart Prebble of ONdigital claiming that the introduction of a digital fee would stifle innovation.

A fee would not only punish the private sector's investment in digital, they said, but also make the services too expensive for some consumers.

Insiders at the BBC consequently seized on the notion of BSkyB pursuing its own agenda. "Sky's case has been that a licence fee would delay uptake of digital, but if they are prepared to bargain then it is clear their concerns are simply the commercial one of wanting to wipe out the competition. It is all a bit hypocritical."

The consensus is that the government will opt for a two-tier fee with a small digital levy and a modest rise in the analogue fee to help soften the blow. How to fund the BBC's digital ambitions and whether it should even try to play a part in the medium have proved controversial. The corporation has said it needs £1.45bn to pursue its digital strategy to 2007.

A report by economist Gavyn Davies last year made the case for a separate levy of £24, which caused uproar in the commercial TV sector. It was dubbed a "digital poll tax" by Mr Ball at BSkyB. A further report from the culture, media and sport select committee in December delivered a withering assessment of the BBC's efforts in digital TV, accusing it of wasting money on unwatched channels.

The committee said the BBC had "singularly failed to make the case for a much-expanded role in the digital era and for additional external funding".

A spokesman for the culture department said the government could not require the BBC to shut down a station, because of a clause in its charter, although it could presumably volunteer to do so if it were made a funding condition.

The official said the delay in the announcement, due this month, was attributable to mechanics rather than political considerations. The decision will be one of the toughest yet for Mr Smith.

fields.headline: Mix teachers well before serving
fields.standfirst: Matthew Barnard found out the hard way that trainees have as much to learn from each other as from books or tutors
fields.trailText: How up on phonology are you? When I first trained to be a TEFL teacher some 15 years ago I didn't have a clue what it involved, and I wasn't alone. None of us on our certificate training course really had much of a grasp of grammar, let alone phonological features because, as native speakers of English, we had had little formal English language learning.
fields.body:
How up on phonology are you? When I first trained to be a TEFL teacher some 15 years ago I didn't have a clue what it involved, and I wasn't alone. None of us on our certificate training course really had much of a grasp of grammar, let alone phonological features because, as native speakers of English, we had had little formal English language learning.

Nor were we able to anticipate the kinds of problems our students might encounter. The only access we had to non-native speakers was in our teaching practice classes, and we soon found out that we were ill-prepared. The textbooks we had referred to when planning our lessons failed us. The problems they suggested would arise were either ridiculously picky or so general - covering so many different language backgrounds - that they were irrelevant to most students.

I did try to take on board the theories presented, but I was far from convinced, preferring to work from observation and experience back to the theory rather than the other way round. As a result my understanding of phonological issues was for some years founded entirely on the problems of those students I encountered in my first years of teaching - for the most part in monolingual Italian classes. This partial grasp of phonology seemed to serve well enough as I climbed the TEFL career ladder to director of studies level - until I became a teacher trainer.

My first job was on an International House certificate course in Hungary open to both native and non-native speakers. There, included in the language-analysis section of the syllabus, was phonology. After initial trepidation I reassured myself that this was only a pre-service course and I knew enough to get by.

It was only when I was studying the trainees' application forms some days before that first course began that I began to have second thoughts. Three out of the first six I looked at were linguistics graduates. When I came across Csaba, Professor of Phonology at the University of Eger, my confidence drained away. What could I do? Spend the remaining days before the course cramming to sort my bi-labial plosives from my dento-labial voiced fricative? Give up and head home? Or swallow my pride and just admit ignorance on day one?

In the event I just went in and did what I thought was appropriate for that sort of course and that particular group of trainees, as any teacher would. Result? I learned a huge amount about phonology from the professor, and he learned how to adapt what he knew to suit his English language students in a more practical way (to be honest he was pretty good at that already).

What I had temporarily forgotten in that initial pre-course panic was the amount that you can learn from your own students, and the amount they learn from each other.

That course was very different from my own initial training simply because of the mix of nationalities within the group and the symbiotic nature of their learning. Everyone started off with some feeling of inadequacy - not just me. The non-native trainees felt their level of English was inadequate compared with the native speakers in the group, while the natives quickly realised how little they knew in the areas of grammar, language awareness and anticipating problems for students (all areas in which their non-native colleagues excelled). In the weeks that followed, though, the two camps recognised the skills they had to draw on and grew increasingly interdependent and appreciative of the other.

As my experience as trainer increased I found that I was able to rely on the members of each teaching practice group to sort out lesson planning. The native speakers would provide good models of pronunciation, a more up-to-date grasp of idiom, a great resource of vocabulary and so on. The non-natives not only had grammar rules at their finger tips but brought all their experience of learning English as a second or third language with them, providing invaluable insight for their native-speaker colleagues.

There were other benefits. I didn't have to fall back on my beginnerÍs Hungarian to provide a model language lesson demonstration - I had a variety of languages within the group to draw on for peer teaching. Then there was the whole aspect of cultural issues within language teaching to explore, comparing language learning experiences, the various hang-ups, problems and expectations of different nationality groups.

The advantages of mixing native and non-native trainees are now more widely appreciated. Four years ago Cambridge/RSA replaced its previously segregated entry-level qualifications with the single Certificate In English Language Teaching To Adults (CELTA). The Trinity College Certificate in the Teaching of English to Speakers of Other Languages (Cert TESOL) is also open to both natives and non-natives, creating more opportunity than ever to train in mixed groups. Non-native candidates have to show a very high standard of English, and the application process is as rigorous for them as it is for their native speaker counterparts.

Because these courses are non-competitive they are a great breeding ground for mutual support and co-operative learning. Theory can immediately be backed up, or not, by your colleagues, and you don't need to spend so much time trawling through the grammar books, trying to grapple with the wisdom of the linguistics experts.

For trainers, too, the benefits are clear - mixed candidates add spice and the opportunity to pursue mutual learning. Rather than fear the professors and multi-lingual language experts as trainees, we can all look forward to the unexpected.

Matthew Barnard is a teacher and teacher trainer at International House, London
