webTitle: Young linguists flourish in US immersion experiment

fields.headline: Young linguists flourish in US immersion experiment
fields.trailText: Julianne Ams, a brown-haired seven-year-old, returned from her first day of school in 1989 giving no sign that she had just begun a bizarre educational experiment. Her maths and science classes at her elementary school in the Washington DC suburb of Fairfax County had been taught in Japanese, a language she did not know, but she acted as if that were no more unusual than playing tag at break time.
fields.body:
Julianne Ams, a brown-haired seven-year-old, returned from her first day of school in 1989 giving no sign that she had just begun a bizarre educational experiment. Her maths and science classes at her elementary school in the Washington DC suburb of Fairfax County had been taught in Japanese, a language she did not know, but she acted as if that were no more unusual than playing tag at break time.

Her mother, Nancy, mystified by such nonchalance, questioned her. "How was it?" "Did you understand anything?"

There were words she did not understand, she told her mother, but the teacher used hand gestures and she learned something. Julianne is now in her last year of high school, fluent in Japanese, learning Spanish and Russian and thinking about a career in international law. Last term she and many of the 320 other students who inaugurated Fairfax's language-immersion programme attended a special ceremony to mark its 10th anniversary.

They were celebrating not only their own linguistic achievements but the remarkable growth of language immersion. When Fairfax County launched its programme at eight elementary schools, only two other Washington area schools had such a curriculum. It is now offered at 28 schools, while nationwide the percentage of elementary schools using immersion jumped from 2% to 8% between 1987 and 1997.

In the typical immersion programme, children spend half the day learning English and social studies from a teacher speaking English, and the other half of the day learning science, maths and health from an instructor speaking the foreign language. Teachers use gestures, pictures and educational toys to help students absorb the new language as they learn to multiply and divide and tell the difference between Mars and Venus. In Fairfax programmes are offered in Spanish, French and German as well as Japanese.

A decade ago the idea that parents would want to immerse their children in a foreign language - at an age when they were still trying to learn how to read and write English - seemed far-fetched to many educators. But the voluntary programmes have proved popular. Many parents have wanted their children to gain early exposure to a foreign language, so they can learn the language more easily and enhance their job prospects in a global economy.

Educators say the approach is one of the only ways for US-born students to achieve a high level of proficiency in a foreign language.

Moreover schools in communities with large concentrations of Spanish-speaking immigrants are increasingly using classes alternating Spanish and English to help children overcome the language barrier - a form of bilingual education that avoids political controversy. Immersion programmes at schools such as Arlington's Key Elementary have roughly equal numbers of children who speak Spanish or English at home, and the students help each other.

Research on the long-term academic effects of immersion programmes is sketchy. But studies in Fairfax and elsewhere have found that the instruction does not hurt students' scores in English, maths or science.

Regla Armengol, one of the original teachers in the Fairfax immersion programme, appreciates the linguistic skills that early exposure to foreign languages produces. But the biggest advantage is exposure to a foreign culture. "They begin to understand and get away from a myopic view of the world and see it as a mosaic with a lot of different pieces," she says.

Washington Post

webTitle: Why foreign training is failing Russia's teachers

fields.headline: Why foreign training is failing Russia's teachers
fields.trailText: A British university recently completed a joint teacher-training project in my home city of Tambov in central Russia. British colleagues and local professionals ran training workshops, organised study trips to Britain, wrote and published teachersÍ training packs, produced videos and set up a website.
fields.body:
A British university recently completed a joint teacher-training project in my home city of Tambov in central Russia. British colleagues and local professionals ran training workshops, organised study trips to Britain, wrote and published teachersÍ training packs, produced videos and set up a website.

With so much accomplished it should be possible to say that the project achieved its goals. Yet the principal aim of projects like these - to develop human resources and to make the process of change sustainable - are all too often missed. The question so often left unanswered is what happens when foreign trainers depart and local teachers go back to their towns and villages? My answer is, not much.

What holds back change is the power of the local teaching culture. Every teacher knows how to teach when the classroom door is closed and there are no inspectors. In Russia teacher-centred lessons are firmly rooted in the minds of teachers, children and their parents. One can often hear parents advising the teacher: "You should be much stricter with him, it will do him good." Learning is also teacher-dependent. Lessons are closely linked to assessment of homework, and the emphasis is put on input from the teacher rather than on output from learners.

So is a teacher-centred lesson a good or a bad thing? Can we say for sure that a learner-centred communicative class is what the children really need? In 20 years from now research might prove the opposite to be true. After all, hasn't there been a return to phonics in Britain after decades of communicative reading?

The conflict between imported methodology and conservative local teaching culture is the achilles heal of most joint training projects. Yet in Russia at least barriers to exploiting and developing local expertise remain firmly in place.

The first barrier is "affective" and is a matter of trust. No matter how well educated or talented they are, local professionals always play the role of students when experts arrive from abroad. Though they may share their local knowledge with their foreign guests they are there to learn.

Another barrier is "ethical" or doing what is proper. There is still a view, held since the time of Peter the Great, that the proper way to boost teachers' professional development is to invite experts from abroad. Today that foreign assistance is even more fiercely fought for because of the logistical support and funding that comes with it.

The third barrier is "conservative", or the belief in the "good" of the precedent. We have always relied on experts from Britain or the United States, and we believe they have helped us to achieve positive results. But as one American teacher trainer said after working here, "Russians applaud, demonstrate, but do not remember".

These barriers can be surmounted, however, and two models for teacher development come to mind. One is the fairly common unfreeze-change-refreeze model. This says that teacher trainers should motivate trainees to change (unfreeze), to develop new professional behaviour based on innovative methodology (change) and to stabilise these changes (refreeze). I call this model pessimistic because it institutionalises that period when the process of change comes to an end and teachers stop developing any further.

My own ideal is an optimistic model of teacher development that is designed to carry on working. The first stage of this model is "Letting the jinnee out of the bottle", or triggering critical thinking in teachers. The second stage is "Fulfiling the four wishes". Every teacher wants to be Successful, Achieving, Great and Effective. Until these wishes are satisfied no real or long-lasting change will take place in teaching. The third stage is "Obtaining a magic wand", or giving teachers research skills.

Critical thinking, professional expertise and research skills are the foundations for teacher-training programmes that are based on local skills and knowledge. Both pre-service students and in-service teachers want to be firm on both their feet, and for this they need a solid grounding in local expertise.

What needs to change is the whole approach to pre-service training and in-service development so that teachers can be armed with the weapons of critical thinking, professional expertise and research skills. Questioning instead of asserting, noticing and taking up instead of "accepting what is passed down" are just some of the strategies we need if teachers are to continue to develop beyond the life of their training project.

Dr Radislav Millrood is head of ELT at Tambov State University, Russia

No matter how well educated or talented they are, local professionals always play the role of students when experts arrive from abroad. Though they may share their local knowledge with their foreign guests they are there to learn. Another barrier is "ethical" or doing what is proper. There is still a view, held since the time of Peter the Great, that the proper way to boost teachers' professional development is to invite experts from abroad. Today that foreign assistance is even more fiercely fought for because of the logistical support and funding that comes with it. The third barrier is "conservative", or the belief in the "good" of the precedent. We have always relied on experts from Britain or the United States, and we believe they have helped us to achieve positive results. But as one American teacher trainer said after working here, "Russians applaud, demonstrate, but do not remember". These barriers can be surmounted, however, and two models for teacher development come to mind. One is the fairly common unfreeze-change-refreeze model. This says that teacher trainers should motivate trainees to change (unfreeze), to develop new professional behaviour based on innovative methodology (change) and to stabilise these changes (refreeze). I call this model pessimistic because it institutionalises that period when the process of change comes to an end and teachers stop developing any further. My own ideal is an optimistic model of teacher development that is designed to carry on working. The first stage of this model is "Letting the jinnee out of the bottle", or triggering critical thinking in teachers. The second stage is "Fulfiling the four wishes". Every teacher wants to be Successful, Achieving, Great and Effective. Until these wishes are satisfied no real or long-lasting change will take place in teaching. The third stage is "Obtaining a magic wand", or giving teachers research skills. Critical thinking, professional expertise and research skills are the foundations for teacher-training programmes that are based on local skills and knowledge. Both pre-service students and in-service teachers want to be firm on both their feet, and for this they need a solid grounding in local expertise. What needs to change is the whole approach to pre-service training and in-service development so that teachers can be armed with the weapons of critical thinking, professional expertise and research skills. Questioning instead of asserting, noticing and taking up instead of "accepting what is passed down" are just some of the strategies we need if teachers are to continue to develop beyond the life of their training project. Dr Radislav Millrood is head of ELT at Tambov State University, Russia

fields.headline: Stories of princes and millionaires
fields.standfirst: Janet Hardy-Gould assesses simplified 'readers' on offer
fields.trailText: Reading a good book in English is a pleasure that learners might not expect to enjoy until they have progressed to advanced level and above. But they would be wrong. ELT publishers have been producing graded readers - original or adapted texts which are graded according to a lexical and structural syllabus - for many decades, allowing learners at all levels to experience the satisfaction of starting and finishing a book.
fields.body:
Reading a good book in English is a pleasure that learners might not expect to enjoy until they have progressed to advanced level and above. But they would be wrong. ELT publishers have been producing graded readers - original or adapted texts which are graded according to a lexical and structural syllabus - for many decades, allowing learners at all levels to experience the satisfaction of starting and finishing a book.

Graded texts have also been used very successfully to support and supplement classroom studies. "Readers provide the ideal resource for extending contact with English outside class hours," says Nick Bullard of Oxford University Press (OUP). "Reading at the appropriate level provides low-stress contextualisation of language seen in class and so facilitates assimilation."

Simplified texts can also provide learners with a positive individual learning experience. According to Catherine Boyce of Cambridge University Press (CUP), "Reading is a magical way for learners to improve English enjoyably, in their own time, at their own pace and without classes or teacher."

Although simplified versions of literary classics, such as Pride And Prejudice or Oliver Twist, are still widely read, other, more modern literary genres have started to appear in recent years. Penguin Readers have developed a number of books based on contemporary film titles such as Saving Private Ryan and Four Weddings And A Funeral.

There has also been a proliferation of biographical readers including Diana, Princess Of Wales in the Oxford Bookworm Factfiles series and Leonardo DiCaprio, Prince William and Brad Pitt in Penguin Readers, which have been designed to appeal to the growing teenage market. Penguin have also ventured into the adult business sector with topics ranging from The Story Of The Internet to Bill Gates's vision of the future, The Road Ahead.

A further key development has been the expansion of many reader lists into the beginner level of English. Macmillan Heinemann have retold classic titles such as Little Women and The Phantom Of The Opera at a low level. "This was at the particular request of teachers who wanted easily accessible editions of titles at the lower end of the grading system, and these have proved very popular with students," says publishing manager Sarah Axten.

OUP have also launched the Oxford Bookworms Starters which are written in the present tense and aim to provide beginners with the satisfaction of finishing a book in English. The series includes illustrated comic-strip stories and interactive stories, where readers choose their own path through the book. One of the most interesting innovations in graded reading material has been the launch of texts on CD-rom. The CD-rom presents the story in text and audio with accompanying illustrations, providing for the integration of reading, listening and speaking skills plus a clear guide to pronunciation. CD-roms will be an important field of expansion in the future for most publishers.

"We believe that there will be an increase in the use of the electronic medium with ELT graded readers and we shall be looking to develop these ideas further in the new millennium," says Axten at Macmillan-Heinemann, which have produced CD-rom format readers at beginner, elementary and intermediate level.

Another continuing trend is the increase in the number of titles available on audio cassette. This format is useful for busy learners who can listen in their car or on a personal stereo. Cassettes are also extremely useful in self-access centres in schools where students develop a range of skills through reading and listening to a text at the same time. In this area there has been the launch of Penguin Readers Activity Packs that contain a reader, cassette and an activity book with specially designed games and activities.

A key issue in simplified reading books over the past 10 years has been a drive to improve the quality of writing and to provide texts that engage and inspire the reader without patronising them. "CUP's books meet a demand for original and contemporary fiction that is relevant for adults and that respects the reader," explains Boyce.

In a move to add a creative dimension to the use of readers in the classroom OUP recently launched their Oxford Bookworms Playscripts series. These graded versions of traditional and contemporary plays are written for both reading and performing in class. Titles include such classics as Romeo And Juliet and The Importance Of Being Earnest as well as original plays created specifically for the series. Drama in the classroom, whether in the form of a simple role-play or a full class performance, can be a much more creative process than simply "reading aloud" and can lead to better language awareness and speaking skills.

Finally, a very positive development for over-worked teachers has been the creation of a wide range of support material by all the major publishers. There has been an increasing recognition that readers require supplementary tests, activities and worksheets for use in the classroom and for self study. This material can provide teachers with motivating and well-crafted lessons without having to spend hours on reading and preparation. Most worksheets are available directly from the publishers or can be downloaded free from their websites.

Further information about readers and support materials can be found at the following websites:

Cambridge University Press: www.cup.cam.ac.uk/elt/readers

Oxford University Press: www.oup.com/elt

Macmillan Heinemann: www.mhelt.com

Penguin Readers: www.penguinreaders.com

webTitle: Global money-makers burdened by more words

fields.headline: Global money-makers burdened by more words
fields.standfirst: John Hughes keeps pace with financial vocabulary
fields.trailText: In today's multinational and multi-service financial sector, narrow job definitions have all but disappeared. Banking and finance staff need to be flexible and to be equipped with technical English that will enable them to work across a much wider range of sectors. As a result students who request a course in "English for banking" expect it to include vocabulary drawn from areas such as accounting, IT, law, management, financial planning, or customer service.
fields.body:
In today's multinational and multi-service financial sector, narrow job definitions have all but disappeared. Banking and finance staff need to be flexible and to be equipped with technical English that will enable them to work across a much wider range of sectors. As a result students who request a course in "English for banking" expect it to include vocabulary drawn from areas such as accounting, IT, law, management, financial planning, or customer service.

This blurring of specialist course content reflects the changes taking place in financial services all over the world. Professor Leo Schuster, who lectures on banking and finance at Ingolstadt university in Germany, observes: "As banking, insurance and finance intermix and offer many services, students entering this world need a wider range of skills and knowledge."

Language trainer James Schofield has also witnessed increased demand for specialist language from non-financial staff. As technical terms are more widely used, employees in other departments "need to be able to talk about financial subjects with their colleagues and foreign partners or discuss concepts such as cash flow and risk in English", he explains.

Even the experts might attend English classes to brush up their terminology. At Siemens in Germany, for example, where new American accounting procedures are being adopted, Schofield finds that everyone is learning new language and new acronyms. "We have to make sure that we incorporate US GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Procedures) language into our courses," he adds.

A firm grasp of changing vocabulary is also crucial in a country such as Poland, where the foreign banks' share of assets in Polish banks now stands at 33%. Ewa Nanowska, who is a financial translator and language course designer, says the basic core vocabulary "is pretty stable, but there are some, sometimes substantial, differences in terminology from institution to institution. All have their own 'language peculiarities'. These house-to-house differences, coupled with national discrepancies, are still in place."

At Siemens the reaction to this problem is to seek to establish a standard worldwide language of finance so that a Siemens employee can talk with colleagues anywhere and use the same terminology.

So is it true to say that financial vocabulary lies at the heart of a financial English course? Ian MacKenzie, author of the textbook Financial English, would say it is at the tertiary level. He believes that the focus should be on vocabulary and the skills of listening and reading. "Students often need to learn the vocabulary that will allow them to read American textbooks and understand English-language lectures."

However, at in-company level the emphasis will probably shift from vocabulary to communication skills. Teaching communication skills is familiar territory for those teachers with a business English background. MacKenzie adds reassuringly that, "the actual classroom methods need not be too different from general EFL teaching". But he also points out that "there is a certain technical vocabulary that has to be used, and in some cases taught".

So before entering the financial English field teachers should be confident users of the vocabulary. They should understand how banking and finance work, be able to use the vocabulary in conversation and absorb financial literature. At the very least, they should be armed with a comprehensive business English dictionary. Mackenzie suggests they also read American economics and corporate finance textbooks.

Another way they can close the knowledge gap and, like their students, keep track of financial language is to listen to the economic news and read the financial press. Aside from the literal meaning of words, they will discover that financial idioms are often drawn from the world of sport, war and flying. It could mean the real difference between profit and loss.

Vocabulary on course

Most providers of specialist financial English courses in Britain teach communication skills, such as language for meetings, presentations, telephoning and social contact, in an international banking and finance context.

Bath-based LTS Training and Consulting's open enrolment course attracts personnel from a range of finance backgrounds. Course director Christine Johnston says that new vocabulary is identified by students during classwork based on specific topics. "We try to include at least one topic that is relevant to each studentÍs work, and they can often explain the latest vocabulary associated with that topic during the group discussion," she says. She also provides students with glossaries of new words for use as self-study materials.

One-to-one courses offer much more scope for teacher and student to focus on specific areas of language. At Pilgrims's business training centre in Canterbury, director Barry Cotgrave explains that there are no set course materials on the one-to-one courses. "We find out exactly what that person does and what they need, in advance, and then collect topical and relevant materials from the press and the Web to use during the course."

John Hughes is a teacher and teacher trainer in Italy

webTitle: Assurance of quality that spans diversity

fields.headline: Assurance of quality that spans diversity
fields.standfirst: Liz McLaren explains how Britain's EFL inspection scheme helps students find the right school
fields.trailText: Britain has a deservedly high reputation for education, especially for teaching English. Coming to Britain is an excellent way for anyone to improve his or her English. There are so many different places in the UK where you can learn English - small privately owned schools, medium-sized schools, schools that are part of large groups, summer schools, EFL units that are part of colleges or universities, and even in a teacher's home. If the variety of places to study is overwhelming, so is the choice of courses.
fields.body:
Britain has a deservedly high reputation for education, especially for teaching English. Coming to Britain is an excellent way for anyone to improve his or her English. There are so many different places in the UK where you can learn English - small privately owned schools, medium-sized schools, schools that are part of large groups, summer schools, EFL units that are part of colleges or universities, and even in a teacher's home. If the variety of places to study is overwhelming, so is the choice of courses.

British EFL provision is so diverse because it is customer- and market- oriented: if there's a demand for a particular type of course, someone will set out to provide it. The downside of this diversity is the difficulty it presents to students trying to decide where to study. The English in Britain Accreditation Scheme is a valuable tool for students faced with this decision.

The English in Britain Accreditation Scheme is run by the British Council in partnership with the Association of Recognised English Language Services (ARELS) and the British Association of State English Language Teaching (BASELT). It is a quality assurance scheme designed to provide prospective students of English with a choice of organisations which are committed to quality and which meet or exceed the agreed standards of the scheme. The partnership reflects the main difference between language providers in the UK - the distinction between private and state sector.

ARELS represents members that are private (commercial/independent of state funding) language schools, while BASELT members are universities, colleges of further or higher education, and other non-independent colleges.

The private sector is not government-regulated, and although the state sector is, the quality control checks rarely focus specifically on EFL. The English in Britain Accreditation Scheme uses experienced EFL professionals to inspect organisations seeking accreditation. After gaining accreditation they are inspected again at least once every three years.

Details of accredited centres can be found on the Web (see below) or you can ask for the English In Britain Guide from your nearest British Council office; some offices also have reference copies of some of the centres' brochures. With a wide variety of centres, courses and locations to choose from, a list of English in Britain accredited organisations is the best place to begin your search for the best English course for you.

When making your choice, you will need to consider what type of course you want: the subject and type of tuition, for example - do you want an English for business course taught in a small group, or one-to-one tuition? You should also think about what type of centre would suit you: somewhere compact, with a family atmosphere (family-run private school), or part of a larger organisation that has British students and teaches subjects other than English?

Similarly, what type of location do you want to study in: a city or a small town; somewhere rural or coastal? That may seem like a lot to think about, but being clear about what you want will make it easier for you to select a course that will best suit you.

Whichever accredited centre you choose, you can rest assured that our inspectors have checked all the things that are important to you. Our inspectors look especially carefully at:

Publicity: you want to be sure that the brochures you read give a true picture of the institution, including its classrooms, the qualifications of its teachers, the resources available, and the kind of accommodation provided. Our inspectors look at all the available publicity, including brochures and websites, to make sure it's accurate.

Teaching: the quality of the teaching is obviously a key element in a study visit to Britain. Our inspectors check that the teachers have qualifications in teaching English as a foreign language. They watch classes and talk to students to make sure they're satisfied.

Resources: we look at the textbooks, library and self-access resources to check that they match what's advertised, and will really help people learn.

Accommodation: whether luxurious or simple, we visit the accommodation that's provided and check that it is suitable for international students to live and study in.

Courses for children: A quarter of language visitors to Britain are under 15 years of age, and we take their care and protection very seriously. Children's courses are checked particularly carefully to make sure that children are safe and properly looked after, that the course is suitable for younger learners, and that there are enough spare-time activities to keep them entertained and help them to continue to learn English outside the classroom.

Also, in the unlikely event that you have a complaint about an accredited English language course that you are not able to resolve with the school or college, we are committed to helping you solve the problem.

So if you're looking for a wide range of high-quality English language courses in a variety of locations offering different approaches to teaching and a selection of out-of-class activities, you'll find that the English in Britain Guide and website are the best starting place.

Liz McLaren is assistant manager of the British CouncilÍs Accreditation Services. Details of accredited centres can be found at www.britishcouncil.org/english and www.EnglishinBritain.co.uk

webTitle: Study with computers that answer back

fields.headline: Study with computers that answer back
fields.standfirst: Multimedia software hasn't replaced teachers but it is still a useful tool for learners, says Roisin Vaughan
fields.trailText: The advantage of multimedia is that it integrates traditional language study media  books, audio cassettes and videos  in one package. This creates an environment that mirrors the real world by fusing sound, sight and movement and providing authentic contexts for language practice. It is also an environment that responds meaningfully to what you are doing.
fields.body:
The advantage of multimedia is that it integrates traditional language study media  books, audio cassettes and videos  in one package. This creates an environment that mirrors the real world by fusing sound, sight and movement and providing authentic contexts for language practice. It is also an environment that responds meaningfully to what you are doing.

As we move into a more technological age, computer-based materials for language learning are becoming more commonplace, and many learners will have experimented with them at home or in the workplace. But those who are thinking about enrolling on a English-language course in Britain may be surprised to find that multimedia has been slow to catch on in some institutions.

Some schools lack extensive computer resources and those that do often experience problems networking multimedia programs. Furthermore software written specifically for English language teaching is still limited. Teachers often favour more "authentic" materials such as on-line encyclopaedias and other reference works, rather than testing out more innovative interactive programs.

Add to this the attitude of students themselves who are often resistant to the idea of spending time in front of a computer rather than with their teacher, and you get a clearer picture of why the uptake of multimedia has been so slow. Most schools do, however, provide computer-based resources for self study, such as access to the internet, and attempt some kind of integration with classroom learning. Learners can expect to spend some time in a self-access centre using multimedia as a research tool to enliven classroom work, as follow-up activities to lessons or as homework.

Glyn Jones is pedagogical consultant in Britain for Eurocentres, the international schools chain. He says that students respond positively to combining class activities with time in the computer room, and those teachers who do not make use of the facilities soon find themselves under pressure from students to do so.

One institution that has gone further than most in exploiting the full potential of multimedia is the University of Wolverhampton. "What works best for us is to formally integrate multimedia into the syllabus, making it a standard part of the course," says Paul Brett, a senior lecturer in EFL. He has played a key role in the development of a business English multimedia course for students preparing to enrol on degree courses at the university.

So how useful is multimedia to students studying in an English speaking country? It cannot develop free speech and extended writing, nor can language generated by a machine ever be as truly authentic as communication with another person. But multimedia can increase students' exposure to the target language by creating authentic contexts for language practice which simulate real situations.

As a self-access resource, multimedia is also easy to administer, user-friendly, efficient and caters for individual learning styles and preferences. In the safety of this multimedia world, students can study at their own pace, in a non-judgmental learning environment, repeating things as many times as they like and receiving instantaneous feedback. Learners are encouraged to explore the materials, take risks and make choices. The resulting shift in control from teacher to learner can help build confidence.

Speed of delivery and corrective feedback means that computers can provide practice of the more routine side of language learning, such as the use of instant gap fills to practise grammar or vocabulary, and can make the most mundane language tasks dynamic and challenging. This saves on class time and, if used as part of a lesson, it can free the teacher from routine tasks and allows more time for individual teaching.

"Language learning requires intensive time on tasks, something not possible in the classroom where factors such as class size mean that most pupils will only get a few opportunities to interact on a one-to-one basis in the foreign language," says Dr Roberta Stock, a publisher of multimedia language courses. So if you want to get the most out of the multimedia facilities your school may offer, it's worth experimenting with it before your trip abroad. When considering schools in Britain that offer computer-based learning, find out exactly how it will be integrated into the syllabus.

As tools for language learning become more sophisticated, multimedia offers an exciting alternative to more traditional materials, and while it cannot and should not replace a teacher, if selected carefully and used appropriately, multimedia can be of enormous benefit to the learner.

Intermediate.
Features video, sound, animated graphics and over 300 interactive exercises. Provides extensive practice of all intermediate level grammar topics with tests to monitor progress.

Reward CD-ROM (Macmillan-Heinemann ELT, www.mhelt.com)
Elementary to upper intermediate.
Eight hours of self-study material based on texts, listening tasks, pictures and dialogues featured in the Reward coursebooks.

Issues in English (Protea Textware, www.proteatextware.com.au/)
Beginner to advanced.
Based around eight issues including animal rights, smoking and the environment and containing 32 video clips.

English for Business (Nomad, www.edulang.com)
Intermediate to advanced.
A series of six CD-roms based on authentic situations in real companies, using a combination of video clips and interactive tasks to help build fluency.

The Longman Interactive American English Dictionary (Longman)
Contains 80,000 words and phrases with sound, video and 500 interactive exercises.

Encarta Encyclopedia (Microsoft, www.microsoft.com)
Includes eight hours of sound, samples of 60 languages, photos, illustrations, animations, video clips, maps and interactive charts.

fields.headline: Overplaying the political football
fields.trailText: It now seems that sport is at the very hub of the political wheel. But using politics to do a decent man out of a job is unacceptable.
fields.body:
Sport used to be dismissed as the "toy department" in any newsroom: vital to readers, listeners and viewers and so often the force with which to unite the country, but somehow removed from the issues of state affecting the wellbeing of the nation at Millbank or Downing Street. Like Pokemon versus Pinochet.

Politics and sport combined during the tragedies in Bradford and Brussels, Olympic boycotts, the growing cancer of drug abuse and rebel tours of South Africa. In those instances, political intervention was inevitable as sport's administrators struggled to cope with issues of commercialisation, ineptitude and racism.

It now seems that sport is at the very hub of the political wheel. Rarely have we experienced such a politically dominated sporting scene as has emerged in recent weeks, from the Wembley Stadium fiasco and the withdrawal of Manchester United from the FA Cup to the immigration debate over Mike Tyson and the ludicrous intervention of four MPs over the future of the Sheffield Wednesday manager.

In addition the number of politically motivated sports organisations in Britain is weighing our sporting nation down with an unacceptable burden of bureaucracy. It's easy to see how Wembley became a sticky tangle of red tape. UK Sport, Sport England, the British Olympic Association, UK Athletics, Wembley National Stadium Limited, the department of culture, media and sport, and the Football Association all had their own simple solutions, but the sheer number of voices singing from different hymn sheets made it all sound like the Sex Pistols rather than the London Symphonic Orchestra.

The confusion over United's involvement in the World Club Championship remains, and Jack Straw's decision to bend immigration laws to accommodate Tyson revealed the extent of the power of sport.

It could be argued that most of these cases did require intervention from Westminster. But events at Hillsborough are altogether different. The meddling of the "Gang of Four" in the future of Danny Wilson and the club chairman Dave Richards is an example of where politics and sport do not, and should not, mix.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary and MP for Sheffield Brightside, the Sheffield Attercliffe MP Clive Betts, Bill Michie of Sheffield Heeley and our old friend Joe Ashton, MP for Bassetlaw, hid under the protection of being "Wednesdayites" and being primarily concerned with the financial future of the club.

Three of them have had the good sense and grace to withdraw from public view, but Ashton is now demanding a Presidential-style TV debate over the issue. The Wednesday chairman, who also happens to be in charge of the Premier League, can fend for himself, but what about Wilson?

Ashton has absolutely no right to demand the sacking of a football club manager, just as a football manager has no justification for calling for the dismissal of an MP.

How would Ashton or Blunkett react if Tony Blair received a letter from Wilson, Sheffield United's manager Neil Warnock and the managers of neighbouring Barnsley and Rotherham, Dave Bassett and Ronnie Moore, criticising the state of schools in the area and, in particular, the performance of the Labour MP for Bassetlaw?

Political interference over an issue of national importance is acceptable even if it may lead to bureaucratic bungling. But when it comes to calling for a decent man to lose his job, Ashton and his cohorts need to be put firmly in their places.

webTitle: UK fund managers 'must adapt or die'

fields.headline: UK fund managers 'must adapt or die'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special reportCentre for Research and Employment and Technology in Europe
fields.trailText: Britain's fund management industry is at risk of losing out to American and European mainland rivals unless it adapts to changing market needs, the Fund Managers' Association warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's fund management industry is at risk of losing out to American and European mainland rivals unless it adapts to changing market needs, the Fund Managers' Association warned yesterday.

In a hard-hitting report UK investment houses are urged to change their structure and the type of people they employ to cope with the the fast growing online economy.

As increasing numbers plan their own pension provisions, product range, customer groups and distribution channels are diversifying. Against this net-driven backdrop product branding and customer management skills have become crucial.

The rules of conducting investment management business are to be drastically overhauled. "Further liberalisation of the savings markets on the continent and in Japan over the next 10 years will produce fresh opportunities," says the report. "Business as usual is no longer an option," says professor Amin Rajan, chief executive of the Centre for Research and Employment and Technology in Europe and author of the study.

In order to stay competetitive UK firms need leaders who can respond strategically to market shifts, who are able to demystify investment management without compromising creativity and who can promote knowledge sharing to temper aggressive individualism.

fields.headline: Kingfisher blames tax for 'rip-off' label
fields.trailText: One of Britain's top retailers has hit back at government claims that profiteering retailers are ripping off consumers by producing research showing that higher taxes account for the lion's share of price differences between Britain and the United States.
fields.body:
One of Britain's top retailers has hit back at government claims that profiteering retailers are ripping off consumers by producing research showing that higher taxes account for the lion's share of price differences between Britain and the United States.

The research, carried out for Kingfisher by accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers, suggests profits play almost no part in explaining the price gap.

With new data from Tesco showing the supermarket is the cheapest in Europe, it adds to the growing body of evidence that the "rip-off Britain" campaign is in danger of backfiring.

Designed to pre-empt bad publicity expected when the government publishes a survey of international price comparisons, the Kingfisher study compares the prices of goods sold by the company's British outlets, including B&Q, Comet and Woolworth, with those charged by their US counterparts.

It found British prices were between 9% and 38% higher than in the US but that VAT, at 17.5% compared with an average US sales tax of 4%, accounts for between 32% and 113% of the price difference.

Other significant factors helping to keep US prices down include cheaper property, labour and distribution costs and economies of scale.

"Profit is not a significant cause of price differences," said David Jobson, director of pricing. In the case of Woolworth versus Wal-Mart, it accounts for 3% of the £29 price difference on a £100 shopping basket of more than 100 goods. In the case of Comet versus Circuit City, profit has a negative impact on the price gap.

Tesco's research showed that the average food basket of about 130 common items was £158.90 in January, or 5.7% cheaper than the average in Europe. The spread ranges from 1.3% cheaper than in Germany to 9.2% lower than in France.

Branded goods tend to be more expensive in Britain but cheaper own-label products more than offset the higher costs of branded goods.

Tesco spokesman Simon Soffe said: "Shoppers will shop on price and quality but if they can't see any point in paying 30p more then they will go for own label. Rip-off Britain does not apply for food. On that we offer good value for money."

webTitle: US loan site launches in Britain

fields.headline: US loan site launches in Britain
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
E-Loan
fields.trailText: The battle for supremacy in the burgeoning online mortgage market heats up this weekend when the self-proclaimed world leader in internet home loans opens for business in Britain.
fields.body:
The battle for supremacy in the burgeoning online mortgage market heats up this weekend when the self-proclaimed world leader in internet home loans opens for business in Britain.

E-Loan, the US-based mortgage broker and lender, is promising British home buyers "a consumer-friendly alternative" to the "entrenched" traditional lenders.

It is understood the company aims to offer access to a wider choice of lenders than any of the online mortgage sites launched so far.

Led by Andrew Armishaw, the former First Direct chief executive, and boasting Rupert Murdoch among its backers, E-Loan's British operation will go head-to-head with mortgage broker John Charcol's online facility, Charcolonline, and Emfinance.com, a subsidiary of listed company Exchange Holdings, both of which launched late last year.

The company has said it aims to "provide consumers in the UK with the same levels of convenience, privacy, choice and cost savings that E-Loan has been delivering in the US over the past two years".

In the US, E-Loan has captured about 25% of the online lending market. There, its website allows borrowers to research, compare and apply for about 50,000 mortgage products online. It claims savings for customers of more than $1,000 (£600) on average by giving them direct access to lending sources, thereby eliminating agents' commissions.

"Consumers will access information from multiple lenders and be able to select from a wide range of products the option best suited to their individual needs," said the company.

Online mortgages are a fledgling industry in Britain but research indicates the number of people using the net to find a home loan is growing rapidly.

Mr Charcol estimated that 20% of its business will come from the net within two years. In the US the online mortgage market was estimated at just over $18bn last year, and Deutsche Bank predicts that this will swell to about $250bn in 2003 - almost 25% of the total mortgage market.

Founded four years ago, E-Loan is being assisted in British launch by EVentures, a company which helps US web businesses set themselves up in Britain by recruiting executives and providing technical support. EVentures is a joint venture between Softbank of the US and EPartners, a media investment company set up by Rupert Murdoch to enable News Corporation exploit emerging online markets.

webTitle: Oil price hurts profit in manufacturing sector

fields.headline: Oil price hurts profit in manufacturing sector
fields.trailText: Profit margins in Britain's hard-pressed manufacturing sector are being squeezed by the fastest rise in oil prices since the fivefold increase during the Yom Kippur war in 1973 brought a sudden end to the long post-war boom, according to government figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
Profit margins in Britain's hard-pressed manufacturing sector are being squeezed by the fastest rise in oil prices since the fivefold increase during the Yom Kippur war in 1973 brought a sudden end to the long post-war boom, according to government figures published yesterday.

Data for producer prices from the office for national statistics showed that industry's fuel and raw material costs are rising at their fastest rate for five years, with the 12% increase in the year to December driven by a 160% rise in the cost of a barrel of crude last year.

Oil prices jumped from a low of $10 (£6) at the start of 1999 to $26 by the year's end, putting additional pressure on British manufacturers already suffering from the impact of the strong pound.

Rising fuel and raw material costs have traditionally been an early warning signal of inflationary pressure building up in the economy. But City analysts said that strong consumer resistance to higher prices in the shops meant there was little indication of this happening.

They said that the figures would be unlikely on their own to trigger a further increase in base rates from the Bank of England next month.

The ONS figures showed that the boost to industry between 1996 and 1998 from lower oil prices and weaker commodity prices came to an end last year.

fields.headline: Banks pull plug on Versailles
fields.trailText: Versailles, the trade finance group which is at the centre of a serious fraud office investigation, collapsed into receivership yesterday.
fields.body:
Versailles, the trade finance group which is at the centre of a serious fraud office investigation, collapsed into receivership yesterday.

Bankers owed up to £55m pulled the plug after investigating auditors discovered what are thought to be large holes in the accounts.

The company's receivership brings down the curtain on the rise to remarkable business success of founder Carl Cushnie, the only black entrepreneur to register in the list of the top 100 wealthiest people.

Mr Cushnie now faces the possibility of legal action from creditors if it can be proved he allowed Versailles to trade when insolvent.

The accountant investigating Versailles on behalf of its banks, PricewaterhouseCoopers, has also been appointed its receivers, and is taking charge of Versailles and whatever assets it can find.

PwC is at present running the company as a going concern, and is thought to be hoping to find a buyer. But it seemed last night that a wind-down of the group's affairs was the most likely outcome.

The company requested on December 8 that its shares should be suspended because it had found its treatment of some trade finance deals may have breached accountancy rules in that they "double counted" transactions.

This, said Versailles, may have inflated turnover by as much as 30%, but would have no effect on profits.

Two days later, the company admitted it had lied on December 8 when it claimed to have uncovered the accounts problems itself. In fact, it had been a department of trade and industry inquiry into an insolvent Versailles client which had first thrown light on the double-counting problem.

At the DTI's instigation, Versailles asked for an opinion from accountant Baker Tilly. When it was unable to give the books a clean bill of health, Versailles asked for its shares to be suspended.

But in the interim Mr Cushnie sold shares equivalent to 5% of the company - worth £29m - at a time when he knew and the market did not that Versailles was under a DTI-prompted inquiry. The sale still left him with about 53% of Versailles.

But whereas the double-counting problem would have wiped perhaps £80m off turnover, thought to be about £250m, it would not have affected profits.

The new accounting gaps, understood to have been uncovered by PwC earlier this week, are of a different order of magnitude, threatening the solvency of the company.

PwC reported the problem at the start of this week. On Tuesday the SFO announced a full-blown criminal investigation into Versailles, and on Wednesday the Versailles board suspended its long-serving finance director, Fred Clough.

But so large are the holes that Versailles is believed to be in danger of trading while insolvent. Bankers NatWest, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays yesterday withdrew their support from the management and put in PwC as receiver.

Versailles specialised in lending to companies with weak balance sheets, and was one of the fastest growing finance firms of the 1990s.

Mr Cushnie lives in Surrey with his wife Angela and their four children. Should he be found to have traded while insolvent, he could face disqualification as a director and civil action by creditors.

Mr Cushnie now faces the possibility of legal action from creditors if it can be proved he allowed Versailles to trade when insolvent. The accountant investigating Versailles on behalf of its banks, PricewaterhouseCoopers, has also been appointed its receivers, and is taking charge of Versailles and whatever assets it can find. PwC is at present running the company as a going concern, and is thought to be hoping to find a buyer. But it seemed last night that a wind-down of the group's affairs was the most likely outcome. The company requested on December 8 that its shares should be suspended because it had found its treatment of some trade finance deals may have breached accountancy rules in that they "double counted" transactions. This, said Versailles, may have inflated turnover by as much as 30%, but would have no effect on profits. Two days later, the company admitted it had lied on December 8 when it claimed to have uncovered the accounts problems itself. In fact, it had been a department of trade and industry inquiry into an insolvent Versailles client which had first thrown light on the double-counting problem. At the DTI's instigation, Versailles asked for an opinion from accountant Baker Tilly. When it was unable to give the books a clean bill of health, Versailles asked for its shares to be suspended. But in the interim Mr Cushnie sold shares equivalent to 5% of the company - worth £29m - at a time when he knew and the market did not that Versailles was under a DTI-prompted inquiry. The sale still left him with about 53% of Versailles. But whereas the double-counting problem would have wiped perhaps £80m off turnover, thought to be about £250m, it would not have affected profits. The new accounting gaps, understood to have been uncovered by PwC earlier this week, are of a different order of magnitude, threatening the solvency of the company. PwC reported the problem at the start of this week. On Tuesday the SFO announced a full-blown criminal investigation into Versailles, and on Wednesday the Versailles board suspended its long-serving finance director, Fred Clough. But so large are the holes that Versailles is believed to be in danger of trading while insolvent. Bankers NatWest, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays yesterday withdrew their support from the management and put in PwC as receiver. Versailles specialised in lending to companies with weak balance sheets, and was one of the fastest growing finance firms of the 1990s. Mr Cushnie lives in Surrey with his wife Angela and their four children. Should he be found to have traded while insolvent, he could face disqualification as a director and civil action by creditors.

fields.headline: Gent olive branch rejected
fields.trailText: German telephone group Mannesmann last night rejected Vodafone's conditional offer of a "modest increase" in its £96bn bid as "derisory" and stepped up its demands for a substantially improved offer.
fields.body:
German telephone group Mannesmann last night rejected Vodafone's conditional offer of a "modest increase" in its £96bn bid as "derisory" and stepped up its demands for a substantially improved offer.

Klaus Esser, Mannesmann's chief executive, insisted that his company be given 58.5% of the merged group - a repeated demand that prompted disbelief in the rival camp for valuing the German firm at £155bn, or almost £50bn more than the new Glaxo SmithKline pharmaceutical group.

Chris Gent, his Vodafone counterpart, changed tack and confirmed that he would be prepared to see Mannesmann own 48.9% of the combined group compared with the current "final-final" offer of 47.2% - but only if the German group's board recommended the offer.

Analysts said Mr Gent's olive branch indicated that his group was worried by a lack of progress and displayed a weakened hand.

"We remain hopeful that Mannesmann will enter into a serious negotiation, but so far their position has been completely unrealistic and unjustified," Mr Gent said.

Mannesmann seized on his move as a sign of nervousness, arguing that the company could significantly overtake Vodafone in size and value on its own within a year and was already outperforming its rival.

Mr Esser has said Mannesmann's share price could reach €350 (£215) within a year but Vodafone calculated that his demand for a clear majority of the merged group's equity already valued the German company at some €480 per share, or £155bn.

Dismissing these estimates as flawed, Mannesmann sources said: "We would expect a standalone company to be substantially bigger and worth more than Vodafone within the next year alone, and that's why we are asking to be compensated properly for our superior prospects."

Even so, Mr Gent declared himself confident that he would win a majority of Mannesmann shareholders.

But analysts suggested the contest was finely balanced, with Mr Gent's offer suggesting an agreed deal could be won before the closing date of February 7.

Vodafone shares, the most heavily traded in London at 212m, rose 2.25p in a falling market to close at 348p; Mannesmann stock rose 2.35%.

webTitle: It's time for a shave, girls

fields.headline: It's time for a shave, girls
fields.standfirst:
Eurovision Part One
Saatchi Gallery, London
**
fields.trailText: There are only three artists in part one of the Saatchi Gallery's largely disappointing Eurovision. As a group there is nothing to connect them, not even any discernible European-ness, whatever that may be. Patricia Ellis's catalogue essay won't enlighten you either: it is garbage.
fields.body:
There are only three artists in part one of the Saatchi Gallery's largely disappointing Eurovision. As a group there is nothing to connect them, not even any discernible European-ness, whatever that may be. Patricia Ellis's catalogue essay won't enlighten you either: it is garbage.

Swiss artist Ugo Rondinone is the troubling artist here. He spray-paints optically disturbing target paintings which look as if they have been redone for a disco, although they remind me more of work by semi-forgotten painters such as Peter Sedgely (a British artist who went to Germany) and Peter Kalkhof (a German artist who moved to Britain). What goes around comes around.

Rondinone also paints black and white lyrical landscapes, like blobby, blown-up engravings. More confusingly, he morphs his own, made-over head on to glossy photographs of young women. This is transvestitism without the actual dressing-up, transgression without tears. Behind the pancake slap and eye-shadow, Rondinone's digitally tweaked five-o'clock shadow lets you know that he knows you know he's a bloke. "For heaven's sake, Ugo, or Olga or whatever your fem name is, get a shave," you squeal.

All his work is so much stylistic cross-dressing. But the morning-after feel of Rondinone's work does have a certain sleazy, Eurotrash allure, I suppose.

Juan Usle's paintings are filled with graphic collisions: think Fiona Rae meets Jonathan Lasker meets René Daniëls. It is all wood-grain scribbles and stray doodles and thin overlays of painted plaid, interrupted by sudden gawky splats and ironic emptiness. I like the jump-cuts and the edgy orchestration of Usle's work, but this is a dull selection of the Spanish artist's work, and does him no favours.

The best work is the photography of Netherlands artist Rineke Dijkstra. We have seen her pictures of adolescent boys and girls, awkwardly posed on chilly beaches before, at the Photographers Gallery in London.

Dijkstra's photographs of new mothers, standing naked, babes in arms, are very beautiful in their utter, striking normality and candour. The mothers stand there, self-conscious, exhausted and proud. One mum has a trickle of blood sliding down her calf.

They all look vulnerable, but happy to share a moment with the camera. Dijkstra captures, in all her work, a kind of nervous intimacy. We meet her subjects' shyness and uncertainty with our own unease. There is nothing sentimental about these pictures. They are so good, I think Saatchi must have bought them by accident.

Until April 2. Details: 0171-624 8299

fields.headline: Retailers feel heat of competition
fields.trailText: Two profit warnings and a dividend alert sent shares in three leading retailers to new lows yesterday and underlined the extent of the tough competition facing high street operators.
fields.body:
Two profit warnings and a dividend alert sent shares in three leading retailers to new lows yesterday and underlined the extent of the tough competition facing high street operators.

Oasis, Arcadia and Moss Bros all warned investors they were facing substantially lower profits because of competition.

Shares in Arcadia, Britain's second largest clothing company, with shops such as Top Shop, Dorothy Perkins and Burton, fell to a record low of 52p, valuing the entire 2,800-store chain at only £98m as the company warned it was unlikely to be able to maintain its dividend this year.

Only six months ago Arcadia paid £151m to take control of the former Sears womenswear business - which brought Miss Selfridge, Wallis and Warehouse into the group - and little more than a year earlier Arcadia was valued at about £1bn.

The company, which is now expected to slump into the red this year, said it had increased its womenswear sales by 4% - at the expense of a 0.7% reduction in margins. But its menswear sales dived 7.1%, and six percentage points were wiped off profit margins.

There has been mounting speculation that chief executive John Hoerner was on the brink of being ousted, but yesterday chairman Adam Broad bent threw his weight behind Mr Hoerner.

Oasis and Moss Bros issued full profits warnings. Moss Bros - which also operates the Cecil Gee and Savoy Taylors Guild chains - said that, as at Arcadia, men were proving hard to part from their money. The group's shares dropped to a five-year low, closing down 13p at 61p.

Oasis had displayed some immunity to the problems which engulfed its rivals last year, but no longer. The group said there was nothing wrong with its goods - just too much competition and no sign of it abating. Its shares, which were changing hands at 282p last year, ended down 25p at a new low of 95p.

fields.headline: Artprice makes bourse debut
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Artprice.com
fields.trailText: This morning Artprice.com will make its debut on France's Nouveau Marché. Nothing too earth-shattering about that, you might think, but in fact Artprice is the first dot.com to hit the Paris market.
fields.body:
This morning Artprice.com will make its debut on France's Nouveau Marché. Nothing too earth-shattering about that, you might think, but in fact Artprice is the first dot.com to hit the Paris market.

"We have online brokers, we have software houses, we have companies specialising in internet technology but until now we have not had a pure dot.com company," said an exchange spokesman.

But although Artprice - which provides a database of the prices paid for almost 2m works of art since 1987 and where LVMH boss Bernard Arnault has a 20% stake through his specialist internet investment fund Europ@web - is the first dot.com to hit the market, it will not be the last.

A number of dot.com companies have indicated their intention to seek a Paris listing over the coming 12 months, according to the spokesman.

The relative slowness of the sector to take off in France is at variance with what has been happening elsewhere in Europe. The UK market is close to double figures in dot.coms - from heavyweights such as QXL and Scoot to more modestly capitalised Startit. Frankfurt has companies such as Ebookers.com and Fluxx.com.

"There are some very strong dot.com valuations out there," according to Andrew Dawber from SG Securities.

One explanation for France's latecomer status could be Minitel: in its day a whizzy system offering among other services travel booking, real time message exchange, lonely hearts adverts and the entire French telephone directory.

Minitel has been left looking slightly old-fashioned by the introduction of the net but may have slowed the spread of internet usage in France.

According to a recent survey just over one in 10 French households has access to the internet - only two-thirds of the European average, and well below Germany with 22% and Holland with 32%.

Another theory is that the difference may be linguistic. French users log on to websites ending in ".fr", such as www.lemonde.fr, and therefore would not think of using a dot.com suffix in company names. Investor caution is also a factor: "French investors are interested but they like mature companies," said one observer.

Chahram Becharat, managing director for Europ@web's European technology investments, acknowledges that France lags behind some of its neighbours.

"Clearly the UK and Germany are ahead of France in terms of market appetite," he said. "They are leading France in terms of maturity - not just in terms of companies but also in terms of the structures of the markets."

But he reckons France will be making an effort to catch up in the near future. "We have quite a few investments in our portfolio in companies which are planning to go public very quickly.

"There is quite a lot of momentum in France now."

By dot.com standards at least Artprice has been around for a while - it was created in January 1997 it has built up its database through the acquisitions of ADEC/Art Price Annual and the American Falk's Art Price Index.

As a result it claims to hold the world's most important databank of art auction results, containing entries on the sales of the works of 170,000 artists from the 10th century onwards. The database now covers more than 2,200 auctioneers in 40 countries.

It recently acquired Xylogic, a Swiss company specialising in software packages dedicated to the art market.

For those for whom the past is not always sufficient guide, the Swiss subsidiary has also developed indicators for the market including econometric indices per artist. Investors, would probably be grateful if it could produce a model for valuing dot.coms, too.

webTitle: I'm having sex with my boss

fields.headline: I'm having sex with my boss
fields.trailText: For the past two months, I've been staying late at the office and telling my wife I have a lot of work to do. But really, my boss and I have been having hot and steamy sex. I'm 24 and she is 25 and very attractive. I always get more from my boss than my wife. What should I do?
fields.body:
The problem

For the past two months, I've been staying late at the office and telling my wife I have a lot of work to do. But really, my boss and I have been having hot and steamy sex. I'm 24 and she is 25 and very attractive. I always get more from my boss than my wife. What should I do?

The solution

As a work psychologist, it is not within my remit to lecture you on the Ten Commandments. Nor is it my place to offer marriage guidance. But the 'dos and don'ts' of office affairs? Now that is where I can help.

Unfortunately the first 'don't' is 'don't have an affair with your boss'. It's obviously too late for that but, at the risk of being the harbinger of doom and gloom, I predict that it will all end in tears (yours).

You are not even having a relationship with your boss - just 'hot and steamy sex' - which might be all well and good now, and may even give you street cred among your mates, but what will happen when the lust wanes, as it inevitably will?

Will your boss be happy to have you working under her when you are no longer under the sheets with her? Or will she be so uncomfortable with your presence that she decides to move you on (ie fires you)? Or perhaps her lust will turn to loathing and you will suddenly find yourself landed with all the worst jobs in the office.

My advice? Put your cards on the table and have an open and honest conversation with your lover. Find out what her expectations are (does she see this as a sexy fling, like you, or something deeper?). Ask her how she would react if you ever split up and see if you can agree some ground rules.

Talking of ground rules, my other piece of advice would be to resist bragging about this relationship to your colleagues and keep the romance out of the public eye. This could help you avoid resentment or accusations that you are sleeping your way to the top.

And as for your getting 'less from your wife'? A healthy dose of realism and a visit to Relate might solve that.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: Technical knockouts
fields.standfirst:
CBSO/Sakari Oramo
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
***
fields.trailText: There are pianists who move, sway, grimace, even sing along as they play - enchanting for some listeners, irritating for others. Stephen Hough is quite different. His body barely moves, his face hardly even twitches. All the action seems to come from the fingers and the forearms. The surprise is in the power of the sound he makes: it is hard to see where the energy is coming from.
fields.body:
There are pianists who move, sway, grimace, even sing along as they play - enchanting for some listeners, irritating for others. Stephen Hough is quite different. His body barely moves, his face hardly even twitches. All the action seems to come from the fingers and the forearms. The surprise is in the power of the sound he makes: it is hard to see where the energy is coming from.

Hough's performance of Saint-Saen's Piano Concerto No 4 was in many ways typical: strong, brilliant in showy writing, lucid and poised in more quietly expressive moments. But the concerto itself is a strange piece: quirky and bland by turns. Moments stick in the memory (the scintillating virtuoso writing of the Scherzo, the striking anticipation of Rachmaninov in the central slow section), but the total effect is very much less than the sum of the parts. It would have been interesting to hear something which stretched Hough's artistry as well as his technique.

Before this, Sakari Oramo conducted the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra. They gave a well-mannered but uninspired account of Mozart's Paris Symphony (No 31). The high points of the evening came in their performance of Holst's The Planets - in the obsessional brutality of Mars, the thunderous good-humour of Jupiter and the elemental visit of Uranus. Best of all was the weird, otherwordly sound of the female voices of the CBSO Youth Chorus in Neptune. Even then the best choirs can go horribly astray in the ethereal fade-out at the end, but these youngsters held truer than most, and in the Symphony Hall acoustic, even the final silence was magical.

fields.headline: Trouser woman celebrates tribunal win
fields.trailText: A former training manager at the Professional Golfers' Association who was sent home for wearing trousers to work was celebrating last night after a "memorable" sex discrimination victory.
fields.body:
A former training manager at the Professional Golfers' Association who was sent home for wearing trousers to work was celebrating last night after a "memorable" sex discrimination victory.

Judy Owen, 39, resigned from her job at The Belfry, the PGA's head office in Sutton Coldfield, West Midlands, within weeks of starting work, in protest at being told to change into a skirt or dress.

An employment tribunal found that she had been discriminated against and victimised and will now consider what level of compensation the mother-of-two will receive.

The PGA is the representative body for Britain's professional golfers.

The equal opportunities commission, which backed the case, urged employers to scrap "old fashioned dress codes" and judge people on the quality of their work, not on what they wear.

"It is amazing that we are even discussing this issue," said chairwoman Julie Mellor. "It sends out a message to other women that you can stand up and challenge something and you can actually take the ultimate option of walking out." She had taken deep offence when told that her trouser suit was unacceptable and said she was "ordered" to wear skirts.

Mrs Owen told the tribunal, which heard the case in Birmingham last year, that she was harassed and bullied by her manager, who referred to women golfers as "dykes and lesbians".

On her second day at work she was told that "women don't wear trousers at the PGA".

"Smart trousers are now a widely accepted alternative to skirts for women at work. Even conservative professionals like the bar now consider trousers to be acceptable business dress for women.

"Cherie Blair wears them and no-one has accused her of not being dressed appropriately." Mrs Owen said she was "saddened" that after 18 months of fighting her case, the PGA had not written an equal opportunities policy and still banned women from wearing trousers.

The level of compensation is expected to be set at another hearing in March, but Mrs Owen said money was not the main reason she had taken the case.

"I was faced with several instances a day of bullying and harassment and my self-esteem zoomed down. It went up again when I walked out."

Mrs Owen, who has two daughters, was only in her £28,000-a-year job for a matter of weeks before resigning.

fields.headline: Hidden talents
fields.standfirst:
Beth Nielsen Chapman
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.trailText: Championed by Terry Wogan and loosely filed under Nashville, Beth Nielsen Chapman has been quietly growing into one of America's most successful singer-songwriters. In Britain, her brand of literate songwriting is about as fashionable as Greek tragedy performed in the original language, but the audience who filled Dingwalls sat spellbound throughout her two hours plus set.
fields.body:
Championed by Terry Wogan and loosely filed under Nashville, Beth Nielsen Chapman has been quietly growing into one of America's most successful singer-songwriters. In Britain, her brand of literate songwriting is about as fashionable as Greek tragedy performed in the original language, but the audience who filled Dingwalls sat spellbound throughout her two hours plus set.

Which was pretty good going, considering that this can't have been one of Chapman's better performances. She was still reeling from bouts of flu and laryngitis, and her voice often staggered fitfully around the contours of her songs, trying to find some semblance of pitch. Occasionally, she gave up altogether and mimed the words. Her singing and songwriting partner Annie Roboff, a dead ringer for actress Sarah Jessica Parker, did a discreet job on keyboards, but her efforts at harmony singing frequently resulted only in terrifying discord. Roboff's solo effort on a song called We All Fall Down was a masterclass in stage fright and insecurity.

It was best, then, to try to concentrate on the inherent qualities of Chapman's songwriting rather than on the vagaries of this performance. While there was a little too much inter-song self-therapy ("This is called Deeper Still and it's about forgiveness"), her best songs can unleash sudden surges of powerful emotion. Most conspicuous among them is Sand and Water, a song she wrote after her husband died of cancer and which was adopted by Elton John as an alternative to his post-Diana version of Candle In The Wind. It is one of those four-square emotional blockbusters which could stop a speeding train.

Picking one's way carefully through a surfeit of winsome, folky stuff on guitar or piano, which conspired to give the impression that Chapman spends far too much time pressing flowers and writing poetry in copperplate longhand, one was rewarded with other nuggets, such as All I Have, the stirring Every December Sky, and the refreshingly up-tempo clapalong of Happy Girl. Chapman and Roboff co-wrote Faith Hill's exuberant hit This Kiss, though their rendition of it here sadly left almost everything to be desired.
